00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
The first is this:

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
that China is not really a nation-state.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
Okay, it's called itself a nation-state

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:16.958
for the last hundred years,

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
but everyone who knows anything about China

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
knows it's a lot older than this.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:23.958
This was what China looked like with the victory of the Qin Dynasty

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:26.958
in 221 B.C. at the end of the warring-state period --

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
the birth of modern China.

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
And you can see it against the boundaries of modern China.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:33.958
Or immediately afterward, the Han Dynasty,

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:35.958
still 2,000 years ago.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
And you can see already it occupies

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
most of what we now know as Eastern China,

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:42.958
which is where the vast majority of Chinese lived then

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
and live now.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Now what is extraordinary about this

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
is, what gives China its sense of being China,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
what gives the Chinese

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
the sense of what it is to be Chinese,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
comes not from the last hundred years,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
not from the nation-state period,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:02.958
which is what happened in the West,

00:04:02.958 --> 00:04:04.958
but from the period, if you like,

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:06.958
of the civilization-state.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:09.958
I'm thinking here, for example,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
of customs like ancestral worship,

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
of a very distinctive notion of the state,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:18.958
likewise, a very distinctive notion of the family,

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
social relationships like guanxi,

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
Confucian values and so on.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
These are all things that come

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
from the period of the civilization-state.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
In other words, China, unlike the Western states and most countries in the world,

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
is shaped by its sense of civilization,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
its existence as a civilization-state,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
rather than as a nation-state.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:40.958
And there's one other thing to add to this, and that is this:

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
Of course we know China's big, huge,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
demographically and geographically,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
with a population of 1.3 billion people.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
What we often aren't really aware of

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:53.958
is the fact

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
that China is extremely diverse

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
and very pluralistic,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
and in many ways very decentralized.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:02.958
You can't run a place on this scale simply from Beijing,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
even though we think this to be the case.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
It's never been the case.

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
So this is China, a civilization-state,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
rather than a nation-state.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
And what does it mean?

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
Well, I think it has all sorts of profound implications.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
I'll give you two quick ones.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
The first is that

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:25.958
the most important political value for the Chinese

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
is unity,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
is the maintenance

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
of Chinese civilization.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
You know, 2,000 years ago, Europe:

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
breakdown -- the fragmentation of the Holy Roman Empire.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
It divided, and it's remained divided ever since.

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
China, over the same time period,

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
went in exactly the opposite direction,

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
very painfully holding this huge civilization,

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
civilization-state, together.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
The second

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
is maybe more prosaic,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
which is Hong Kong.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
Do you remember the handover of Hong Kong

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
by Britain to China in 1997?

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
You may remember

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
what the Chinese constitutional proposition was.

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
One country, two systems.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
And I'll lay a wager

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
that barely anyone in the West believed them.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
"Window dressing.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
When China gets its hands on Hong Kong,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
that won't be the case."

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
Thirteen years on,

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
the political and legal system in Hong Kong

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
is as different now as it was in 1997.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:27.958
We were wrong. Why were we wrong?

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
We were wrong because we thought, naturally enough,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
in nation-state ways.

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
Think of German unification, 1990.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
What happened?

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
Well, basically the East was swallowed by the West.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
One nation, one system.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
That is the nation-state mentality.

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:46.958
But you can't run a country like China,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
a civilization-state,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
on the basis of one civilization, one system.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
It doesn't work.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:56.958
So actually the response of China

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
to the question of Hong Kong --

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
as it will be to the question of Taiwan --

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
was a natural response:

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
one civilization, many systems.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
Let me offer you another building block

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
to try and understand China --

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
maybe not sort of a comfortable one.

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
The Chinese have a very, very different

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
conception of race

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
to most other countries.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
Do you know,

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
of the 1.3 billion Chinese,

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
over 90 percent of them

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
think they belong to the same race,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
the Han?

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
Now, this is completely different

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
from the world's [other] most populous countries.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
India, the United States,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
Indonesia, Brazil --

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
all of them are multiracial.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
The Chinese don't feel like that.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
China is only multiracial

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.958
really at the margins.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
So the question is, why?

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
Well the reason, I think, essentially

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
is, again, back to the civilization-state.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
A history of at least 2,000 years,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
a history of conquest, occupation,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
absorption, assimilation and so on,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
led to the process by which,

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
over time, this notion of the Han emerged --

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
of course, nurtured

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
by a growing and very powerful sense

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
of cultural identity.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
Now the great advantage of this historical experience

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:26.958
has been that, without the Han,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
China could never have held together.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
The Han identity has been the cement

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
which has held this country together.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
The great disadvantage of it

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
is that the Han have a very weak conception

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
of cultural difference.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
They really believe

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
in their own superiority,

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
and they are disrespectful

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
of those who are not.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Hence their attitude, for example,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
to the Uyghurs and to the Tibetans.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
Or let me give you my third building block,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
the Chinese state.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:01.958
Now the relationship

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
between the state and society in China

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
is very different from that in the West.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
Now we in the West

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
overwhelmingly seem to think -- in these days at least --

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:16.958
that the authority and legitimacy of the state

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
is a function of democracy.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
The problem with this proposition

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:25.958
is that the Chinese state

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
enjoys more legitimacy

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
and more authority

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
amongst the Chinese

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
than is true

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
with any Western state.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And the reason for this

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
is because --

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
well, there are two reasons, I think.

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
And it's obviously got nothing to do with democracy,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
because in our terms the Chinese certainly don't have a democracy.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
And the reason for this is,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
firstly, because the state in China

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
is given a very special --

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
it enjoys a very special significance

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
as the representative,

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
the embodiment and the guardian

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
of Chinese civilization,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
of the civilization-state.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
This is as close as China gets

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
to a kind of spiritual role.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
And the second reason is because,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
whereas in Europe

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
and North America,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
the state's power is continuously challenged --

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
I mean in the European tradition,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
historically against the church,

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
against other sectors of the aristocracy,

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
against merchants and so on --

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
for 1,000 years,

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
the power of the Chinese state

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
has not been challenged.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
It's had no serious rivals.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
So you can see

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:48.958
that the way in which power has been constructed in China

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
is very different from our experience

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
in Western history.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
The result, by the way,

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:59.958
is that the Chinese have a very different view of the state.

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
Whereas we tend to view it as an intruder,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:06.958
a stranger,

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
certainly an organ

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
whose powers need to be limited

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
or defined and constrained,

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
the Chinese don't see the state like that at all.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
The Chinese view the state

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
as an intimate -- not just as an intimate actually,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
as a member of the family --

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
not just in fact as a member of the family,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
but as the head of the family,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
the patriarch of the family.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
This is the Chinese view of the state --

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
very, very different to ours.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
It's embedded in society in a different kind of way

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
to what is the case

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
in the West.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
And I would suggest to you that actually what we are dealing with here,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
in the Chinese context,

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
is a new kind of paradigm,

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
which is different from anything

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
we've had to think about in the past.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
Know that China believes in the market and the state.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
I mean, Adam Smith,

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
already writing in the late 18th century, said,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
"The Chinese market is larger and more developed

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
and more sophisticated

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
than anything in Europe."

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
And, apart from the Mao period,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
that has remained more or less the case ever since.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
But this is combined

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:19.958
with an extremely strong and ubiquitous state.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
The state is everywhere in China.

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
I mean, it's leading firms --

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
many of them are still publicly owned.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
Private firms, however large they are, like Lenovo,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
depend in many ways on state patronage.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
Targets for the economy and so on

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
are set by the state.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
And the state, of course, its authority flows into lots of other areas --

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
as we are familiar with --

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
with something like the one-child policy.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
Moreover, this is a very old state tradition,

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
a very old tradition of statecraft.

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
I mean, if you want an illustration of this,

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
the Great Wall is one.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
But this is another, this is the Grand Canal,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
which was constructed in the first instance

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
in the fifth century B.C.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
and was finally completed

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
in the seventh century A.D.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:05.958
It went for 1,114 miles,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
linking Beijing

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
with Hangzhou and Shanghai.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
So there's a long history

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:15.958
of extraordinary state infrastructural projects

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
in China,

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.958
which I suppose helps us to explain what we see today,

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
which is something like the Three Gorges Dam

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
and many other expressions

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
of state competence

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
within China.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.958
So there we have three building blocks

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:34.958
for trying to understand the difference that is China --

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
the civilization-state,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
the notion of race

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
and the nature of the state

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
and its relationship to society.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
And yet we still insist, by and large,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:51.958
in thinking that we can understand China

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:54.958
by simply drawing on Western experience,

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
looking at it through Western eyes,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
using Western concepts.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
If you want to know why

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
we unerringly seem to get China wrong --

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
our predictions about what's going to happen to China are incorrect --

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:11.958
this is the reason.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:13.958
Unfortunately, I think,

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
I have to say that I think

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
attitude towards China

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
is that of a kind of little Westerner mentality.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
It's kind of arrogant.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
It's arrogant in the sense

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:27.958
that we think that we are best,

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
and therefore we have the universal measure.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
And secondly, it's ignorant.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
We refuse to really address

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
the issue of difference.

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
You know, there's a very interesting passage

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
in a book by Paul Cohen, the American historian.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
And Paul Cohen argues

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:50.958
that the West thinks of itself

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
as probably the most cosmopolitan

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
of all cultures.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
But it's not.

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:58.958
In many ways,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:00.958
it's the most parochial,

00:15:00.958 --> 00:15:03.958
because for 200 years,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
the West has been so dominant in the world

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:08.958
that it's not really needed

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
to understand other cultures,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
other civilizations.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
Because, at the end of the day,

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
it could, if necessary by force,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
get its own way.

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
Whereas those cultures --

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
virtually the rest of the world, in fact,

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
which have been in a far weaker position, vis-a-vis the West --

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
have been thereby forced to understand the West,

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
because of the West's presence in those societies.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
And therefore, they are, as a result,

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
more cosmopolitan in many ways than the West.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
I mean, take the question of East Asia.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
East Asia: Japan, Korea, China, etc. --

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
a third of the world's population lives there.

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
Now the largest economic region in the world.

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
And I'll tell you now,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:53.958
that East Asianers, people from East Asia,

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:55.958
are far more knowledgeable

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
about the West

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:01.958
than the West is about East Asia.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
Now this point is very germane, I'm afraid,

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
to the present.

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:09.958
Because what's happening? Back to that chart at the beginning,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
the Goldman Sachs chart.

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
What is happening

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
is that, very rapidly in historical terms,

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.958
the world is being driven

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
and shaped,

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
not by the old developed countries,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
but by the developing world.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
We've seen this

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
in terms of the G20

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:32.958
usurping very rapidly the position of the G7,

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:35.958
or the G8.

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
And there are two consequences of this.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
First, the West

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
is rapidly losing

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
its influence in the world.

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
There was a dramatic illustration of this actually a year ago --

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
Copenhagen, climate change conference.

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:52.958
Europe was not at the final negotiating table.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
When did that last happen?

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:57.958
I would wager it was probably about 200 years ago.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:17:00.958
And that is what is going to happen in the future.

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:02.958
And the second implication

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
is that the world will inevitably, as a consequence,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:09.958
become increasingly unfamiliar to us,

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.958
because it'll be shaped by cultures and experiences and histories

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:15.958
that we are not really familiar with,

00:17:15.958 --> 00:17:17.958
or conversant with.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:19.958
And at last, I'm afraid -- take Europe;

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
America is slightly different --

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
but Europeans by and large, I have to say,

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
are ignorant,

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
are unaware

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
about the way the world is changing.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:35.958
Some people -- I've got an English friend in China,

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
and he said, "The continent is sleepwalking into oblivion."

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:42.958
Well, maybe that's true,

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:44.958
maybe that's an exaggeration.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
But there's another problem which goes along with this --

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:50.958
that Europe is increasingly out of touch with the world --

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:53.958
and that is a sort of

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
loss of a sense of the future.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
I mean, Europe once, of course, once commanded the future

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:00.958
in its confidence.

00:18:00.958 --> 00:18:03.958
Take the 19th century, for example.

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
But this, alas, is no longer true.

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:09.958
If you want to feel the future, if you want to taste the future,

00:18:09.958 --> 00:18:12.958
try China -- there's old Confucius.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:14.958
This is a railway station

00:18:14.958 --> 00:18:16.958
the likes of which you've never seen before.

00:18:16.958 --> 00:18:18.958
It doesn't even look like a railway station.

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
This is the new [Wuhan] railway station

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
for the high-speed trains.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
China already has a bigger network

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
than any other country in the world

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:30.958
and will soon have more than all the rest of the world put together.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
Or take this: now this is an idea,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:35.958
but it's an idea to be tried out shortly

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:37.958
in a suburb of Beijing.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
Here you have a megabus,

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:43.958
on the upper deck carries about 2,000 people.

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
It travels on rails

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:47.958
down a suburban road,

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
and the cars travel underneath it.

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
And it does speeds of up to about 100 miles an hour.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
Now this is the way things are going to move,

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:58.958
because China has a very specific problem,

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:00.958
which is different from Europe

00:19:00.958 --> 00:19:02.958
and different from the United States:

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
China has huge numbers of people and no space.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
So this is a solution to a situation

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
where China's going to have

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:11.958
many, many, many cities

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:13.958
over 20 million people.

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:16.958
Okay, so how would I like to finish?

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:19.958
Well, what should our attitude be

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:22.958
towards this world

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:24.958
that we see

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:26.958
very rapidly developing

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:28.958
before us?

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:32.958
I think there will be good things about it and there will be bad things about it.

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:34.958
But I want to argue, above all,

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:37.958
a big-picture positive for this world.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:41.958
For 200 years,

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:47.958
the world was essentially governed

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:51.958
by a fragment of the human population.

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:55.958
That's what Europe and North America represented.

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:57.958
The arrival of countries

00:19:57.958 --> 00:19:59.958
like China and India --

00:19:59.958 --> 00:20:01.958
between them 38 percent of the world's population --

00:20:01.958 --> 00:20:04.958
and others like Indonesia and Brazil and so on,

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:10.958
represent the most important single act

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:12.958
of democratization

00:20:12.958 --> 00:20:14.958
in the last 200 years.

00:20:14.958 --> 00:20:16.958
Civilizations and cultures,

00:20:16.958 --> 00:20:19.958
which had been ignored, which had no voice,

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:21.958
which were not listened to, which were not known about,

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:23.958
will have a different sort

00:20:23.958 --> 00:20:26.958
of representation in this world.

00:20:26.958 --> 00:20:28.958
As humanists, we must welcome, surely,

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:30.958
this transformation,

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:32.958
and we will have to learn

00:20:32.958 --> 00:20:34.958
about these civilizations.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:37.958
This big ship here

00:20:37.958 --> 00:20:39.958
was the one sailed in by Zheng He

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:41.958
in the early 15th century

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:43.958
on his great voyages

00:20:43.958 --> 00:20:46.958
around the South China Sea, the East China Sea

00:20:46.958 --> 00:20:49.958
and across the Indian Ocean to East Africa.

00:20:49.958 --> 00:20:53.958
The little boat in front of it

00:20:53.958 --> 00:20:55.958
was the one in which, 80 years later,

00:20:55.958 --> 00:20:58.958
Christopher Columbus crossed the Atlantic.

00:20:58.958 --> 00:21:00.958
(Laughter)

00:21:00.958 --> 00:21:02.958
Or, look carefully

00:21:02.958 --> 00:21:04.958
at this silk scroll

00:21:04.958 --> 00:21:07.958
made by ZhuZhou

00:21:07.958 --> 00:21:10.958
in 1368.

00:21:10.958 --> 00:21:12.958
I think they're playing golf.

00:21:12.958 --> 00:21:15.958
Christ, the Chinese even invented golf.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:18.958
Welcome to the future. Thank you.

00:21:18.958 --> 00:21:21.958
(Applause)

title: It's time to redesign medical data
transcript: I'm going to be talking to you about how we can tap a really underutilized resource in health care, which is the patient, or, as I like to use the scientific term, people. Because we are all patients, we are all people. Even doctors are patients at some point. So I want to talk about that as an opportunity that we really have failed to engage with very well in this country and, in fact, worldwide. If you want to get at the big part — I mean from a public health level, where my training is — you're looking at behavioral issues. You're looking at things where people are actually given information, and they're not following through with it. It's a problem that manifests itself in diabetes, obesity, many forms of heart disease, even some forms of cancer — when you think of smoking. Those are all behaviors where people know what they're supposed to do. They know what they're supposed to be doing, but they're not doing it.Now behavior change is something that is a long-standing problem in medicine. It goes all the way back to Aristotle. And doctors hate it, right? I mean, they complain about it all the time. We talk about it in terms of engagement, or non-compliance. When people don't take their pills, when people don't follow doctors' orders — these are behavior problems. But for as much as clinical medicine agonizes over behavior change, there's not a lot of work done in terms of trying to fix that problem. So the crux of it comes down to this notion of decision-making — giving information to people in a form that doesn't just educate them or inform them, but actually leads them to make better decisions, better choices in their lives.One part of medicine, though, has faced the problem of behavior change pretty well, and that's dentistry. Dentistry might seem — and I think it is — many dentists would have to acknowledge it's somewhat of a mundane backwater of medicine. Not a lot of cool, sexy stuff happening in dentistry. But they have really taken this problem of behavior change and solved it. It's the one great preventive health success we have in our health care system. People brush and floss their teeth. They don't do it as much as they should, but they do it.So I'm going to talk about one experiment that a few dentists in Connecticut cooked up about 30 years ago. So this is an old experiment, but it's a really good one, because it was very simple, so it's an easy story to tell. So these Connecticut dentists decided that they wanted to get people to brush their teeth and floss their teeth more often, and they were going to use one variable: they wanted to scare them. They wanted to tell them how bad it would be if they didn't brush and floss their teeth. They had a big patient population. They divided them up into two groups. They had a low-fear population, where they basically gave them a 13-minute presentation, all based in science, but told them that, if you didn't brush and floss your teeth, you could get gum disease. If you get gum disease, you will lose your teeth, but you'll get dentures, and it won't be that bad. So that was the low-fear group. The high-fear group, they laid it on really thick. They showed bloody gums. They showed puss oozing out from between their teeth. They told them that their teeth were going to fall out. They said that they could have infections that would spread from their jaws to other parts of their bodies, and ultimately, yes, they would lose their teeth. They would get dentures, and if you got dentures, you weren't going to be able to eat corn-on-the-cob, you weren't going to be able to eat apples, you weren't going to be able to eat steak. You'll eat mush for the rest of your life. So go brush and floss your teeth. That was the message. That was the experiment.Now they measured one other variable. They wanted to capture one other variable, which was the patients' sense of efficacy. This was the notion of whether the patients felt that they actually would go ahead and brush and floss their teeth. So they asked them at the beginning, "Do you think you'll actually be able to stick with this program?" And the people who said, "Yeah, yeah. I'm pretty good about that," they were characterized as high efficacy, and the people who said, "Eh, I never get around to brushing and flossing as much as I should," they were characterized as low efficacy. So the upshot was this. The upshot of this experiment was that fear was not really a primary driver of the behavior at all. The people who brushed and flossed their teeth were not necessarily the people who were really scared about what would happen — it's the people who simply felt that they had the capacity to change their behavior. So fear showed up as not really the driver. It was the sense of efficacy.So I want to isolate this, because it was a great observation — 30 years ago, right, 30 years ago — and it's one that's laid fallow in research. It was a notion that really came out of Albert Bandura's work, who studied whether people could get a sense of empowerment. The notion of efficacy basically boils down to one — that if somebody believes that they have the capacity to change their behavior. In health care terms, you could characterize this as whether or not somebody feels that they see a path towards better health, that they can actually see their way towards getting better health, and that's a very important notion. It's an amazing notion. We don't really know how to manipulate it, though, that well. Except, maybe we do.So fear doesn't work, right? Fear doesn't work. And this is a great example of how we haven't learned that lesson at all. This is a campaign from the American Diabetes Association. This is still the way we're communicating messages about health. I mean, I showed my three-year-old this slide last night, and he's like, "Papa, why is an ambulance in these people's homes?" And I had to explain, "They're trying to scare people." And I don't know if it works.Now here's what does work: personalized information works. Again, Bandura recognized this years ago, decades ago. When you give people specific information about their health, where they stand, and where they want to get to, where they might get to, that path, that notion of a path — that tends to work for behavior change. So let me just spool it out a little bit. So you start with personalized data, personalized information that comes from an individual, and then you need to connect it to their lives. You need to connect it to their lives, hopefully not in a fear-based way, but one that they understand. Okay, I know where I sit. I know where I'm situated. And that doesn't just work for me in terms of abstract numbers — this overload of health information that we're inundated with. But it actually hits home. It's not just hitting us in our heads; it's hitting us in our hearts. There's an emotional connection to information because it's from us. That information then needs to be connected to choices, needs to be connected to a range of options, directions that we might go to — trade-offs, benefits. Finally, we need to be presented with a clear point of action. We need to connect the information always with the action, and then that action feeds back into different information, and it creates, of course, a feedback loop.Now this is a very well-observed and well-established notion for behavior change. But the problem is that things — in the upper-right corner there — personalized data, it's been pretty hard to come by. It's a difficult and expensive commodity, until now. So I'm going to give you an example, a very simple example of how this works. So we've all seen these. These are the "your speed limit" signs. You've seen them all around, especially these days as radars are cheaper. And here's how they work in the feedback loop. So you start with the personalized data where the speed limit on the road that you are at that point is 25, and, of course, you're going faster than that. We always are. We're always going above the speed limit. The choice in this case is pretty simple. We either keep going fast, or we slow down. We should probably slow down, and that point of action is probably now. We should take our foot off the pedal right now, and generally we do. These things are shown to be pretty effective in terms of getting people to slow down. They reduce speeds by about five to 10 percent. They last for about five miles, in which case we put our foot back on the pedal. But it works, and it even has some health repercussions. Your blood pressure might drop a little bit. Maybe there's fewer accidents, so there's public health benefits.But by and large, this is a feedback loop that's so nifty and too rare. Because in health care, most health care, the data is very removed from the action. It's very difficult to line things up so neatly. But we have an opportunity. So I want to talk about, I want to shift now to think about how we deliver health information in this country, how we actually get information. This is a pharmaceutical ad. Actually, it's a spoof. It's not a real pharmaceutical ad. Nobody's had the brilliant idea of calling their drug Havidol quite yet. But it looks completely right. So it's exactly the way we get health information and pharmaceutical information, and it just sounds perfect. And then we turn the page of the magazine, and we see this — now this is the page the FDA requires pharmaceutical companies to put into their ads, or to follow their ads, and to me, this is one of the most  cynical exercises in medicine. Because we know. Who among us would actually say that people read this? And who among us would actually say that people who do try to read this actually get anything out of it? This is a bankrupt effort at communicating health information. There is no good faith in this.So this is a different approach. This is an approach that has been developed by a couple researchers at Dartmouth Medical School, Lisa Schwartz and Steven Woloshin. And they created this thing called the "drug facts box." They took inspiration from, of all things, Cap'n Crunch. They went to the nutritional information box and saw that what works for cereal, works for our food, actually helps people understand what's in their food. God forbid we should use that same standard that we make Cap'n Crunch live by and bring it to drug companies. So let me just walk through this quickly. It says very clearly what the drug is for, specifically who it is good for, so you can start to personalize your understanding of whether the information is relevant to you or whether the drug is relevant to you. You can understand exactly what the benefits are. It isn't this kind of vague promise that it's going to work no matter what, but you get the statistics for how effective it is. And finally, you understand what those choices are. You can start to unpack the choices involved because of the side effects. Every time you take a drug, you're walking into a possible side effect. So it spells those out in very clean terms, and that works.So I love this. I love that drug facts box. And so I was thinking about, what's an opportunity that I could have to help people understand information? What's another latent body of information that's out there that people are really not putting to use? And so I came up with this: lab test results. Blood test results are this great source of information. They're packed with information. They're just not for us. They're not for people. They're not for patients. They go right to doctors. And God forbid — I think many doctors, if you really asked them, they don't really understand all this stuff either. This is the worst presented information. You ask Tufte, and he would say, "Yes, this is the absolute worst presentation of information possible."What we did at Wired was we went, and I got our graphic design department to re-imagine these lab reports. So that's what I want to walk you through. So this is the general blood work before, and this is the after, this is what we came up with. The after takes what was four pages — that previous slide was actually the first of four pages of data that's just the general blood work. It goes on and on and on, all these values, all these numbers you don't know. This is our one-page summary. We use the notion of color. It's an amazing notion that color could be used. So on the top-level you have your overall results, the things that might jump out at you from the fine print. Then you can drill down and understand how actually we put your level in context, and we use color to illustrate exactly where your value falls. In this case, this patient is slightly at risk of diabetes because of their glucose level.Likewise, you can go over your lipids and, again, understand what your overall cholesterol level is and then break down into the HDL and the LDL if you so choose. But again, always using color and personalized proximity to that information. All those other values, all those pages and pages of values that are full of nothing, we summarize. We tell you that you're okay, you're normal. But you don't have to wade through it. You don't have to go through the junk. And then we do two other very important things that kind of help fill in this feedback loop: we help people understand in a little more detail what these values are and what they might indicate. And then we go a further step — we tell them what they can do. We give them some insight into what choices they can make, what actions they can take. So that's our general blood work test.Then we went to CRP test. In this case, it's a sin of omission. They have this huge amount of space, and they don't use it for anything, so we do. Now the CRP test is often done following a cholesterol test, or in conjunction with a cholesterol test. So we take the bold step of putting the cholesterol information on the same page, which is the way the doctor is going to evaluate it. So we thought the patient might actually want to know the context as well. It's a protein that shows up when your blood vessels might be inflamed, which might be a risk for heart disease. What you're actually measuring is spelled out in clean language. Then we use the information that's already in the lab report. We use the person's age and their gender to start to fill in the personalized risks. So we start to use the data we have to run a very simple calculation that's on all sorts of online calculators to get a sense of what the actual risk is.The last one I'll show you is a PSA test. Here's the before, and here's the after. Now a lot of our effort on this one — as many of you probably know, a PSA test is a very controversial test. It's used to test for prostate cancer, but there are all sorts of reasons why your prostate might be enlarged. And so we spent a good deal of our time indicating that. We again personalized the risks. So this patient is in their 50s, so we can actually give them a very precise estimate of what their risk for prostate cancer is. In this case it's about 25 percent, based on that. And then again, the follow-up actions.So our cost for this was less than 10,000 dollars, all right. That's what Wired magazine spent on this. Why is Wired magazine doing this? (Laughter) Quest Diagnostics and LabCorp, the two largest lab testing companies — last year, they made profits of over 700 million dollars and over 500 million dollars respectively. Now this is not a problem of resources; this is a problem of incentives. We need to recognize that the target of this information should not be the doctor, should not be the insurance company. It should be the patient. It's the person who actually, in the end, is going to be having to change their lives and then start adopting new behaviors.This is information that is incredibly powerful. It's an incredibly powerful catalyst to change. But we're not using it. It's just sitting there. It's being lost. So I want to just offer four questions that every patient should ask, because I don't actually expect people to start developing these lab test reports. But you can create your own feedback loop. Anybody can create their feedback loop by asking these simple questions: Can I have my results? And the only acceptable answer is — (Audience: Yes.) — yes. What does this mean? Help me understand what the data is. What are my options? What choices are now on the table? And then, what's next? How do I integrate this information into the longer course of my life?So I want to wind up by just showing that people have the capacity to understand this information. This is not beyond the grasp of ordinary people. You do not need to have the education level of people in this room. Ordinary people are capable of understanding this information, if we only go to the effort of presenting it to them in a form that they can engage with. And engagement is essential here, because it's not just giving them information; it's giving them an opportunity to act. That's what engagement is. It's different from compliance. It works totally different from the way we talk about behavior in medicine today. And this information is out there.I've been talking today about latent information, all this information that exists in the system that we're not putting to use. But there are all sorts of other bodies of information that are coming online, and we need to recognize the capacity of this information to engage people, to help people and to change the course of their lives.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
And doctors hate it, right?

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
I mean, they complain about it all the time.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
We talk about it in terms of engagement, or non-compliance.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
When people don't take their pills,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
when people don't follow doctors' orders --

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
these are behavior problems.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
But for as much as clinical medicine

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
agonizes over behavior change,

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
there's not a lot of work done

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
in terms of trying to fix that problem.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
So the crux of it

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
comes down to this notion of decision-making --

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
giving information to people in a form

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:41.958
that doesn't just educate them

00:01:41.958 --> 00:01:43.958
or inform them,

00:01:43.958 --> 00:01:45.958
but actually leads them to make better decisions,

00:01:45.958 --> 00:01:47.958
better choices in their lives.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.958
One part of medicine, though,

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:53.958
has faced the problem of behavior change pretty well,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.958
and that's dentistry.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.958
Dentistry might seem -- and I think it is --

00:01:57.958 --> 00:01:59.958
many dentists would have to acknowledge

00:01:59.958 --> 00:02:01.958
it's somewhat of a mundane backwater of medicine.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.958
Not a lot of cool, sexy stuff happening in dentistry.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:07.958
But they have really taken this problem of behavior change

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:09.958
and solved it.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
It's the one great preventive health success

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
we have in our health care system.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
People brush and floss their teeth.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
They don't do it as much as they should, but they do it.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
So I'm going to talk about one experiment

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
that a few dentists in Connecticut

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
cooked up about 30 years ago.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
So this is an old experiment, but it's a really good one,

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
because it was very simple,

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
so it's an easy story to tell.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
So these Connecticut dentists decided

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
that they wanted to get people to brush their teeth and floss their teeth more often,

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
and they were going to use one variable:

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
they wanted to scare them.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:42.958
They wanted to tell them how bad it would be

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
if they didn't brush and floss their teeth.

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:47.958
They had a big patient population.

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:49.958
They divided them up into two groups.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:51.958
They had a low-fear population,

00:02:51.958 --> 00:02:53.958
where they basically gave them a 13-minute presentation,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
all based in science,

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
but told them that, if you didn't brush and floss your teeth,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:01.958
you could get gum disease. If you get gum disease, you will lose your teeth,

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
but you'll get dentures, and it won't be that bad.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
So that was the low-fear group.

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
The high-fear group, they laid it on really thick.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
They showed bloody gums.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
They showed puss oozing out from between their teeth.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
They told them that their teeth were going to fall out.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:17.958
They said that they could have infections

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
that would spread from their jaws to other parts of their bodies,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
and ultimately, yes, they would lose their teeth.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
They would get dentures, and if you got dentures,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
you weren't going to be able to eat corn-on-the-cob,

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
you weren't going to be able to eat apples,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
you weren't going to be able to eat steak.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
You'll eat mush for the rest of your life.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:35.958
So go brush and floss your teeth.

00:03:35.958 --> 00:03:37.958
That was the message. That was the experiment.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:39.958
Now they measured one other variable.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:41.958
They wanted to capture one other variable,

00:03:41.958 --> 00:03:44.958
which was the patients' sense of efficacy.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
This was the notion of whether the patients felt

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
that they actually would go ahead and brush and floss their teeth.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:51.958
So they asked them at the beginning,

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
"Do you think you'll actually be able to stick with this program?"

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
And the people who said, "Yeah, yeah. I'm pretty good about that,"

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
they were characterized as high efficacy,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
and the people who said,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
"Eh, I never get around to brushing and flossing as much as I should,"

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
they were characterized as low efficacy.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:06.958
So the upshot was this.

00:04:06.958 --> 00:04:08.958
The upshot of this experiment

00:04:08.958 --> 00:04:11.958
was that fear was not really a primary driver

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
of the behavior at all.

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
The people who brushed and flossed their teeth

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
were not necessarily the people

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
who were really scared about what would happen --

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
it's the people who simply felt that they had the capacity

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
to change their behavior.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:27.958
So fear showed up as not really the driver.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:30.958
It was the sense of efficacy.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
So I want to isolate this,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
because it was a great observation --

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
30 years ago, right, 30 years ago --

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
and it's one that's laid fallow in research.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
It was a notion that really came out

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
of Albert Bandura's work,

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
who studied whether

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:48.958
people could get a sense of empowerment.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
The notion of efficacy basically boils down to one -- that

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
if somebody believes that they have the capacity to change their behavior.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:57.958
In health care terms, you could characterize this

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
as whether or not somebody feels

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
that they see a path towards better health,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
that they can actually see their way towards getting better health,

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
and that's a very important notion.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
It's an amazing notion.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
We don't really know how to manipulate it, though, that well.

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
Except, maybe we do.

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
So fear doesn't work, right? Fear doesn't work.

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
And this is a great example

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:20.958
of how we haven't learned that lesson at all.

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
This is a campaign from the American Diabetes Association.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
This is still the way we're communicating messages about health.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
I mean, I showed my three-year-old this slide last night,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
and he's like, "Papa, why is an ambulance in these people's homes?"

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:36.958
And I had to explain, "They're trying to scare people."

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
And I don't know if it works.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
Now here's what does work:

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
personalized information works.

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
Again, Bandura recognized this

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
years ago, decades ago.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
When you give people specific information

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
about their health, where they stand,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
and where they want to get to, where they might get to,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
that path, that notion of a path --

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
that tends to work for behavior change.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
So let me just spool it out a little bit.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:01.958
So you start with personalized data, personalized information

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
that comes from an individual,

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
and then you need to connect it to their lives.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
You need to connect it to their lives,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
hopefully not in a fear-based way, but one that they understand.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
Okay, I know where I sit. I know where I'm situated.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
And that doesn't just work for me in terms of abstract numbers --

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
this overload of health information

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
that we're inundated with.

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
But it actually hits home.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:24.958
It's not just hitting us in our heads; it's hitting us in our hearts.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
There's an emotional connection to information

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
because it's from us.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
That information then needs to be connected to choices,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
needs to be connected to a range of options,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
directions that we might go to --

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
trade-offs, benefits.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
Finally, we need to be presented with a clear point of action.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
We need to connect the information

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
always with the action,

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
and then that action feeds back

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
into different information,

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
and it creates, of course, a feedback loop.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
Now this is a very well-observed and well-established notion

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
for behavior change.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
But the problem is that things -- in the upper-right corner there --

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
personalized data, it's been pretty hard to come by.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
It's a difficult and expensive commodity,

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
until now.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:08.958
So I'm going to give you an example, a very simple example of how this works.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
So we've all seen these. These are the "your speed limit" signs.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
You've seen them all around,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
especially these days as radars are cheaper.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
And here's how they work in the feedback loop.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
So you start with the personalized data

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
where the speed limit on the road that you are at that point

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
is 25,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and, of course, you're going faster than that.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
We always are. We're always going above the speed limit.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
The choice in this case is pretty simple.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
We either keep going fast, or we slow down.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
We should probably slow down,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
and that point of action is probably now.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
We should take our foot off the pedal right now,

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
and generally we do. These things are shown to be pretty effective

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
in terms of getting people to slow down.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
They reduce speeds by about five to 10 percent.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
They last for about five miles,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
in which case we put our foot back on the pedal.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
But it works, and it even has some health repercussions.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
Your blood pressure might drop a little bit.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.958
Maybe there's fewer accidents, so there's public health benefits.

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
But by and large, this is a feedback loop

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
that's so nifty and too rare.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
Because in health care, most health care,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
the data is very removed from the action.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
It's very difficult to line things up so neatly.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
But we have an opportunity.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
So I want to talk about, I want to shift now to think about

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
how we deliver health information in this country,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:19.958
how we actually get information.

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
This is a pharmaceutical ad.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Actually, it's a spoof. It's not a real pharmaceutical ad.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
Nobody's had the brilliant idea

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
of calling their drug Havidol quite yet.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
But it looks completely right.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
So it's exactly the way we get

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
health information and pharmaceutical information,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
and it just sounds perfect.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
And then we turn the page of the magazine,

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and we see this --

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:47.958
now this is the page the FDA requires pharmaceutical companies

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
to put into their ads, or to follow their ads,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:54.958
and to me, this is one of the most 
cynical exercises in medicine.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
Because we know.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
Who among us would actually say that people read this?

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
And who among us would actually say

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
that people who do try to read this

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
actually get anything out of it?

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
This is a bankrupt effort

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
at communicating health information.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
There is no good faith in this.

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
So this is a different approach.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:16.958
This is an approach that has been developed

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
by a couple researchers at Dartmouth Medical School,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
Lisa Schwartz and Steven Woloshin.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:24.958
And they created this thing called the "drug facts box."

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
They took inspiration from, of all things,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
Cap'n Crunch.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
They went to the nutritional information box

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
and saw that what works for cereal, works for our food,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
actually helps people understand what's in their food.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
God forbid we should use that same standard

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
that we make Cap'n Crunch live by

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
and bring it to drug companies.

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
So let me just walk through this quickly.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
It says very clearly what the drug is for, specifically who it is good for,

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
so you can start to personalize your understanding

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
of whether the information is relevant to you

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
or whether the drug is relevant to you.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
You can understand exactly what the benefits are.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
It isn't this kind of vague promise that it's going to work no matter what,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
but you get the statistics for how effective it is.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
And finally, you understand what those choices are.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
You can start to unpack the choices involved

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
because of the side effects.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
Every time you take a drug, you're walking into a possible side effect.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
So it spells those out in very clean terms,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
and that works.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
So I love this. I love that drug facts box.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
And so I was thinking about,

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
what's an opportunity that I could have

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:28.958
to help people understand information?

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:32.958
What's another latent body of information that's out there

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
that people are really not putting to use?

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
And so I came up with this: lab test results.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Blood test results are this great source of information.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
They're packed with information.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
They're just not for us. They're not for people. They're not for patients.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
They go right to doctors.

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:51.958
And God forbid -- I think many doctors, if you really asked them,

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
they don't really understand all this stuff either.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
This is the worst presented information.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:11:00.958
You ask Tufte, and he would say,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:03.958
"Yes, this is the absolute worst presentation of information possible."

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
What we did at Wired

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
was we went, and I got our graphic design department

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
to re-imagine these lab reports.

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
So that's what I want to walk you through.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
So this is the general blood work before,

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
and this is the after, this is what we came up with.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
The after takes what was four pages --

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
that previous slide was actually

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
the first of four pages of data

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:24.958
that's just the general blood work.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
It goes on and on and on, all these values, all these numbers you don't know.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
This is our one-page summary.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
We use the notion of color.

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:35.958
It's an amazing notion that color could be used.

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:38.958
So on the top-level you have your overall results,

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.958
the things that might jump out at you from the fine print.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:43.958
Then you can drill down

00:11:43.958 --> 00:11:46.958
and understand how actually we put your level in context,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
and we use color to illustrate

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
exactly where your value falls.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
In this case, this patient is slightly at risk of diabetes

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
because of their glucose level.

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
Likewise, you can go over your lipids

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
and, again, understand what your overall cholesterol level is

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
and then break down into the HDL and the LDL if you so choose.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
But again, always using color

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
and personalized proximity

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
to that information.

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
All those other values,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
all those pages and pages of values that are full of nothing,

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
we summarize.

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
We tell you that you're okay, you're normal.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
But you don't have to wade through it. You don't have to go through the junk.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
And then we do two other very important things

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
that kind of help fill in this feedback loop:

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
we help people understand in a little more detail

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
what these values are and what they might indicate.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
And then we go a further step -- we tell them what they can do.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
We give them some insight

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
into what choices they can make, what actions they can take.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
So that's our general blood work test.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
Then we went to CRP test.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
In this case, it's a sin of omission.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
They have this huge amount of space,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
and they don't use it for anything, so we do.

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
Now the CRP test is often done

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
following a cholesterol test,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
or in conjunction with a cholesterol test.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
So we take the bold step

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
of putting the cholesterol information on the same page,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
which is the way the doctor is going to evaluate it.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
So we thought the patient might actually want to know the context as well.

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
It's a protein that shows up

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
when your blood vessels might be inflamed,

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
which might be a risk for heart disease.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
What you're actually measuring

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
is spelled out in clean language.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
Then we use the information

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
that's already in the lab report.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
We use the person's age and their gender

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
to start to fill in the personalized risks.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:25.958
So we start to use the data we have

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
to run a very simple calculation

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
that's on all sorts of online calculators

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
to get a sense of what the actual risk is.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
The last one I'll show you is a PSA test.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:37.958
Here's the before, and here's the after.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
Now a lot of our effort on this one --

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
as many of you probably know,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
a PSA test is a very controversial test.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
It's used to test for prostate cancer,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
but there are all sorts of reasons

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:49.958
why your prostate might be enlarged.

00:13:49.958 --> 00:13:51.958
And so we spent a good deal of our time

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
indicating that.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
We again personalized the risks.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
So this patient is in their 50s,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
so we can actually give them a very precise estimate

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:01.958
of what their risk for prostate cancer is.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
In this case it's about 25 percent, based on that.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
And then again, the follow-up actions.

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
So our cost for this was less than 10,000 dollars, all right.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
That's what Wired magazine spent on this.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:15.958
Why is Wired magazine doing this?

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:18.958
(Laughter)

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
Quest Diagnostics and LabCorp,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
the two largest lab testing companies --

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
last year, they made profits of over 700 million dollars

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
and over 500 million dollars respectively.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:31.958
Now this is not a problem of resources;

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.958
this is a problem of incentives.

00:14:34.958 --> 00:14:37.958
We need to recognize that the target of this information

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
should not be the doctor, should not be the insurance company.

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
It should be the patient.

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
It's the person who actually, in the end,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
is going to be having to change their lives

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
and then start adopting new behaviors.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
This is information that is incredibly powerful.

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
It's an incredibly powerful catalyst to change.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
But we're not using it. It's just sitting there.

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
It's being lost.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
So I want to just offer four questions

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
that every patient should ask,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
because I don't actually expect people

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
to start developing these lab test reports.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
But you can create your own feedback loop.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
Anybody can create their feedback loop by asking these simple questions:

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
Can I have my results?

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
And the only acceptable answer is --

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
(Audience: Yes.) -- yes.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
What does this mean? Help me understand what the data is.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
What are my options? What choices are now on the table?

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
And then, what's next?

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
How do I integrate this information

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
into the longer course of my life?

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:30.958
So I want to wind up by just showing

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
that people have the capacity to understand this information.

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
This is not beyond the grasp of ordinary people.

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:38.958
You do not need to have the education level of people in this room.

00:15:38.958 --> 00:15:41.958
Ordinary people are capable of understanding this information,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
if we only go to the effort of presenting it to them

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
in a form that they can engage with.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
And engagement is essential here,

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
because it's not just giving them information;

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
it's giving them an opportunity to act.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:54.958
That's what engagement is. It's different from compliance.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:57.958
It works totally different from the way we talk about behavior

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
in medicine today.

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
And this information is out there.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
I've been talking today about latent information,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
all this information that exists in the system

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
that we're not putting to use.

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
But there are all sorts of other bodies of information

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:11.958
that are coming online,

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:14.958
and we need to recognize the capacity of this information

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.958
to engage people, to help people

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
and to change the course of their lives.

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
Thank you very much.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
(Applause)

title: Drawing on humor for change
transcript: (Laughter)I was afraid of womanhood. Not that I'm not afraid now, but I've learned to pretend. I've learned to be flexible. In fact, I've developed some interesting tools to help me deal with this fear. Let me explain. Back in the '50s and '60s, when I was growing up, little girls were supposed to be kind and thoughtful and pretty and gentle and soft, and we were supposed to fit into roles that were sort of shadowy — really not quite clear what we were supposed to be.(Laughter)There were plenty of role models all around us. We had our mothers, our aunts, our cousins, our sisters, and of course, the ever-present media bombarding us with images and words, telling us how to be. Now my mother was different. She was a homemaker, but she and I didn't go out and do girlie things together, and she didn't buy me pink outfits. Instead, she knew what I needed, and she bought me a book of cartoons. And I just ate it up. I drew, and I drew, and since I knew that humor was acceptable in my family, I could draw, do what I wanted to do, and not have to perform, not have to speak — I was very shy — and I could still get approval. I was launched as a cartoonist. Now when we're young, we don't always know. We know there are rules out there, but we don't always know — we don't perform them right, even though we are imprinted at birth with these things, and we're told what the most important color in the world is. We're told what shape we're supposed to be in. (Laughter) We're told what to wear — (Laughter) — and how to do our hair — (Laughter) — and how to behave.Now the rules that I'm talking about are constantly being monitored by the culture. We're being corrected, and the primary policemen are women, because we are the carriers of the tradition. We pass it down from generation to generation. Not only that — we always have this vague notion that something's expected of us. And on top of all off these rules, they keep changing. (Laughter) We don't know what's going on half the time, so it puts us in a very tenuous position.(Laughter)Now if you don't like these rules, and many of us don't — I know I didn't, and I still don't, even though I follow them half the time, not quite aware that I'm following them — what better way than to change them [than] with humor? Humor relies on the traditions of a society. It takes what we know, and it twists it. It takes the codes of behavior and the codes of dress, and it makes it unexpected, and that's what elicits a laugh. Now what if you put together women and humor? I think you can get change. Because women are on the ground floor, and we know the traditions so well, we can bring a different voice to the table.Now I started drawing in the middle of a lot of chaos. I grew up not far from here in Washington D.C. during the Civil Rights movement, the assassinations, the Watergate hearings and then the feminist movement, and I think I was drawing, trying to figure out what was going on. And then also my family was in chaos, and I drew to try to bring my family together — (Laughter) — try to bring my family together with laughter. It didn't work. My parents got divorced, and my sister was arrested. But I found my place. I found that I didn't have to wear high heels, I didn't have to wear pink, and I could feel like I fit in.Now when I was a little older, in my 20s, I realized there are not many women in cartooning. And I thought, "Well, maybe I can break the little glass ceiling of cartooning," and so I did. I became a cartoonist. And then I thought — in my 40s I started thinking, "Well, why don't I do something? I always loved political cartoons, so why don't I do something with the content of my cartoons to make people think about the stupid rules that we're following as well as laugh?"Now my perspective is a particularly — (Laughter) — my perspective is a particularly American perspective. I can't help it. I live here. Even though I've traveled a lot, I still think like an American woman. But I believe that the rules that I'm talking about are universal, of course — that each culture has its different codes of behavior and dress and traditions, and each woman has to deal with these same things that we do here in the U.S. Consequently, we have. Women, because we're on the ground, we know the tradition. We have amazing antennae.Now my work lately has been to collaborate with international cartoonists, which I so enjoy, and it's given me a greater appreciation for the power of cartoons to get at the truth, to get at the issues quickly and succinctly. And not only that, it can get to the viewer through not only the intellect, but through the heart. My work also has allowed me to collaborate with women cartoonists from across the world — countries such as Saudi Arabia, Iran, Turkey, Argentina, France — and we have sat together and laughed and talked and shared our difficulties. And these women are working so hard to get their voices heard in some very difficult circumstances. But I feel blessed to be able to work with them.And we talk about how women have such strong perceptions, because of our tenuous position and our role as tradition-keepers, that we can have the great potential to be change-agents. And I think, I truly believe, that we can change this thing one laugh at a time.Thank you.(Applause)
