could know something about you

00:07:50.282 --> 00:07:51.488
and use it to help you,

00:07:51.512 --> 00:07:54.332
there's an even more valuable
application than that.

00:07:54.356 --> 00:07:57.427
That you could know
something about yourself.

00:07:58.182 --> 00:08:01.360
We could know sides of ourselves
that were all but invisible

00:08:01.384 --> 00:08:03.933
and come to see things
that were previously hidden.

00:08:04.791 --> 00:08:07.537
Let me show you an example
of what I'm talking about here.

00:08:07.561 --> 00:08:10.104
Here's an application
that I created for the iPad.

00:08:10.128 --> 00:08:15.367
So the goal of the original game Zen Bound
is to wrap a rope around a wooden form.

00:08:15.391 --> 00:08:16.935
So you use it with your headset.

00:08:16.959 --> 00:08:19.815
The headset connects wirelessly
to an iPad or a smartphone.

00:08:20.156 --> 00:08:24.486
In that headset, you have fabric sensors
on your forehead and above the ear.

00:08:24.510 --> 00:08:26.032
In the original Zen Bound game,

00:08:26.056 --> 00:08:28.934
you play it by scrolling
your fingers over the pad.

00:08:29.442 --> 00:08:31.384
In the game that we created, of course,

00:08:31.408 --> 00:08:35.560
you control the wooden form
that's on the screen there with your mind.

00:08:35.964 --> 00:08:38.183
As you focus on the wooden form,

00:08:38.207 --> 00:08:39.402
it rotates.

00:08:39.426 --> 00:08:42.459
The more you focus,
the faster the rotation.

00:08:42.816 --> 00:08:44.466
This is for real.

00:08:44.490 --> 00:08:45.934
This is not a fake.

00:08:46.556 --> 00:08:48.396
What's really interesting to me though

00:08:48.420 --> 00:08:52.290
is at the end of the game, you get stats
and feedback about how you did.

00:08:52.314 --> 00:08:56.403
You have graphs and charts
that tell you how your brain was doing --

00:08:56.427 --> 00:08:59.479
not just how much rope you used
or what your high score is,

00:08:59.503 --> 00:09:03.351
but what was going on inside of your mind.

00:09:03.756 --> 00:09:05.625
And this is valuable feedback

00:09:05.649 --> 00:09:10.168
that we can use to understand
what's going on inside of ourselves.

00:09:11.992 --> 00:09:15.186
I like to call this "intra-active."

00:09:16.048 --> 00:09:19.249
Normally, we think
about technology as interactive.

00:09:19.749 --> 00:09:22.460
This technology is intra-active.

00:09:23.520 --> 00:09:27.109
It understands what's inside of you

00:09:27.133 --> 00:09:29.498
and builds a sort
of responsive relationship

00:09:29.522 --> 00:09:31.519
between you and your technology

00:09:31.543 --> 00:09:35.498
so that you can use this information
to move you forward.

00:09:35.930 --> 00:09:40.392
So you can use this information
to understand you in a responsive loop.

00:09:40.852 --> 00:09:42.605
At InteraXon --

00:09:44.370 --> 00:09:49.944
intra-active technology
is one of our really defining mandates.

00:09:50.626 --> 00:09:55.526
It's how we understand the world inside
and reflect it outside

00:09:55.550 --> 00:09:57.593
into this tight loop.

00:09:58.623 --> 00:10:01.752
For example, thought-controlled computing

00:10:01.776 --> 00:10:04.933
can teach children with ADD
how to improve their focus.

00:10:05.384 --> 00:10:09.699
With ADD, children have a low proportion
of beta waves for focus states

00:10:09.723 --> 00:10:11.756
and a high proportion of theta states.

00:10:11.780 --> 00:10:14.966
So you can create applications
that reward focused brain states.

00:10:14.990 --> 00:10:18.195
So you can imagine kids playing
video games with their brain waves

00:10:18.219 --> 00:10:20.688
and improving their ADD
symptoms as they do it.

00:10:20.712 --> 00:10:22.606
This can be as effective as Ritalin.

00:10:23.543 --> 00:10:25.384
Perhaps even more importantly,

00:10:25.408 --> 00:10:27.985
thought-controlled computing
can give children with ADD

00:10:28.009 --> 00:10:30.912
insights into their own fluctuating
mental states,

00:10:30.936 --> 00:10:34.568
so they can better understand themselves
and their learning needs.

00:10:34.592 --> 00:10:38.568
The way these children will be able to use
their new awareness to improve themselves

00:10:38.592 --> 00:10:41.516
will upend many of the damaging
and widespread social stigmas

00:10:41.540 --> 00:10:45.380
that people who are diagnosed
as different are challenged with.

00:10:45.872 --> 00:10:47.228
We can peer inside our heads

00:10:47.252 --> 00:10:50.035
and interact with what was once
locked away from us,

00:10:50.059 --> 00:10:52.957
what once mystified and separated us.

00:10:54.300 --> 00:10:57.590
Brainwave technology can understand us,
anticipate our emotions

00:10:57.614 --> 00:10:59.627
and find the best solutions for our needs.

00:10:59.651 --> 00:11:02.397
Imagine this collected
awareness of the individual

00:11:02.421 --> 00:11:04.933
computed and reflected
across an entire lifespan.

00:11:05.416 --> 00:11:08.933
Imagine the insights that you can gain
from this kind of second sight.

00:11:09.439 --> 00:11:12.384
It would be like plugging
into your own personal Google.

00:11:12.754 --> 00:11:14.004
On the subject of Google,

00:11:14.028 --> 00:11:15.934
today you can search and tag images

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:19.330
based on the thoughts and feelings
you had while you watched them.

00:11:19.354 --> 00:11:22.098
You can tag pictures
of baby animals as happy,

00:11:22.122 --> 00:11:24.592
or whatever baby animals are to you,

00:11:24.616 --> 00:11:28.436
and then you can search that database,
navigating with your feelings,

00:11:28.460 --> 00:11:30.934
rather than the keywords
that just hint at them.

00:11:31.527 --> 00:11:33.786
Or you could tag Facebook photos

00:11:33.810 --> 00:11:38.402
with the emotions that you had
associated with those memories

00:11:38.426 --> 00:11:42.128
and then instantly prioritize
the streams that catch your attention,

00:11:42.852 --> 00:11:44.081
just like this.

00:11:45.405 --> 00:11:48.491
Humanizing technology
is about taking what's already natural

00:11:48.515 --> 00:11:50.115
about the human-tech experience

00:11:50.139 --> 00:11:53.525
and building technology
seamlessly in tandem with it.

00:11:53.549 --> 00:11:55.858
As it aligns with our human behaviors,

00:11:55.882 --> 00:11:59.058
it can allow us to make
better sense of what we do

00:11:59.082 --> 00:12:01.317
and, more importantly, why.

00:12:01.824 --> 00:12:04.934
Creating a big picture
out of all the important little details

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.208
that make up who we are.

00:12:07.872 --> 00:12:11.420
With humanized technology we can monitor
the quality of your sleep cycles.

00:12:11.961 --> 00:12:16.213
When our productivity starts to slacken,
we can go back to that data

00:12:16.237 --> 00:12:20.185
and see how we can make more effective
balance between work and play.

00:12:20.890 --> 00:12:24.823
Do you know what causes fatigue in you
or what brings out your energetic self,

00:12:24.847 --> 00:12:26.765
what triggers cause you to be depressed

00:12:26.789 --> 00:12:30.307
or what fun things are going
to bring you out of that funk?

00:12:31.715 --> 00:12:33.361
Imagine if you had access to data

00:12:33.385 --> 00:12:36.582
that allowed you to rank
on a scale of overall happiness

00:12:36.606 --> 00:12:39.462
which people in your life
made you the happiest,

00:12:40.185 --> 00:12:42.581
or what activities brought you joy.

00:12:42.605 --> 00:12:45.660
Would you make more time for those people?
Would you prioritize?

00:12:45.684 --> 00:12:46.959
Would you get a divorce?

00:12:46.983 --> 00:12:48.368
(Laughter)

00:12:48.392 --> 00:12:50.881
What thought-controlled computing
can allow you to do

00:12:50.905 --> 00:12:53.697
is build colorful layered
pictures of our lives.

00:12:53.721 --> 00:12:57.207
And with this, we can get the skinny
on our psychological happenings

00:12:57.231 --> 00:12:59.639
and build a story
of our behaviors over time.

00:13:00.077 --> 00:13:03.296
We can begin to see the underlying
narratives that propel us forward

00:13:03.320 --> 00:13:05.909
and tell us about what's going on.

00:13:06.731 --> 00:13:11.259
And from this, we can learn
how to change the plot, the outcome

00:13:11.283 --> 00:13:14.269
and the character of our personal stories.

00:13:15.524 --> 00:13:19.665
Two millennia ago, those Greeks
had some powerful insights.

00:13:20.380 --> 00:13:22.800
They knew that a fundamental
piece falls into place

00:13:22.824 --> 00:13:25.563
when you start to live
out their little phrase,

00:13:25.587 --> 00:13:27.934
when you come into contact with yourself.

00:13:28.379 --> 00:13:31.730
They understood the power
of human narrative

00:13:31.754 --> 00:13:35.750
and the value that we place on humans
as changing, evolving and growing.

00:13:36.306 --> 00:13:38.934
But they understood something
more fundamental --

00:13:39.783 --> 00:13:41.934
the sheer joy in discovery,

00:13:43.064 --> 00:13:45.593
the delight and fascination
that we get from the world

00:13:45.617 --> 00:13:47.193
and being ourselves in it;

00:13:47.816 --> 00:13:52.609
the richness that we get from seeing,
feeling and knowing the lives that we are.

00:13:53.485 --> 00:13:54.652
My mom's an artist,

00:13:54.676 --> 00:13:58.534
and as a child, I'd often see her bring
things to life with the stroke of a brush.

00:13:58.558 --> 00:14:01.166
One moment, it was
all white space, pure possibility.

00:14:01.190 --> 00:14:04.686
The next, it was alive
with her colorful ideas and expressions.

00:14:05.415 --> 00:14:10.260
As I sat easel-side, watching her
transform canvas after canvas,

00:14:11.111 --> 00:14:13.676
I learned that you could
create your own world.

00:14:14.791 --> 00:14:16.995
I learned that our own inner worlds --

00:14:17.019 --> 00:14:20.159
our ideas, emotions and imaginations --

00:14:20.183 --> 00:14:22.934
were, in fact, not bound
by our brains and bodies.

00:14:23.466 --> 00:14:26.809
If you could think it,
if you could discover it,

00:14:26.833 --> 00:14:28.546
you could bring it to life.

00:14:29.795 --> 00:14:31.934
To me, thought-controlled computing

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:34.361
is as simple and powerful
as a paintbrush --

00:14:34.385 --> 00:14:37.933
one more tool to unlock and enliven
the hidden worlds within us.

00:14:38.921 --> 00:14:43.190
I look forward to the day
that I can sit beside you, easel-side,

00:14:43.748 --> 00:14:47.863
watching the world that we can create
with our new toolboxes

00:14:47.887 --> 00:14:50.933
and the discoveries
that we can make about ourselves.

00:14:52.450 --> 00:14:53.657
Thank you.

00:14:53.681 --> 00:14:55.481
(Applause)

title: The council of dads
transcript: My story actually began when I was four years old and my family moved to a new neighborhood in our hometown of Savannah, Georgia. And this was the 1960s when actually all the streets in this neighborhood were named after Confederate war generals. We lived on Robert E. Lee Boulevard. And when I was five, my parents gave me an orange Schwinn Sting-Ray bicycle. It had a swooping banana seat and those ape hanger handlebars that made the rider look like an orangutan. That's why they were called ape hangers. They were actually modeled on hotrod motorcycles of the 1960s, which I'm sure my mom didn't know. And one day I was exploring this cul-de-sac hidden away a few streets away. And I came back, and I wanted to turn around and get back to that street more quickly, so I decided to turn around in this big street that intersected our neighborhood, and wham! I was hit by a passing sedan. My mangled body flew in one direction, my mangled bike flew in the other. And I lay on the pavement stretching over that yellow line, and one of my neighbors came running over. "Andy, Andy, how are you doing?" she said, using the name of my older brother. (Laughter) "I'm Bruce," I said, and promptly passed out.I broke my left femur that day — it's the largest bone in your body — and spent the next two months in a body cast that went from my chin to the tip of my toe to my right knee, and a steel bar went from my right knee to my left ankle. And for the next 38 years, that accident was the only medically interesting thing that ever happened to me. In fact, I made a living by walking. I traveled around the world, entered different cultures, wrote a series of books about my travels, including "Walking the Bible." I hosted a television show by that name on PBS. I was, for all the world, the "walking guy." Until, in May 2008, a routine visit to my doctor and a routine blood test produced evidence in the form of an alkaline phosphatase number that something might be wrong with my bones. And my doctor, on a whim, sent me to get a full-body bone scan, which showed that there was some growth in my left leg. That sent me to an X-ray, then to an MRI. And one afternoon, I got a call from my doctor. "The tumor in your leg is not consistent with a benign tumor." I stopped walking, and it took my mind a second to convert that double negative into a much more horrifying negative. I have cancer. And to think that the tumor was in the same bone, in the same place in my body as the accident 38 years earlier — it seemed like too much of a coincidence.So that afternoon, I went back to my house, and my three year-old identical twin daughters, Eden and Tybee Feiler, came running to meet me. They'd just turned three, and they were into all things pink and purple. In fact, we called them Pinkalicious and Purplicious — although I must say, our favorite nickname occurred on their birthday, April 15th. When they were born at 6:14 and 6:46 on April 15, 2005, our otherwise grim, humorless doctor looked at his watch, and was like, "Hmm, April 15th — tax day. Early filer and late filer." (Laughter) The next day I came to see him. I was like, "Doctor, that was a really good joke." And he was like, "You're the writer, kid." Anyway — so they had just turned three, and they came and they were doing this dance they had just made up where they were twirling faster and faster until they tumbled to the ground, laughing with all the glee in the world. I crumbled. I kept imagining all the walks I might not take with them, the art projects I might not mess up, the boyfriends I might not scowl at, the aisles I might not walk down. Would they wonder who I was, I thought. Would they yearn for my approval, my love, my voice?A few days later, I woke with an idea of how I might give them that voice. I would reach out to six men from all parts of my life and ask them to be present in the passages of my daughters' lives. "I believe my girls will have plenty of opportunities in their lives," I wrote these men. "They'll have loving families and welcoming homes, but they may not have me. They may not have their dad. Will you help be their dad?" And I said to myself I would call this group of men "the Council of Dads."Now as soon as I had this idea, I decided I wouldn't tell my wife. Okay. She's a very upbeat, naturally excited person. There's this idea in this culture — I don't have to tell you — that you sort of "happy" your way through a problem. We should focus on the positive. My wife, as I said, she grew up outside of Boston. She's got a big smile. She's got a big personality. She's got big hair — although, she told me recently, I can't say she has big hair, because if I say she has big hair, people will think she's from Texas. And it's apparently okay to marry a boy from Georgia, but not to have hair from Texas. And actually, in her defense, if she were here right now, she would point out that, when we got married in Georgia, there were three questions on the marriage certificate license, the third of which was, "Are you related?" (Laughter) I said, "Look, in Georgia at least we want to know. In Arkansas they don't even ask." What I didn't tell her is, if she said, "Yes," you could jump. You don't need the 30-day waiting period. Because you don't need the get-to-know-you session at that point.So I wasn't going to tell her about this idea, but the next day I couldn't control myself, I told her. And she loved the idea, but she quickly started rejecting my nominees. She was like, "Well, I love him, but I would never ask him for advice." So it turned out that starting a council of dads was a very efficient way to find out what my wife really thought of my friends.(Laughter)So we decided that we needed a set of rules, and we came up with a number. And the first one was no family, only friends. We thought our family would already be there. Second, men only. We were trying to fill the dad-space in the girls' lives. And then third, sort of a dad for every side. We kind of went through my personality and tried to get a dad who represented each different thing. So what happened was I wrote a letter to each of these men. And rather than send it, I decided to read it to them in person. Linda, my wife, joked that it was like having six different marriage proposals. I sort of friend-married each of these guys.And the first of these guys was Jeff Schumlin. Now Jeff led this trip I took to Europe when I graduated from high school in the early 1980s. And on that first day we were in this youth hostel in a castle. And I snuck out behind, and there was a moat, a fence and a field of cows. And Jeff came up beside me and said, "So, have you ever been cow tipping?" I was like, "Cow tipping? He was like, "Yeah. Cows sleep standing up. So if you approach them from behind, down wind, you can push them over and they go thud in the mud." So before I had a chance to determine whether this was right or not, we had jumped the moat, we had climbed the fence, we were tiptoeing through the dung and approaching some poor, dozing cow.So a few weeks after my diagnosis, we went up to Vermont, and I decided to put Jeff as the first person in the Council of Dads. And we went to this apple orchard, and I read him this letter. "Will you help be their dad?" And I got to the end — he was crying and I was crying — and then he looked at me, and he said, "Yes." I was like, "Yes?" I kind of had forgotten there was a question at the heart of my letter. And frankly, although I keep getting asked this, it never occurred to me that anybody would turn me down under the circumstances. And then I asked him a question, which I ended up asking to all the dads and ended up really encouraging me to write this story down in a book. And that was, "What's the one piece of advice you would give to my girls?"And Jeff's advice was, "Be a traveller, not a tourist. Get off the bus. Seek out what's different. Approach the cow." "So it's 10 years from now," I said, "and my daughters are about to take their first trip abroad, and I'm not here. What would you tell them?" He said, "I would approach this journey as a young child might approach a mud puddle. You can bend over and look at your reflection in the mirror and maybe run your finger and make a small ripple, or you can jump in and thrash around and see what it feels like, what it smells like." And as he talked he had that glint in his eye that I first saw back in Holland — the glint that says, "Let's go cow tipping," even though we never did tip the cow, even though no one tips the cow, even though cows don't sleep standing up. He said, "I want to see you back here girls, at the end of this experience, covered in mud."Two weeks after my diagnosis, a biopsy confirmed I had a seven-inch osteosarcoma in my left femur. Six hundred Americans a year get an osteosarcoma. Eighty-five percent are under 21. Only a hundred adults a year get one of these diseases. Twenty years ago, doctors would have cut off my leg and hoped, and there was a 15 percent survival rate. And then in the 1980's, they determined that one particular cocktail of chemo could be effective, and within weeks I had started that regimen. And since we are in a medical room, I went through four and a half months of chemo. Actually I had Cisplatin, Doxorubicin and very high-dose Methotrexate.And then I had a 15-hour surgery in which my surgeon, Dr. John Healey at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York, took out my left femur and replaced it with titanium. And if you did see the Sanjay special, you saw these enormous screws that they screwed into my pelvis. Then he took my fibula from my calf, cut it out and then relocated it to my thigh, where it now lives. And what he actually did was he de-vascularized it from my calf and re-vascularized it in my thigh and then connected it to the good parts of my knee and my hip. And then he took out a third of my quadriceps muscle. This is a surgery so rare only two human beings have survived it before me. And my reward for surviving it was to go back for four more months of chemo. It was, as we said in my house, a lost year.Because in those opening weeks, we all had nightmares. And one night I had a nightmare that I was walking through my house, sat at my desk and saw photographs of someone else's children sitting on my desk. And I remember a particular one night that, when you told that story of — I don't know where you are Dr. Nuland — of William Sloane Coffin — it made me think of it. Because I was in the hospital after, I think it was my fourth round of chemo when my numbers went to zero, and I had basically no immune system. And they put me in an infectious disease ward at the hospital. And anybody who came to see me had to cover themselves in a mask and cover all of the extraneous parts of their body. And one night I got a call from my mother-in-law that my daughters, at that time three and a half, were missing me and feeling my absence. And I hung up the phone, and I put my face in my hands, and I screamed this silent scream. And what you said, Dr. Nuland — I don't know where you are — made me think of this today. Because the thought that came to my mind was that the feeling that I had was like a primal scream.And what was so striking — and one of the messages I want to leave you here with today — is the experience. As I became less and less human — and at this moment in my life, I was probably 30 pounds less than I am right now. Of course, I had no hair and no immune system. They were actually putting blood inside my body. At that moment I was less and less human, I was also, at the same time, maybe the most human I've ever been. And what was so striking about that time was, instead of repulsing people, I was actually proving to be a magnet for people. People were incredibly drawn. When my wife and I had kids, we thought it would be all-hands-on-deck. Instead, it was everybody running the other way. And when I had cancer, we thought it'd be everybody running the other way. Instead, it was all-hands-on-deck. And when people came to me, rather than being incredibly turned off by what they saw — I was like a living ghost — they were incredibly moved to talk about what was going on in their own lives.Cancer, I found, is a passport to intimacy. It is an invitation, maybe even a mandate, to enter the most vital arenas of human life, the most sensitive and the most frightening, the ones that we never want to go to, but when we do go there, we feel incredibly transformed when we do. And this also happened to my girls as they began to see, and, we thought, maybe became an ounce more compassionate. One day, my daughter Tybee, Tybee came to me, and she said, "I have so much love for you in my body, daddy, I can't stop giving you hugs and kisses. And when I have no more love left, I just drink milk, because that's where love comes from." (Laughter) And one night my daughter Eden came to me. And as I lifted my leg out of bed, she reached for my crutches and handed them to me. In fact, if I cling to one memory of this year, it would be walking down a darkened hallway with five spongy fingers grasping the handle underneath my hand. I didn't need the crutch anymore, I was walking on air.And one of the profound things that happened was this act of actually connecting to all these people. And it made me think — and I'll just note for the record — one word that I've only heard once actually was when we were all doing Tony Robbins yoga yesterday — the one word that has not been mentioned in this seminar actually is the word "friend." And yet from everything we've been talking about — compliance, or addiction, or weight loss — we now know that community is important, and yet it's one thing we don't actually bring in. And there was something incredibly profound about sitting down with my closest friends and telling them what they meant to me. And one of the things that I learned is that over time, particularly men, who used to be non-communicative, are becoming more and more communicative. And that particularly happened — there was one in my life — is this Council of Dads that Linda said, what we were talking about, it's like what the moms talk about at school drop-off.And no one captures this modern manhood to me more than David Black. Now David is my literary agent. He's about five-foot three and a half on a good day, standing fully upright in cowboy boots. And on kind of the manly-male front, he answers the phone — I can say this I guess because you've done it here — he answers the phone, "Yo, motherfucker." He gives boring speeches about obscure bottles of wine, and on his 50th birthday he bought a convertible sports car — although, like a lot of men, he's impatient; he bought it on his 49th. But like a lot of modern men, he hugs, he bakes, he leaves work early to coach Little League. Someone asked me if he cried when I asked him to be in the council of dads. I was like, "David cries when you invite him to take a walk." (Laughter) But he's a literary agent, which means he's a broker of dreams in a world where most dreams don't come true. And this is what we wanted him to capture — what it means to have setbacks and then aspirations. And I said, "What's the most valuable thing you can give to a dreamer?" And he said, "A belief in themselves." "But when I came to see you," I said, "I didn't believe in myself. I was at a wall." He said, "I don't see the wall," and I'm telling you the same, Don't see the wall. You may encounter one from time to time, but you've got to find a way to get over it, around it, or through it. But whatever you do, don't succumb to it. Don't give in to the wall.My home is not far from the Brooklyn Bridge, and during the year and a half I was on crutches, it became a sort of symbol to me. So one day near the end of my journey, I said, "Come on girls, let's take a walk across the Brooklyn Bridge." We set out on crutches. I was on crutches, my wife was next to me, my girls were doing these rockstar poses up ahead. And because walking was one of the first things I lost, I spent most of that year thinking about this most elemental of human acts. Walking upright, we are told, is the threshold of what made us human. And yet, for the four million years humans have been walking upright, the act is essentially unchanged. As my physical therapist likes to say, "Every step is a tragedy waiting to happen." You nearly fall with one leg, then you catch yourself with the other. And the biggest consequence of walking on crutches — as I did for a year and a half — is that you walk slower. You hurry, you get where you're going, but you get there alone. You go slow, you get where you're going, but you get there with this community you built along the way.At the risk of admission, I was never nicer than the year I was on crutches. 200 years ago, a new type of pedestrian appeared in Paris. He was called a "flaneur," one who wanders the arcades. And it was the custom of those flaneurs to show they were men of leisure by taking turtles for walks and letting the reptile set the pace. And I just love this ode to slow moving. And it's become my own motto for my girls. Take a walk with a turtle. Behold the world in pause. And this idea of pausing may be the single biggest lesson I took from my journey.There's a quote from Moses on the side of the Liberty Bell, and it comes from a passage in the book of Leviticus, that every seven years you should let the land lay fallow. And every seven sets of seven years, the land gets an extra year of rest during which time all families are reunited and people surrounded with the ones they love. That 50th year is called the jubilee year, and it's the origin of that term. And though I'm shy of 50, it captures my own experience. My lost year was my jubilee year. By laying fallow, I planted the seeds for a healthier future and was reunited with the ones I love.Come the one year anniversary of my journey, I went to see my surgeon, Dr. John Healey — and by the way, Healey, great name for a doctor. He's the president of the International Society of Limb Salvage, which is the least euphemistic term I've ever heard. And I said, "Dr. Healey, if my daughters come to you one day and say, 'What should I learn from my daddy's story?' what would you tell them?" He said, "I would tell them what I know, and that is everybody dies, but not everybody lives. I want you to live."I wrote a letter to my girls that appears at the end of my book, "The Council of Dads," and I listed these lessons, a few of which you've heard here today: Approach the cow, pack your flipflops, don't see the wall, live the questions, harvest miracles. As I looked at this list — to me it was sort of like a psalm book of living — I realized, we may have done it for our girls, but it really changed us. And that is, the secret of the Council of Dads, is that my wife and I did this in an attempt to help our daughters, but it really changed us.So I stand here today as you see now, walking without crutches or a cane. And last week I had my 18-month scans. And as you all know, anybody with cancer has to get follow-up scans. In my case it's quarterly. And all the collective minds in this room, I dare say, can never find a solution for scan-xiety. As I was going there, I was wondering, what would I say depending on what happened here. I got good news that day, and I stand here today cancer-free, walking without aid and hobbling forward.And I just want to mention briefly in passing — I'm past my time limit — but I just want to briefly mention in passing that one of the nice things that can come out of a conference like this is, at a similar meeting, back in the spring, Anne Wojcicki heard about our story and very quickly — in a span of three weeks — put the full resources of 23andMe, and we announced an initiative in July to get to decode the genome of anybody, a living person with a heart tissue, bone sarcoma. And she told me last night, in the three months since we've done it, we've gotten 300 people who've contributed to this program. And the epidemiologists here will tell you, that's half the number of people who get the disease in one year in the United States. So if you go to 23andMe, or if you go to councilofdads.com, you can click on a link. And we encourage anybody to join this effort.But I'll just close what I've been talking about by leaving you with this message: May you find an excuse to reach out to some long-lost pal, or to that college roommate, or to some person you may have turned away from. May you find a mud puddle to jump in someplace, or find a way to get over, around, or through any wall that stands between you and one of your dreams. And every now and then, find a friend, find a turtle, and take a long, slow walk.Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
My story actually began when I was four years old

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
and my family moved to a new neighborhood

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
in our hometown of Savannah, Georgia.

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
And this was the 1960s

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:22.958
when actually all the streets in this neighborhood

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
were named after Confederate war generals.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:27.958
We lived on Robert E. Lee Boulevard.

00:00:27.958 --> 00:00:29.958
And when I was five,

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:32.958
my parents gave me an orange Schwinn Sting-Ray bicycle.

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:35.958
It had a swooping banana seat and those ape hanger handlebars

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
that made the rider look like an orangutan.

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
That's why they were called ape hangers.

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:43.958
They were actually modeled on hotrod motorcycles of the 1960s,

00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:45.958
which I'm sure my mom didn't know.

00:00:45.958 --> 00:00:48.958
And one day I was exploring this cul-de-sac

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
hidden away a few streets away.

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
And I came back,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
and I wanted to turn around and get back to that street more quickly,

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:57.958
so I decided to turn around in this big street

00:00:57.958 --> 00:00:59.958
that intersected our neighborhood,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:02.958
and wham! I was hit by a passing sedan.

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:04.958
My mangled body flew in one direction,

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:07.958
my mangled bike flew in the other.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
And I lay on the pavement stretching over that yellow line,

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
and one of my neighbors came running over.

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:15.958
"Andy, Andy, how are you doing?" she said, using the name of my older brother.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:17.958
(Laughter)

00:01:17.958 --> 00:01:20.958
"I'm Bruce," I said, and promptly passed out.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
I broke my left femur that day --

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
it's the largest bone in your body --

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
and spent the next two months in a body cast

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
that went from my chin to the tip of my toe

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
to my right knee,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:33.958
and a steel bar went from my right knee

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
to my left ankle.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
And for the next 38 years,

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
that accident was the only medically interesting thing

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
that ever happened to me.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
In fact, I made a living by walking.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
I traveled around the world, entered different cultures,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
wrote a series of books about my travels,

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:50.958
including "Walking the Bible."

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
I hosted a television show by that name

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
on PBS.

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:57.958
I was, for all the world, the "walking guy."

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
Until, in May 2008,

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
a routine visit to my doctor

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
and a routine blood test

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:07.958
produced evidence in the form of an alkaline phosphatase number

00:02:07.958 --> 00:02:10.958
that something might be wrong with my bones.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
And my doctor, on a whim, sent me to get a full-body bone scan,

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:17.958
which showed that there was some growth in my left leg.

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
That sent me to an X-ray, then to an MRI.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:23.958
And one afternoon, I got a call from my doctor.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:26.958
"The tumor in your leg

00:02:26.958 --> 00:02:28.958
is not consistent with a benign tumor."

00:02:28.958 --> 00:02:30.958
I stopped walking,

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:33.958
and it took my mind a second to convert that double negative

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
into a much more horrifying negative.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
I have cancer.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
And to think that the tumor was in the same bone,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
in the same place in my body

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:45.958
as the accident 38 years earlier --

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
it seemed like too much of a coincidence.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
So that afternoon, I went back to my house,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
and my three year-old identical twin daughters, Eden and Tybee Feiler,

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:55.958
came running to meet me.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:57.958
They'd just turned three,

00:02:57.958 --> 00:02:59.958
and they were into all things pink and purple.

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:02.958
In fact, we called them Pinkalicious and Purplicious --

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
although I must say, our favorite nickname

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
occurred on their birthday, April 15th.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
When they were born at 6:14 and 6:46

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:12.958
on April 15, 2005,

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
our otherwise grim, humorless doctor looked at his watch,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.958
and was like, "Hmm, April 15th -- tax day.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.958
Early filer and late filer."

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:24.958
(Laughter)

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:28.958
The next day I came to see him. I was like, "Doctor, that was a really good joke."

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
And he was like, "You're the writer, kid."

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
Anyway -- so they had just turned three,

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
and they came and they were doing this dance they had just made up

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
where they were twirling faster and faster until they tumbled to the ground,

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
laughing with all the glee in the world.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
I crumbled.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:45.958
I kept imagining all the walks I might not take with them,

00:03:45.958 --> 00:03:47.958
the art projects I might not mess up,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
the boyfriends I might not scowl at,

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:52.958
the aisles I might not walk down.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
Would they wonder who I was, I thought.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
Would they yearn for my approval,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
my love, my voice?

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
A few days later, I woke with an idea

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
of how I might give them that voice.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
I would reach out to six men

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
from all parts of my life

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
and ask them to be present

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
in the passages of my daughters' lives.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
"I believe my girls will have plenty of opportunities in their lives,"

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
I wrote these men.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:18.958
"They'll have loving families and welcoming homes,

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:20.958
but they may not have me.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:22.958
They may not have their dad.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
Will you help be their dad?"

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
And I said to myself

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
I would call this group of men "the Council of Dads."

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:32.958
Now as soon as I had this idea,

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:35.958
I decided I wouldn't tell my wife. Okay.

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:37.958
She's a very upbeat,

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
naturally excited person.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
There's this idea in this culture -- I don't have to tell you --

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
that you sort of "happy" your way through a problem.

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
We should focus on the positive.

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
My wife, as I said, she grew up outside of Boston.

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
She's got a big smile. She's got a big personality.

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
She's got big hair --

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
although, she told me recently, I can't say she has big hair,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
because if I say she has big hair,

00:04:57.958 --> 00:04:59.958
people will think she's from Texas.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
And it's apparently okay to marry a boy from Georgia,

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:04.958
but not to have hair from Texas.

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:06.958
And actually, in her defense, if she were here right now,

00:05:06.958 --> 00:05:09.958
she would point out that, when we got married in Georgia,

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:11.958
there were three questions

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:13.958
on the marriage certificate license,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
the third of which was, "Are you related?"

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
(Laughter)

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
I said, "Look, in Georgia at least we want to know.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
In Arkansas they don't even ask."

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:26.958
What I didn't tell her is, if she said, "Yes," you could jump.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
You don't need the 30-day waiting period.

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:31.958
Because you don't need the get-to-know-you session at that point.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
So I wasn't going to tell her about this idea,

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
but the next day I couldn't control myself, I told her.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
And she loved the idea,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
but she quickly started rejecting my nominees.

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
She was like, "Well, I love him, but I would never ask him for advice."

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
So it turned out that starting a council of dads

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
was a very efficient way to find out

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
what my wife really thought of my friends.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
(Laughter)

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
So we decided that we needed a set of rules,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
and we came up with a number.

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:58.958
And the first one was no family, only friends.

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
We thought our family would already be there.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
Second, men only.

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
We were trying to fill the dad-space in the girls' lives.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:07.958
And then third, sort of a dad for every side.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.958
We kind of went through my personality

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.958
and tried to get a dad who represented each different thing.

00:06:11.958 --> 00:06:13.958
So what happened was I wrote a letter to each of these men.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And rather than send it,

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
I decided to read it to them in person.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
Linda, my wife, joked that it was like having six different marriage proposals.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:24.958
I sort of friend-married each of these guys.

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:26.958
And the first of these guys was Jeff Schumlin.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
Now Jeff led this trip I took to Europe

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
when I graduated from high school in the early 1980s.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
And on that first day we were in this youth hostel in a castle.

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
And I snuck out behind,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
and there was a moat, a fence and a field of cows.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
And Jeff came up beside me and said,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
"So, have you ever been cow tipping?"

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
I was like, "Cow tipping?

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
He was like, "Yeah. Cows sleep standing up.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
So if you approach them from behind, down wind,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
you can push them over and they go thud in the mud."

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
So before I had a chance to determine whether this was right or not,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
we had jumped the moat, we had climbed the fence,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
we were tiptoeing through the dung

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:02.958
and approaching some poor, dozing cow.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
So a few weeks after my diagnosis,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
we went up to Vermont,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
and I decided to put Jeff as the first person in the Council of Dads.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:13.958
And we went to this apple orchard, and I read him this letter.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
"Will you help be their dad?"

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
And I got to the end -- he was crying and I was crying --

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
and then he looked at me, and he said, "Yes."

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
I was like, "Yes?"

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
I kind of had forgotten there was a question at the heart of my letter.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
And frankly, although I keep getting asked this,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
it never occurred to me that anybody would turn me down

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:30.958
under the circumstances.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
And then I asked him a question, which I ended up asking to all the dads

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
and ended up really encouraging me to write this story down in a book.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
And that was, "What's the one piece of advice

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
you would give to my girls?"

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
And Jeff's advice was,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
"Be a traveller, not a tourist.

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.958
Get off the bus. Seek out what's different.

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:49.958
Approach the cow."

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
"So it's 10 years from now," I said,

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
"and my daughters are about to take their first trip abroad, and I'm not here.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
What would you tell them?"

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
He said, "I would approach this journey

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
as a young child might approach a mud puddle.

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
You can bend over and look at your reflection in the mirror

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.958
and maybe run your finger and make a small ripple,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
or you can jump in and thrash around

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:11.958
and see what it feels like, what it smells like."

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:13.958
And as he talked he had that glint in his eye

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:15.958
that I first saw back in Holland --

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
the glint that says, "Let's go cow tipping,"

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
even though we never did tip the cow,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
even though no one tips the cow,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
even though cows don't sleep standing up.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:29.958
He said, "I want to see you back here girls, at the end of this experience,

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
covered in mud."

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
Two weeks after my diagnosis, a biopsy confirmed

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
I had a seven-inch osteosarcoma

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
in my left femur.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
Six hundred Americans a year get an osteosarcoma.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
Eighty-five percent are under 21.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
Only a hundred adults a year

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
get one of these diseases.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
Twenty years ago, doctors would have cut off my leg and hoped,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
and there was a 15 percent survival rate.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
And then in the 1980's, they determined

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
that one particular cocktail of chemo could be effective,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
and within weeks I had started that regimen.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
And since we are in a medical room,

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
I went through four and a half months of chemo.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
Actually I had Cisplatin, Doxorubicin

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
and very high-dose Methotrexate.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
And then I had a 15-hour surgery

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
in which my surgeon, Dr. John Healey

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
took out my left femur

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
and replaced it with titanium.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
And if you did see the Sanjay special,

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
you saw these enormous screws

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
that they screwed into my pelvis.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
Then he took my fibula from my calf,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
cut it out and then relocated it to my thigh,

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
where it now lives.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And what he actually did was he de-vascularized it from my calf

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
and re-vascularized it in my thigh

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
and then connected it

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
to the good parts of my knee and my hip.

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.958
And then he took out a third of my quadriceps muscle.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
This is a surgery so rare

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
only two human beings have survived it before me.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And my reward for surviving it

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
was to go back for four more months of chemo.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
It was, as we said in my house,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
a lost year.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
Because in those opening weeks, we all had nightmares.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
And one night I had a nightmare that I was walking through my house,

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
sat at my desk and saw photographs of someone else's children

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
sitting on my desk.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
And I remember a particular one night that, when you told that story of --

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
I don't know where you are Dr. Nuland --

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
of William Sloane Coffin --

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
it made me think of it.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:26.958
Because I was in the hospital after, I think it was my fourth round of chemo

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:29.958
when my numbers went to zero, and I had basically no immune system.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
And they put me in an infectious disease ward at the hospital.

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:35.958
And anybody who came to see me had to cover themselves in a mask

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
and cover all of the extraneous parts of their body.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
And one night I got a call from my mother-in-law

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
that my daughters, at that time three and a half,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
were missing me and feeling my absence.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:48.958
And I hung up the phone,

00:10:48.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and I put my face in my hands,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:54.958
and I screamed this silent scream.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
And what you said, Dr. Nuland -- I don't know where you are --

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
made me think of this today.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
Because the thought that came to my mind

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
was that the feeling that I had

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
was like a primal scream.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
And what was so striking --

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
and one of the messages I want to leave you here with today --

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
is the experience.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
As I became less and less human --

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
and at this moment in my life, I was probably 30 pounds less than I am right now.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
Of course, I had no hair and no immune system.

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
They were actually putting blood inside my body.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
At that moment I was less and less human,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
I was also, at the same time,

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
maybe the most human I've ever been.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:33.958
And what was so striking about that time

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
was, instead of repulsing people,

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
I was actually proving to be a magnet for people.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
People were incredibly drawn.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
When my wife and I had kids, we thought it would be all-hands-on-deck.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Instead, it was everybody running the other way.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:47.958
And when I had cancer, we thought it'd be everybody running the other way.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:49.958
Instead, it was all-hands-on-deck.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
And when people came to me,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:53.958
rather than being incredibly turned off by what they saw --

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:55.958
I was like a living ghost --

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:57.958
they were incredibly moved

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.958
to talk about what was going on in their own lives.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
Cancer, I found, is a passport to intimacy.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
It is an invitation, maybe even a mandate,

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:08.958
to enter the most vital arenas of human life,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
the most sensitive and the most frightening,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
the ones that we never want to go to,

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
but when we do go there,

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
we feel incredibly transformed when we do.

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
And this also happened to my girls as they began to see,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
and, we thought, maybe became an ounce more compassionate.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
One day, my daughter Tybee,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
Tybee came to me, and she said, "I have so much love for you in my body, daddy,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
I can't stop giving you hugs and kisses.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
And when I have no more love left, I just drink milk,

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
because that's where love comes from."

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
(Laughter)

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
And one night my daughter Eden came to me.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:41.958
And as I lifted my leg out of bed,

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
she reached for my crutches and handed them to me.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
In fact, if I cling to one memory of this year,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:48.958
it would be walking down a darkened hallway

00:12:48.958 --> 00:12:50.958
with five spongy fingers

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
grasping the handle underneath my hand.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
I didn't need the crutch anymore,

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
I was walking on air.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And one of the profound things that happened

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
was this act of actually connecting to all these people.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
And it made me think -- and I'll just note for the record --

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
one word that I've only heard once actually

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
was when we were all doing Tony Robbins yoga yesterday --

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
the one word that has not been mentioned in this seminar actually

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
is the word "friend."

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
And yet from everything we've been talking about --

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
compliance, or addiction, or weight loss --

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
we now know that community is important,

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
and yet it's one thing we don't actually bring in.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
And there was something incredibly profound

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
about sitting down with my closest friends

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
and telling them what they meant to me.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
And one of the things that I learned is that over time,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:33.958
particularly men, who used to be non-communicative,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
are becoming more and more communicative.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
And that particularly happened -- there was one in my life --

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
is this Council of Dads

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
that Linda said, what we were talking about,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
it's like what the moms talk about at school drop-off.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
And no one captures this modern manhood to me

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
more than David Black.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Now David is my literary agent.

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
He's about five-foot three and a half on a good day,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
standing fully upright in cowboy boots.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And on kind of the manly-male front, he answers the phone --

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
I can say this I guess because you've done it here --

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
he answers the phone, "Yo, motherfucker."

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:05.958
He gives boring speeches about obscure bottles of wine,

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:08.958
and on his 50th birthday he bought a convertible sports car --

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
although, like a lot of men, he's impatient; he bought it on his 49th.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
But like a lot of modern men, he hugs, he bakes,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
he leaves work early to coach Little League.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
Someone asked me if he cried when I asked him to be in the council of dads.

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
I was like, "David cries when you invite him to take a walk."

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
(Laughter)

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:25.958
But he's a literary agent,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
which means he's a broker of dreams in a world where most dreams don't come true.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
And this is what we wanted him to capture --

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
what it means to have setbacks and then aspirations.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
And I said, "What's the most valuable thing you can give to a dreamer?"

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:39.958
And he said, "A belief in themselves."

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
"But when I came to see you," I said, "I didn't believe in myself.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
I was at a wall."

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
He said, "I don't see the wall," and I'm telling you the same,

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
Don't see the wall.

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:49.958
You may encounter one from time to time,

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
but you've got to find a way to get over it, around it, or through it.

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
But whatever you do, don't succumb to it.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
Don't give in to the wall.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
My home is not far from the Brooklyn Bridge,

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
and during the year and a half I was on crutches,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
it became a sort of symbol to me.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
So one day near the end of my journey,

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:10.958
I said, "Come on girls, let's take a walk across the Brooklyn Bridge."

00:15:10.958 --> 00:15:12.958
We set out on crutches.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
I was on crutches, my wife was next to me,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:17.958
my girls were doing these rockstar poses up ahead.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:20.958
And because walking was one of the first things I lost,

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:22.958
I spent most of that year

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:24.958
thinking about this most elemental of human acts.

00:15:24.958 --> 00:15:26.958
Walking upright, we are told,

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:29.958
is the threshold of what made us human.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
And yet, for the four million years humans have been walking upright,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
the act is essentially unchanged.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
As my physical therapist likes to say,

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
"Every step is a tragedy waiting to happen."

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
You nearly fall with one leg,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:44.958
then you catch yourself with the other.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
And the biggest consequence of walking on crutches --

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
as I did for a year and a half --

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
is that you walk slower.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
You hurry,

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
you get where you're going, but you get there alone.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:57.958
You go slow, you get where you're going,

00:15:57.958 --> 00:15:59.958
but you get there with this community

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:01.958
you built along the way.

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:03.958
At the risk of admission, I was never nicer

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:05.958
than the year I was on crutches.

00:16:05.958 --> 00:16:07.958
200 years ago,

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:10.958
a new type of pedestrian appeared in Paris.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:13.958
He was called a "flaneur," one who wanders the arcades.

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
And it was the custom of those flaneurs

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
to show they were men of leisure

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
by taking turtles for walks

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
and letting the reptile set the pace.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
And I just love this ode to slow moving.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
And it's become my own motto for my girls.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
Take a walk with a turtle.

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
Behold the world in pause.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
And this idea of pausing

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
may be the single biggest lesson I took from my journey.

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
There's a quote from Moses

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
on the side of the Liberty Bell,

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
and it comes from a passage in the book of Leviticus,

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:48.958
that every seven years you should let the land lay fallow.

00:16:48.958 --> 00:16:50.958
And every seven sets of seven years,

00:16:50.958 --> 00:16:53.958
the land gets an extra year of rest

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
during which time all families are reunited

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
and people surrounded with the ones they love.

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
That 50th year is called the jubilee year,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
and it's the origin of that term.

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
And though I'm shy of 50,

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
it captures my own experience.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:10.958
My lost year was my jubilee year.

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:12.958
By laying fallow,

00:17:12.958 --> 00:17:14.958
I planted the seeds for a healthier future

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
and was reunited with the ones I love.

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:19.958
Come the one year anniversary of my journey,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
I went to see my surgeon, Dr. John Healey --

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
and by the way, Healey, great name for a doctor.

00:17:25.958 --> 00:17:28.958
He's the president of the International Society of Limb Salvage,

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:31.958
which is the least euphemistic term I've ever heard.

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:34.958
And I said, "Dr. Healey, if my daughters come to you one day

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
and say, 'What should I learn from my daddy's story?'

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:38.958
what would you tell them?"

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:40.958
He said, "I would tell them what I know,

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:44.958
and that is everybody dies,

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:47.958
but not everybody lives.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
I want you to live."

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
I wrote a letter to my girls

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
that appears at the end of my book, "The Council of Dads,"

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
and I listed these lessons,

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
a few of which you've heard here today:

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
Approach the cow, pack your flipflops,

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
don't see the wall,

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.958
live the questions,

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:05.958
harvest miracles.

00:18:05.958 --> 00:18:08.958
As I looked at this list -- to me it was sort of like a psalm book of living --

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:11.958
I realized, we may have done it for our girls,

00:18:11.958 --> 00:18:13.958
but it really changed us.

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:15.958
And that is, the secret of the Council of Dads,

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
is that my wife and I did this

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:20.958
in an attempt to help our daughters,

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
but it really changed us.

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
So I stand here today

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:28.958
as you see now, walking without crutches or a cane.

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
And last week I had my 18-month scans.

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
And as you all know,

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:34.958
anybody with cancer has to get follow-up scans.

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:36.958
In my case it's quarterly.

00:18:36.958 --> 00:18:38.958
And all the collective minds in this room, I dare say,

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:41.958
can never find a solution for scan-xiety.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
As I was going there, I was wondering, what would I say

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
depending on what happened here.

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:49.958
I got good news that day,

00:18:49.958 --> 00:18:51.958
and I stand here today cancer-free,

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:53.958
walking without aid

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
and hobbling forward.

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:59.958
And I just want to mention briefly in passing -- I'm past my time limit --

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
but I just want to briefly mention in passing

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:03.958
that one of the nice things that can come out of a conference like this

00:19:03.958 --> 00:19:05.958
is, at a similar meeting,

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
back in the spring,

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
Anne Wojcicki heard about our story

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:11.958
and very quickly -- in a span of three weeks --

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:13.958
put the full resources of 23andMe,

00:19:13.958 --> 00:19:16.958
and we announced an initiative in July

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:18.958
to get to decode the genome

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:21.958
of anybody, a living person

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
with a heart tissue, bone sarcoma.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:27.958
And she told me last night, in the three months since we've done it,

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:30.958
we've gotten 300 people who've contributed to this program.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:32.958
And the epidemiologists here will tell you,

00:19:32.958 --> 00:19:34.958
that's half the number of people who get the disease

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:36.958
in one year in the United States.

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:38.958
So if you go to 23andMe,

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:41.958
or if you go to councilofdads.com, you can click on a link.

00:19:41.958 --> 00:19:44.958
And we encourage anybody to join this effort.

00:19:44.958 --> 00:19:47.958
But I'll just close what I've been talking about

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:49.958
by leaving you with this message:

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:51.958
May you find an excuse to reach out to some long-lost pal,

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:53.958
or to that college roommate,

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:55.958
or to some person you may have turned away from.

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:58.958
May you find a mud puddle to jump in someplace,

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:00.958
or find a way to get over, around, or through any wall

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:03.958
that stands between you and one of your dreams.

00:20:03.958 --> 00:20:05.958
And every now and then,

00:20:05.958 --> 00:20:07.958
find a friend, find a turtle,

00:20:07.958 --> 00:20:10.958
and take a long, slow walk.

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.958
Thank you very much.

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:23.958
(Applause)

title: Reviving New York's rivers -- with oysters!
transcript: I am passionate about the American landscape and how the physical form of the land, from the great Central Valley of California to the bedrock of Manhattan, has really shaped our history and our character. But one thing is clear. In the last 100 years alone, our country — and this is a sprawl map of America — our country has systematically flattened and homogenized the landscape to the point where we've forgotten our relationship with the plants and animals that live alongside us and the dirt beneath our feet. And so, how I see my work contributing is sort of trying to literally re-imagine these connections and physically rebuild them. This graph represents what we're dealing with now in the built environment. And it's really a conflux of urban population rising, biodiversity plummeting and also, of course, sea levels rising and climate changing.So when I also think about design, I think about trying to rework and re-engage the lines on this graph in a more productive way. And you can see from the arrow here indicating "you are here," I'm trying to sort of blend and meld these two very divergent fields of urbanism and ecology, and sort of bring them together in an exciting new way. So the era of big infrastructure is over. I mean, these sort of top-down, mono-functional, capital-intensive solutions are really not going to cut it. We need new tools and new approaches. Similarly, the idea of architecture as this sort of object in the field, devoid of context, is really not the — excuse me, it's fairly blatant — is really not the approach that we need to take. So we need new stories, new heroes and new tools.So now I want to introduce you to my new hero in the global climate change war, and that is the eastern oyster. So, albeit a very small creature and very modest, this creature is incredible, because it can agglomerate into these mega-reef structures. Now that could be a dog door, it could be someone going somewhere where they shouldn't, like a little brother into a little sister's room. There's all kinds of different things that you can imagine for that.Now here's something — a 3D printer. That's another tool that's really taken off — really, really interesting. This is Makerbot. And there are industrial versions of this — about 20,000 dollars. These guys came up with a kit version for 750 dollars, and that means that hobbyists and ordinary folks can get a hold of this and begin playing with 3D printers. Now they don't know what they want to do with it, but they're going to figure it out. They will only figure it out by getting their hands on it and playing with it. You could build your own satellite and get it into space for like 8,000 dollars. Think how much money and how many years it took NASA to get satellites into space. In fact, these guys actually work for NASA, and they're trying to pioneer using off-the-shelf components, cheap things that aren't specialized that they can combine and send up into space.Makers are a source of innovation, and I think it relates back to something like the birth of the personal computer industry. This is Steve Wozniak. Where does he learn about computers? It's the Homebrew Computer Club — just like a hackerspace. And he says, "I could go there all day long and talk to people and share ideas for free." Well he did a little bit better than free. And we've got to get this into schools, or into communities in many, many ways — the ability to tinker, to shape and reshape the world around us. There's a great opportunity today — and that's what I really care about the most. An the answer to the question: what will America make? It's more makers.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:21.958

an alert message goes to your iPhone.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
There's all kinds of different things

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
that you can imagine for that.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
some new brackets for the box.

Well you printed out the brackets

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
and then replaced the old brackets with the new ones.

Isn't that cool?

So makers harvest technology

from all the places around us.

This is a radar speed detector

that was developed from a Hot Wheels toy.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
And they do interesting things.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
They're really creating new areas and exploring areas

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
that you might only think --

the military is doing drones --

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
well, there is a whole community of people

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:47.958
building autonomous airplanes, or vehicles --

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
something that you could program to fly on its own,

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
without a stick or anything, to figure out what path it's going.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
Fascinating work they're doing.

We just had an issue on space exploration,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
DIY space exploration.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
This is probably the best time in the history of mankind

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
to love space.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:07.958
You could build your own satellite and get it into space

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
for like 8,000 dollars.

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
Think how much money and how many years it took NASA

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:15.958
to get satellites into space.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
In fact, these guys actually work for NASA,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
and they're trying to pioneer using off-the-shelf components,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
cheap things that aren't specialized

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
that they can combine

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
and send up into space.

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:28.958
Makers are a source of innovation,

and I think it relates back to something

like the birth of the personal computer industry.

It's the Homebrew Computer Club -- just like a hackerspace.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
and talk to people

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and share ideas for free."

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
Well he did a little bit better than free.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
But it's important to understand

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
that a lot of the origins of our industries --

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
even like Henry Ford --

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
come from this idea of playing

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:58.958
and figuring things out in groups.

00:10:58.958 --> 00:11:00.958
Well, if I haven't convinced you that you're a maker,

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.958
I hope I could convince you

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
that our next generation should be makers,

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
that kids are particularly interested in this,

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
in this ability to control the physical world

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
and be able to use things like micro-controllers

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
and build robots.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
And we've got to get this into schools,

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
or into communities in many, many ways --

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.958
the ability to tinker,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
to shape and reshape the world around us.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
There's a great opportunity today --

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
and that's what I really care about the most.

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
An the answer to the question: what will America make?

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
It's more makers.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
Thank you very much.
