00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
But other adults

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
say incredibly painful things.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
They say, "How dare you take this child out of the house

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
and terrify other people.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
Shouldn't you be doing something about this? Why haven't you had it removed?"

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
And other children in curiosity come up and poke the lesion,

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
because -- a natural curiosity.

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
And that obviously alerts the child

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
to their unusual nature.

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
After surgery, everything normalizes.

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
The adults behave more naturally,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:04.958
and the children play more readily with other children.

00:04:04.958 --> 00:04:07.958
As teenagers --

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
just think back to your teenage years --

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
we're going through a dramatic

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:13.958
and often disproportionate change

00:04:13.958 --> 00:04:15.958
in our facial appearance.

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
We're trying to struggle to find our identity.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
We crave the approval of our peers.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
So our facial appearance is vital to us

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:24.958
as we're trying to project ourselves to the world.

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
Just remember that single acne spot

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
that crippled you for several days.

00:04:30.958 --> 00:04:33.958
How long did you spend looking in the mirror every day,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:36.958
practicing your sardonic look, practicing your serious look,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
trying to look like Sean Connery, as I did,

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
trying to raise one eyebrow?

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
It's a crippling time.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:46.958
I've chosen to show this profile view of Sue

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:49.958
because what it shows is her lower jaw jutting forward

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:51.958
and her lower lip jutting forward.

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
I'd like you all in the audience now to push your lower jaw forward.

00:04:54.958 --> 00:04:56.958
Turn to the person next to you,

00:04:56.958 --> 00:04:58.958
push your lower jaws forward. Turn to the person next to you

00:04:58.958 --> 00:05:00.958
and look at them -- they look miserable.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
That's exactly what people used to say to Sue.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
She wasn't miserable at all.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
But people used to say to her, "Why are you so miserable?"

00:05:09.958 --> 00:05:12.958
People were making misjudgments all the time

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
on her mood.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:17.958
Teachers and peers were underestimating her; she was teased at school.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
So she chose to have facial surgery.

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
After the facial surgery,

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:24.958
she said, "My face now reflects my personality.

00:05:24.958 --> 00:05:27.958
People know now that I'm enthusiastic,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
that I'm a happy person."

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:33.958
And that's the change that can be achieved for teenagers.

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
Is this change, though, a real change,

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:38.958
or is it a figment of the imagination

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:40.958
of the patient themselves?

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
Well we studied teenagers' attitudes

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
to photographs of patients having this corrective facial surgery.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
And what we found was --

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
we jumbled up the photographs

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
so they couldn't recognize the before and after --

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
what we found was that the patients were regarded

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
as being more attractive after the surgery.

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:58.958
Well that's not surprising, but we also asked them to judge them

00:05:58.958 --> 00:06:00.958
on honesty, intelligence,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
friendliness, violence.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
They were all perceived as being

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
less than normal in all those characteristics --

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
more violent, etc. -- before the surgery.

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
After the surgery,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
they were perceived as being more intelligent,

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
more friendly, more honest, less violent --

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
and yet we hadn't operated on their intellect

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
or their character.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
When people get older,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
they don't necessarily choose to follow this kind of surgery.

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
Their presence in the consultation suite

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
is a result of the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
What happens to them

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
is that they may have suffered cancer or trauma.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
So this is a photograph of Henry,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
two weeks after he had a malignant cancer removed

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
from the left side of his face -- his cheekbone,

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
his upper jaw, his eye-socket.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:47.958
He looks pretty good at this stage.

00:06:47.958 --> 00:06:50.958
But over the course of the next 15 years he had 14 more operations,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
as the disease ravaged his face

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
and destroyed my reconstruction regularly.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:56.958
I learned a huge amount from Henry.

00:06:56.958 --> 00:06:58.958
Henry taught me

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
that you can carry on working.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
He worked as an advocate. He continued to play cricket.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
He enjoyed life to the full,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
and this was probably because he had a successful, fulfilling job

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
and a caring family

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
and was able to participate socially.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
He maintained a calm insouciance.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:17.958
I don't say he overcame this; he didn't overcome it.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
This was something more than that. He ignored it.

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
He ignored the disfigurement that was happening in his life

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:26.958
and carried on oblivious to it.

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:28.958
And that's what these people can do.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
Henriapi illustrates this phenomenon as well.

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:32.958
This is a man in his 20s

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:35.958
whose first visit out of Nigeria was with this malignant cancer

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
that he came to the United Kingdom to have operated on.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
It was my longest operation.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:42.958
It took 23 hours. I did it with my neurosurgeon.

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
We removed all the bones at the right side of his face --

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
his eye, his nose,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
the skull bones, the facial skin --

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
and reconstructed him with tissue from the back.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
He continued to work as a psychiatric nurse.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
He got married. He had a son called Jeremiah.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
And again, he said,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
"This painting of me with my son Jeremiah

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
shows me as the successful man that I feel that I am."

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
His facial disfigurement

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:08.958
did not affect him

00:08:08.958 --> 00:08:10.958
because he had the support of a family;

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:12.958
he had a successful, fulfilling job.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
So we've seen that we can change people's faces.

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:17.958
But when we change people's faces,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:19.958
are we changing their identity --

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
for better or for worse?

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
For instance,

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
there are two different types of facial surgery.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
We can categorize it like that.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
We can say there are patients who choose to have facial surgery --

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
like Sue.

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
When they have facial surgery,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
they feel their lives have changed

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
because other people perceive them

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
as better people.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
They don't feel different.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
They feel that they've actually gained

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
what they never had,

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:49.958
that their face now reflects their personality.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
And actually that's probably the difference between cosmetic surgery

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
and this kind of surgery.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
Because you might say, "Well, this type of surgery

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
might be regarded as cosmetic."

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
If you do cosmetic surgery, patients are often less happy.

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
They're trying to achieve difference in their lives.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
Sue wasn't trying to achieve difference in her life.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
She was just trying to achieve the face

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
that matched her personality.

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
But then we have other people

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:18.958
who don't choose to have facial surgery.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
They're people who have their face shot off.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
I'll move it off, and we'll have a blank slide for those who are squeamish amongst you.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
They have it forced upon them.

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
And again, as I told you,

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
if they have a caring family

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
and good work life,

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
then they can lead normal and fulfilled lives.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
Their identity doesn't change.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
Is this business

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
about appearance and preoccupation with it

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
a Western phenomenon?

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
Muzetta's family give the lie to this.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
This is a little Bangladeshi girl from the east end of London

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:52.958
who's got a huge malignant tumor on the right side of her face,

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
which has already made her blind

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
and which is rapidly growing and is going to kill her shortly.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
After she had surgery to remove the tumor,

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
her parents dressed her in this beautiful green velvet dress,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
a pink ribbon in her hair,

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and they wanted the painting to be shown around the world,

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
despite the fact that they were orthodox Muslims

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
and the mother wore a full burqa.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
So it's not simply a Western phenomenon.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
We make judgments on people's faces

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
all the time.

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
It's been going on since we can think of Lombroso

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
and the way he would define criminal faces.

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
He said you could see criminal faces,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
judging them just on the photographs that were showed.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
Good-looking people

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
are always judged as being more friendly.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
We look at O.J. --

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
he's a good-looking guy.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
We'd like to spend time with him. He looks friendly.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:44.958
Now we know that he's a convicted wife-batterer,

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
and actually he's not the good guy.

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:50.958
And beauty doesn't equate to goodness,

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:53.958
and certainly doesn't equate to contentment.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
So we've talked about the static face

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
and judging the static face,

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
but actually, we're more comfortable

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
with judging the moving face.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
We think we can judge people on their expressions.

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
U.K. jurors in the U.K. justice system

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
like to see a live witness

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
to see whether they can pick up the telltale signs of mendacity --

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
the blink, the hesitation.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
And so they want to see live witnesses.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
Todorov tells us that, in a tenth of a second,

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
we can make a judgment on somebody's face.

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
Are we uncomfortable with this image? Yes, we are.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
Would we be happy if our doctor's face, our lawyer's face,

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
our financial adviser's face was covered?

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
We'd be pretty uncomfortable.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
But are we good at making the judgments

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
on facial appearance and movement?

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
The truth is that there's a five-minute rule,

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
not the tenth-of-a-second rule like Todorov, but a five-minute rule.

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
If you spend five minutes with somebody,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
you start looking beyond their facial appearance,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
and the people who you're initially attracted to

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
may seem boring and you lose interest in them,

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
and the people who you didn't immediately seek out,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
because you didn't find them particularly attractive,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
become attractive people

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
because of their personality.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
So we've talked a lot about facial appearance.

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
I now want to share

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
a little bit of the surgery that we do --

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
where we're at and where we're going.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
This is an image of Ann

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
who's had her right jaw removed and the base of her skull removed.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
And you can see in the images afterward,

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
we've managed to reconstruct her successfully.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
But that's not good enough.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
This is what Ann wants. She wants to be out kayaking,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
she wants to be out climbing mountains.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
And that's what she achieved, and that's what we have to get to.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
This is a horrific image,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
so I'm putting my hand up now.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
This is a photograph of Adi,

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
a Nigerian bank manager who had his face shot off

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
in an armed robbery.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
And he lost his lower jaw, his lip, his chin

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
and his upper jaw and teeth.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
This is the bar that he set for us.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
"I want to look like this. This is how I looked before."

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
So with modern technology,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
we used computers to make models.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
We made a model of the jaw without bone in it.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
We then bent a plate up to it.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
We put it in place

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:58.958
so we knew it was an accurate position.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:01.958
We then put bone and tissue from the back.

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
Here you can see the plate holding it,

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
and you can see the implants being put in --

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
so that in one operation

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:11.958
we achieve this

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
and this.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
So the patient's life is restored.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:17.958
That's the good news.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
However, his chin skin

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:21.958
doesn't look the same as it did before.

00:13:21.958 --> 00:13:23.958
It's skin from his back.

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
It's thicker, it's darker, it's coarser, it doesn't have the contours.

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
And that's where we're failing,

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
and that's where we need the face transplant.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
The face transplant has a role

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
probably in burns patients to replace the skin.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
We can replace the underlying skeletal structure,

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
but we're still not good at replacing the facial skin.

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
So it's very valuable

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
to have that tool in our armamentarium.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:46.958
But the patients are going to have to take drugs

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
that suppress their immune system for the rest of their lives.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
What does that mean?

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
They have an increased risk of infection, an increased risk of malignancy.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
This is not a life-saving transplant --

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
like a heart, or liver, or lung transplant --

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
it is a quality-of-life transplant,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
and as a result,

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
are the patients going to say, if they get a malignant cancer 10 or 15 years on,

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
"I wish I'd had conventional reconstructive techniques rather than this

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
because I'm now dying of a malignant cancer"? We don't know yet.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
We also don't know what they feel

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
about recognition and identity.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
Bernard Devauchelle and Sylvie Testelin, who did the first operation,

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
are studying that.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
Donors are going to be short on the ground,

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
because how many people want to have their loved one's face

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
removed at the point of death?

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
So there are going to be problems

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
with face transplantation.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
So the better news is

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
the future's almost here --

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
and the future is tissue engineering.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
Just imagine,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
I can make a biologically-degradable template.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:48.958
I can put it in place where it's meant to be.

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:50.958
I can sprinkle a few cells,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:52.958
stem cells from the patient's own hip,

00:14:52.958 --> 00:14:54.958
a little bit of genetically engineered protein,

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:58.958
and lo and behold, leave it for four months and the face is grown.

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
This is a bit like a Julia Child recipe.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
But we've still got problems.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
We've got mouth cancer to solve.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
We're still not curing enough patients -- it's the most disfiguring cancer.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
We're still not reconstructing them well enough.

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
In the U.K. we have an epidemic

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958

title: Curating humanity's heritage
transcript: As a child, I was raised by native Hawaiian elders — three old women who took care of me while my parents worked. The year is 1963. We're at the ocean. It's twilight. We're watching the rising of the stars and the shifting of the tides. It's a stretch of beach we know so well. The smooth stones on the sand are familiar to us. If you saw these women on the street in their faded clothes, you might dismiss them as poor and simple. That would be a mistake. These women are descendants of Polynesian navigators, trained in the old ways by their elders, and now they're passing it on to me. They teach me the names of the winds and the rains, of astronomy according to a genealogy of stars. There's a new moon on the horizon. Hawaiians say it's a good night for fishing. They begin to chant.[Hawaiian chant]When they finish, they sit in a circle and ask me to come to join them. They want to teach me about my destiny. I thought every seven-year-old went through this. (Laughter) "Baby girl, someday the world will be in trouble. People will forget their wisdom. It will take elders' voices from the far corners of the world to call the world into balance. You will go far away. It will sometimes be a lonely road. We will not be there. But you will look into the eyes of seeming strangers, and you will recognize your ohana, your family. And it will take all of you. It will take all of you." These words, I hold onto all my life. Because the idea of doing it alone terrifies me.The year is 2007. I'm on a remote island in Micronesia. Satawal is one half-mile long by one mile wide. It's the home of my mentor. His name is Pius Mau Piailug. Mau is a palu, a navigator priest. He's also considered the greatest wave finder in the world. There are fewer than a handful of palu left on this island. Their tradition is so extraordinary that these mariners sailed three million square miles across the Pacific without the use of instruments. They could synthesize patterns in nature using the rising and setting of stars, the sequence and direction of waves, the flight patterns of certain birds. Even the slightest hint of color on the underbelly of a cloud would inform them and help them navigate with the keenest accuracy.When Western scientists would join Mau on the canoe and watch him go into the hull, it appeared that an old man was going to rest. In fact, the hull of the canoe is the womb of the vessel. It is the most accurate place to feel the rhythm and sequence and direction of waves. Mau was, in fact, gathering explicit data using his entire body. It's what he had been trained to do since he was five years old. Now science may dismiss this methodology, but Polynesian navigators use it today because it provides them an accurate determination of the angle and direction of their vessel.The palu also had an uncanny ability to forecast weather conditions days in advance. Sometimes I'd be with Mau on a cloud-covered night and we'd sit at the easternmost coast of the island, and he would look out, and then he would say, "Okay, we go." He saw that first glint of light — he knew what the weather was going to be three days from now.Their achievements, intellectually and scientifically, are extraordinary, and they are so relevant for these times that we are in when we are riding out storms. We are in such a critical moment of our collective history. They have been compared to astronauts — these elder navigators who sail vast open oceans in double-hulled canoes thousands of miles from a small island. Their canoes, our rockets; their sea, our space. The wisdom of these elders is not a mere collection of stories about old people in some remote spot. This is part of our collective narrative. It's humanity's DNA. We cannot afford to lose it.The year is 2010. Just as the women in Hawaii that raised me predicted, the world is in trouble. We live in a society bloated with data, yet starved for wisdom. We're connected 24/7, yet anxiety, fear, depression and loneliness is at an all-time high. We must course-correct. An African shaman said, "Your society worships the jester while the king stands in plain clothes." The link between the past and the future is fragile. This I know intimately, because even as I travel throughout the world to listen to these stories and record them, I struggle. I am haunted by the fact that I no longer remember the names of the winds and the rains.Mau passed away five months ago, but his legacy and lessons live on. And I am reminded that throughout the world there are cultures with vast sums of knowledge in them, as potent as the Micronesian navigators, that are going dismissed, that this is a testament to brilliant, brilliant technology and science and wisdom that is vanishing rapidly. Because when an elder dies a library is burned, and throughout the world, libraries are ablaze.I am grateful for the fact that I had a mentor like Mau who taught me how to navigate. And I realize through a lesson that he shared that we continue to find our way. And this is what he said: "The island is the canoe; the canoe, the island." And what he meant was, if you are voyaging and far from home, your very survival depends on everyone aboard. You cannot make the voyage alone, you were never meant to. This whole notion of every man for himself is completely unsustainable. It always was.So in closing I would offer you this: The planet is our canoe, and we are the voyagers. True navigation begins in the human heart. It's the most important map of all. Together, may we journey well.(Applause)

title: Understanding cancer through proteomics
transcript: I admit that I'm a little bit nervous here because I'm going to say some radical things, about how we should think about cancer differently, to an audience that contains a lot of people who know a lot more about cancer than I do. But I will also contest that I'm not as nervous as I should be because I'm pretty sure I'm right about this. (Laughter) And that this, in fact, will be the way that we treat cancer in the future. In order to talk about cancer, I'm going to actually have to — let me get the big slide here. First, I'm going to try to give you a different perspective of genomics. I want to put it in perspective of the bigger picture of all the other things that are going on — and then talk about something you haven't heard so much about, which is proteomics. Having explained those, that will set up for what I think will be a different idea about how to go about treating cancer.So let me start with genomics. It is the hot topic. It is the place where we're learning the most. This is the great frontier. But it has its limitations. And in particular, you've probably all heard the analogy that the genome is like the blueprint of your body, and if that were only true, it would be great, but it's not. It's like the parts list of your body. It doesn't say how things are connected, what causes what and so on. So if I can make an analogy, let's say that you were trying to tell the difference between a good restaurant, a healthy restaurant and a sick restaurant, and all you had was the list of ingredients that they had in their larder. So it might be that, if you went to a French restaurant and you looked through it and you found they only had margarine and they didn't have butter, you could say, "Ah, I see what's wrong with them. I can make them healthy." And there probably are special cases of that. You could certainly tell the difference between a Chinese restaurant and a French restaurant by what they had in a larder. So the list of ingredients does tell you something, and sometimes it tells you something that's wrong. If they have tons of salt, you might guess they're using too much salt, or something like that. But it's limited, because really to know if it's a healthy restaurant, you need to taste the food, you need to know what goes on in the kitchen, you need the product of all of those ingredients.So if I look at a person and I look at a person's genome, it's the same thing. The part of the genome that we can read is the list of ingredients. And so indeed, there are times when we can find ingredients that [are] bad. Cystic fibrosis is an example of a disease where you just have a bad ingredient and you have a disease, and we can actually make a direct correspondence between the ingredient and the disease. But most things, you really have to know what's going on in the kitchen, because, mostly, sick people used to be healthy people — they have the same genome. So the genome really tells you much more about predisposition. So what you can tell is you can tell the difference between an Asian person and a European person by looking at their ingredients list. But you really for the most part can't tell the difference between a healthy person and a sick person — except in some of these special cases.So why all the big deal about genetics? Well first of all, it's because we can read it, which is fantastic. It is very useful in certain circumstances. It's also the great theoretical triumph of biology. It's the one theory that the biologists ever really got right. It's fundamental to Darwin and Mendel and so on. And so it's the one thing where they predicted a theoretical construct. So Mendel had this idea of a gene as an abstract thing, and Darwin built a whole theory that depended on them existing, and then Watson and Crick actually looked and found one. So this happens in physics all the time. You predict a black hole, and you look out the telescope and there it is, just like you said. But it rarely happens in biology. So this great triumph — it's so good, there's almost a religious experience in biology. And Darwinian evolution is really the core theory.So the other reason it's been very popular is because we can measure it, it's digital. And in fact, thanks to Kary Mullis, you can basically measure your genome in your kitchen with a few extra ingredients. So for instance, by measuring the genome, we've learned a lot about how we're related to other kinds of animals by the closeness of our genome, or how we're related to each other — the family tree, or the tree of life. There's a huge amount of information about the genetics just by comparing the genetic similarity. Now of course, in medical application, that is very useful because it's the same kind of information that the doctor gets from your family medical history — except probably, your genome knows much more about your medical history than you do. And so by reading the genome, we can find out much more about your family than you probably know. And so we can discover things that probably you could have found by looking at enough of your relatives, but they may be surprising. I did the 23andMe thing and was very surprised to discover that I am fat and bald. (Laughter) But sometimes you can learn much more useful things about that.But mostly what you need to know, to find out if you're sick, is not your predispositions, but it's actually what's going on in your body right now. So to do that, what you really need to do, you need to look at the things that the genes are producing and what's happening after the genetics, and that's what proteomics is about. Just like genome mixes the study of all the genes, proteomics is the study of all the proteins. And the proteins are all of the little things in your body that are signaling between the cells — actually, the machines that are operating — that's where the action is. Basically, a human body is a conversation going on, both within the cells and between the cells, and they're telling each other to grow and to die, and when you're sick, something's gone wrong with that conversation. And so the trick is — unfortunately, we don't have an easy way to measure these like we can measure the genome.So the problem is that measuring — if you try to measure all the proteins, it's a very elaborate process. It requires hundreds of steps, and it takes a long, long time. And it matters how much of the protein it is. It could be very significant that a protein changed by 10 percent, so it's not a nice digital thing like DNA. And basically our problem is somebody's in the middle of this very long stage, they pause for just a moment, and they leave something in an enzyme for a second, and all of a sudden all the measurements from then on don't work. And so then people get very inconsistent results when they do it this way. People have tried very hard to do this. I tried this a couple of times and looked at this problem and gave up on it.I kept getting this call from this oncologist named David Agus. And Applied Minds gets a lot of calls from people who want help with their problems, and I didn't think this was a very likely one to call back, so I kept on giving him to the delay list. And then one day, I get a call from John Doerr, Bill Berkman and Al Gore on the same day saying return David Agus's phone call. (Laughter) So I was like, "Okay. This guy's at least resourceful." (Laughter) So we started talking, and he said, "I really need a better way to measure proteins." I'm like, "Looked at that. Been there. Not going to be easy." He's like, "No, no. I really need it. I mean, I see patients dying every day because we don't know what's going on inside of them. We have to have a window into this." And he took me through specific examples of when he really needed it. And I realized, wow, this would really make a big difference, if we could do it, and so I said, "Well, let's look at it."Applied Minds has enough play money that we can go and just work on something without getting anybody's funding or permission or anything. So we started playing around with this. And as we did it, we realized this was the basic problem — that taking the sip of coffee — that there were humans doing this complicated process and that what really needed to be done was to automate this process like an assembly line and build robots that would measure proteomics. And so we did that, and working with David, we made a little company called Applied Proteomics eventually, which makes this robotic assembly line, which, in a very consistent way, measures the protein. And I'll show you what that protein measurement looks like.Basically, what we do is we take a drop of blood out of a patient, and we sort out the proteins in the drop of blood according to how much they weigh, how slippery they are, and we arrange them in an image. And so we can look at literally hundreds of thousands of features at once out of that drop of blood. And we can take a different one tomorrow, and you will see your proteins tomorrow will be different — they'll be different after you eat or after you sleep. They really tell us what's going on there. And so this picture, which looks like a big smudge to you, is actually the thing that got me really thrilled about this and made me feel like we were on the right track. So if I zoom into that picture, I can just show you what it means. We sort out the proteins — from left to right is the weight of the fragments that we're getting, and from top to bottom is how slippery they are. So we're zooming in here just to show you a little bit of it. And so each of these lines represents some signal that we're getting out of a piece of a protein. And you can see how the lines occur in these little groups of bump, bump, bump, bump, bump. And that's because we're measuring the weight so precisely that — carbon comes in different isotopes, so if it has an extra neutron on it, we actually measure it as a different chemical. So we're actually measuring each isotope as a different one.And so that gives you an idea of how exquisitely sensitive this is. So seeing this picture is sort of like getting to be Galileo and looking at the stars and looking through the telescope for the first time, and suddenly you say, "Wow, it's way more complicated than we thought it was." But we can see that stuff out there and actually see features of it. So this is the signature out of which we're trying to get patterns. So what we do with this is, for example, we can look at two patients, one that responded to a drug and one that didn't respond to a drug, and ask, "What's going on differently inside of them?" And so we can make these measurements precisely enough that we can overlay two patients and look at the differences.So here we have Alice in green and Bob in red. We overlay them. This is actual data. And you can see, mostly it overlaps and it's yellow, but there's some things that just Alice has and some things that just Bob has. And if we find a pattern of things of the responders to the drug, we see that in the blood, they have the condition that allows them to respond to this drug. We might not even know what this protein is, but we can see it's a marker for the response to the disease. So this already, I think, is tremendously useful in all kinds of medicine. But I think this is actually just the beginning of how we're going to treat cancer. So let me move to cancer.The thing about cancer — when I got into this, I really knew nothing about it, but working with David Agus, I started watching how cancer was actually being treated and went to operations where it was being cut out. And as I looked at it, to me it didn't make sense how we were approaching cancer, and in order to make sense of it, I had to learn where did this come from. We're treating cancer almost like it's an infectious disease. We're treating it as something that got inside of you that we have to kill. So this is the great paradigm. This is another case where a theoretical paradigm in biology really worked — was the germ theory of disease. So what doctors are mostly trained to do is diagnose — that is, put you into a category and apply a scientifically proven treatment for that diagnosis — and that works great for infectious diseases. So if we put you in the category of you've got syphilis, we can give you penicillin. We know that that works. If you've got malaria, we give you quinine or some derivative of it. And so that's the basic thing doctors are trained to do, and it's miraculous in the case of infectious disease — how well it works. And many people in this audience probably wouldn't be alive if doctors didn't do this.But now let's apply that to systems diseases like cancer. The problem is that, in cancer, there isn't something else that's inside of you. It's you; you're broken. That conversation inside of you got mixed up in some way. So how do we diagnose that conversation? Well, right now what we do is we divide it by part of the body — you know, where did it appear? — and we put you in different categories according to the part of the body. And then we do a clinical trial for a drug for lung cancer and one for prostate cancer and one for breast cancer, and we treat these as if they're separate diseases and that this way of dividing them had something to do with what actually went wrong. And of course, it really doesn't have that much to do with what went wrong because cancer is a failure of the system. And in fact, I think we're even wrong when we talk about cancer as a thing. I think this is the big mistake. I think cancer should not be a noun. We should talk about cancering as something we do, not something we have. And so those tumors, those are symptoms of cancer. And so your body is probably cancering all the time, but there are lots of systems in your body that keep it under control.And so to give you an idea of an analogy of what I mean by thinking of cancering as a verb, imagine we didn't know anything about plumbing, and the way that we talked about it, we'd come home and we'd find a leak in our kitchen and we'd say, "Oh, my house has water." We might divide it — the plumber would say, "Well, where's the water?" "Well, it's in the kitchen." "Oh, you must have kitchen water." That's kind of the level at which it is. "Kitchen water, well, first of all, we'll go in there and we'll mop out a lot of it. And then we know that if we sprinkle Drano around the kitchen, that helps. Whereas living room water, it's better to do tar on the roof." And it sounds silly, but that's basically what we do. And I'm not saying you shouldn't mop up your water if you have cancer, but I'm saying that's not really the problem; that's the symptom of the problem.What we really need to get at is the process that's going on, and that's happening at the level of the proteonomic actions, happening at the level of why is your body not healing itself in the way that it normally does? Because normally, your body is dealing with this problem all the time. So your house is dealing with leaks all the time, but it's fixing them. It's draining them out and so on. So what we need is to have a causative model of what's actually going on, and proteomics actually gives us the ability to build a model like that.David got me invited to give a talk at National Cancer Institute and Anna Barker was there. And so I gave this talk and said, "Why don't you guys do this?" And Anna said, "Because nobody within cancer would look at it this way. But what we're going to do, is we're going to create a program for people outside the field of cancer to get together with doctors who really know about cancer and work out different programs of research." So David and I applied to this program and created a consortium at USC where we've got some of the best oncologists in the world and some of the best biologists in the world, from Cold Spring Harbor, Stanford, Austin — I won't even go through and name all the places — to have a research project that will last for five years where we're really going to try to build a model of cancer like this. We're doing it in mice first, and we will kill a lot of mice in the process of doing this, but they will die for a good cause. And we will actually try to get to the point where we have a predictive model where we can understand, when cancer happens, what's actually happening in there and which treatment will treat that cancer.So let me just end with giving you a little picture of what I think cancer treatment will be like in the future. So I think eventually, once we have one of these models for people, which we'll get eventually — I mean, our group won't get all the way there — but eventually we'll have a very good computer model — sort of like a global climate model for weather. It has lots of different information about what's the process going on in this proteomic conversation on many different scales. And so we will simulate in that model for your particular cancer — and this also will be for ALS, or any kind of system neurodegenerative diseases, things like that — we will simulate specifically you, not just a generic person, but what's actually going on inside you.And in that simulation, what we could do is design for you specifically a sequence of treatments, and it might be very gentle treatments, very small amounts of drugs. It might be things like, don't eat that day, or give them a little chemotherapy, maybe a little radiation. Of course, we'll do surgery sometimes and so on. But design a program of treatments specifically for you and help your body guide back to health — guide your body back to health. Because your body will do most of the work of fixing it if we just sort of prop it up in the ways that are wrong. We put it in the equivalent of splints. And so your body basically has lots and lots of mechanisms for fixing cancer, and we just have to prop those up in the right way and get them to do the job.And so I believe that this will be the way that cancer will be treated in the future. It's going to require a lot of work, a lot of research. There will be many teams like our team that work on this. But I think eventually, we will design for everybody a custom treatment for cancer.So thank you very much.(Applause)

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
I admit that I'm a little bit nervous here

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:17.958
because I'm going to say some radical things,

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
about how we should think about cancer differently,

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:22.958
to an audience that contains a lot of people

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:25.958
who know a lot more about cancer than I do.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:29.958
But I will also contest that I'm not as nervous as I should be

00:00:29.958 --> 00:00:31.958
because I'm pretty sure I'm right about this.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:33.958
(Laughter)

00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:35.958
And that this, in fact, will be

00:00:35.958 --> 00:00:38.958
the way that we treat cancer in the future.

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:41.958
In order to talk about cancer,

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
I'm going to actually have to --

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
let me get the big slide here.

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
First, I'm going to try to give you a different perspective of genomics.

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
I want to put it in perspective of the bigger picture

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:57.958
of all the other things that are going on --

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:00.958
and then talk about something you haven't heard so much about, which is proteomics.

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
Having explained those,

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
that will set up for what I think will be a different idea

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
about how to go about treating cancer.

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
So let me start with genomics.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:11.958
It is the hot topic.

00:01:11.958 --> 00:01:13.958
It is the place where we're learning the most.

00:01:13.958 --> 00:01:15.958
This is the great frontier.

00:01:15.958 --> 00:01:18.958
But it has its limitations.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
And in particular, you've probably all heard the analogy

00:01:21.958 --> 00:01:24.958
that the genome is like the blueprint of your body,

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:26.958
and if that were only true, it would be great,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:28.958
but it's not.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
It's like the parts list of your body.

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
It doesn't say how things are connected,

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
what causes what and so on.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
So if I can make an analogy,

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
let's say that you were trying to tell the difference

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
between a good restaurant, a healthy restaurant

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
and a sick restaurant,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
and all you had was the list of ingredients

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
that they had in their larder.

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.958
So it might be that, if you went to a French restaurant

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
and you looked through it and you found

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
they only had margarine and they didn't have butter,

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
you could say, "Ah, I see what's wrong with them.

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
I can make them healthy."

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.958
And there probably are special cases of that.

00:02:02.958 --> 00:02:04.958
You could certainly tell the difference

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.958
between a Chinese restaurant and a French restaurant

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:08.958
by what they had in a larder.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
So the list of ingredients does tell you something,

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
and sometimes it tells you something that's wrong.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:17.958
If they have tons of salt,

00:02:17.958 --> 00:02:20.958
you might guess they're using too much salt, or something like that.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
But it's limited,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
because really to know if it's a healthy restaurant,

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
you need to taste the food, you need to know what goes on in the kitchen,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
you need the product of all of those ingredients.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
So if I look at a person

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:35.958
and I look at a person's genome, it's the same thing.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
The part of the genome that we can read

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:39.958
is the list of ingredients.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
And so indeed,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
there are times when we can find ingredients

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
that [are] bad.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:47.958
Cystic fibrosis is an example of a disease

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
where you just have a bad ingredient and you have a disease,

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:53.958
and we can actually make a direct correspondence

00:02:53.958 --> 00:02:56.958
between the ingredient and the disease.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:59.958
But most things, you really have to know what's going on in the kitchen,

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
because, mostly, sick people used to be healthy people --

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
they have the same genome.

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
So the genome really tells you much more

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:07.958
about predisposition.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:09.958
So what you can tell

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
is you can tell the difference between an Asian person and a European person

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
by looking at their ingredients list.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
But you really for the most part can't tell the difference

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:19.958
between a healthy person and a sick person --

00:03:19.958 --> 00:03:21.958
except in some of these special cases.

00:03:21.958 --> 00:03:23.958
So why all the big deal

00:03:23.958 --> 00:03:25.958
about genetics?

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
Well first of all,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:30.958
it's because we can read it, which is fantastic.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:33.958
It is very useful in certain circumstances.

00:03:33.958 --> 00:03:36.958
It's also the great theoretical triumph

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
of biology.

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
It's the one theory

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
that the biologists ever really got right.

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
It's fundamental to Darwin

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:46.958
and Mendel and so on.

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:49.958
And so it's the one thing where they predicted a theoretical construct.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
So Mendel had this idea of a gene

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:55.958
as an abstract thing,

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
and Darwin built a whole theory

00:03:57.958 --> 00:03:59.958
that depended on them existing,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:01.958
and then Watson and Crick

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
actually looked and found one.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
So this happens in physics all the time.

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
You predict a black hole,

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:10.958
and you look out the telescope and there it is, just like you said.

00:04:10.958 --> 00:04:12.958
But it rarely happens in biology.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:15.958
So this great triumph -- it's so good,

00:04:15.958 --> 00:04:17.958
there's almost a religious experience

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:19.958
in biology.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
And Darwinian evolution

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
is really the core theory.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
So the other reason it's been very popular

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
is because we can measure it, it's digital.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:33.958
And in fact,

00:04:33.958 --> 00:04:35.958
thanks to Kary Mullis,

00:04:35.958 --> 00:04:39.958
you can basically measure your genome in your kitchen

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
with a few extra ingredients.

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.958
So for instance, by measuring the genome,

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:49.958
we've learned a lot about how we're related to other kinds of animals

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
by the closeness of our genome,

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
or how we're related to each other -- the family tree,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
or the tree of life.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
There's a huge amount of information about the genetics

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:03.958
just by comparing the genetic similarity.

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
Now of course, in medical application,

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:07.958
that is very useful

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
because it's the same kind of information

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
that the doctor gets from your family medical history --

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
except probably,

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:18.958
your genome knows much more about your medical history than you do.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:20.958
And so by reading the genome,

00:05:20.958 --> 00:05:23.958
we can find out much more about your family than you probably know.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
And so we can discover things

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
that probably you could have found

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
by looking at enough of your relatives,

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:32.958
but they may be surprising.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
I did the 23andMe thing

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and was very surprised to discover that I am fat and bald.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:44.958
(Laughter)

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
But sometimes you can learn much more useful things about that.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:50.958
But mostly

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
what you need to know, to find out if you're sick,

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:54.958
is not your predispositions,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:57.958
but it's actually what's going on in your body right now.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:05:59.958
So to do that, what you really need to do,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
you need to look at the things

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
that the genes are producing

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
and what's happening after the genetics,

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:07.958
and that's what proteomics is about.

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:10.958
Just like genome mixes the study of all the genes,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
proteomics is the study of all the proteins.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And the proteins are all of the little things in your body

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:18.958
that are signaling between the cells --

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
actually, the machines that are operating --

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
that's where the action is.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
Basically, a human body

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
is a conversation going on,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
both within the cells and between the cells,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:34.958
and they're telling each other to grow and to die,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:36.958
and when you're sick,

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:38.958
something's gone wrong with that conversation.

00:06:38.958 --> 00:06:40.958
And so the trick is --

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:43.958
unfortunately, we don't have an easy way to measure these

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
like we can measure the genome.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
So the problem is that measuring --

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
if you try to measure all the proteins, it's a very elaborate process.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
It requires hundreds of steps,

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
and it takes a long, long time.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
And it matters how much of the protein it is.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
It could be very significant that a protein changed by 10 percent,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
so it's not a nice digital thing like DNA.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
And basically our problem is somebody's in the middle

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
of this very long stage,

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
they pause for just a moment,

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
and they leave something in an enzyme for a second,

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
and all of a sudden all the measurements from then on

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
don't work.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
And so then people get very inconsistent results

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
when they do it this way.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
People have tried very hard to do this.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
I tried this a couple of times

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
and looked at this problem and gave up on it.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
I kept getting this call from this oncologist

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
named David Agus.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
And Applied Minds gets a lot of calls

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
from people who want help with their problems,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:37.958
and I didn't think this was a very likely one to call back,

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:40.958
so I kept on giving him to the delay list.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
And then one day,

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
I get a call from John Doerr, Bill Berkman

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
and Al Gore on the same day

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
saying return David Agus's phone call.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
(Laughter)

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
So I was like, "Okay. This guy's at least resourceful."

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:56.958
(Laughter)

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
So we started talking,

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
and he said, "I really need a better way to measure proteins."

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
I'm like, "Looked at that. Been there.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
Not going to be easy."

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
He's like, "No, no. I really need it.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:11.958
I mean, I see patients dying every day

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
because we don't know what's going on inside of them.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
We have to have a window into this."

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
And he took me through

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
specific examples of when he really needed it.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
And I realized, wow, this would really make a big difference,

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
if we could do it,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
and so I said, "Well, let's look at it."

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:29.958
Applied Minds has enough play money

00:08:29.958 --> 00:08:31.958
that we can go and just work on something

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
without getting anybody's funding or permission or anything.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
So we started playing around with this.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:39.958
And as we did it, we realized this was the basic problem --

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
that taking the sip of coffee --

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
that there were humans doing this complicated process

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
and that what really needed to be done

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
was to automate this process like an assembly line

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
and build robots

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
that would measure proteomics.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
And so we did that,

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
and working with David,

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
we made a little company called Applied Proteomics eventually,

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
which makes this robotic assembly line,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
which, in a very consistent way, measures the protein.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:08.958
And I'll show you what that protein measurement looks like.

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:11.958
Basically, what we do

00:09:11.958 --> 00:09:13.958
is we take a drop of blood

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
out of a patient,

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
and we sort out the proteins

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
in the drop of blood

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
according to how much they weigh,

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
how slippery they are,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
and we arrange them in an image.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
And so we can look at literally

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
hundreds of thousands of features at once

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:32.958
out of that drop of blood.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
And we can take a different one tomorrow,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
and you will see your proteins tomorrow will be different --

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
they'll be different after you eat or after you sleep.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:42.958
They really tell us what's going on there.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
And so this picture,

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
which looks like a big smudge to you,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
is actually the thing that got me really thrilled about this

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
and made me feel like we were on the right track.

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:54.958
So if I zoom into that picture,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.958
I can just show you what it means.

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.958
We sort out the proteins -- from left to right

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
is the weight of the fragments that we're getting,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
and from top to bottom is how slippery they are.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
So we're zooming in here just to show you a little bit of it.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
And so each of these lines

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
represents some signal that we're getting out of a piece of a protein.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
And you can see how the lines occur

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:19.958
in these little groups of bump, bump, bump, bump, bump.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:22.958
And that's because we're measuring the weight so precisely that --

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
carbon comes in different isotopes,

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
so if it has an extra neutron on it,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:31.958
we actually measure it as a different chemical.

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:34.958
So we're actually measuring each isotope as a different one.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And so that gives you an idea

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
of how exquisitely sensitive this is.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
So seeing this picture

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
is sort of like getting to be Galileo

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
and looking at the stars

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
and looking through the telescope for the first time,

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:50.958
and suddenly you say, "Wow, it's way more complicated than we thought it was."

00:10:50.958 --> 00:10:52.958
But we can see that stuff out there

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:54.958
and actually see features of it.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:57.958
So this is the signature out of which we're trying to get patterns.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
So what we do with this

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
is, for example, we can look at two patients,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
one that responded to a drug and one that didn't respond to a drug,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
and ask, "What's going on differently

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:08.958
inside of them?"

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:11.958
And so we can make these measurements precisely enough

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:14.958
that we can overlay two patients and look at the differences.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
So here we have Alice in green

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
and Bob in red.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
We overlay them. This is actual data.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:24.958
And you can see, mostly it overlaps and it's yellow,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:26.958
but there's some things that just Alice has

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
and some things that just Bob has.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
And if we find a pattern of things

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:34.958
of the responders to the drug,

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
we see that in the blood,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:38.958
they have the condition

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:40.958
that allows them to respond to this drug.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
We might not even know what this protein is,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
but we can see it's a marker

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
for the response to the disease.

00:11:49.958 --> 00:11:51.958
So this already, I think,

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
is tremendously useful in all kinds of medicine.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
But I think this is actually

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
just the beginning

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
of how we're going to treat cancer.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:02.958
So let me move to cancer.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
The thing about cancer --

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
when I got into this,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
I really knew nothing about it,

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
but working with David Agus,

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:13.958
I started watching how cancer was actually being treated

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:16.958
and went to operations where it was being cut out.

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:18.958
And as I looked at it,

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
to me it didn't make sense

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
how we were approaching cancer,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
and in order to make sense of it,

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
I had to learn where did this come from.

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:32.958
We're treating cancer almost like it's an infectious disease.

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:34.958
We're treating it as something that got inside of you

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:36.958
that we have to kill.

00:12:36.958 --> 00:12:38.958
So this is the great paradigm.

00:12:38.958 --> 00:12:40.958
This is another case

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
where a theoretical paradigm in biology really worked --

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
was the germ theory of disease.

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
So what doctors are mostly trained to do

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:49.958
is diagnose --

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
that is, put you into a category

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
and apply a scientifically proven treatment

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
for that diagnosis --

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:58.958
and that works great for infectious diseases.

00:12:58.958 --> 00:13:00.958
So if we put you in the category

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
of you've got syphilis, we can give you penicillin.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
We know that that works.

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
If you've got malaria, we give you quinine

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:09.958
or some derivative of it.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And so that's the basic thing doctors are trained to do,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
and it's miraculous

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
in the case of infectious disease --

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
how well it works.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
And many people in this audience probably wouldn't be alive

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
if doctors didn't do this.

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:26.958
But now let's apply that

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
to systems diseases like cancer.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
The problem is that, in cancer,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
there isn't something else

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
that's inside of you.

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
It's you; you're broken.

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:40.958
That conversation inside of you

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:42.958
got mixed up in some way.

00:13:42.958 --> 00:13:44.958
So how do we diagnose that conversation?

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
Well, right now what we do is we divide it by part of the body --

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
you know, where did it appear? --

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
and we put you in different categories

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
according to the part of the body.

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
And then we do a clinical trial

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
for a drug for lung cancer

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and one for prostate cancer and one for breast cancer,

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:04.958
and we treat these as if they're separate diseases

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and that this way of dividing them

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
had something to do with what actually went wrong.

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
And of course, it really doesn't have that much to do

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:12.958
with what went wrong

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:15.958
because cancer is a failure of the system.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
And in fact, I think we're even wrong

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
when we talk about cancer as a thing.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
I think this is the big mistake.

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:26.958
I think cancer should not be a noun.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:28.958
We should talk about cancering

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:31.958
as something we do, not something we have.

00:14:31.958 --> 00:14:33.958
And so those tumors,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
those are symptoms of cancer.

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
And so your body is probably cancering all the time,

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
but there are lots of systems in your body

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
that keep it under control.

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
And so to give you an idea

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.958
of an analogy of what I mean

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
by thinking of cancering as a verb,

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
imagine we didn't know anything about plumbing,

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
and the way that we talked about it,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
we'd come home and we'd find a leak in our kitchen

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:02.958
and we'd say, "Oh, my house has water."

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:05.958
We might divide it -- the plumber would say, "Well, where's the water?"

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:08.958
"Well, it's in the kitchen." "Oh, you must have kitchen water."

00:15:08.958 --> 00:15:11.958
That's kind of the level at which it is.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
"Kitchen water,

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
well, first of all, we'll go in there and we'll mop out a lot of it.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:18.958
And then we know that if we sprinkle Drano around the kitchen,

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:21.958
that helps.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
Whereas living room water,

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
it's better to do tar on the roof."

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
And it sounds silly,

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
but that's basically what we do.

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:32.958
And I'm not saying you shouldn't mop up your water if you have cancer,

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:35.958
but I'm saying that's not really the problem;

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
that's the symptom of the problem.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
What we really need to get at

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:41.958
is the process that's going on,

00:15:41.958 --> 00:15:43.958
and that's happening at the level

00:15:43.958 --> 00:15:45.958
of the proteonomic actions,

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
happening at the level of why is your body not healing itself

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
in the way that it normally does?

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:53.958
Because normally, your body is dealing with this problem all the time.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.958
So your house is dealing with leaks all the time,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
but it's fixing them. It's draining them out and so on.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
So what we need

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:07.958
is to have a causative model

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:09.958
of what's actually going on,

00:16:09.958 --> 00:16:12.958
and proteomics actually gives us

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:15.958
the ability to build a model like that.

00:16:15.958 --> 00:16:17.958
David got me invited

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
to give a talk at National Cancer Institute

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
and Anna Barker was there.

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
And so I gave this talk

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
and said, "Why don't you guys do this?"

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:30.958
And Anna said,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
"Because nobody within cancer

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
would look at it this way.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
But what we're going to do, is we're going to create a program

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:40.958
for people outside the field of cancer

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
to get together with doctors

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:45.958
who really know about cancer

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:49.958
and work out different programs of research."

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
So David and I applied to this program

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
and created a consortium

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
at USC

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
where we've got some of the best oncologists in the world

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
and some of the best biologists in the world,

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:03.958
from Cold Spring Harbor,

00:17:03.958 --> 00:17:05.958
Stanford, Austin --

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:08.958
I won't even go through and name all the places --

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
to have a research project

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
that will last for five years

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
where we're really going to try to build a model of cancer like this.

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
We're doing it in mice first,

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
and we will kill a lot of mice

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:22.958
in the process of doing this,

00:17:22.958 --> 00:17:24.958
but they will die for a good cause.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:27.958
And we will actually try to get to the point

00:17:27.958 --> 00:17:29.958
where we have a predictive model

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
where we can understand,

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
when cancer happens,

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:35.958
what's actually happening in there

00:17:35.958 --> 00:17:38.958
and which treatment will treat that cancer.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
So let me just end with giving you a little picture

00:17:41.958 --> 00:17:44.958
of what I think cancer treatment will be like in the future.

00:17:44.958 --> 00:17:46.958
So I think eventually,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:48.958
once we have one of these models for people,

00:17:48.958 --> 00:17:50.958
which we'll get eventually --

00:17:50.958 --> 00:17:52.958
I mean, our group won't get all the way there --

00:17:52.958 --> 00:17:55.958
but eventually we'll have a very good computer model --

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:58.958
sort of like a global climate model for weather.

00:17:58.958 --> 00:18:01.958
It has lots of different information

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:04.958
about what's the process going on in this proteomic conversation

00:18:04.958 --> 00:18:06.958
on many different scales.

00:18:06.958 --> 00:18:08.958
And so we will simulate

00:18:08.958 --> 00:18:10.958
in that model

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:13.958
for your particular cancer --

00:18:13.958 --> 00:18:15.958
and this also will be for ALS,

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:18.958
or any kind of system neurodegenerative diseases,

00:18:18.958 --> 00:18:20.958
things like that --

00:18:20.958 --> 00:18:22.958
we will simulate

00:18:22.958 --> 00:18:24.958
specifically you,

00:18:24.958 --> 00:18:26.958
not just a generic person,

00:18:26.958 --> 00:18:28.958
but what's actually going on inside you.

00:18:28.958 --> 00:18:30.958
And in that simulation, what we could do

00:18:30.958 --> 00:18:32.958
is design for you specifically

00:18:32.958 --> 00:18:34.958
a sequence of treatments,

00:18:34.958 --> 00:18:37.958
and it might be very gentle treatments, very small amounts of drugs.

00:18:37.958 --> 00:18:40.958
It might be things like, don't eat that day,

00:18:40.958 --> 00:18:42.958
or give them a little chemotherapy,

00:18:42.958 --> 00:18:44.958
maybe a little radiation.

00:18:44.958 --> 00:18:47.958
Of course, we'll do surgery sometimes and so on.

00:18:47.958 --> 00:18:50.958
But design a program of treatments specifically for you

00:18:50.958 --> 00:18:53.958
and help your body

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:56.958
guide back to health --

00:18:56.958 --> 00:18:58.958
guide your body back to health.

00:18:58.958 --> 00:19:02.958
Because your body will do most of the work of fixing it

00:19:02.958 --> 00:19:05.958
if we just sort of prop it up in the ways that are wrong.

00:19:05.958 --> 00:19:07.958
We put it in the equivalent of splints.

00:19:07.958 --> 00:19:09.958
And so your body basically has lots and lots of mechanisms

00:19:09.958 --> 00:19:11.958
for fixing cancer,

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:14.958
and we just have to prop those up in the right way

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:16.958
and get them to do the job.

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:18.958
And so I believe that this will be the way

00:19:18.958 --> 00:19:20.958
that cancer will be treated in the future.

00:19:20.958 --> 00:19:22.958
It's going to require a lot of work,

00:19:22.958 --> 00:19:24.958
a lot of research.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:27.958
There will be many teams like our team

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.958
that work on this.

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:31.958
But I think eventually,

00:19:31.958 --> 00:19:33.958
we will design for everybody

00:19:33.958 --> 00:19:37.958
a custom treatment for cancer.

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:39.958
So thank you very much.

00:19:39.958 --> 00:19:45.958
(Applause)

title: A modern take on piano, violin, cello
transcript: (Applause)(Music)(Applause)Angella Ahn: Thank you. (Applause) Thank you so much. We are so honored to be here at TEDWomen, sharing our music with you. What an exciting and inspiring event. What you just heard is "Skylife" by David Balakrishnan. We want to play you one more selection. It's by Astor Piazzolla, an Argentine composer.
