title: A historic moment in the Arab world
transcript: Ten years ago exactly, I was in Afghanistan. I was covering the war in Afghanistan, and I witnessed, as a reporter for Al Jazeera, the amount of suffering and destruction that emerged out of a war like that. Then, two years later, I covered another war — the war in Iraq. I was placed at the center of that war because I was covering the war from the northern part of Iraq. And the war ended with a regime change, like the one in Afghanistan. And that regime that we got rid of was actually a dictatorship, an authoritarian regime, that for decades created a great sense of paralysis within the nation, within the people themselves. However, the change that came through foreign intervention created even worse circumstances for the people and deepened the sense of paralysis and inferiority in that part of the world.For decades, we have lived under authoritarian regimes — in the Arab world, in the Middle East. These regimes created something within us during this period. I'm 43 years old right now. For the last 40 years, I have seen almost the same faces for kings and presidents ruling us — old, aged, authoritarian, corrupt situations — regimes that we have seen around us. And for a moment I was wondering, are we going to live in order to see real change happening on the ground, a change that does not come through foreign intervention, through the misery of occupation, through nations invading our land and deepening the sense of inferiority sometimes? The Iraqis: yes, they got rid of Saddam Hussein, but when they saw their land occupied by foreign forces they felt very sad, they felt that their dignity had suffered. And this is why they revolted. This is why they did not accept. And actually other regimes, they told their citizens, "Would you like to see the situation of Iraq? Would you like to see civil war, sectarian killing? Would you like to see destruction? Would you like to see foreign troops on your land?" And the people thought for themselves, "Maybe we should live with this kind of authoritarian situation that we find ourselves in, instead of having the second scenario." That was one of the worst nightmares that we have seen.For 10 years, unfortunately we have found ourselves reporting images of destruction, images of killing, of sectarian conflicts, images of violence, emerging from a magnificent piece of land, a region that one day was the source of civilizations and art and culture for thousands of years. Now I am here to tell you that the future that we were dreaming for has eventually arrived. A new generation, well-educated, connected, inspired by universal values and a global understanding, has created a new reality for us. We have found a new way to express our feelings and to express our dreams: these young people who have restored self-confidence in our nations in that part of the world, who have given us new meaning for freedom and empowered us to go down to the streets. Nothing happened. No violence. Nothing. Just step out of your house, raise your voice and say, "We would like to see the end of the regime."This is what happened in Tunisia. Over a few days, the Tunisian regime that invested billions of dollars in the security agencies, billions of dollars in maintaining, trying to maintain, its prisons, collapsed, disappeared, because of the voices of the public. People who were inspired to go down to the streets and to raise their voices, they tried to kill. The intelligence agencies wanted to arrest people. They found something called Facebook. They found something called Twitter. They were surprised by all of these kinds of issues. And they said, "These kids are misled." Therefore, they asked their parents to go down to the streets and collect them, bring them back home. This is what they were telling. This is their propaganda. "Bring these kids home because they are misled." But yes, these youth who have been inspired by universal values, who are idealistic enough to imagine a magnificent future and, at the same time, realistic enough to balance this kind of imagination and the process leading to it — not using violence, not trying to create chaos — these young people, they did not go home. Parents actually went to the streets and they supported them. And this is how the revolution was born in Tunisia.We in Al Jazeera were banned from Tunisia for years, and the government did not allow any Al Jazeera reporter to be there. But we found that these people in the street, all of them are our reporters, feeding our newsroom with pictures, with videos and with news. And suddenly that newsroom in Doha became a center that received all this kind of input from ordinary people — people who are connected and people who have ambition and who have liberated themselves from the feeling of inferiority. And then we took that decision: We are unrolling the news. We are going to be the voice for these voiceless people. We are going to spread the message. Yes, some of these young people are connected to the Internet, but the connectivity in the Arab world is very little, is very small, because of many problems that we are suffering from. But Al Jazeera took the voice from these people and we amplified [it]. We put it in every sitting room in the Arab world — and internationally, globally, through our English channel.And then people started to feel that there's something new happening. And then Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali decided to leave. And then Egypt started, and Hosni Mubarak decided to leave. And now Libya as you see it. And then you have Yemen. And you have many other countries trying to see and to rediscover that feeling of, "How do we imagine a future which is magnificent and peaceful and tolerant?" I want to tell you something, that the Internet and connectivity has created [a] new mindset. But this mindset has continued to be faithful to the soil and to the land that it emerged from. And while this was the major difference between many initiatives before to create change, before we thought, and governments told us — and even sometimes it was true — that change was imposed on us, and people rejected that, because they thought that it is alien to their culture. Always, we believed that change will spring from within, that change should be a reconciliation with culture, cultural diversity, with our faith in our tradition and in our history, but at the same time, open to universal values, connected with the world, tolerant to the outside. And this is the moment that is happening right now in the Arab world. This is the right moment, and this is the actual moment that we see all of these meanings meet together and then create the beginning of this magnificent era that will emerge from the region.How did the elite deal with that — the so-called political elite? In front of Facebook, they brought the camels in Tahrir Square. In front of Al Jazeera, they started creating tribalism. And then when they failed, they started speaking about conspiracies that emerged from Tel Aviv and Washington in order to divide the Arab world. They started telling the West, "Be aware of Al-Qaeda. Al-Qaeda is taking over our territories. These are Islamists trying to create new Imaras. Be aware of these people who [are] coming to you in order to ruin your great civilization." Fortunately, people right now cannot be deceived. Because this corrupt elite in that region has lost even the power of deception. They could not, and they cannot, imagine how they could really deal with this reality. They have lost. They have been detached from their people, from the masses, and now we are seeing them collapsing one after the other.Al Jazeera is not a tool of revolution. We do not create revolutions. However, when something of that magnitude happens, we are at the center of the coverage. We were banned from Egypt, and our correspondents, some of them were arrested. But most of our camera people and our journalists, they went underground in Egypt — voluntarily — to report what happened in Tahrir Square. For 18 days, our cameras were broadcasting, live, the voices of the people in Tahrir Square. I remember one night when someone phoned me on my cellphone — ordinary person who I don't know — from Tahrir Square. He told me, "We appeal to you not to switch off the cameras. If you switch off the cameras tonight, there will be a genocide. You are protecting us by showing what is happening at Tahrir Square." I felt the responsibility to phone our correspondents there and to phone our newsroom and to tell them, "Make your best not to switch off the cameras at night, because the guys there really feel confident when someone is reporting their story — and they feel protected as well."So we have a chance to create a new future in that part of the world. We have a chance to go and to think of the future as something which is open to the world. Let us not repeat the mistake of Iran, of [the] Mosaddeq revolution. Let us free ourselves — especially in the West — from thinking about that part of the world based on oil interest, or based on interests of the illusion of stability and security. The stability and security of authoritarian regimes cannot create but terrorism and violence and destruction. Let us accept the choice of the people. Let us not pick and choose who we would like to rule their future. The future should be ruled by people themselves, even sometimes if they are voices that might now scare us. But the values of democracy and the freedom of choice that is sweeping the Middle East at this moment in time is the best opportunity for the world, for the West and the East, to see stability and to see security and to see friendship and to see tolerance emerging from the Arab world, rather than the images of violence and terrorism. Let us support these people. Let us stand for them. And let us give up our narrow selfishness in order to embrace change, and in order to celebrate with the people of that region a great future and hope and tolerance. The future has arrived, and the future is now. I thank you very much.(Applause)Thank you very much.(Applause)Chris Anderson: I just have a couple of questions for you. Thank you for coming here. How would you characterize the historical significance of what's happened? Is this a story-of-the-year, a story-of-the-decade or something more?Wadah Khanfar: Actually, this may be the biggest story that we have ever covered. We have covered many wars. We have covered a lot of tragedies, a lot of problems, a lot of conflict zones, a lot of hot spots in the region, because we were centered at the middle of it. But this is a story — it is a great story; it is beautiful. It is not something that you only cover because you have to cover a great incident. You are witnessing change in history. You are witnessing the birth of a new era. And this is what the story's all about.CA: There are a lot of people in the West who are still skeptical, or think this may just be an intermediate stage before much more alarming chaos. You really believe that if there are democratic elections in Egypt now, that a government could emerge that espouses some of the values you've spoken about so inspiringly?WK: And people actually, after the collapse of the Hosni Mubarak regime, the youth who have organized themselves in certain groups and councils, they are guarding the transformation and they are trying to put it on a track in order to satisfy the values of democracy, but at the same time also to make it reasonable and to make it rational, not to go out of order. In my opinion, these people are much more wiser than, not only the political elite, even the intellectual elite, even opposition leaders including political parties. At this moment in time, the youth in the Arab world are much more wiser and capable of creating the change than the old — including the political and cultural and ideological old regimes.(Applause)CA: We are not to get involved politically and interfere in that way. What should people here at TED, here in the West, do if they want to connect or make a difference and they believe in what's happening here?WK: I think we have discovered a very important issue in the Arab world — that people care, people care about this great transformation. Mohamed Nanabhay who's sitting with us, the head of Aljazeera.net, he told me that a 2,500 percent increase of accessing our website from various parts of the world. Fifty percent of it is coming from America. Because we discovered that people care, and people would like to know — they are receiving the stream through our Internet. Unfortunately in the United States, we are not covering but Washington D.C. at this moment in time for Al Jazeera English. But I can tell you, this is the moment to celebrate through connecting ourselves with those people in the street and expressing our support to them and expressing this kind of feeling, universal feeling, of supporting the weak and the oppressed to create a much better future for all of us.CA: Well Wadah, a group of members of the TED community, TEDxCairo, are meeting as we speak. They've had some speakers there. I believe they've heard your talk. Thank you for inspiring them and for inspiring all of us. Thank you so much.(Applause)

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
And now Libya as you see it.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
And then you have Yemen.

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
And you have many other countries trying to see

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:24.958
and to rediscover that feeling

00:07:24.958 --> 00:07:26.958
of, "How do we imagine a future

00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.958
which is magnificent and peaceful and tolerant?"

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
I want to tell you something,

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:36.958
that the Internet and connectivity

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
has created [a] new mindset.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
But this mindset

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
has continued to be faithful

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:45.958
to the soil and to the land

00:07:45.958 --> 00:07:48.958
that it emerged from.

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
And while this was the major difference

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:54.958
between many initiatives before

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
to create change,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
before we thought, and governments told us --

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
and even sometimes it was true --

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:04.958
that change was imposed on us,

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
and people rejected that,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
because they thought that it is alien to their culture.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:12.958
Always, we believed

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:15.958
that change will spring from within,

00:08:15.958 --> 00:08:19.958
that change should be a reconciliation

00:08:19.958 --> 00:08:22.958
with culture, cultural diversity,

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
with our faith in our tradition

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
and in our history,

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
but at the same time,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
open to universal values, connected with the world,

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:33.958
tolerant to the outside.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
And this is the moment

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
that is happening right now in the Arab world.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
This is the right moment, and this is the actual moment

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
that we see all of these meanings meet together

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:44.958
and then create the beginning

00:08:44.958 --> 00:08:46.958
of this magnificent era

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
that will emerge from the region.

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
How did the elite deal with that --

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
the so-called political elite?

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
In front of Facebook,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
they brought the camels in Tahrir Square.

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:03.958
In front of Al Jazeera,

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:07.958
they started creating tribalism.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
And then when they failed,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
they started speaking about conspiracies

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
that emerged from Tel Aviv and Washington

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
in order to divide the Arab world.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:20.958
They started telling the West,

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:22.958
"Be aware of Al-Qaeda.

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
Al-Qaeda is taking over our territories.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
These are Islamists

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
trying to create new Imaras.

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:30.958
Be aware of these people

00:09:30.958 --> 00:09:33.958
who [are] coming to you

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
in order to ruin your great civilization."

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
Fortunately,

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
people right now cannot be deceived.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:44.958
Because this corrupt elite

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
in that region

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:50.958
has lost even the power of deception.

00:09:50.958 --> 00:09:52.958
They could not, and they cannot, imagine

00:09:52.958 --> 00:09:55.958
how they could really deal with this reality.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
They have lost.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
They have been detached

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
from their people, from the masses,

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
and now we are seeing them collapsing

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
one after the other.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
Al Jazeera is not

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:13.958
a tool of revolution.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
We do not create revolutions.

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
However,

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:20.958
when something of that magnitude happens,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:23.958
we are at the center of the coverage.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
We were banned from Egypt,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
and our correspondents,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
some of them were arrested.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
But most of our camera people

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
and our journalists,

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:38.958
they went underground in Egypt -- voluntarily --

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:41.958
to report what happened in Tahrir Square.

00:10:41.958 --> 00:10:43.958
For 18 days,

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:46.958
our cameras were broadcasting, live,

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
the voices of the people in Tahrir Square.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
I remember one night

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
when someone phoned me on my cellphone --

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:55.958
ordinary person who I don't know -- from Tahrir Square.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
He told me, "We appeal to you

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
not to switch off the cameras.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
If you switch off the cameras tonight,

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
there will be a genocide.

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
You are protecting us

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:08.958
by showing what is happening at Tahrir Square."

00:11:08.958 --> 00:11:10.958
I felt the responsibility

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
to phone our correspondents there

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
and to phone our newsroom

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:16.958
and to tell them, "Make your best

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
not to switch off the cameras at night,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
because the guys there really feel confident

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
when someone is reporting their story --

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
and they feel protected as well."

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:29.958
So we have a chance

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:31.958
to create a new future

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
in that part of the world.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
We have a chance

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
to go and to think of the future

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
as something which is open to the world.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Let us not repeat the mistake of Iran,

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
of [the] Mosaddeq revolution.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
Let us free ourselves -- especially in the West --

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
from thinking about that part of the world

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:55.958
based on oil interest,

00:11:55.958 --> 00:11:58.958
or based on interests

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.958
of the illusion of stability and security.

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.958
The stability and security

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:07.958
of authoritarian regimes

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
cannot create

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
but terrorism and violence and destruction.

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:14.958
Let us accept the choice of the people.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:16.958
Let us not pick and choose

00:12:16.958 --> 00:12:19.958
who we would like to rule their future.

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:21.958
The future should be ruled

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:23.958
by people themselves,

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:25.958
even sometimes if they are voices

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:27.958
that might now scare us.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:30.958
But the values of democracy

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:32.958
and the freedom of choice

00:12:32.958 --> 00:12:35.958
that is sweeping the Middle East at this moment in time

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
is the best opportunity for the world,

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:39.958
for the West and the East,

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
to see stability and to see security

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:45.958
and to see friendship and to see tolerance

00:12:45.958 --> 00:12:47.958
emerging from the Arab world,

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
rather than the images of violence and terrorism.

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.958
Let us support these people.

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
Let us stand for them.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
And let us give up

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
our narrow selfishness

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
in order to embrace change,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:04.958
and in order to celebrate with the people of that region

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
a great future

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
and hope and tolerance.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:11.958
The future has arrived,

00:13:11.958 --> 00:13:13.958
and the future is now.

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:15.958
I thank you very much.

00:13:15.958 --> 00:13:28.958
(Applause)

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
Thank you very much.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:35.958
(Applause)

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
Chris Anderson: I just have a couple of questions for you.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
Thank you for coming here.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
How would you characterize the historical significance

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
of what's happened?

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
Is this a story-of-the-year, a story-of-the-decade

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
or something more?

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:51.958
Wadah Khanfar: Actually, this may be the biggest story that we have ever covered.

00:13:51.958 --> 00:13:53.958
We have covered many wars.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
We have covered a lot of tragedies, a lot of problems,

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
a lot of conflict zones, a lot of hot spots in the region,

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:00.958
because we were centered at the middle of it.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:04.958
But this is a story -- it is a great story; it is beautiful.

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:07.958
It is not something that you only cover

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:10.958
because you have to cover a great incident.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
You are witnessing change in history.

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
You are witnessing the birth of a new era.

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
And this is what the story's all about.

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:20.958
CA: There are a lot of people in the West

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:22.958
who are still skeptical,

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:25.958
or think this may just be an intermediate stage

00:14:25.958 --> 00:14:28.958
before much more alarming chaos.

00:14:28.958 --> 00:14:30.958
You really believe

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
that if there are democratic elections in Egypt now,

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
that a government could emerge

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:38.958
that espouses some of the values you've spoken about so inspiringly?

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:40.958
WK: And people actually,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.958
after the collapse of the Hosni Mubarak regime,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:45.958
the youth who have organized themselves

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:48.958
in certain groups and councils,

00:14:48.958 --> 00:14:51.958
they are guarding the transformation

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and they are trying to put it on a track

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
in order to satisfy

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
the values of democracy,

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
but at the same time

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
also to make it reasonable

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
and to make it rational,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
not to go out of order.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
In my opinion, these people are much more wiser

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
than, not only the political elite,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
even the intellectual elite, even opposition leaders

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
including political parties.

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
At this moment in time, the youth in the Arab world

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
are much more wiser

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
and capable of creating the change

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
than the old --

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:27.958
including the political and cultural

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:29.958
and ideological

00:15:29.958 --> 00:15:31.958
old regimes.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
(Applause)

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
CA: We are not to get involved politically and interfere in that way.

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:40.958
What should people here at TED,

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
here in the West,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
do if they want to connect or make a difference

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:47.958
and they believe in what's happening here?

00:15:47.958 --> 00:15:49.958
WK: I think we have discovered a very important issue in the Arab world --

00:15:49.958 --> 00:15:51.958
that people care,

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:54.958
people care about this great transformation.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
Mohamed Nanabhay who's sitting with us,

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:59.958
the head of Aljazeera.net,

00:15:59.958 --> 00:16:04.958
he told me that a 2,500 percent increase

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
of accessing our website

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
from various parts of the world.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
Fifty percent of it is coming from America.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
Because we discovered that people care,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
and people would like to know --

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
they are receiving the stream through our Internet.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
Unfortunately in the United States,

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:22.958
we are not covering but Washington D.C. at this moment in time

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:24.958
for Al Jazeera English.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:27.958
But I can tell you, this is the moment to celebrate

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:29.958
through connecting ourselves

00:16:29.958 --> 00:16:31.958
with those people in the street

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:34.958
and expressing our support to them

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:38.958
and expressing this kind of feeling, universal feeling,

00:16:38.958 --> 00:16:41.958
of supporting the weak and the oppressed

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:44.958
to create a much better future for all of us.

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:47.958
CA: Well Wadah, a group of members of the TED community,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
TEDxCairo,

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
are meeting as we speak.

00:16:51.958 --> 00:16:53.958
They've had some speakers there.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:55.958
I believe they've heard your talk.

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:57.958
Thank you for inspiring them and for inspiring all of us.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
Thank you so much.

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
(Applause)

title: My wish: Use art to turn the world inside out
transcript: Two weeks ago I was in my studio in Paris, and the phone rang and I heard, "Hey, JR, you won the TED Prize 2011. You have to make a wish to save the world." I was lost. I mean, I can't save the world. Nobody can. The world is fucked up. Come on, you have dictators ruling the world, population is growing by millions, there's no more fish in the sea, the North Pole is melting and as the last TED Prize winner said, we're all becoming fat. (Laughter) Except maybe French people. Whatever. So I called back and I told her, "Look, Amy, tell the TED guys I just won't show up. I can't do anything to save the world." She said, "Hey, JR, your wish is not to save the world, but to change the world." "Oh, all right." (Laughter) "That's cool." I mean, technology, politics, business do change the world — not always in a good way, but they do. What about art? Could art change the world?I started when I was 15 years old. And at that time, I was not thinking about changing the world. I was doing graffiti — writing my name everywhere, using the city as a canvas. I was going in the tunnels of Paris, on the rooftops with my friends. Each trip was an excursion, was an adventure. It was like leaving our mark on society, to say, "I was here," on the top of a building.So when I found a cheap camera on the subway, I started documenting those adventures with my friends and gave them back as photocopies — really small photos just that size. That's how, at 17 years old, I started pasting them. And I did my first "expo de rue," which means sidewalk gallery. And I framed it with color so you would not confuse it with advertising. I mean, the city's the best gallery I could imagine. I would never have to make a book and then present it to a gallery and let them decide if my work was nice enough to show it to people. I would control it directly with the public in the streets.So that's Paris. I would change — depending on the places I would go — the title of the exhibition. That's on the Champs-Elysees. I was quite proud of that one. Because I was just 18 and I was just up there on the top of the Champs-Elysees. Then when the photo left, the frame was still there.(Laughter)November 2005: the streets are burning. A large wave of riots had broken into the first projects of Paris. Everyone was glued to the TV, watching disturbing, frightening images taken from the edge of the neighborhood. I mean, these kids, without control, throwing Molotov cocktails, attacking the cops and the firemen, looting everything they could in the shops. These were criminals, thugs, dangerous, destroying their own environment.And then I saw it — could it be possible? — my photo on a wall revealed by a burning car — a pasting I'd done a year earlier — an illegal one — still there. I mean, these were the faces of my friends. I know those guys. All of them are not angels, but they're not monsters either. So it was kind of weird to see those images and those eyes stare back at me through a television.So I went back there with a 28 mm lens. It was the only one I had at that time. But with that lens, you have to be as close as 10 inches from the person. So you can do it only with their trust. So I took full portraits of people from Le Bosquet. They were making scary faces to play the caricature of themselves. And then I pasted huge posters everywhere in the bourgeois area of Paris with the name, age, even building number of these guys. A year later, the exhibition was displayed in front of the city hall of Paris. And we go from thug images, who've been stolen and distorted by the media, who's now proudly taking over his own image. That's where I realized the power of paper and glue. So could art change the world?A year later, I was listening to all the noise about the Middle East conflict. I mean, at that time, trust me, they were only referring to the Israeli and Palestinian conflict. So with my friend Marco, we decided to go there and see who are the real Palestinians and who are the real Israelis. Are they so different? When we got there, we just went in the street, started talking with people everywhere, and we realized that things were a bit different from the rhetoric we heard in the media. So we decided to take portraits of Palestinians and Israelis doing the same jobs — taxi-driver, lawyer, cooks. Asked them to make a face as a sign of commitment. Not a smile — that really doesn't tell about who you are and what you feel. They all accepted to be pasted next to the other. I decided to paste in eight Israeli and Palestinian cities and on both sides of the wall. We launched the biggest illegal art exhibition ever. We called the project Face 2 Face.The experts said, "No way. The people will not accept. The army will shoot you, and Hamas will kidnap you." We said, "Okay, let's try and push as far as we can." I love the way that people will ask me, "How big will my photo be?" "It will be as big as your house." When we did the wall, we did the Palestinian side. So we arrived with just our ladders and we realized that they were not high enough. And so Palestinians guys say, "Calm down. No wait. I'm going to find you a solution." So he went to the Church of Nativity and brought back an old ladder that was so old that it could have seen Jesus being born. (Laughter) We did Face 2 Face with only six friends, two ladders, two brushes, a rented car, a camera and 20,000 square feet of paper. We had all sorts of help from all walks of life.Okay, for example, that's Palestine. We're in Ramallah right now. We're pasting portraits — so both portraits in the streets in a crowded market. People come around us and start asking, "What are you doing here?" "Oh, we're actually doing an art project and we are pasting an Israeli and a Palestinian doing the same job. And those ones are actually two taxi-drivers." And then there was always a silence. "You mean you're pasting an Israeli face — doing a face — right here?" "Well, yeah, yeah, that's part of the project." And I would always leave that moment, and we would ask them, "So can you tell me who is who?" And most of them couldn't say.(Applause)We even pasted on Israeli military towers, and nothing happened. When you paste an image, it's just paper and glue. People can tear it, tag on it, or even pee on it — some are a bit high for that, I agree — but the people in the street, they are the curator. The rain and the wind will take them off anyway. They are not meant to stay. But exactly four years after, the photos, most of them are still there. Face 2 Face demonstrated that what we thought impossible was possible — and, you know what, even easy. We didn't push the limit; we just showed that they were further than anyone thought.In the Middle East, I experienced my work in places without [many] museums. So the reactions in the street were kind of interesting. So I decided to go further in this direction and go in places where there were zero museums. When you go in these developing societies, women are the pillars of their community, but the men are still the ones holding the streets. So we were inspired to create a project where men will pay tribute to women by posting their photos. I called that project Women Are Heroes. When I listened to all the stories everywhere I went on the continents, I couldn't always understand the complicated circumstances of their conflict. I just observed. Sometimes there was no words, no sentence, just tears. I just took their pictures and pasted them.Women Are Heroes took me around the world. Most of the places I went to, I decided to go there because I've heard about it through the media. So for example, in June 2008, I was watching TV in Paris, and then I heard about this terrible thing that happened in Rio de Janeiro — the first favela of Brazil named Providencia. Three kids — that was three students — were [detained] by the army because they were not carrying their papers. And the army took them, and instead of bringing them to the police station, they brought them to an enemy favela where they get chopped into pieces. I was shocked. All Brazil was shocked. I heard it was one of the most violent favelas, because the largest drug cartel controls it. So I decided to go there.When I arrived — I mean, I didn't have any contact with any NGO. There was none in place — no association, no NGOs, nothing — no eyewitnesses. So we just walked around, and we met a woman, and I showed her my book. And she said, "You know what? We're hungry for culture. We need culture out there." So I went out and I started with the kids. I just took a few photos of the kids, and the next day I came with the posters and we pasted them. The day after, I came back and they were already scratched. But that's okay. I wanted them to feel that this art belongs to them.Then the next day, I held a meeting on the main square and some women came. They were all linked to the three kids that got killed. There was the mother, the grandmother, the best friend — they all wanted to shout the story. After that day, everyone in the favela gave me the green light. I took more photos, and we started the project. The drug lords were kind of worried about us filming in the place, so I told them, "You know what? I'm not interested in filming the violence and the weapons. You see that enough in the media. What I want to show is the incredible life and energy. I've been seeing it around me the last few days." So that's a really symbolic pasting, because that's the first one we did that you couldn't see from the city. And that's where the three kids got arrested, and that's the grandmother of one of them. And on that stairs, that's where the traffickers always stand and there's a lot of exchange of fire. Everyone there understood the project. And then we pasted everywhere — the whole hill.(Applause)What was interesting is that the media couldn't get in. I mean, you should see that. They would have to film us from a really long distance by helicopter and then have a really long lens, and we would see ourselves, on TV, pasting. And they would put a number: "Please call this number if you know what's going on in Providencia." We just did a project and then left so the media wouldn't know. So how can we know about the project? So they had to go and find the women and get an explanation from them. So you create a bridge between the media and the anonymous women.We kept traveling. We went to Africa, Sudan, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Kenya. In war-torn places like Monrovia, people come straight to you. I mean, they want to know what you're up to. They kept asking me, "What is the purpose of your project? Are you an NGO? Are you the media?" Art. Just doing art. Some people question, "Why is it in black and white? Don't you have color in France?" (Laughter) Or they tell you, "Are these people all dead?" Some who understood the project would explain it to others. And to a man who did not understand, I heard someone say, "You know, you've been here for a few hours trying to understand, discussing with your fellows. During that time, you haven't thought about what you're going to eat tomorrow. This is art." I think it's people's curiosity that motivates them to come into the projects. And then it becomes more. It becomes a desire, a need, an armor. On this bridge that's in Monrovia, ex-rebel soldiers helped us pasting a portrait of a woman that might have been raped during the war. Women are always the first ones targeted during conflict.This is Kibera, Kenya, one of the largest slums of Africa. You might have seen images about the post-election violence that happened there in 2008. This time we covered the roofs of the houses, but we didn't use paper, because paper doesn't prevent the rain from leaking inside the house — vinyl does. Then art becomes useful. So the people kept it. You know what I love is, for example, when you see the biggest eye there, there are so [many] houses inside. And I went there a few months ago — photos are still there — and it was missing a piece of the eye. So I asked the people what happened. "Oh, that guy just moved." (Laughter) When the roofs were covered, a woman said as a joke, "Now God can see me." When you look at Kibera now, they look back.Okay, India. Before I start that, just so you know, each time we go to a place, we don't have authorization, so we set up like commandos — we're a group of friends who arrive there, and we try to paste on the walls. But there are places where you just can't paste on a wall. In India it was just impossible to paste. I heard culturally and because of the law, they would just arrest us at the first pasting. So we decided to paste white, white on the walls. So imagine white guys pasting white papers. So people would come to us and ask us, "Hey, what are you up to?" "Oh, you know, we're just doing art." "Art?" Of course, they were confused. But you know how India has a lot of dust in the streets, and the more dust you would have going up in the air, on the white paper you can almost see, but there is this sticky part like when you reverse a sticker. So the more dust you have, the more it will reveal the photo. So we could just walk in the street during the next days and the photos would get revealed by themselves. (Applause) Thank you. So we didn't get caught this time.Each project — that's a film from Women Are Heroes. (Music) Okay. For each project we do a film. And most of what you see — that's a trailer from "Women Are Heroes" — its images, photography, taken one after the other. And the photos kept traveling even without us. (Laughter) (Applause) Hopefully, you'll see the film, and you'll understand the scope of the project and what the people felt when they saw those photos. Because that's a big part of it. There's layers behind each photo. Behind each image is a story.Women Are Heroes created a new dynamic in each of the communities, and the women kept that dynamic after we left. For example, we did books — not for sale — that all the community would get. But to get it, they would have to [get] it signed by one of the women. We did that in most of the places. We go back regularly. And so in Providencia, for example, in the favela, we have a cultural center running there. In Kibera, each year we cover more roofs. Because of course, when we left, the people who were just at the edge of the project said, "Hey, what about my roof?" So we decided to come the year after and keep doing the project.A really important point for me is that I don't use any brand or corporate sponsors. So I have no responsibility to anyone but myself and the subjects. (Applause) And that is for me one of the more important things in the work. I think, today, as important as the result is the way you do things. And that has always been a central part of the work. And what's interesting is that fine line that I have with images and advertising. We just did some pasting in Los Angeles on another project in the last weeks. And I was even invited to cover the MOCA museum. But yesterday the city called them and said, "Look, you're going to have to tear it down. Because this can be taken for advertising, and because of the law, it has to be taken down." But tell me, advertising for what?The people I photograph were proud to participate in the project and to have their photo in the community. But they asked me for a promise basically. They asked me, "Please, make our story travel with you." So I did. That's Paris. That's Rio. In each place, we built exhibitions with a story, and the story traveled. You understand the full scope of the project. That's London. New York. And today, they are with you in Long Beach.All right, recently I started a public art project where I don't use my artwork anymore. I use Man Ray, Helen Levitt, Giacomelli, other people's artwork. It doesn't matter today if it's your photo or not. The importance is what you do with the images, the statement it makes where it's pasted. So for example, I pasted the photo of the minaret in Switzerland a few weeks after they voted the law forbidding minarets in the country. (Applause) This image of three men wearing gas masks was taken in Chernobyl originally, and I pasted it in Southern Italy, where the mafia sometimes bury the garbage under the ground.In some ways, art can change the world. Art is not supposed to change the world, to change practical things, but to change perceptions. Art can change the way we see the world. Art can create an analogy. Actually the fact that art cannot change things makes it a neutral place for exchanges and discussions, and then enables you to change the world. When I do my work, I have two kinds of reactions. People say, "Oh, why don't you go in Iraq or Afghanistan. They would be really useful." Or, "How can we help?" I presume that you belong to the second category, and that's good, because for that project, I'm going to ask you to take the photos and paste them.So now my wish is: (mock drum roll) (Laughter) I wish for you to stand up for what you care about by participating in a global art project, and together we'll turn the world inside out. And this starts right now. Yes, everyone in the room. Everyone watching. I wanted that wish to actually start now. So a subject you're passionate about, a person who you want to tell their story or even your own photos — tell me what you stand for. Take the photos, the portraits, upload it — I'll give you all the details — and I'll send you back your poster. Join by groups and reveal things to the world. The full data is on the website — insideoutproject.net — that is launching today.What we see changes who we are. When we act together, the whole thing is much more than the sum of the parts. So I hope that, together, we'll create something that the world will remember. And this starts right now and depends on you.Thank you.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)

WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:14.958
Two weeks ago I was in my studio in Paris,

00:00:14.958 --> 00:00:16.958
and the phone rang and I heard,

00:00:16.958 --> 00:00:18.958
"Hey, JR,

00:00:18.958 --> 00:00:20.958
you won the TED Prize 2011.

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:23.958
You have to make a wish to save the world."

00:00:23.958 --> 00:00:25.958
I was lost.

00:00:25.958 --> 00:00:28.958
I mean, I can't save the world. Nobody can.

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:30.958
The world is fucked up.

00:00:30.958 --> 00:00:32.958
Come on, you have dictators ruling the world,

00:00:32.958 --> 00:00:34.958
population is growing by millions,

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:36.958
there's no more fish in the sea,

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
the North Pole is melting

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:40.958
and as the last TED Prize winner said,

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
we're all becoming fat.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
(Laughter)

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
Except maybe French people.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:48.958
Whatever.

00:00:48.958 --> 00:00:50.958
So I called back

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:52.958
and I told her,

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
"Look, Amy,

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
tell the TED guys I just won't show up.

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
I can't do anything to save the world."

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
She said, "Hey, JR,

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:03.958
your wish is not to save the world, but to change the world."

00:01:03.958 --> 00:01:05.958
"Oh, all right."

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
(Laughter)

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:09.958
"That's cool."

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
I mean, technology, politics, business

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
do change the world --

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
not always in a good way, but they do.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
What about art?

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:21.958
Could art change the world?

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:24.958
I started when I was 15 years old.

00:01:24.958 --> 00:01:27.958
And at that time, I was not thinking about changing the world.

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:29.958
I was doing graffiti --

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
writing my name everywhere,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
using the city as a canvas.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
I was going in the tunnels of Paris,

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
on the rooftops with my friends.

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
Each trip was an excursion,

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
was an adventure.

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
It was like leaving our mark on society,

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:49.958
to say, "I was here," on the top of a building.

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
So when I found a cheap camera on the subway,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:57.958
I started documenting those adventures with my friends

00:01:57.958 --> 00:02:00.958
and gave them back as photocopies --

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
really small photos just that size.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:10.958
That's how, at 17 years old,

00:02:10.958 --> 00:02:12.958
I started pasting them.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
And I did my first "expo de rue,"

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
which means sidewalk gallery.

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:19.958
And I framed it with color

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:22.958
so you would not confuse it with advertising.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
I mean, the city's the best gallery I could imagine.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
I would never have to make a book and then present it to a gallery

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
and let them decide

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
if my work was nice enough to show it to people.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:37.958
I would control it directly with the public

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
in the streets.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.958
So that's Paris.

00:02:42.958 --> 00:02:44.958
I would change --

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
depending on the places I would go --

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
the title of the exhibition.

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
That's on the Champs-Elysees.

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
I was quite proud of that one.

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
Because I was just 18

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
and I was just up there on the top of the Champs-Elysees.

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
Then when the photo left,

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
the frame was still there.

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
(Laughter)

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
November 2005:

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
the streets are burning.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
A large wave of riots

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:11.958
had broken into the first projects of Paris.

00:03:12.958 --> 00:03:14.958
Everyone was glued to the TV,

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:18.958
watching disturbing, frightening images

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:21.958
taken from the edge of the neighborhood.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.958
I mean, these kids, without control,

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.958
throwing Molotov cocktails,

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.958
attacking the cops and the firemen,

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:31.958
looting everything they could in the shops.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
These were criminals, thugs, dangerous,

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
destroying their own environment.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
And then I saw it -- could it be possible? --

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
my photo on a wall

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
revealed by a burning car --

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.958
a pasting I'd done a year earlier --

00:03:48.958 --> 00:03:51.958
an illegal one -- still there.

00:03:51.958 --> 00:03:53.958
I mean, these were the faces of my friends.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
I know those guys.

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
All of them are not angels,

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
but they're not monsters either.

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:03.958
So it was kind of weird to see

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
those images and those eyes stare back at me through a television.

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
So I went back there

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
with a 28 mm lens.

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
It was the only one I had at that time.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
But with that lens,

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
you have to be as close as 10 inches from the person.

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:22.958
So you can do it only with their trust.

00:04:22.958 --> 00:04:26.958
So I took full portraits of people from Le Bosquet.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:28.958
They were making scary faces

00:04:28.958 --> 00:04:31.958
to play the caricature of themselves.

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:46.958
And then I pasted huge posters everywhere

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
in the bourgeois area of Paris

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:51.958
with the name, age, even building number

00:04:51.958 --> 00:04:54.958
of these guys.

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:02.958
A year later,

00:05:02.958 --> 00:05:05.958
the exhibition was displayed in front of the city hall of Paris.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
And we go from thug images,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.958
who've been stolen and distorted by the media,

00:05:11.958 --> 00:05:14.958
who's now proudly taking over his own image.

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
That's where I realized

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
the power of paper and glue.

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:29.958
So could art change the world?

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
A year later,

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
I was listening to all the noise

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
about the Middle East conflict.

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
I mean, at that time, trust me,

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
they were only referring to the Israeli and Palestinian conflict.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:41.958
So with my friend Marco,

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:43.958
we decided to go there

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:46.958
and see who are the real Palestinians and who are the real Israelis.

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
Are they so different?

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:51.958
When we got there, we just went in the street,

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:54.958
started talking with people everywhere,

00:05:54.958 --> 00:05:56.958
and we realized that things were a bit different

00:05:56.958 --> 00:05:59.958
from the rhetoric we heard in the media.

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
So we decided to take portraits

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
of Palestinians and Israelis

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
doing the same jobs --

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
taxi-driver, lawyer, cooks.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
Asked them to make a face as a sign of commitment.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
Not a smile -- that really doesn't tell

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
about who you are and what you feel.

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
They all accepted

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
to be pasted next to the other.

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
I decided to paste

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:27.958
in eight Israeli and Palestinian cities

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
and on both sides of the wall.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:33.958
We launched the biggest illegal art exhibition ever.

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
We called the project Face 2 Face.

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
The experts said, "No way.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
The people will not accept.

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
The army will shoot you, and Hamas will kidnap you."

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:47.958
We said, "Okay, let's try and push as far as we can."

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
I love the way that people will ask me,

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
"How big will my photo be?"

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
"It will be as big as your house."

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
When we did the wall, we did the Palestinian side.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
So we arrived with just our ladders

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
and we realized that they were not high enough.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
And so Palestinians guys say,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
"Calm down. No wait. I'm going to find you a solution."

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
So he went to the Church of Nativity

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and brought back an old ladder

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
that was so old that it could have seen Jesus being born.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
(Laughter)

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
We did Face 2 Face with only six friends,

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
two ladders, two brushes,

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
a rented car, a camera

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
and 20,000 square feet of paper.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
We had all sorts of help

00:07:30.958 --> 00:07:33.958
from all walks of life.

00:07:35.958 --> 00:07:37.958
Okay, for example, that's Palestine.

00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:39.958
We're in Ramallah right now.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
We're pasting portraits --

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
so both portraits in the streets in a crowded market.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
People come around us and start asking,

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
"What are you doing here?"

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
"Oh, we're actually doing an art project

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
and we are pasting an Israeli and a Palestinian doing the same job.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
And those ones are actually two taxi-drivers."

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
And then there was always a silence.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
"You mean you're pasting an Israeli face --

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
doing a face -- right here?"

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
"Well, yeah, yeah, that's part of the project."

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
And I would always leave that moment,

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
and we would ask them,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
"So can you tell me who is who?"

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And most of them couldn't say.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:22.958
(Applause)

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:25.958
We even pasted on Israeli military towers,

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:27.958
and nothing happened.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
When you paste an image, it's just paper and glue.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
People can tear it, tag on it, or even pee on it --

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
some are a bit high for that, I agree --

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
but the people in the street,

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
they are the curator.

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
The rain and the wind will take them off anyway.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
They are not meant to stay.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
But exactly four years after,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
the photos, most of them are still there.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Face 2 Face demonstrated

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:54.958
that what we thought impossible was possible --

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
and, you know what, even easy.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:58.958
We didn't push the limit;

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
we just showed that they were further than anyone thought.

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
In the Middle East, I experienced my work

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
in places without [many] museums.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
So the reactions in the street

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
were kind of interesting.

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
So I decided to go further in this direction

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:18.958
and go in places where there were zero museums.

00:09:20.958 --> 00:09:23.958
When you go in these developing societies,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
women are the pillars of their community,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
but the men are still the ones holding the streets.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
So we were inspired to create a project

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:35.958
where men will pay tribute to women

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:38.958
by posting their photos.

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:42.958
I called that project Women Are Heroes.

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:44.958
When I listened to all the stories

00:09:44.958 --> 00:09:46.958
everywhere I went on the continents,

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
I couldn't always understand

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
the complicated circumstances of their conflict.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
I just observed.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
Sometimes there was no words,

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
no sentence, just tears.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:03.958
I just took their pictures

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:06.958
and pasted them.

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:10.958
Women Are Heroes took me around the world.

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:12.958
Most of the places I went to,

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
I decided to go there

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
because I've heard about it through the media.

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
So for example, in June 2008,

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
I was watching TV in Paris,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
and then I heard about this terrible thing

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
that happened in Rio de Janeiro --

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.958
the first favela of Brazil named Providencia.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:31.958
Three kids -- that was three students --

00:10:31.958 --> 00:10:33.958
were [detained] by the army

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
because they were not carrying their papers.

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
And the army took them,

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
and instead of bringing them to the police station,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
they brought them to an enemy favela

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
where they get chopped into pieces.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
I was shocked.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
All Brazil was shocked.

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:52.958
I heard it was one of the most violent favelas,

00:10:52.958 --> 00:10:55.958
because the largest drug cartel controls it.

00:10:55.958 --> 00:10:57.958
So I decided to go there.

00:10:57.958 --> 00:10:59.958
When I arrived --

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
I mean, I didn't have any contact with any NGO.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:05.958
There was none in place -- no association, no NGOs, nothing --

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
no eyewitnesses.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
So we just walked around,

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
and we met a woman,

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
and I showed her my book.

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:15.958
And she said, "You know what?

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:17.958
We're hungry for culture.

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:20.958
We need culture out there."

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
So I went out and I started with the kids.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
I just took a few photos of the kids,

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
and the next day I came with the posters and we pasted them.

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
The day after, I came back and they were already scratched.

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
But that's okay.

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:36.958
I wanted them to feel that this art belongs to them.

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:40.958
Then the next day, I held a meeting on the main square

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
and some women came.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:46.958
They were all linked to the three kids that got killed.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
There was the mother, the grandmother, the best friend --

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
they all wanted to shout the story.

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
After that day,

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
everyone in the favela gave me the green light.

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:02.958
I took more photos, and we started the project.

00:12:02.958 --> 00:12:04.958
The drug lords were kind of worried

00:12:04.958 --> 00:12:06.958
about us filming in the place,

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:08.958
so I told them, "You know what?

00:12:08.958 --> 00:12:10.958
I'm not interested in filming the violence and the weapons.

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
You see that enough in the media.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
What I want to show is the incredible life and energy.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
I've been seeing it around me the last few days."

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
So that's a really symbolic pasting,

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:23.958
because that's the first one we did that you couldn't see from the city.

00:12:23.958 --> 00:12:26.958
And that's where the three kids got arrested,

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:29.958
and that's the grandmother of one of them.

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:31.958
And on that stairs,

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:33.958
that's where the traffickers always stand

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
and there's a lot of exchange of fire.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:38.958
Everyone there understood the project.

00:12:39.958 --> 00:12:42.958
And then we pasted everywhere -- the whole hill.

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:52.958
(Applause)

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:54.958
What was interesting is that the media couldn't get in.

00:12:54.958 --> 00:12:56.958
I mean, you should see that.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:12:59.958
They would have to film us from a really long distance by helicopter

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:01.958
and then have a really long lens,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.958
and we would see ourselves, on TV, pasting.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:05.958
And they would put a number: "Please call this number

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:07.958
if you know what's going on in Providencia."

00:13:07.958 --> 00:13:10.958
We just did a project and then left

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
so the media wouldn't know.

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
So how can we know about the project?

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:17.958
So they had to go and find the women

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:19.958
and get an explanation from them.

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
So you create a bridge between the media

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
and the anonymous women.

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
We kept traveling.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
We went to Africa, Sudan, Sierra Leone,

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:31.958
Liberia, Kenya.

00:13:31.958 --> 00:13:33.958
In war-torn places like Monrovia,

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:35.958
people come straight to you.

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
I mean, they want to know what you're up to.

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:40.958
They kept asking me, "What is the purpose of your project?

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
Are you an NGO? Are you the media?"

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.958
Art. Just doing art.

00:13:46.958 --> 00:13:48.958
Some people question, "Why is it in black and white?

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
Don't you have color in France?"

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
(Laughter)

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
Or they tell you, "Are these people all dead?"

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
Some who understood the project would explain it to others.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
And to a man who did not understand, I heard someone say,

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
"You know, you've been here for a few hours

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
trying to understand, discussing with your fellows.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
During that time, you haven't thought about

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:10.958
what you're going to eat tomorrow.

00:14:10.958 --> 00:14:13.958
This is art."

00:14:13.958 --> 00:14:16.958
I think it's people's curiosity

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:19.958
that motivates them

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:21.958
to come into the projects.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:23.958
And then it becomes more.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
It becomes a desire, a need, an armor.

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
On this bridge that's in Monrovia,

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
ex-rebel soldiers helped us pasting a portrait

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:36.958
of a woman that might have been raped during the war.

00:14:36.958 --> 00:14:38.958
Women are always the first ones targeted

00:14:38.958 --> 00:14:41.958
during conflict.

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:43.958
This is Kibera, Kenya,

00:14:43.958 --> 00:14:46.958
one of the largest slums of Africa.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
You might have seen images about the post-election violence

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:52.958
that happened there in 2008.

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
This time we covered the roofs of the houses,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:58.958
but we didn't use paper,

00:14:58.958 --> 00:15:01.958
because paper doesn't prevent the rain

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
from leaking inside the house --

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:05.958
vinyl does.

00:15:05.958 --> 00:15:07.958
Then art becomes useful.

00:15:07.958 --> 00:15:09.958
So the people kept it.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:12.958
You know what I love is, for example, when you see the biggest eye there,

00:15:12.958 --> 00:15:14.958
there are so [many] houses inside.

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
And I went there a few months ago --

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:19.958
photos are still there -- and it was missing a piece of the eye.

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:21.958
So I asked the people what happened.

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
"Oh, that guy just moved."

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:27.958
(Laughter)

00:15:27.958 --> 00:15:30.958
When the roofs were covered, a woman said as a joke,

00:15:30.958 --> 00:15:32.958
"Now God can see me."

00:15:32.958 --> 00:15:34.958
When you look at Kibera now,

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
they look back.

00:15:40.958 --> 00:15:42.958
Okay, India.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
Before I start that, just so you know,

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
each time we go to a place, we don't have authorization,

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
so we set up like commandos --

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
we're a group of friends who arrive there,

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:52.958
and we try to paste on the walls.

00:15:52.958 --> 00:15:55.958
But there are places where you just can't paste on a wall.

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
In India it was just impossible to paste.

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:01.958
I heard culturally and because of the law,

00:16:01.958 --> 00:16:04.958
they would just arrest us at the first pasting.

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
So we decided to paste white,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
white on the walls.

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
So imagine white guys pasting white papers.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
So people would come to us and ask us,

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
"Hey, what are you up to?"

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
"Oh, you know, we're just doing art." "Art?"

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
Of course, they were confused.

00:16:20.958 --> 00:16:23.958
But you know how India has a lot of dust in the streets,

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
and the more dust you would have

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
going up in the air,

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
on the white paper you can almost see,

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:32.958
but there is this sticky part

00:16:32.958 --> 00:16:34.958
like when you reverse a sticker.

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:37.958
So the more dust you have, the more it will reveal the photo.

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:40.958
So we could just walk in the street during the next days

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:42.958
and the photos would get revealed by themselves.

00:16:42.958 --> 00:16:49.958
(Applause)

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:51.958
Thank you.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
So we didn't get caught this time.

00:16:57.958 --> 00:16:59.958
Each project -- that's a film

00:16:59.958 --> 00:17:02.958
from Women Are Heroes.

00:17:02.958 --> 00:17:05.958
(Music)

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
Okay.

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
For each project we do

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
a film.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
And most of what you see -- that's a trailer from "Women Are Heroes" --

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:17.958
its images, photography,

00:17:17.958 --> 00:17:20.958
taken one after the other.

00:17:38.958 --> 00:17:41.958
And the photos kept traveling even without us.

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
(Laughter)

00:18:19.958 --> 00:18:29.958
(Applause)

00:18:29.958 --> 00:18:31.958
Hopefully, you'll see the film,

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:33.958
and you'll understand the scope of the project

00:18:33.958 --> 00:18:35.958
and what the people felt when they saw those photos.

00:18:35.958 --> 00:18:38.958
Because that's a big part of it. There's layers behind each photo.

00:18:38.958 --> 00:18:41.958
Behind each image is a story.

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:43.958
Women Are Heroes created a new dynamic

00:18:43.958 --> 00:18:45.958
in each of the communities,

00:18:45.958 --> 00:18:48.958
and the women kept that dynamic after we left.

00:18:48.958 --> 00:18:51.958
For example, we did books -- not for sale --

00:18:51.958 --> 00:18:53.958
that all the community would get.

00:18:53.958 --> 00:18:57.958
But to get it, they would have to [get] it signed by one of the women.

00:18:57.958 --> 00:18:59.958
We did that in most of the places.

00:18:59.958 --> 00:19:01.958
We go back regularly.

00:19:01.958 --> 00:19:04.958
And so in Providencia, for example, in the favela,

00:19:04.958 --> 00:19:06.958
we have a cultural center running there.

00:19:06.958 --> 00:19:08.958
In Kibera, each year we cover more roofs.

00:19:08.958 --> 00:19:11.958
Because of course, when we left, the people who were just at the edge of the project

00:19:11.958 --> 00:19:14.958
said, "Hey, what about my roof?"

00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:16.958
So we decided to come the year after

00:19:16.958 --> 00:19:19.958
and keep doing the project.

00:19:19.958 --> 00:19:21.958
A really important point for me

00:19:21.958 --> 00:19:24.958
is that I don't use any brand or corporate sponsors.

00:19:24.958 --> 00:19:26.958
So I have no responsibility

00:19:26.958 --> 00:19:28.958
to anyone but myself

00:19:28.958 --> 00:19:30.958
and the subjects.

00:19:30.958 --> 00:19:34.958
(Applause)

00:19:34.958 --> 00:19:36.958
And that is for me

00:19:36.958 --> 00:19:38.958
one of the more important things in the work.

00:19:38.958 --> 00:19:40.958
I think, today,

00:19:40.958 --> 00:19:43.958
as important as the result is the way you do things.

00:19:43.958 --> 00:19:46.958
And that has always been a central part of the work.

00:19:47.958 --> 00:19:49.958
And what's interesting is that fine line that I have

00:19:49.958 --> 00:19:51.958
with images and advertising.

00:19:51.958 --> 00:19:53.958
We just did some pasting in Los Angeles

00:19:53.958 --> 00:19:56.958
on another project in the last weeks.

00:19:56.958 --> 00:20:00.958
And I was even invited to cover the MOCA museum.

00:20:00.958 --> 00:20:02.958
But yesterday the city called them and said,

00:20:02.958 --> 00:20:04.958
"Look, you're going to have to tear it down.

00:20:04.958 --> 00:20:06.958
Because this can be taken for advertising,

00:20:06.958 --> 00:20:08.958
and because of the law,

00:20:08.958 --> 00:20:10.958
it has to be taken down."

00:20:10.958 --> 00:20:13.958
But tell me, advertising for what?

00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:15.958
The people I photograph

00:20:15.958 --> 00:20:17.958
were proud to participate in the project

00:20:17.958 --> 00:20:19.958
and to have their photo in the community.

00:20:19.958 --> 00:20:21.958
But they asked me for a promise basically.

00:20:21.958 --> 00:20:25.958
They asked me, "Please, make our story travel with you."

00:20:25.958 --> 00:20:28.958
So I did. That's Paris.

00:20:28.958 --> 00:20:30.958
That's Rio.

00:20:30.958 --> 00:20:34.958
In each place, we built exhibitions with a story, and the story traveled.

00:20:34.958 --> 00:20:36.958
You understand the full scope of the project.

00:20:36.958 --> 00:20:39.958
That's London.

00:20:39.958 --> 00:20:41.958
New York.

00:20:41.958 --> 00:20:44.958
And today, they are with you in Long Beach.

00:20:45.958 --> 00:20:48.958
All right, recently I started a public art project

00:20:48.958 --> 00:20:51.958
where I don't use my artwork anymore.

00:20:51.958 --> 00:20:54.958
I use Man Ray, Helen Levitt,

00:20:54.958 --> 00:20:56.958
Giacomelli, other people's artwork.

00:20:56.958 --> 00:20:59.958
It doesn't matter today if it's your photo or not.

00:20:59.958 --> 00:21:01.958
The importance is what you do

00:21:01.958 --> 00:21:03.958
with the images,

00:21:03.958 --> 00:21:06.958
the statement it makes where it's pasted.

00:21:06.958 --> 00:21:09.958
So for example, I pasted the photo of the minaret

00:21:09.958 --> 00:21:11.958
in Switzerland

00:21:11.958 --> 00:21:15.958
a few weeks after they voted the law forbidding minarets in the country.

00:21:15.958 --> 00:21:21.958
(Applause)

00:21:21.958 --> 00:21:24.958
This image of three men wearing gas masks

00:21:24.958 --> 00:21:26.958
was taken in Chernobyl originally,

00:21:26.958 --> 00:21:29.958
and I pasted it in Southern Italy,

00:21:29.958 --> 00:21:33.958
where the mafia sometimes bury the garbage under the ground.

00:21:35.958 --> 00:21:37.958
In some ways, art can change the world.

00:21:37.958 --> 00:21:39.958
Art is not supposed to change the world,

00:21:39.958 --> 00:21:41.958
to change practical things,

00:21:41.958 --> 00:21:43.958
but to change perceptions.

00:21:43.958 --> 00:21:45.958
Art can change

00:21:45.958 --> 00:21:47.958
the way we see the world.

00:21:47.958 --> 00:21:50.958
Art can create an analogy.

00:21:50.958 --> 00:21:53.958
Actually the fact that art cannot change things

00:21:53.958 --> 00:21:55.958
makes it a neutral place

00:21:55.958 --> 00:21:58.958
for exchanges and discussions,

00:21:58.958 --> 00:22:01.958
and then enables you to change the world.

00:22:01.958 --> 00:22:03.958
When I do my work,

00:22:03.958 --> 00:22:05.958
I have two kinds of reactions.

00:22:05.958 --> 00:22:08.958
People say, "Oh, why don't you go in Iraq or Afghanistan.

00:22:08.958 --> 00:22:10.958
They would be really useful."

00:22:10.958 --> 00:22:13.958
Or, "How can we help?"

00:22:13.958 --> 00:22:16.958
I presume that you belong to the second category,

00:22:16.958 --> 00:22:18.958
and that's good,

00:22:18.958 --> 00:22:20.958
because for that project,

00:22:20.958 --> 00:22:22.958
I'm going to ask you to take the photos

00:22:22.958 --> 00:22:25.958
and paste them.

00:22:25.958 --> 00:22:27.958
So now my wish is:

00:22:27.958 --> 00:22:29.958
(mock drum roll)

00:22:29.958 --> 00:22:31.958
(Laughter)

00:22:32.958 --> 00:22:35.958
I wish for you to stand up

00:22:35.958 --> 00:22:38.958
for what you care about

00:22:38.958 --> 00:22:41.958
by participating in a global art project,

00:22:41.958 --> 00:22:46.958
and together we'll turn the world inside out.

00:22:47.958 --> 00:22:49.958
And this starts right now.

00:22:49.958 --> 00:22:51.958
Yes, everyone in the room.

00:22:51.958 --> 00:22:54.958
Everyone watching.

00:22:54.958 --> 00:22:56.958
I wanted that wish

00:22:56.958 --> 00:22:58.958
to actually start now.

00:22:58.958 --> 00:23:01.958
So a subject you're passionate about, a person who you want to tell their story

00:23:01.958 --> 00:23:03.958
or even your own photos --

00:23:03.958 --> 00:23:05.958
tell me what you stand for.

00:23:05.958 --> 00:23:07.958
Take the photos, the portraits,

00:23:07.958 --> 00:23:10.958
upload it -- I'll give you all the details --

00:23:10.958 --> 00:23:13.958
and I'll send you back your poster. Join by groups

00:23:13.958 --> 00:23:16.958
and reveal things to the world.

00:23:16.958 --> 00:23:19.958
The full data is on the website --

00:23:19.958 --> 00:23:21.958
insideoutproject.net --

00:23:21.958 --> 00:23:24.958
that is launching today.

00:23:24.958 --> 00:23:26.958
What we see changes who we are.

00:23:26.958 --> 00:23:28.958
When we act together,

00:23:28.958 --> 00:23:31.958
the whole thing is much more than the sum of the parts.

00:23:32.958 --> 00:23:34.958
So I hope that, together, we'll create something
