00:06:02.035 --> 00:06:04.161
Then I started getting
letters from teachers,

00:06:04.185 --> 00:06:06.010
and the teachers would write, saying,

00:06:06.034 --> 00:06:08.255
"We've used your videos
to flip the classroom.

00:06:08.279 --> 00:06:10.856
You've given the lectures,
so now what we do --"

00:06:10.880 --> 00:06:14.418
And this could happen in every classroom
in America tomorrow --

00:06:14.442 --> 00:06:17.696
"what I do is I assign
the lectures for homework,

00:06:17.720 --> 00:06:19.743
and what used to be homework,

00:06:19.767 --> 00:06:22.719
I now have the students
doing in the classroom."

00:06:22.743 --> 00:06:25.211
And I want to pause here --

00:06:25.235 --> 00:06:29.828
(Applause)

00:06:29.852 --> 00:06:33.149
I want to pause here, because there's
a couple of interesting things.

00:06:33.173 --> 00:06:35.374
One, when those teachers are doing that,

00:06:35.398 --> 00:06:36.934
there's the obvious benefit --

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.458
the benefit that now their students

00:06:39.482 --> 00:06:42.004
can enjoy the videos in the way
that my cousins did,

00:06:42.028 --> 00:06:45.434
they can pause, repeat at their
own pace, at their own time.

00:06:45.458 --> 00:06:48.639
But the more interesting thing --
and this is the unintuitive thing

00:06:48.663 --> 00:06:51.041
when you talk about technology
in the classroom --

00:06:51.065 --> 00:06:53.951
by removing the one-size-fits-all
lecture from the classroom,

00:06:53.975 --> 00:06:56.975
and letting students have
a self-paced lecture at home,

00:06:56.999 --> 00:06:58.650
then when you go to the classroom,

00:06:58.674 --> 00:07:01.174
letting them do work,
having the teacher walk around,

00:07:01.198 --> 00:07:04.284
having the peers actually be able
to interact with each other,

00:07:04.308 --> 00:07:09.942
these teachers have used technology
to humanize the classroom.

00:07:09.966 --> 00:07:12.428
They took a fundamentally
dehumanizing experience --

00:07:12.452 --> 00:07:14.943
30 kids with their fingers on their lips,

00:07:14.967 --> 00:07:16.921
not allowed to interact with each other.

00:07:16.945 --> 00:07:18.437
A teacher, no matter how good,

00:07:18.461 --> 00:07:21.770
has to give this one-size-fits-all
lecture to 30 students --

00:07:21.794 --> 00:07:24.157
blank faces, slightly antagonistic --

00:07:24.181 --> 00:07:25.752
and now it's a human experience,

00:07:25.776 --> 00:07:28.085
now they're actually
interacting with each other.

00:07:28.109 --> 00:07:30.894
So once the Khan Academy --

00:07:30.918 --> 00:07:32.070
I quit my job,

00:07:32.094 --> 00:07:34.538
and we turned into a real organization --

00:07:34.562 --> 00:07:36.355
we're a not-for-profit --

00:07:36.379 --> 00:07:39.473
the question is, how do we take this
to the next level?

00:07:39.497 --> 00:07:43.005
How do we take what those teachers
were doing to its natural conclusion?

00:07:43.029 --> 00:07:44.934
And so, what I'm showing over here,

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:47.592
these are actual exercises

00:07:47.616 --> 00:07:49.934
that I started writing for my cousins.

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:52.054
The ones I started
were much more primitive.

00:07:52.078 --> 00:07:55.448
This is a more competent version of it.

00:07:55.472 --> 00:07:58.861
But the paradigm here is, we'll generate
as many questions as you need,

00:07:58.885 --> 00:08:01.934
until you get that concept,
until you get 10 in a row.

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.934
And the Khan Academy videos are there.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:06.291
You get hints, the actual
steps for that problem,

00:08:06.315 --> 00:08:08.272
if you don't know how to do it.

00:08:08.296 --> 00:08:10.606
The paradigm here seems
like a very simple thing:

00:08:10.630 --> 00:08:11.828
10 in a row, you move on.

00:08:11.852 --> 00:08:13.432
But it's fundamentally different

00:08:13.456 --> 00:08:15.743
than what's happening
in classrooms right now.

00:08:15.767 --> 00:08:17.669
In a traditional classroom,

00:08:17.693 --> 00:08:20.934
you have homework, lecture,
homework, lecture,

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.797
and then you have a snapshot exam.

00:08:22.821 --> 00:08:26.478
And that exam, whether you get
a 70 percent, an 80 percent,

00:08:26.502 --> 00:08:27.947
a 90 percent or a 95 percent,

00:08:27.971 --> 00:08:30.414
the class moves on to the next topic.

00:08:30.438 --> 00:08:32.183
And even that 95 percent student --

00:08:32.207 --> 00:08:34.216
what was the five percent
they didn't know?

00:08:34.240 --> 00:08:38.061
Maybe they didn't know what happens when
you raise something to the zeroth power.

00:08:38.085 --> 00:08:40.334
Then you build on that
in the next concept.

00:08:40.358 --> 00:08:43.698
That's analogous to --
imagine learning to ride a bicycle.

00:08:43.722 --> 00:08:46.591
Maybe I give you a lecture ahead of time,

00:08:46.615 --> 00:08:50.528
and I give you a bicycle for two weeks,
then I come back after two weeks,

00:08:50.552 --> 00:08:53.702
and say, "Well, let's see.
You're having trouble taking left turns.

00:08:53.726 --> 00:08:56.963
You can't quite stop.
You're an 80 percent bicyclist."

00:08:56.987 --> 00:08:59.409
So I put a big "C" stamp
on your forehead --

00:08:59.433 --> 00:09:00.495
(Laughter)

00:09:00.519 --> 00:09:02.281
and then I say, "Here's a unicycle."

00:09:02.305 --> 00:09:03.399
(Laughter)

00:09:03.423 --> 00:09:05.258
But as ridiculous as that sounds,

00:09:05.282 --> 00:09:08.934
that's exactly what's happening
in our classrooms right now.

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:11.567
And the idea is you fast forward

00:09:11.591 --> 00:09:14.577
and good students start failing
algebra all of the sudden,

00:09:14.601 --> 00:09:16.905
and start failing
calculus all of the sudden,

00:09:16.929 --> 00:09:19.287
despite being smart,
despite having good teachers,

00:09:19.311 --> 00:09:22.055
and it's usually because they have
these Swiss cheese gaps

00:09:22.079 --> 00:09:24.288
that kept building
throughout their foundation.

00:09:24.312 --> 00:09:27.890
So our model is: learn math
the way you'd learn anything,

00:09:27.914 --> 00:09:29.260
like riding a bicycle.

00:09:29.284 --> 00:09:32.355
Stay on that bicycle.
Fall off that bicycle.

00:09:32.379 --> 00:09:35.410
Do it as long as necessary,
until you have mastery.

00:09:35.434 --> 00:09:36.934
The traditional model,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.530
it penalizes you
for experimentation and failure,

00:09:39.554 --> 00:09:41.577
but it does not expect mastery.

00:09:41.601 --> 00:09:44.665
We encourage you to experiment.
We encourage you to fail.

00:09:44.689 --> 00:09:46.339
But we do expect mastery.

00:09:47.879 --> 00:09:49.799
This is just another one of the modules.

00:09:49.823 --> 00:09:51.243
This is trigonometry.

00:09:51.267 --> 00:09:53.782
This is shifting and reflecting functions.

00:09:54.529 --> 00:09:55.933
And they all fit together.

00:09:55.957 --> 00:09:57.915
We have about 90 of these right now.

00:09:57.939 --> 00:09:59.548
You can go to the site right now,

00:09:59.572 --> 00:10:01.644
it's all free,
not trying to sell anything.

00:10:01.668 --> 00:10:04.808
But the general idea is that they all
fit into this knowledge map.

00:10:04.832 --> 00:10:07.951
That top node right there,
that's literally single-digit addition,

00:10:07.975 --> 00:10:10.250
it's like one plus one is equal to two.

00:10:10.274 --> 00:10:12.626
The paradigm is, once you get
10 in a row on that,

00:10:12.650 --> 00:10:15.833
it keeps forwarding you
to more and more advanced modules.

00:10:15.857 --> 00:10:18.936
Further down the knowledge map,

00:10:18.960 --> 00:10:21.207
we're getting into more
advanced arithmetic.

00:10:21.231 --> 00:10:24.404
Further down, you start getting
into pre-algebra and early algebra.

00:10:24.428 --> 00:10:28.171
Further down, you start getting
into algebra one, algebra two,

00:10:28.195 --> 00:10:29.727
a little bit of precalculus.

00:10:30.100 --> 00:10:33.297
And the idea is, from this we can
actually teach everything --

00:10:33.321 --> 00:10:37.163
well, everything that can be taught
in this type of a framework.

00:10:37.187 --> 00:10:39.996
So you can imagine -- and this
is what we are working on --

00:10:40.020 --> 00:10:43.583
from this knowledge map, you have
logic, you have computer programming,

00:10:43.607 --> 00:10:46.107
you have grammar, you have genetics,

00:10:46.131 --> 00:10:49.290
all based off of that core of,
if you know this and that,

00:10:49.314 --> 00:10:51.654
now you're ready for this next concept.

00:10:52.567 --> 00:10:54.869
Now that can work well
for an individual learner,

00:10:54.893 --> 00:10:57.025
and I encourage you
to do it with your kids,

00:10:57.049 --> 00:11:00.088
but I also encourage everyone
in the audience to do it yourself.

00:11:00.112 --> 00:11:02.314
It'll change what happens
at the dinner table.

00:11:02.338 --> 00:11:03.494
But what we want to do

00:11:03.518 --> 00:11:06.596
is use the natural conclusion
of the flipping of the classroom

00:11:06.620 --> 00:11:08.993
that those early teachers
had emailed me about.

00:11:09.017 --> 00:11:10.610
And so what I'm showing you here,

00:11:10.634 --> 00:11:13.522
this is data from a pilot
in the Los Altos school district,

00:11:13.546 --> 00:11:16.862
where they took two fifth-grade classes
and two seventh-grade classes,

00:11:16.886 --> 00:11:19.137
and completely gutted
their old math curriculum.

00:11:19.161 --> 00:11:22.596
These kids aren't using textbooks,
or getting one-size-fits-all lectures.

00:11:22.620 --> 00:11:26.613
They're doing Khan Academy, that software,
for roughly half of their math class.

00:11:26.637 --> 00:11:29.844
I want to be clear: we don't view this
as a complete math education.

00:11:29.868 --> 00:11:32.766
What it does is -- this is
what's happening in Los Altos --

00:11:32.790 --> 00:11:35.191
it frees up time --
it's the blocking and tackling,

00:11:35.215 --> 00:11:38.191
making sure you know how to move
through a system of equations,

00:11:38.215 --> 00:11:40.850
and it frees up time
for the simulations, for the games,

00:11:40.874 --> 00:11:42.890
for the mechanics, for the robot-building,

00:11:42.914 --> 00:11:45.796
for the estimating how high
that hill is based on its shadow.

00:11:45.820 --> 00:11:48.376
And so the paradigm is
the teacher walks in every day,

00:11:48.400 --> 00:11:50.178
every kid works at their own pace --

00:11:50.202 --> 00:11:53.733
this is actually a live dashboard
from the Los Altos school district --

00:11:53.757 --> 00:11:55.328
and they look at this dashboard.

00:11:55.352 --> 00:11:57.042
Every row is a student.

00:11:57.066 --> 00:11:58.934
Every column is one of those concepts.

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:01.101
Green means the student's
already proficient.

00:12:01.125 --> 00:12:03.649
Blue means they're working
on it -- no need to worry.

00:12:03.673 --> 00:12:04.934
Red means they're stuck.

00:12:05.386 --> 00:12:08.631
And what the teacher does
is literally just say,

00:12:08.655 --> 00:12:10.330
"Let me intervene on the red kids."

00:12:10.354 --> 00:12:12.719
Or even better, "Let me get
one of the green kids,

00:12:12.743 --> 00:12:14.789
who are already proficient
in that concept,

00:12:14.813 --> 00:12:18.326
to be the first line of attack,
and actually tutor their peer."

00:12:19.958 --> 00:12:25.559
(Applause)

00:12:25.583 --> 00:12:28.934
Now, I come from a very
data-centric reality,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.697
so we don't want that teacher
to even go and intervene

00:12:31.721 --> 00:12:33.767
and have to ask the kid awkward questions:

00:12:33.791 --> 00:12:37.101
"What don't you understand? What do
you understand?" and all the rest.

00:12:37.125 --> 00:12:40.360
So our paradigm is to arm teachers
with as much data as possible --

00:12:40.384 --> 00:12:42.434
data that, in any other
field, is expected,

00:12:42.458 --> 00:12:44.497
in finance, marketing, manufacturing --

00:12:44.521 --> 00:12:47.318
so the teachers can diagnose
what's wrong with the students

00:12:47.342 --> 00:12:50.230
so they can make their interaction
as productive as possible.

00:12:50.254 --> 00:12:53.088
Now teachers know exactly
what the students have been up to,

00:12:53.112 --> 00:12:55.997
how long they've spent each day,
what videos they've watched,

00:12:56.021 --> 00:12:58.855
when did they pause the videos,
what did they stop watching,

00:12:58.879 --> 00:13:01.602
what exercises are they using,
what have they focused on?

00:13:01.626 --> 00:13:04.499
The outer circle shows
what exercises they were focused on.

00:13:04.523 --> 00:13:07.228
The inner circle shows
the videos they're focused on.

00:13:07.839 --> 00:13:09.276
The data gets pretty granular,

00:13:09.300 --> 00:13:12.387
so you can see the exact problems
the student got right or wrong.

00:13:12.411 --> 00:13:14.140
Red is wrong, blue is right.

00:13:14.164 --> 00:13:17.138
The leftmost question is the first one
the student attempted.

00:13:17.162 --> 00:13:18.804
They watched the video over there.

00:13:18.828 --> 00:13:21.772
And you can see, eventually
they were able to get 10 in a row.

00:13:21.796 --> 00:13:25.151
It's almost like you can see them
learning over those last 10 problems.

00:13:25.175 --> 00:13:28.262
They also got faster -- the height
is how long it took them.

00:13:30.179 --> 00:13:34.678
When you talk about self-paced learning,
it makes sense for everyone --

00:13:34.702 --> 00:13:37.123
in education-speak,
"differentiated learning" --

00:13:37.147 --> 00:13:40.829
but it's kind of crazy, what happens
when you see it in a classroom.

00:13:40.853 --> 00:13:45.297
Because every time we've done this,
in every classroom we've done,

00:13:45.321 --> 00:13:47.645
over and over again,
if you go five days into it,

00:13:47.669 --> 00:13:49.682
there's a group of kids who've raced ahead

00:13:49.706 --> 00:13:51.619
and a group who are a little bit slower.

00:13:51.643 --> 00:13:54.046
In a traditional model,
in a snapshot assessment,

00:13:54.070 --> 00:13:56.982
you say, "These are the gifted kids,
these are the slow kids.

00:13:57.006 --> 00:13:58.974
Maybe they should be tracked differently.

00:13:58.998 --> 00:14:01.228
Maybe we should put them
in different classes."

00:14:01.252 --> 00:14:03.656
But when you let students
work at their own pace --

00:14:03.680 --> 00:14:05.281
we see it over and over again --

00:14:05.305 --> 00:14:07.730
you see students who took
a little bit extra time

00:14:07.754 --> 00:14:09.605
on one concept or the other,

00:14:09.629 --> 00:14:11.825
but once they get through that concept,

00:14:11.849 --> 00:14:13.197
they just race ahead.

00:14:13.221 --> 00:14:16.593
And so the same kids that you
thought were slow six weeks ago,

00:14:16.617 --> 00:14:18.276
you now would think are gifted.

00:14:18.300 --> 00:14:20.292
And we're seeing it over and over again.

00:14:20.316 --> 00:14:22.101
It makes you really wonder

00:14:22.125 --> 00:14:25.424
how much all of the labels maybe
a lot of us have benefited from

00:14:25.448 --> 00:14:28.030
were really just due
to a coincidence of time.

00:14:31.185 --> 00:14:36.217
Now as valuable as something like this is
in a district like Los Altos,

00:14:36.241 --> 00:14:37.934
our goal is to use technology

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.934
to humanize, not just in Los Altos,
but on a global scale,

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:43.461
what's happening in education.

00:14:43.485 --> 00:14:45.786
And that brings up an interesting point.

00:14:45.810 --> 00:14:48.540
A lot of the effort
in humanizing the classroom

00:14:48.564 --> 00:14:51.484
is focused on student-to-teacher ratios.

00:14:51.508 --> 00:14:54.007
In our mind, the relevant metric is:

00:14:54.031 --> 00:14:57.933
student-to-valuable-human-time-
with-the-teacher ratio.

00:14:57.957 --> 00:15:00.482
So in a traditional model,
most of the teacher's time

00:15:00.506 --> 00:15:02.878
is spent doing lectures
and grading and whatnot.

00:15:02.902 --> 00:15:05.798
Maybe five percent of their time
is sitting next to students

00:15:05.822 --> 00:15:06.982
and working with them.

00:15:07.006 --> 00:15:09.013
Now, 100 percent of their time is.

00:15:09.037 --> 00:15:12.307
So once again, using technology,
not just flipping the classroom,

00:15:12.331 --> 00:15:14.689
you're humanizing
the classroom, I'd argue,

00:15:14.713 --> 00:15:16.727
by a factor of five or 10.

00:15:17.354 --> 00:15:19.084
As valuable as that is in Los Altos,

00:15:19.108 --> 00:15:21.149
imagine what it does to the adult learner,

00:15:21.173 --> 00:15:23.236
who's embarrassed to go back
and learn stuff

00:15:23.260 --> 00:15:25.712
they should have known
before going back to college.

00:15:25.736 --> 00:15:31.669
Imagine what it does
to a street kid in Calcutta,

00:15:31.693 --> 00:15:34.435
who has to help his family during the day,

00:15:34.459 --> 00:15:36.865
and that's the reason
he or she can't go to school.

00:15:36.889 --> 00:15:39.372
Now they can spend two hours
a day and remediate,

00:15:39.396 --> 00:15:41.721
or get up to speed
and not feel embarrassed

00:15:41.745 --> 00:15:43.934
about what they do or don't know.

00:15:44.364 --> 00:15:45.992
Now imagine what happens where --

00:15:46.016 --> 00:15:48.927
we talked about the peers
teaching each other

00:15:48.951 --> 00:15:50.760
inside of a classroom.

00:15:50.784 --> 00:15:52.514
But this is all one system.

00:15:52.538 --> 00:15:55.840
There's no reason why you can't
have that peer-to-peer tutoring

00:15:55.864 --> 00:15:57.934
beyond that one classroom.

00:15:57.958 --> 00:16:00.934
Imagine what happens
if that student in Calcutta

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.126
all of the sudden can tutor your son,

00:16:03.150 --> 00:16:05.611
or your son can tutor
that kid in Calcutta.

00:16:06.079 --> 00:16:07.934
And I think what you'll see emerging

00:16:07.958 --> 00:16:13.861
is this notion of a global
one-world classroom.

00:16:14.560 --> 00:16:17.934
And that's essentially
what we're trying to build.

00:16:18.520 --> 00:16:19.672
Thank you.

00:16:19.696 --> 00:16:26.607
(Applause)

00:16:27.918 --> 00:16:30.354
Bill Gates: I'll ask about two
or three questions.

00:16:30.378 --> 00:16:32.100
Salman Khan: Oh, OK.

00:16:32.124 --> 00:16:33.457
(Applause continues)

00:16:59.669 --> 00:17:01.018
(Applause ends)

00:17:01.042 --> 00:17:03.978
BG: I've seen some things
you're doing in the system,

00:17:04.002 --> 00:17:06.439
that have to do with motivation
and feedback --

00:17:06.463 --> 00:17:08.934
energy points, merit badges.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.989
Tell me what you're thinking there.

00:17:11.013 --> 00:17:13.609
SK: Oh yeah. No, we have
an awesome team working on it.

00:17:13.633 --> 00:17:15.736
I have to be clear,
it's not just me anymore.

00:17:15.760 --> 00:17:17.245
I'm still doing all the videos,

00:17:17.269 --> 00:17:19.571
but we have a rock-star team
doing the software.

00:17:19.595 --> 00:17:22.754
We've put a bunch of game mechanics
in there, where you get badges,

00:17:22.778 --> 00:17:26.037
we're going to start having leader boards
by area, you get points.

00:17:26.061 --> 00:17:27.887
It's actually been pretty interesting.

00:17:27.911 --> 00:17:29.470
Just the wording of the badging,

00:17:29.494 --> 00:17:31.701
or how many points you get
for doing something,

00:17:31.725 --> 00:17:33.362
we see on a system-wide basis,

00:17:33.386 --> 00:17:36.024
like tens of thousands
of fifth-graders or sixth-graders

00:17:36.048 --> 00:17:39.223
going one direction or another,
depending what badge you give them.

00:17:39.247 --> 00:17:41.310
(Laughter)

00:17:41.334 --> 00:17:43.934
BG: And the collaboration
you're doing with Los Altos,

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.135
how did that come about?

00:17:46.159 --> 00:17:49.198
SK: Los Altos, it was kind of crazy.

00:17:49.222 --> 00:17:52.031
Once again, I didn't expect it
to be used in classrooms.

00:17:52.055 --> 00:17:53.934
Someone from their board came and said,

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:56.785
"What would you do if you had
carte Blanche in a classroom?"

00:17:56.809 --> 00:17:59.825
I said, "Well, every student
would work at their own pace,

00:17:59.849 --> 00:18:02.046
on something like this,
we'd give a dashboard."

00:18:02.070 --> 00:18:05.269
They said, "This is kind of radical.
We have to think about it."

00:18:05.293 --> 00:18:09.095
Me and the rest of the team were like,
"They're never going to want to do this."

00:18:09.119 --> 00:18:12.540
But literally the next day they were like,
"Can you start in two weeks?"

00:18:12.564 --> 00:18:14.015
(Laughter)

00:18:14.039 --> 00:18:16.936
BG: So fifth-grade math
is where that's going on right now?

00:18:16.960 --> 00:18:19.959
SK: It's two fifth-grade classes
and two seventh-grade classes.

00:18:19.983 --> 00:18:21.849
They're doing it at the district level.

00:18:21.873 --> 00:18:24.945
I think what they're excited about
is they can follow these kids,

00:18:24.969 --> 00:18:28.382
not only in school; on Christmas,
we saw some of the kids were doing it.

00:18:28.406 --> 00:18:31.934
We can track everything, track them
as they go through the entire district.

00:18:31.958 --> 00:18:34.886
Through the summers, as they go
from one teacher to the next,

00:18:34.910 --> 00:18:38.710
you have this continuity of data that
even at the district level, they can see.

00:18:38.734 --> 00:18:41.934
BG: So some of those views we saw
were for the teacher

00:18:41.958 --> 00:18:45.649
to go in and track actually
what's going on with those kids.

00:18:45.673 --> 00:18:47.999
So you're getting feedback
on those teacher views

00:18:48.023 --> 00:18:49.736
to see what they think they need?

00:18:49.760 --> 00:18:54.116
SK: Oh yeah. Most of those
were specs by the teachers.

00:18:54.140 --> 00:18:57.150
We made some of those for students
so they could see their data,

00:18:57.174 --> 00:19:00.286
but we have a very tight design loop
with the teachers themselves.

00:19:00.310 --> 00:19:02.534
And they're saying,
"Hey, this is nice, but --"

00:19:02.558 --> 00:19:04.947
Like that focus graph,
a lot of the teachers said,

00:19:04.971 --> 00:19:07.511
"I have a feeling a lot of the kids
are jumping around

00:19:07.535 --> 00:19:09.137
and not focusing on one topic."

00:19:09.161 --> 00:19:10.634
So we made that focus diagram.

00:19:10.658 --> 00:19:13.298
So it's all been teacher-driven.
It's been pretty crazy.

00:19:13.322 --> 00:19:14.895
BG: Is this ready for prime time?

00:19:14.919 --> 00:19:19.273
Do you think a lot of classes next school
year should try this thing out?

00:19:19.297 --> 00:19:20.455
SK: Yeah, it's ready.

00:19:20.479 --> 00:19:23.197
We've got a million people
on the site already,

00:19:23.221 --> 00:19:26.153
so we can handle a few more.

00:19:26.177 --> 00:19:27.934
(Laughter)

00:19:27.958 --> 00:19:29.934
No, no reason why it really can't happen

00:19:29.958 --> 00:19:32.568
in every classroom in America tomorrow.

00:19:32.592 --> 00:19:35.072
BG: And the vision of the tutoring thing.

00:19:35.096 --> 00:19:37.934
The idea there is,
if I'm confused about a topic,

00:19:37.958 --> 00:19:40.110
somehow right in the user interface,

00:19:40.134 --> 00:19:42.270
I'd find people who are volunteering,

00:19:42.294 --> 00:19:44.032
maybe see their reputation,

00:19:44.056 --> 00:19:47.233
and I could schedule and connect up
with those people?

00:19:47.257 --> 00:19:51.006

I recommend everyone in this audience do.

00:19:51.030 --> 00:19:54.092
Those dashboards the teachers have,
you can go log in right now

00:19:54.116 --> 00:19:55.934
and you can essentially become a coach

00:19:55.958 --> 00:19:58.934
for your kids, your nephews, your cousins,

00:19:58.958 --> 00:20:01.787
or maybe some kids
at the Boys and Girls Club.

00:20:01.811 --> 00:20:04.343
And yeah, you can start
becoming a mentor, a tutor,

00:20:04.367 --> 00:20:05.839
really immediately.

00:20:05.863 --> 00:20:07.256
But yeah, it's all there.

00:20:07.848 --> 00:20:09.006
BG: Well, it's amazing.

00:20:09.030 --> 00:20:12.092
I think you just got a glimpse
of the future of education.

00:20:12.116 --> 00:20:13.934
BG: Thank you.
SK: Thank you.

title: The birth of a word
transcript: Imagine if you could record your life — everything you said, everything you did, available in a perfect memory store at your fingertips, so you could go back and find memorable moments and relive them, or sift through traces of time and discover patterns in your own life that previously had gone undiscovered. Well that's exactly the journey that my family began five and a half years ago. This is my wife and collaborator, Rupal. And on this day, at this moment, we walked into the house with our first child, our beautiful baby boy. And we walked into a house with a very special home video recording system.(Video) Man: Okay.Deb Roy: This moment and thousands of other moments special for us were captured in our home because in every room in the house, if you looked up, you'd see a camera and a microphone, and if you looked down, you'd get this bird's-eye view of the room. Here's our living room, the baby bedroom, kitchen, dining room and the rest of the house. And all of these fed into a disc array that was designed for a continuous capture. So here we are flying through a day in our home as we move from sunlit morning through incandescent evening and, finally, lights out for the day. Over the course of three years, we recorded eight to 10 hours a day, amassing roughly a quarter-million hours of multi-track audio and video.So you're looking at a piece of what is by far the largest home video collection ever made. (Laughter) And what this data represents for our family at a personal level, the impact has already been immense, and we're still learning its value. Countless moments of unsolicited natural moments, not posed moments, are captured there, and we're starting to learn how to discover them and find them.But there's also a scientific reason that drove this project, which was to use this natural longitudinal data to understand the process of how a child learns language — that child being my son. And so with many privacy provisions put in place to protect everyone who was recorded in the data, we made elements of the data available to my trusted research team at MIT so we could start teasing apart patterns in this massive data set, trying to understand the influence of social environments on language acquisition. So we're looking here at one of the first things we started to do. This is my wife and I cooking breakfast in the kitchen, and as we move through space and through time, a very everyday pattern of life in the kitchen.In order to convert this opaque, 90,000 hours of video into something that we could start to see, we use motion analysis to pull out, as we move through space and through time, what we call space-time worms. And this has become part of our toolkit for being able to look and see where the activities are in the data, and with it, trace the pattern of, in particular, where my son moved throughout the home, so that we could focus our transcription efforts, all of the speech environment around my son — all of the words that he heard from myself, my wife, our nanny, and over time, the words he began to produce. So with that technology and that data and the ability to, with machine assistance, transcribe speech, we've now transcribed well over seven million words of our home transcripts. And with that, let me take you now for a first tour into the data.So you've all, I'm sure, seen time-lapse videos where a flower will blossom as you accelerate time. I'd like you to now experience the blossoming of a speech form. My son, soon after his first birthday, would say "gaga" to mean water. And over the course of the next half-year, he slowly learned to approximate the proper adult form, "water." So we're going to cruise through half a year in about 40 seconds. No video here, so you can focus on the sound, the acoustics, of a new kind of trajectory: gaga to water.(Audio) Baby: Gagagagagaga Gaga gaga gaga guga guga guga wada gaga gaga guga gaga wader guga guga water water water water water water water water water.DR: He sure nailed it, didn't he.(Applause)So he didn't just learn water. Over the course of the 24 months, the first two years that we really focused on, this is a map of every word he learned in chronological order. And because we have full transcripts, we've identified each of the 503 words that he learned to produce by his second birthday. He was an early talker. And so we started to analyze why. Why were certain words born before others? This is one of the first results that came out of our study a little over a year ago that really surprised us. The way to interpret this apparently simple graph is, on the vertical is an indication of how complex caregiver utterances are based on the length of utterances. And the [horizontal] axis is time.And all of the data, we aligned based on the following idea: Every time my son would learn a word, we would trace back and look at all of the language he heard that contained that word. And we would plot the relative length of the utterances. And what we found was this curious phenomena, that caregiver speech would systematically dip to a minimum, making language as simple as possible, and then slowly ascend back up in complexity. And the amazing thing was that bounce, that dip, lined up almost precisely with when each word was born — word after word, systematically. So it appears that all three primary caregivers — myself, my wife and our nanny — were systematically and, I would think, subconsciously restructuring our language to meet him at the birth of a word and bring him gently into more complex language. And the implications of this — there are many, but one I just want to point out, is that there must be amazing feedback loops. Of course, my son is learning from his linguistic environment, but the environment is learning from him. That environment, people, are in these tight feedback loops and creating a kind of scaffolding that has not been noticed until now.But that's looking at the speech context. What about the visual context? We're not looking at — think of this as a dollhouse cutaway of our house. We've taken those circular fish-eye lens cameras, and we've done some optical correction, and then we can bring it into three-dimensional life. So welcome to my home. This is a moment, one moment captured across multiple cameras. The reason we did this is to create the ultimate memory machine, where you can go back and interactively fly around and then breathe video-life into this system. What I'm going to do is give you an accelerated view of 30 minutes, again, of just life in the living room. That's me and my son on the floor. And there's video analytics that are tracking our movements. My son is leaving red ink. I am leaving green ink. We're now on the couch, looking out through the window at cars passing by. And finally, my son playing in a walking toy by himself.Now we freeze the action, 30 minutes, we turn time into the vertical axis, and we open up for a view of these interaction traces we've just left behind. And we see these amazing structures — these little knots of two colors of thread we call "social hot spots." The spiral thread we call a "solo hot spot." And we think that these affect the way language is learned. What we'd like to do is start understanding the interaction between these patterns and the language that my son is exposed to to see if we can predict how the structure of when words are heard affects when they're learned — so in other words, the relationship between words and what they're about in the world.So here's how we're approaching this. In this video, again, my son is being traced out. He's leaving red ink behind. And there's our nanny by the door.(Video) Nanny: You want water? (Baby: Aaaa.) Nanny: All right. (Baby: Aaaa.)DR: She offers water, and off go the two worms over to the kitchen to get water. And what we've done is use the word "water" to tag that moment, that bit of activity. And now we take the power of data and take every time my son ever heard the word water and the context he saw it in, and we use it to penetrate through the video and find every activity trace that co-occurred with an instance of water. And what this data leaves in its wake is a landscape. We call these wordscapes. This is the wordscape for the word water, and you can see most of the action is in the kitchen. That's where those big peaks are over to the left. And just for contrast, we can do this with any word. We can take the word "bye" as in "good bye." And we're now zoomed in over the entrance to the house. And we look, and we find, as you would expect, a contrast in the landscape where the word "bye" occurs much more in a structured way. So we're using these structures to start predicting the order of language acquisition, and that's ongoing work now.In my lab, which we're peering into now, at MIT — this is at the media lab. This has become my favorite way of videographing just about any space. Three of the key people in this project, Philip DeCamp, Rony Kubat and Brandon Roy are pictured here. Philip has been a close collaborator on all the visualizations you're seeing. And Michael Fleischman was another Ph.D. student in my lab who worked with me on this home video analysis, and he made the following observation: that "just the way that we're analyzing how language connects to events which provide common ground for language, that same idea we can take out of your home, Deb, and we can apply it to the world of public media." And so our effort took an unexpected turn.Think of mass media as providing common ground and you have the recipe for taking this idea to a whole new place. We've started analyzing television content using the same principles — analyzing event structure of a TV signal — episodes of shows, commercials, all of the components that make up the event structure. And we're now, with satellite dishes, pulling and analyzing a good part of all the TV being watched in the United States. And you don't have to now go and instrument living rooms with microphones to get people's conversations, you just tune into publicly available social media feeds.So we're pulling in about three billion comments a month, and then the magic happens. You have the event structure, the common ground that the words are about, coming out of the television feeds; you've got the conversations that are about those topics; and through semantic analysis — and this is actually real data you're looking at from our data processing — each yellow line is showing a link being made between a comment in the wild and a piece of event structure coming out of the television signal. And the same idea now can be built up. And we get this wordscape, except now words are not assembled in my living room. Instead, the context, the common ground activities, are the content on television that's driving the conversations. And what we're seeing here, these skyscrapers now, are commentary that are linked to content on television. Same concept, but looking at communication dynamics in a very different sphere.And so fundamentally, rather than, for example, measuring content based on how many people are watching, this gives us the basic data for looking at engagement properties of content. And just like we can look at feedback cycles and dynamics in a family, we can now open up the same concepts and look at much larger groups of people. This is a subset of data from our database — just 50,000 out of several million — and the social graph that connects them through publicly available sources. And if you put them on one plain, a second plain is where the content lives. So we have the programs and the sporting events and the commercials, and all of the link structures that tie them together make a content graph. And then the important third dimension. Each of the links that you're seeing rendered here is an actual connection made between something someone said and a piece of content. And there are, again, now tens of millions of these links that give us the connective tissue of social graphs and how they relate to content. And we can now start to probe the structure in interesting ways.So if we, for example, trace the path of one piece of content that drives someone to comment on it, and then we follow where that comment goes, and then look at the entire social graph that becomes activated and then trace back to see the relationship between that social graph and content, a very interesting structure becomes visible. We call this a co-viewing clique, a virtual living room if you will. And there are fascinating dynamics at play. It's not one way. A piece of content, an event, causes someone to talk. They talk to other people. That drives tune-in behavior back into mass media, and you have these cycles that drive the overall behavior.Another example — very different — another actual person in our database — and we're finding at least hundreds, if not thousands, of these. We've given this person a name. This is a pro-amateur, or pro-am media critic who has this high fan-out rate. So a lot of people are following this person — very influential — and they have a propensity to talk about what's on TV. So this person is a key link in connecting mass media and social media together.One last example from this data: Sometimes it's actually a piece of content that is special. So if we go and look at this piece of content, President Obama's State of the Union address from just a few weeks ago, and look at what we find in this same data set, at the same scale, the engagement properties of this piece of content are truly remarkable. A nation exploding in conversation in real time in response to what's on the broadcast. And of course, through all of these lines are flowing unstructured language. We can X-ray and get a real-time pulse of a nation, real-time sense of the social reactions in the different circuits in the social graph being activated by content.So, to summarize, the idea is this: As our world becomes increasingly instrumented and we have the capabilities to collect and connect the dots between what people are saying and the context they're saying it in, what's emerging is an ability to see new social structures and dynamics that have previously not been seen. It's like building a microscope or telescope and revealing new structures about our own behavior around communication. And I think the implications here are profound, whether it's for science, for commerce, for government, or perhaps most of all, for us as individuals.And so just to return to my son, when I was preparing this talk, he was looking over my shoulder, and I showed him the clips I was going to show to you today, and I asked him for permission — granted. And then I went on to reflect, "Isn't it amazing, this entire database, all these recordings, I'm going to hand off to you and to your sister" — who arrived two years later — "and you guys are going to be able to go back and re-experience moments that you could never, with your biological memory, possibly remember the way you can now?" And he was quiet for a moment. And I thought, "What am I thinking? He's five years old. He's not going to understand this." And just as I was having that thought, he looked up at me and said, "So that when I grow up, I can show this to my kids?" And I thought, "Wow, this is powerful stuff."So I want to leave you with one last memorable moment from our family. This is the first time our son took more than two steps at once — captured on film. And I really want you to focus on something as I take you through. It's a cluttered environment; it's natural life. My mother's in the kitchen, cooking, and, of all places, in the hallway, I realize he's about to do it, about to take more than two steps. And so you hear me encouraging him, realizing what's happening, and then the magic happens. Listen very carefully. About three steps in, he realizes something magic is happening, and the most amazing feedback loop of all kicks in, and he takes a breath in, and he whispers "wow" and instinctively I echo back the same. And so let's fly back in time to that memorable moment.(Video) DR: Hey. Come here. Can you do it? Oh, boy. Can you do it? Baby: Yeah. DR: Ma, he's walking.(Laughter)(Applause)DR: Thank you.(Applause)

so you can focus on the sound, the acoustics,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
of a new kind of trajectory:

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
gaga to water.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:05:04.958
(Audio) Baby: Gagagagagaga

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:08.958
Gaga gaga gaga

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:13.958
guga guga guga

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:18.958
wada gaga gaga guga gaga

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.958
wader guga guga

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:25.958
water water water

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:31.958
water water water

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:35.958
water water

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
water.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
DR: He sure nailed it, didn't he.

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:46.958
(Applause)

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
So he didn't just learn water.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
Over the course of the 24 months,

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:53.958
the first two years that we really focused on,

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:57.958
this is a map of every word he learned in chronological order.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
And because we have full transcripts,

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:02.958
we've identified each of the 503 words

00:06:02.958 --> 00:06:04.958
that he learned to produce by his second birthday.

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
He was an early talker.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
And so we started to analyze why.

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
Why were certain words born before others?

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
This is one of the first results

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.958
that came out of our study a little over a year ago

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
that really surprised us.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
The way to interpret this apparently simple graph

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
is, on the vertical is an indication

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:26.958
of how complex caregiver utterances are

00:06:26.958 --> 00:06:28.958
based on the length of utterances.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
And the [horizontal] axis is time.

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
And all of the data,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:36.958
we aligned based on the following idea:

00:06:36.958 --> 00:06:39.958
Every time my son would learn a word,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:42.958
we would trace back and look at all of the language he heard

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
that contained that word.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:48.958
And we would plot the relative length of the utterances.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:51.958
And what we found was this curious phenomena,

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:54.958
that caregiver speech would systematically dip to a minimum,

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
making language as simple as possible,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
and then slowly ascend back up in complexity.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
And the amazing thing was

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
that bounce, that dip,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:06.958
lined up almost precisely

00:07:06.958 --> 00:07:08.958
with when each word was born --

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:10.958
word after word, systematically.

00:07:10.958 --> 00:07:12.958
So it appears that all three primary caregivers --

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:15.958
myself, my wife and our nanny --

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
were systematically and, I would think, subconsciously

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
restructuring our language

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
to meet him at the birth of a word

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:27.958
and bring him gently into more complex language.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
And the implications of this -- there are many,

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
but one I just want to point out,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
is that there must be amazing feedback loops.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Of course, my son is learning

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
from his linguistic environment,

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:41.958
but the environment is learning from him.

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:44.958
That environment, people, are in these tight feedback loops

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
and creating a kind of scaffolding

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
that has not been noticed until now.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.958
But that's looking at the speech context.

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
What about the visual context?

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
We're not looking at --

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
think of this as a dollhouse cutaway of our house.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:01.958
We've taken those circular fish-eye lens cameras,

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
and we've done some optical correction,

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:07.958
and then we can bring it into three-dimensional life.

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
So welcome to my home.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
This is a moment,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
one moment captured across multiple cameras.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
The reason we did this is to create the ultimate memory machine,

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
where you can go back and interactively fly around

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
and then breathe video-life into this system.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:25.958
What I'm going to do

00:08:25.958 --> 00:08:28.958
is give you an accelerated view of 30 minutes,

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
again, of just life in the living room.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
That's me and my son on the floor.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:35.958
And there's video analytics

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:37.958
that are tracking our movements.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:40.958
My son is leaving red ink. I am leaving green ink.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
We're now on the couch,

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:45.958
looking out through the window at cars passing by.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
And finally, my son playing in a walking toy by himself.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:51.958
Now we freeze the action, 30 minutes,

00:08:51.958 --> 00:08:53.958
we turn time into the vertical axis,

00:08:53.958 --> 00:08:55.958
and we open up for a view

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
of these interaction traces we've just left behind.

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:01.958
And we see these amazing structures --

00:09:01.958 --> 00:09:04.958
these little knots of two colors of thread

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:06.958
we call "social hot spots."

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:08.958
The spiral thread

00:09:08.958 --> 00:09:10.958
we call a "solo hot spot."

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
And we think that these affect the way language is learned.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
What we'd like to do

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
is start understanding

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
the interaction between these patterns

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
and the language that my son is exposed to

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
to see if we can predict

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:25.958
how the structure of when words are heard

00:09:25.958 --> 00:09:27.958
affects when they're learned --

00:09:27.958 --> 00:09:29.958
so in other words, the relationship

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:33.958
between words and what they're about in the world.

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:35.958
So here's how we're approaching this.

00:09:35.958 --> 00:09:37.958
In this video,

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
again, my son is being traced out.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
He's leaving red ink behind.

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
And there's our nanny by the door.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:46.958
(Video) Nanny: You want water? (Baby: Aaaa.)

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:49.958
Nanny: All right. (Baby: Aaaa.)

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
DR: She offers water,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
and off go the two worms

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
over to the kitchen to get water.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:57.958
And what we've done is use the word "water"

00:09:57.958 --> 00:09:59.958
to tag that moment, that bit of activity.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
And now we take the power of data

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:04.958
and take every time my son

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
ever heard the word water

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
and the context he saw it in,

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
and we use it to penetrate through the video

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
and find every activity trace

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:17.958
that co-occurred with an instance of water.

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
And what this data leaves in its wake

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
is a landscape.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:23.958
We call these wordscapes.

00:10:23.958 --> 00:10:25.958
This is the wordscape for the word water,

00:10:25.958 --> 00:10:27.958
and you can see most of the action is in the kitchen.

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
That's where those big peaks are over to the left.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
And just for contrast, we can do this with any word.

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
We can take the word "bye"

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
as in "good bye."

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:39.958
And we're now zoomed in over the entrance to the house.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:42.958
And we look, and we find, as you would expect,

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
a contrast in the landscape

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:47.958
where the word "bye" occurs much more in a structured way.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
So we're using these structures

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
to start predicting

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
the order of language acquisition,

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
and that's ongoing work now.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
In my lab, which we're peering into now, at MIT --

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
this is at the media lab.

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
This has become my favorite way

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
of videographing just about any space.

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
Three of the key people in this project,

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
Philip DeCamp, Rony Kubat and Brandon Roy are pictured here.

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:12.958
Philip has been a close collaborator

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:14.958
on all the visualizations you're seeing.

00:11:14.958 --> 00:11:17.958
And Michael Fleischman

00:11:17.958 --> 00:11:19.958
was another Ph.D. student in my lab

00:11:19.958 --> 00:11:22.958
who worked with me on this home video analysis,

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:25.958
and he made the following observation:

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:27.958
that "just the way that we're analyzing

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:30.958
how language connects to events

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
which provide common ground for language,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:36.958
that same idea we can take out of your home, Deb,

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
and we can apply it to the world of public media."

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
And so our effort took an unexpected turn.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Think of mass media

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
as providing common ground

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
and you have the recipe

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:51.958
for taking this idea to a whole new place.

00:11:51.958 --> 00:11:54.958
We've started analyzing television content

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
using the same principles --

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
analyzing event structure of a TV signal --

00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.958
episodes of shows,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
commercials,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
all of the components that make up the event structure.

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
And we're now, with satellite dishes, pulling and analyzing

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:12.958
a good part of all the TV being watched in the United States.

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:15.958
And you don't have to now go and instrument living rooms with microphones

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:17.958
to get people's conversations,

00:12:17.958 --> 00:12:20.958
you just tune into publicly available social media feeds.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
So we're pulling in

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
about three billion comments a month,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
and then the magic happens.

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
You have the event structure,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
the common ground that the words are about,

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
coming out of the television feeds;

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
you've got the conversations

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
that are about those topics;

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
and through semantic analysis --

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
and this is actually real data you're looking at

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
from our data processing --

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:47.958
each yellow line is showing a link being made

00:12:47.958 --> 00:12:50.958
between a comment in the wild

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:53.958
and a piece of event structure coming out of the television signal.

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
And the same idea now

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
can be built up.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And we get this wordscape,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
except now words are not assembled in my living room.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:06.958
Instead, the context, the common ground activities,

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:09.958
are the content on television that's driving the conversations.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And what we're seeing here, these skyscrapers now,

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
are commentary

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
that are linked to content on television.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
Same concept,

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
but looking at communication dynamics

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
in a very different sphere.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
And so fundamentally, rather than, for example,

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
measuring content based on how many people are watching,

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
this gives us the basic data

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
for looking at engagement properties of content.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And just like we can look at feedback cycles

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:38.958
and dynamics in a family,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
we can now open up the same concepts

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:44.958
and look at much larger groups of people.

00:13:44.958 --> 00:13:47.958
This is a subset of data from our database --

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
just 50,000 out of several million --

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
and the social graph that connects them

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:55.958
through publicly available sources.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:57.958
And if you put them on one plain,

00:13:57.958 --> 00:14:00.958
a second plain is where the content lives.

00:14:00.958 --> 00:14:03.958
So we have the programs

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:05.958
and the sporting events

00:14:05.958 --> 00:14:07.958
and the commercials,

00:14:07.958 --> 00:14:09.958
and all of the link structures that tie them together

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:11.958
make a content graph.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:15.958
And then the important third dimension.

00:14:15.958 --> 00:14:17.958
Each of the links that you're seeing rendered here

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:19.958
is an actual connection made

00:14:19.958 --> 00:14:22.958
between something someone said

00:14:22.958 --> 00:14:24.958
and a piece of content.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:27.958
And there are, again, now tens of millions of these links

00:14:27.958 --> 00:14:30.958
that give us the connective tissue of social graphs

00:14:30.958 --> 00:14:33.958
and how they relate to content.

00:14:33.958 --> 00:14:35.958
And we can now start to probe the structure

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
in interesting ways.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:40.958
So if we, for example, trace the path

00:14:40.958 --> 00:14:42.958
of one piece of content

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:44.958
that drives someone to comment on it,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:47.958
and then we follow where that comment goes,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.958
and then look at the entire social graph that becomes activated

00:14:50.958 --> 00:14:53.958
and then trace back to see the relationship

00:14:53.958 --> 00:14:55.958
between that social graph and content,

00:14:55.958 --> 00:14:57.958
a very interesting structure becomes visible.

00:14:57.958 --> 00:14:59.958
We call this a co-viewing clique,

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:02.958
a virtual living room if you will.

00:15:02.958 --> 00:15:04.958
And there are fascinating dynamics at play.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
It's not one way.

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
A piece of content, an event, causes someone to talk.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
They talk to other people.

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:14.958
That drives tune-in behavior back into mass media,

00:15:14.958 --> 00:15:16.958
and you have these cycles

00:15:16.958 --> 00:15:18.958
that drive the overall behavior.

00:15:18.958 --> 00:15:20.958
Another example -- very different --

00:15:20.958 --> 00:15:23.958
another actual person in our database --

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:26.958
and we're finding at least hundreds, if not thousands, of these.

00:15:26.958 --> 00:15:28.958
We've given this person a name.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
This is a pro-amateur, or pro-am media critic

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
who has this high fan-out rate.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:37.958
So a lot of people are following this person -- very influential --

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
and they have a propensity to talk about what's on TV.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
So this person is a key link

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.958
in connecting mass media and social media together.

00:15:45.958 --> 00:15:48.958
One last example from this data:

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:51.958
Sometimes it's actually a piece of content that is special.

00:15:51.958 --> 00:15:55.958
So if we go and look at this piece of content,

00:15:55.958 --> 00:15:58.958
President Obama's State of the Union address

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.958
from just a few weeks ago,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.958
and look at what we find in this same data set,

00:16:03.958 --> 00:16:06.958
at the same scale,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
the engagement properties of this piece of content

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:10.958
are truly remarkable.

00:16:10.958 --> 00:16:12.958
A nation exploding in conversation

00:16:12.958 --> 00:16:14.958
in real time

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:17.958
in response to what's on the broadcast.

00:16:17.958 --> 00:16:19.958
And of course, through all of these lines

00:16:19.958 --> 00:16:21.958
are flowing unstructured language.

00:16:21.958 --> 00:16:23.958
We can X-ray

00:16:23.958 --> 00:16:25.958
and get a real-time pulse of a nation,

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:27.958
real-time sense

00:16:27.958 --> 00:16:30.958
of the social reactions in the different circuits in the social graph

00:16:30.958 --> 00:16:33.958
being activated by content.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:36.958
So, to summarize, the idea is this:

00:16:36.958 --> 00:16:39.958
As our world becomes increasingly instrumented

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:41.958
and we have the capabilities

00:16:41.958 --> 00:16:43.958
to collect and connect the dots

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:45.958
between what people are saying

00:16:45.958 --> 00:16:47.958
and the context they're saying it in,

00:16:47.958 --> 00:16:49.958
what's emerging is an ability

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
to see new social structures and dynamics

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:54.958
that have previously not been seen.

00:16:54.958 --> 00:16:56.958
It's like building a microscope or telescope

00:16:56.958 --> 00:16:58.958
and revealing new structures

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
about our own behavior around communication.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
And I think the implications here are profound,

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
whether it's for science,

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
for commerce, for government,

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:10.958
or perhaps most of all,

00:17:10.958 --> 00:17:13.958
for us as individuals.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
And so just to return to my son,

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:19.958
when I was preparing this talk, he was looking over my shoulder,

00:17:19.958 --> 00:17:21.958
and I showed him the clips I was going to show to you today,

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
and I asked him for permission -- granted.

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
And then I went on to reflect,

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
"Isn't it amazing,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:32.958
this entire database, all these recordings,

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
I'm going to hand off to you and to your sister" --

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:37.958
who arrived two years later --

00:17:37.958 --> 00:17:40.958
"and you guys are going to be able to go back and re-experience moments

00:17:40.958 --> 00:17:43.958

title: How to keep rivers and streams flowing
transcript: This is a river. This is a stream. This is a river. This is happening all over the country. There are tens of thousands of miles of dewatered streams in the United States. On this map, the colored areas represent water conflicts. Similar problems are emerging in the East as well. The reasons vary state to state, but mostly in the details. There are 4,000 miles of dewatered streams in Montana alone. They would ordinarily support fish and other wildlife. They're the veins of the ecosystem, and they're often empty veins.I want to tell you the story of just one of these streams, because it's an archetype for the larger story. This is Prickly Pear Creek. It runs through a populated area from East Helena to Lake Helena. It supports wild fish including cutthroat, brown and rainbow trout. Nearly every year for more than a hundred years ... it looked like this in the summer. How did we get here? Well, it started back in the late 1800s when people started settling in places like Montana. In short, there was a lot of water and there weren't very many people. But as more people showed up wanting water, the folks who were there first got a little concerned, and in 1865, Montana passed its first water law. It basically said, everybody near the stream can share in the stream. Oddly, a lot of people showed up wanting to share the stream, and the folks who were there first got concerned enough to bring out their lawyers. There were precedent-setting suits in 1870 and 1872, both involving Prickly Pear Creek. And in 1921, the Montana Supreme Court ruled in a case involving Prickly Pear that the folks who were there first had the first, or "senior water rights." These senior water rights are key.The problem is that all over the West now it looks like this. Some of these creeks have claims for 50 to 100 times more water than is actually in the stream. And the senior water rights holders, if they don't use their water right, they risk losing their water right — along with the economic value that goes with it. So they have no incentive to conserve. So it's not just about the number of people; the system itself creates a disincentive to conserve because you can lose your water right if you don't use it. So after decades of lawsuits and 140 years, now, of experience, we still have this. It's a broken system. There's a disincentive to conserve, because if you don't use your water right, you can lose your water right. And I'm sure you all know, this has created significant conflicts between the agricultural and environmental communities.OK, now I'm going to change gears here. Most of you will be happy to know that the rest of the presentation's free ...(Laughter)and some of you'll be happy to know that it involves beer.(Laughter)There's another thing happening around the country, which is that companies are starting to get concerned about their water footprint. They're concerned about securing an adequate supply of water, they're trying to be really efficient with their water use, and they're concerned about how their water use affects the image of their brand. Well, it's a national problem, but I'm going to tell you another story from Montana ... and it involves beer. I bet you didn't know, it takes about 5 pints of water to make a pint of beer. If you include all the drain, it takes more than a hundred pints of water to make a pint of beer.Now the brewers in Montana have already done a lot to reduce their water consumption, but they still use millions of gallons of water. I mean, there's water in beer. So what can they do about this remaining water footprint that can have serious effects on the ecosystem? These ecosystems are really important to the Montana brewers and their customers. After all, there's a strong correlation between water and fishing, and for some, there's a strong correlation between fishing and beer.(Laughter)So the Montana brewers and their customers are concerned and they're looking for some way to address the problem.So how can they address this remaining water footprint? Remember Prickly Pear. Up until now, business water stewardship has been limited to measuring and reducing, and we're suggesting that the next step is to restore. Remember Prickly Pear. It's a broken system. You've got a disincentive to conserve, because if you don't use your water right, you risk losing your water right. Well, we decided to connect these two worlds — the world of the companies with their water footprints and the world of the farmers with their senior water rights on these creeks. In some states, senior water rights holders can leave their water in the stream while legally protecting it from others, and maintaining their water right. After all, it is their water right, and if they want to use that water right to help the fish grow in the stream, it's their right to do so. But they have no incentive to do so.So, working with local water trusts, we created an incentive to do so. We pay them to leave their water in stream. That's what's happening here. This individual has made the choice and is closing this water diversion, leaving the water in the stream. He doesn't lose the water right, he just chooses to apply that right, or some portion of it, to the stream, instead of to the land. Because he's the senior water-rights holder, he can protect the water from other users in the stream. OK? He gets paid to leave the water in the stream.This guy's measuring the water that this leaves in the stream. We then take the measured water, we divide it into thousand-gallon increments. Each increment gets a serial number and a certificate, and then the brewers and others buy those certificates as a way to return water to these degraded ecosystems. The brewers pay to restore water to the stream. It provides a simple, inexpensive and measurable way to return water to these degraded ecosystems, while giving farmers an economic choice and giving businesses concerned about their water footprints an easy way to deal with them.After 140 years of conflict and 100 years of dry streams, a circumstance that litigation and regulation has not solved, we put together a market-based, willing buyer, willing seller solution — a solution that does not require litigation. It's about giving folks concerned about their water footprints a real opportunity to put water where it's critically needed, into these degraded ecosystems, while at the same time providing farmers a meaningful economic choice about how their water is used.These transactions create allies, not enemies. They connect people rather than dividing them. And they provide needed economic support for rural communities. And most importantly, it's working. We've returned more than four billion gallons of water to degraded ecosystems. We've connected senior water-rights holders with brewers in Montana, with hotels and tea companies in Oregon, and with high-tech companies that use a lot of water in the Southwest. And when we make these connections, we can and we do turn this ... into this.(Applause)Thank you very much.(Applause)
