00:04:54.278 --> 00:04:57.334
They are in green energy consulting,
or something like that.

00:04:57.358 --> 00:04:59.311
And they really practice what they preach

00:04:59.335 --> 00:05:02.254
because this office doesn't have
any electric lighting at all.

00:05:02.278 --> 00:05:06.534
It has only, on one side,
this big, big glass window

00:05:06.558 --> 00:05:10.134
that helps to let the sunlight
enter deep into the space

00:05:10.158 --> 00:05:13.574
and create a beautiful quality there
and a great dynamic range.

00:05:13.598 --> 00:05:16.214
So it can be very dim over there,
and you do your work,

00:05:16.238 --> 00:05:19.014
and it can be very bright over there,
and you do your work.

00:05:19.038 --> 00:05:22.934
But actually, the human eye
turns out to be remarkably adaptable

00:05:22.958 --> 00:05:26.854
to all these different light conditions
that together create an environment

00:05:26.878 --> 00:05:29.294
that is never boring
and that is never dull,

00:05:29.318 --> 00:05:31.958
and therefore helps us
to enhance our lives.

00:05:33.358 --> 00:05:36.654
I really owe a short introduction
of this man to you.

00:05:36.678 --> 00:05:40.614
This is Richard Kelly
who was born 100 years ago,

00:05:40.638 --> 00:05:44.454
which is the reason I bring him up now,
because it's kind of an anniversary year.

00:05:44.478 --> 00:05:49.574
In the 1930s, Richard Kelly
was the first person to really describe

00:05:49.598 --> 00:05:51.534
a methodology of modern lighting design.

00:05:51.558 --> 00:05:53.374
And he coined three terms,

00:05:53.398 --> 00:05:57.294
which are "focal glow,"
"ambient luminescence"

00:05:57.318 --> 00:05:58.974
and "play of the brilliants" --

00:05:58.998 --> 00:06:03.494
three very distinctly different
ideas about light in architecture

00:06:03.518 --> 00:06:07.494
that all together
make up this beautiful experience.

00:06:07.518 --> 00:06:08.934
So to begin with, focal glow.

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.534
He meant something like this --

00:06:10.558 --> 00:06:12.934
where the light
gives direction to the space

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.934
and helps you to get around.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:16.174
Or something like this,

00:06:16.198 --> 00:06:18.814
which is the lighting design
he did for General Motors,

00:06:18.838 --> 00:06:20.054
for the car showroom.

00:06:20.078 --> 00:06:21.294
And you enter that space,

00:06:21.318 --> 00:06:24.614
and you feel like,
"Wow! This is so impressive,"

00:06:24.638 --> 00:06:28.694
just because of this focal point,
this huge light source in the middle.

00:06:28.718 --> 00:06:30.433
To me, it is something from theater,

00:06:30.457 --> 00:06:32.654
and I will get back to that
a little bit later.

00:06:32.678 --> 00:06:36.334
It's the spotlight on the artist
that helps you to focus.

00:06:36.358 --> 00:06:39.174
It could also be the sunlight
that breaks through the clouds

00:06:39.198 --> 00:06:42.614
and lights up a patch of the land,

00:06:42.638 --> 00:06:46.198
highlighting it
compared to the dim environment.

00:06:47.078 --> 00:06:50.854
Or it can be in today's retail,
in the shopping environment --

00:06:50.878 --> 00:06:54.894
lighting the merchandise and creating
accents that help you to get around.

00:06:54.918 --> 00:06:57.934
Ambient luminescence
is something very different.

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:01.054
Richard Kelly saw it
as something infinite,

00:07:01.078 --> 00:07:03.374
something without any focus,

00:07:03.398 --> 00:07:08.214
something where all details
actually dissolve in infinity.

00:07:08.238 --> 00:07:14.134
And I see it as a very comfortable kind
of light that really helps us to relax

00:07:14.158 --> 00:07:15.574
and to contemplate.

00:07:15.598 --> 00:07:17.414
It could also be something like this:

00:07:17.438 --> 00:07:19.534
the National Museum of Science in London,

00:07:19.558 --> 00:07:24.654
where this blue is embracing
all the exhibitions and galleries

00:07:24.678 --> 00:07:27.174
in one large gesture.

00:07:27.198 --> 00:07:28.414
And then finally,

00:07:28.438 --> 00:07:30.894
Kelly's play of brilliants added to that

00:07:30.918 --> 00:07:34.254
really some play, I think,
of the skyline of Hong Kong,

00:07:34.278 --> 00:07:36.614
or perhaps the chandelier
in the opera house,

00:07:36.638 --> 00:07:38.254
or in the theater here,

00:07:38.278 --> 00:07:42.454
which is the decoration,
the icing on the cake, something playful,

00:07:42.478 --> 00:07:46.014
something that is just an addition
to the architectural environment,

00:07:46.038 --> 00:07:47.254
I would say.

00:07:47.278 --> 00:07:49.854
These three distinct elements, together,

00:07:49.878 --> 00:07:53.038
make a lighting environment
that helps us to feel better.

00:07:53.638 --> 00:07:55.774
And we can only
create these out of darkness.

00:07:55.798 --> 00:07:57.374
And I will explain that further.

00:07:57.398 --> 00:08:00.574
And I guess that is something
that Richard Kelly, here on the left,

00:08:00.598 --> 00:08:02.934
was explaining
to Ludwig Mies van Der Rohe.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.694
And behind them,
you see that Seagram Building

00:08:05.718 --> 00:08:10.158
that later turned into an icon
of modern lighting design.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.743
Those times, there were
some early attempts

00:08:13.767 --> 00:08:15.254
also for light therapy already.

00:08:15.278 --> 00:08:16.454
You can see here a photo

00:08:16.478 --> 00:08:18.614
from the United States
Library of Medicine,

00:08:18.638 --> 00:08:21.734
where people are put
in the sun to get better.

00:08:21.758 --> 00:08:24.949
It's a little bit of a different story,
this health aspect of light,

00:08:24.973 --> 00:08:26.533
than what I'm telling you today.

00:08:27.318 --> 00:08:29.694
In today's modern medicine,

00:08:29.718 --> 00:08:35.214
there is a real understanding of light
in an almost biochemical way.

00:08:35.238 --> 00:08:39.934
And there is the idea
that, when we look at things,

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:42.134
it is the yellow light
that helps us the most,

00:08:42.158 --> 00:08:44.134
that we are the most sensitive for.

00:08:44.158 --> 00:08:46.774
But our circadian rhythms,

00:08:46.798 --> 00:08:49.254
which are the rhythms
that help us to wake and sleep

00:08:49.278 --> 00:08:51.654
and be alert and relaxed
and so forth and so on,

00:08:51.678 --> 00:08:54.414
they are much more triggered
by blue light.

00:08:54.438 --> 00:08:58.334
And by modulating the amount
of blue in our environment,

00:08:58.358 --> 00:09:01.734
we can help people
to relax, or to be alert,

00:09:01.758 --> 00:09:04.054
to fall asleep, or to stay awake.

00:09:04.078 --> 00:09:10.094
And that is how, maybe in the near future,
light can help hospitals

00:09:10.118 --> 00:09:15.534
to make people better sooner,
recover them quicker.

00:09:15.558 --> 00:09:18.934
Maybe in the airplane,
we can overcome jet lag like that.

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:22.740
Perhaps in school,
we can help children to learn better

00:09:22.764 --> 00:09:24.812
because they concentrate more
on their work.

00:09:24.836 --> 00:09:27.334
And you can imagine
a lot more applications.

00:09:27.358 --> 00:09:28.934
But I would like to talk further

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:34.734
about the combination
of light and darkness

00:09:34.758 --> 00:09:36.678
as a quality in our life.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:41.854
So light is, of course,
for social interaction also --

00:09:41.878 --> 00:09:45.534
to create relationships
with all the features around us.

00:09:45.558 --> 00:09:47.934
It is the place where we gather around

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:50.214
when we have to say something
to each other.

00:09:50.238 --> 00:09:52.414
And it is all about this planet.

00:09:52.438 --> 00:09:54.694
But when you look at this planet at night,

00:09:54.718 --> 00:09:56.054
it looks like this.

00:09:56.078 --> 00:09:59.614
And I think this is the most shocking
image in my talk today.

00:09:59.638 --> 00:10:03.254
Because all this light here
goes up to the sky.

00:10:03.278 --> 00:10:07.174
It never reaches the ground
where it was meant for.

00:10:07.198 --> 00:10:09.334
It never is to the benefit of people.

00:10:09.358 --> 00:10:11.174
It only spoils the darkness.

00:10:11.198 --> 00:10:14.414
So at a global scale, it looks like this.

00:10:14.438 --> 00:10:17.174
And, I mean, that is quite amazing,
what you see here --

00:10:17.198 --> 00:10:22.534
how much light goes up into the sky
and never reaches the ground.

00:10:22.558 --> 00:10:25.294
Because if we look at the Earth
the way it should be,

00:10:25.318 --> 00:10:28.334
it would be something
like this very inspiring image

00:10:28.358 --> 00:10:32.654
where darkness is for our imagination
and for contemplation

00:10:32.678 --> 00:10:35.358
and to help us to relate to everything.

00:10:36.238 --> 00:10:37.654
The world is changing though,

00:10:37.678 --> 00:10:39.894
and urbanization
is a big driver of everything.

00:10:39.918 --> 00:10:42.336
I took this photo
two weeks ago in Guangzhou,

00:10:42.360 --> 00:10:44.015
and I realized that 10 years ago,

00:10:44.039 --> 00:10:47.799
there was nothing like this,
of these buildings.

00:10:48.678 --> 00:10:50.774
It was just a much smaller city,

00:10:50.798 --> 00:10:54.254
and the pace of urbanization
is incredible and enormous.

00:10:54.278 --> 00:10:57.294
And we have to understand
these main questions:

00:10:57.318 --> 00:11:00.934
How do people move
through these new urban spaces?

00:11:00.958 --> 00:11:02.534
How do they share their culture?

00:11:02.558 --> 00:11:04.398
How do we tackle things like mobility?

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.854
And how can light help there?

00:11:06.878 --> 00:11:08.334
Because the new technologies,

00:11:08.358 --> 00:11:10.814
they seem to be
in a really interesting position

00:11:10.838 --> 00:11:14.694
to contribute to the solutions
of urbanization

00:11:14.718 --> 00:11:18.054
and to provide us
with better environments.

00:11:18.078 --> 00:11:19.454
It's not that long ago

00:11:19.478 --> 00:11:23.214
that our lighting was just done
with these kinds of lamps.

00:11:23.238 --> 00:11:25.334
And of course,
we had the metal-halide lamps

00:11:25.358 --> 00:11:27.454
and fluorescent lamps
and things like that.

00:11:27.478 --> 00:11:28.974
Now we have LED,

00:11:28.998 --> 00:11:33.054
but here you see the latest one,
and you see how incredibly small it is.

00:11:33.078 --> 00:11:36.694
And this is exactly
what offers us a unique opportunity,

00:11:36.718 --> 00:11:39.934
because this tiny, tiny size allows us

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.294
to put the light
wherever we really need it.

00:11:42.318 --> 00:11:45.214
And we can actually leave it out
where it's not needed at all

00:11:45.238 --> 00:11:46.934
and where we can preserve darkness.

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:49.454
So that is a really interesting
proposition, I think,

00:11:49.478 --> 00:11:53.054
and a new way of lighting
the architectural environment

00:11:53.078 --> 00:11:54.958
with our well-being in mind.

00:11:55.558 --> 00:11:59.334
The problem is, though, that I wanted
to explain to you how this really works --

00:11:59.358 --> 00:12:01.774
but I can have four of these on my finger,

00:12:01.798 --> 00:12:03.894
so you would not be able
to really see them.

00:12:03.918 --> 00:12:06.974
So I asked our laboratory
to do something about it,

00:12:06.998 --> 00:12:09.014
and they said,
"Well, we can do something."

00:12:09.038 --> 00:12:11.574
They created for me
the biggest LED in the world

00:12:11.598 --> 00:12:13.614
especially for TEDx in Amsterdam.

00:12:13.638 --> 00:12:14.974
So here it is.

00:12:14.998 --> 00:12:17.414
It's the same thing
as you can see over there --

00:12:17.438 --> 00:12:19.054
just 200 times bigger.

00:12:19.078 --> 00:12:21.414
And I will very quickly
show you how it works.

00:12:21.438 --> 00:12:24.294
So just to explain.

00:12:24.318 --> 00:12:30.518
Now, every LED that is made
these days gives blue light.

00:12:31.518 --> 00:12:34.734
Now, this is not very pleasant
and comfortable.

00:12:34.758 --> 00:12:41.654
And for that reason,
we cover the LED with a phosphor cap.

00:12:41.678 --> 00:12:44.374
And the phosphor is excited by the blue

00:12:44.398 --> 00:12:47.494
and makes the light white
and warm and pleasant.

00:12:47.518 --> 00:12:49.854
And then when you add the lens to that,

00:12:49.878 --> 00:12:53.574
you can bundle the light
and send it wherever you need it

00:12:53.598 --> 00:12:56.934
without any need to spill any light
to the sky or anywhere else.

00:12:56.958 --> 00:13:00.254
So you can preserve the darkness
and make the light.

00:13:00.278 --> 00:13:05.374
I just wanted to show that to you
so you understand how this works.

00:13:05.398 --> 00:13:06.414
(Applause)

00:13:06.438 --> 00:13:07.626
Thank you.

00:13:07.650 --> 00:13:08.714
(Applause)

00:13:08.738 --> 00:13:09.934
We can go further.

00:13:09.958 --> 00:13:13.174
So we have to rethink
the way we light our cities.

00:13:13.198 --> 00:13:17.934
We have to think again
about light as a default solution.

00:13:17.958 --> 00:13:20.374
Why are all these motorways
permanently lit?

00:13:20.398 --> 00:13:21.614
Is it really needed?

00:13:21.638 --> 00:13:23.334
Can we maybe be much more selective

00:13:23.358 --> 00:13:26.694
and create better environments
that also benefit from darkness?

00:13:26.718 --> 00:13:28.934
Can we be much more gentle with light?

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:31.774
Like here -- this is
a very low light level actually.

00:13:31.798 --> 00:13:35.414
Can we engage people more
in the lighting projects that we create,

00:13:35.438 --> 00:13:38.014
so they really want
to connect with it, like here?

00:13:38.038 --> 00:13:39.898
Or can we create simply sculptures

00:13:39.922 --> 00:13:42.534
that are very inspiring
to be in and to be around?

00:13:42.558 --> 00:13:44.534
And can we preserve the darkness?

00:13:44.558 --> 00:13:46.797
Because to find a place
like this today on Earth

00:13:46.821 --> 00:13:49.461
is really very, very challenging.

00:13:50.398 --> 00:13:53.694
And to find a starry sky like this
is even more difficult.

00:13:53.718 --> 00:13:56.694
Even in the oceans,
we are creating a lot of light

00:13:56.718 --> 00:13:58.174
that we could actually ban

00:13:58.198 --> 00:14:01.854
also for animal life
to have a much greater well-being.

00:14:01.878 --> 00:14:05.174
And it's known that migrating birds,
for example, get very disoriented

00:14:05.198 --> 00:14:07.254
because of these offshore platforms.

00:14:07.278 --> 00:14:10.054
And we discovered that
when we make those lights green,

00:14:10.078 --> 00:14:12.094
the birds, they actually go the right way.

00:14:12.118 --> 00:14:14.134
They are not disturbed anymore.

00:14:14.158 --> 00:14:15.976
And it turns out once again

00:14:16.000 --> 00:14:20.158
that spectral sensitivity
is very important here.

00:14:20.878 --> 00:14:23.334
In all of these examples, I think,

00:14:23.358 --> 00:14:26.254
we should start making
the light out of darkness,

00:14:26.278 --> 00:14:30.174
and use the darkness as a canvas --
like the visual artists do,

00:14:30.198 --> 00:14:32.454
like Edward Hopper in this painting.

00:14:32.478 --> 00:14:35.174
I think that there is
a lot of suspense in this painting.

00:14:35.198 --> 00:14:39.414
I think, when I see it,
I start to think, who are those people?

00:14:39.438 --> 00:14:41.694
Where have they come from?
Where are they going?

00:14:41.718 --> 00:14:42.934
What just happened?

00:14:42.958 --> 00:14:45.214
What will be happening
in the next five minutes?

00:14:45.238 --> 00:14:48.094
And it only embodies
all these stories and all this suspense

00:14:48.118 --> 00:14:49.974
because of the darkness and the light.

00:14:49.998 --> 00:14:51.774
Edward Hopper was a real master

00:14:51.798 --> 00:14:55.414
in creating the narration
by working with light and dark.

00:14:55.438 --> 00:14:56.734
And we can learn from that

00:14:56.758 --> 00:15:00.534
and create more interesting
and inspiring architectural environments.

00:15:00.558 --> 00:15:03.014
We can do that in commercial
spaces like this.

00:15:03.038 --> 00:15:05.894
And you can still also go outside

00:15:05.918 --> 00:15:10.734
and enjoy the greatest show
in the universe,

00:15:10.758 --> 00:15:13.198
which is, of course, the universe itself.

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:20.374
So I give you this wonderful,
informative image of the sky,

00:15:20.398 --> 00:15:22.054
ranging from the inner city,

00:15:22.078 --> 00:15:25.774
where you may see one or two stars
and nothing else,

00:15:25.798 --> 00:15:28.134
all the way to the rural environments,

00:15:28.158 --> 00:15:32.414
where you can enjoy this great
and gorgeous and beautiful performance

00:15:32.438 --> 00:15:34.814
of the constellations and the stars.

00:15:34.838 --> 00:15:36.918
In architecture, it works just the same.

00:15:37.598 --> 00:15:40.974
By appreciating the darkness
when you design the light,

00:15:40.998 --> 00:15:43.574
you create much more
interesting environments

00:15:43.598 --> 00:15:45.918
that truly enhance our lives.

00:15:46.518 --> 00:15:50.534
This is the most well-known example,
Tadao Ando's Church of the Light.

00:15:50.558 --> 00:15:56.174
But I also think
of Peter Zumthor's spa in Vals,

00:15:56.198 --> 00:15:59.014
where light and dark,
in very gentle combinations,

00:15:59.038 --> 00:16:01.574
alter each other to define the space.

00:16:01.598 --> 00:16:04.894
Or Richard MacCormac's
Southwark tube station in London,

00:16:04.918 --> 00:16:08.489
where you can really see the sky,
even though you are under the ground.

00:16:09.118 --> 00:16:10.814
And finally, I want to point out

00:16:10.838 --> 00:16:13.334
that a lot of this inspiration
comes from theater.

00:16:13.358 --> 00:16:17.494
And I think it's fantastic
that we are today experiencing TEDx

00:16:17.518 --> 00:16:20.014
in a theater for the first time

00:16:20.038 --> 00:16:24.414
because I think we really owe
to the theater a big thanks.

00:16:24.438 --> 00:16:26.694
It wouldn't be
such an inspiring scenography

00:16:26.718 --> 00:16:27.918
without this theater.

00:16:28.518 --> 00:16:34.734
And I think the theater is a place
where we truly enhance life with light.

00:16:34.758 --> 00:16:35.974
Thank you very much.

00:16:35.998 --> 00:16:41.958
(Applause)

title: If I should have a daughter ...
transcript: If I should have a daughter, instead of "Mom," she's going to call me "Point B," because that way she knows that no matter what happens, at least she can always find her way to me.And I'm going to paint solar systems on the backs of her hands so she has to learn the entire universe before she can say, "Oh, I know that like the back of my hand."And she's going to learn that this life will hit you hard in the face, wait for you to get back up just so it can kick you in the stomach. But getting the wind knocked out of you is the only way to remind your lungs how much they like the taste of air. There is hurt, here, that cannot be fixed by Band-Aids or poetry.So the first time she realizes that Wonder Woman isn't coming, I'll make sure she knows she doesn't have to wear the cape all by herself, because no matter how wide you stretch your fingers, your hands will always be too small to catch all the pain you want to heal. Believe me, I've tried. "And, baby," I'll tell her, don't keep your nose up in the air like that. I know that trick; I've done it a million times. You're just smelling for smoke so you can follow the trail back to a burning house, so you can find the boy who lost everything in the fire to see if you can save him. Or else find the boy who lit the fire in the first place, to see if you can change him. But I know she will anyway, so instead I'll always keep an extra supply of chocolate and rain boots nearby, because there is no heartbreak that chocolate can't fix. Okay, there's a few that chocolate can't fix.But that's what the rain boots are for, because rain will wash away everything, if you let it. I want her to look at the world through the underside of a glass-bottom boat, to look through a microscope at the galaxies that exist on the pinpoint of a human mind, because that's the way my mom taught me. That there'll be days like this.(Singing) There'll be days like this, my momma said. When you open your hands to catch and wind up with only blisters and bruises; when you step out of the phone booth and try to fly and the very people you want to save are the ones standing on your cape; when your boots will fill with rain, and you'll be up to your knees in disappointment. And those are the very days you have all the more reason to say thank you.Because there's nothing more beautiful than the way the ocean refuses to stop kissing the shoreline, no matter how many times it's sent away. You will put the wind in win some, lose some. You will put the star in starting over, and over. And no matter how many land mines erupt in a minute, be sure your mind lands on the beauty of this funny place called life. And yes, on a scale from one to over-trusting, I am pretty damn naive. But I want her to know that this world is made out of sugar. It can crumble so easily, but don't be afraid to stick your tongue out and taste it."Baby," I'll tell her, "remember, your momma is a worrier, and your poppa is a warrior, and you are the girl with small hands and big eyes who never stops asking for more." Remember that good things come in threes and so do bad things. Always apologize when you've done something wrong, but don't you ever apologize for the way your eyes refuse to stop shining. Your voice is small, but don't ever stop singing. And when they finally hand you heartache, when they slip war and hatred under your door and offer you handouts on street-corners of cynicism and defeat, you tell them that they really ought to meet your mother.(Applause)Thank you. Thank you.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)Thanks.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)All right, so I want you to take a moment, and I want you to think of three things that you know to be true. They can be about whatever you want — technology, entertainment, design, your family, what you had for breakfast. The only rule is don't think too hard. Okay, ready? Go. Okay.So here are three things I know to be true. I know that Jean-Luc Godard was right when he said that, "A good story has a beginning, a middle and an end, although not necessarily in that order." I know that I'm incredibly nervous and excited to be up here, which is greatly inhibiting my ability to keep it cool.(Laughter)And I know that I have been waiting all week to tell this joke.(Laughter)Why was the scarecrow invited to TED? Because he was out standing in his field.(Laughter)I'm sorry. Okay, so these are three things I know to be true. But there are plenty of things I have trouble understanding. So I write poems to figure things out. Sometimes the only way I know how to work through something is by writing a poem. Sometimes I get to the end of the poem, look back and go, "Oh, that's what this is all about," and sometimes I get to the end of the poem and haven't solved anything, but at least I have a new poem out of it.Spoken-word poetry is the art of performance poetry. I tell people it involves creating poetry that doesn't just want to sit on paper, that something about it demands it be heard out loud or witnessed in person.When I was a freshman in high school, I was a live wire of nervous hormones. And I was underdeveloped and over-excitable. And despite my fear of ever being looked at for too long, I was fascinated by the idea of spoken-word poetry. I felt that my two secret loves, poetry and theater, had come together, had a baby, a baby I needed to get to know. So I decided to give it a try. My first spoken-word poem, packed with all the wisdom of a 14-year-old, was about the injustice of being seen as unfeminine. The poem was very indignant, and mainly exaggerated, but the only spoken-word poetry that I had seen up until that point was mainly indignant, so I thought that's what was expected of me.The first time that I performed, the audience of teenagers hooted and hollered their sympathy, and when I came off the stage, I was shaking. I felt this tap on my shoulder, and I turned around to see this giant girl in a hoodie sweatshirt emerge from the crowd. She was maybe eight feet tall and looked like she could beat me up with one hand, but instead she just nodded at me and said, "Hey, I really felt that. Thanks." And lightning struck. I was hooked.I discovered this bar on Manhattan's Lower East Side that hosted a weekly poetry open Mic, and my bewildered, but supportive, parents took me to soak in every ounce of spoken word that I could. I was the youngest by at least a decade, but somehow the poets at the Bowery Poetry Club didn't seem bothered by the 14-year-old wandering about. In fact, they welcomed me.And it was here, listening to these poets share their stories, that I learned that spoken-word poetry didn't have to be indignant, it could be fun or painful or serious or silly. The Bowery Poetry Club became my classroom and my home, and the poets who performed encouraged me to share my stories as well. Never mind the fact that I was 14. They told me, "Write about being 14." So I did and stood amazed every week when these brilliant, grown-up poets laughed with me and groaned their sympathy and clapped and told me, "Hey, I really felt that too."Now I can divide my spoken-word journey into three steps. Step one was the moment I said, "I can. I can do this." And that was thanks to a girl in a hoodie. Step two was the moment I said, "I will. I will continue. I love spoken word. I will keep coming back week after week." And step three began when I realized I didn't have to write indignant poems, if that's not what I was. There were things that were specific to me, and the more that I focused on those things, the weirder my poetry got, but the more that it felt like mine. It's not just the adage "Write what you know." It's about gathering up all of the knowledge and experience you've collected up to now to help you dive into the things you don't know. I use poetry to help me work through what I don't understand, but I show up to each new poem with a backpack full of everywhere else that I've been.When I got to university, I met a fellow poet who shared my belief in the magic of spoken-word poetry. And actually, Phil Kaye and I coincidentally also share the same last name. When I was in high school I had created Project V.O.I.C.E. as a way to encourage my friends to do spoken word with me. But Phil and I decided to reinvent Project V.O.I.C.E., this time changing the mission to using spoken-word poetry as a way to entertain, educate and inspire. We stayed full-time students, but in between we traveled, performing and teaching nine-year-olds to MFA candidates, from California to Indiana to India to a public high school just up the street from campus.And we saw over and over the way that spoken-word poetry cracks open locks. But it turns out sometimes, poetry can be really scary. Turns out sometimes, you have to trick teenagers into writing poetry. So I came up with lists. Everyone can write lists. And the first list that I assign is "10 Things I Know to be True." And here's what happens, you would discover it too if we all started sharing our lists out loud. At a certain point, you would realize that someone has the exact same thing, or one thing very similar, to something on your list. And then someone else has something the complete opposite of yours. Third, someone has something you've never even heard of before. Fourth, someone has something you thought you knew everything about, but they're introducing a new angle of looking at it. And I tell people that this is where great stories start from — these four intersections of what you're passionate about and what others might be invested in.And most people respond really well to this exercise. But one of my students, a freshman named Charlotte, was not convinced. Charlotte was very good at writing lists, but she refused to write any poems. "Miss," she'd say, "I'm just not interesting. I don't have anything interesting to say." So I assigned her list after list, and one day I assigned the list "10 Things I Should Have Learned by Now." Number three on Charlotte's list was, "I should have learned not to crush on guys three times my age." I asked her what that meant, and she said, "Miss, it's kind of a long story." And I said, "Charlotte, it sounds pretty interesting to me." And so she wrote her first poem, a love poem unlike any I had ever heard before. And the poem began, "Anderson Cooper is a gorgeous man."(Laughter)"Did you see him on 60 Minutes, racing Michael Phelps in a pool — nothing but swim trunks on — diving in the water, determined to beat this swimming champion? After the race, he tossed his wet, cloud-white hair and said, 'You're a god.' No, Anderson, you're the god."(Laughter)(Applause)Now, I know that the number one rule to being cool is to seem unfazed, to never admit that anything scares you or impresses you or excites you. Somebody once told me it's like walking through life like this. You protect yourself from all the unexpected miseries or hurt that might show up. But I try to walk through life like this. And yes, that means catching all of those miseries and hurt, but it also means that when beautiful, amazing things just fall out of the sky, I'm ready to catch them. I use spoken word to help my students rediscover wonder, to fight their instincts to be cool and unfazed and, instead, actively pursue being engaged with what goes on around them, so that they can reinterpret and create something from it.It's not that I think that spoken-word poetry is the ideal art form. I'm always trying to find the best way to tell each story. I write musicals; I make short films alongside my poems. But I teach spoken-word poetry because it's accessible. Not everyone can read music or owns a camera, but everyone can communicate in some way, and everyone has stories that the rest of us can learn from. Plus, spoken-word poetry allows for immediate connection. It's not uncommon to feel like you're alone or that nobody understands you, but spoken word teaches that if you have the ability to express yourself and the courage to present those stories and opinions, you could be rewarded with a room full of your peers, or your community, who will listen. And maybe even a giant girl in a hoodie who will connect with what you've shared. And that is an amazing realization to have, especially when you're 14. Plus, now with YouTube, that connection's not even limited to the room we're in. I'm so lucky that there's this archive of performances that I can share with my students. It allows for even more opportunities for them to find a poet or a poem that they connect to.Once you've figured this out, it is tempting to keep writing the same poem, or keep telling the same story, over and over, once you've figured out that it will gain you applause. It's not enough to just teach that you can express yourself. You have to grow and explore and take risks and challenge yourself. And that is step three: infusing the work you're doing with the specific things that make you you, even while those things are always changing. Because step three never ends. But you don't get to start on step three, until you take step one first: "I can."I travel a lot while I'm teaching, and I don't always get to watch all of my students reach their step three, but I was very lucky with Charlotte, that I got to watch her journey unfold the way it did. I watched her realize that, by putting the things that she knows to be true into the work she's doing, she can create poems that only Charlotte can write, about eyeballs and elevators and Dora the Explorer. And I'm trying to tell stories only I can tell — like this story. I spent a lot of time thinking about the best way to tell this story, and I wondered if the best way was going to be a PowerPoint, a short film — And where exactly was the beginning, the middle or the end? I wondered whether I'd get to the end of this talk and finally have figured it all out, or not.And I always thought that my beginning was at the Bowery Poetry Club, but it's possible that it was much earlier. In preparing for TED, I discovered this diary page in an old journal. I think December 54th was probably supposed to be 24th. It's clear that when I was a child, I definitely walked through life like this. I think that we all did. I would like to help others rediscover that wonder — to want to engage with it, to want to learn, to want to share what they've learned, what they've figured out to be true and what they're still figuring out.So I'd like to close with this poem.When they bombed Hiroshima, the explosion formed a mini-supernova, so every living animal, human or plant that received direct contact with the rays from that sun was instantly turned to ash. And what was left of the city soon followed. The long-lasting damage of nuclear radiation caused an entire city and its population to turn into powder. When I was born, my mom says I looked around the whole hospital room with a stare that said, "This? I've done this before." She says I have old eyes. When my Grandpa Genji died, I was only five years old, but I took my mom by the hand and told her, "Don't worry, he'll come back as a baby." And yet, for someone who's apparently done this already, I still haven't figured anything out yet. My knees still buckle every time I get on a stage. My self-confidence can be measured out in teaspoons mixed into my poetry, and it still always tastes funny in my mouth. But in Hiroshima, some people were wiped clean away, leaving only a wristwatch or a diary page. So no matter that I have inhibitions to fill all my pockets, I keep trying, hoping that one day I'll write a poem I can be proud to let sit in a museum exhibit as the only proof I existed. My parents named me Sarah, which is a biblical name. In the original story, God told Sarah she could do something impossible, and — she laughed, because the first Sarah, she didn't know what to do with impossible. And me? Well, neither do I, but I see the impossible every day. Impossible is trying to connect in this world, trying to hold onto others while things are blowing up around you, knowing that while you're speaking, they aren't just waiting for their turn to talk — they hear you. They feel exactly what you feel at the same time that you feel it. It's what I strive for every time I open my mouth — that impossible connection. There's this piece of wall in Hiroshima that was completely burnt black by the radiation. But on the front step, a person who was sitting there blocked the rays from hitting the stone. The only thing left now is a permanent shadow of positive light. After the A-bomb, specialists said it would take 75 years for the radiation-damaged soil of Hiroshima City to ever grow anything again. But that spring, there were new buds popping up from the earth. When I meet you, in that moment, I'm no longer a part of your future. I start quickly becoming part of your past. But in that instant, I get to share your present. And you, you get to share mine. And that is the greatest present of all. So if you tell me I can do the impossible — I'll probably laugh at you. I don't know if I can change the world yet, because I don't know that much about it — and I don't know that much about reincarnation either, but if you make me laugh hard enough, sometimes I forget what century I'm in. This isn't my first time here. This isn't my last time here. These aren't the last words I'll share. But just in case, I'm trying my hardest to get it right this time around.Thank you.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.744 --> 00:00:15.402
If I should have a daughter,

00:00:15.426 --> 00:00:17.537
instead of "Mom,"

00:00:17.561 --> 00:00:20.862
she's going to call me "Point B,"

00:00:20.886 --> 00:00:23.513
because that way she knows
that no matter what happens,

00:00:23.537 --> 00:00:25.934
at least she can always find
her way to me.

00:00:26.481 --> 00:00:29.878
And I'm going to paint solar systems
on the backs of her hands

00:00:29.902 --> 00:00:31.840
so she has to learn the entire universe

00:00:31.864 --> 00:00:34.958
before she can say, "Oh, I know that
like the back of my hand."

00:00:35.315 --> 00:00:36.934
And she's going to learn

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:39.934
that this life will hit you
hard in the face,

00:00:39.958 --> 00:00:43.253
wait for you to get back up just
so it can kick you in the stomach.

00:00:43.277 --> 00:00:45.189
But getting the wind knocked out of you

00:00:45.213 --> 00:00:47.059
is the only way to remind your lungs

00:00:47.083 --> 00:00:48.934
how much they like the taste of air.

00:00:49.709 --> 00:00:51.234
There is hurt, here,

00:00:51.258 --> 00:00:53.598
that cannot be fixed
by Band-Aids or poetry.

00:00:53.622 --> 00:00:56.934
So the first time she realizes
that Wonder Woman isn't coming,

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.472
I'll make sure she knows

00:00:58.496 --> 00:01:00.895
she doesn't have to wear
the cape all by herself,

00:01:00.919 --> 00:01:03.409
because no matter how wide
you stretch your fingers,

00:01:03.433 --> 00:01:05.108
your hands will always be too small

00:01:05.132 --> 00:01:07.649
to catch all the pain you want to heal.

00:01:07.673 --> 00:01:09.652
Believe me, I've tried.

00:01:09.676 --> 00:01:10.971
"And, baby," I'll tell her,

00:01:10.995 --> 00:01:13.113
don't keep your nose up
in the air like that.

00:01:13.137 --> 00:01:15.411
I know that trick;
I've done it a million times.

00:01:15.435 --> 00:01:16.934
You're just smelling for smoke

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:19.934
so you can follow the trail
back to a burning house,

00:01:19.958 --> 00:01:22.577
so you can find the boy
who lost everything in the fire

00:01:22.601 --> 00:01:23.933
to see if you can save him.

00:01:24.531 --> 00:01:27.934
Or else find the boy who lit
the fire in the first place,

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:30.435
to see if you can change him.

00:01:30.459 --> 00:01:31.934
But I know she will anyway,

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.006
so instead I'll always keep
an extra supply

00:01:34.030 --> 00:01:36.148
of chocolate and rain boots nearby,

00:01:36.172 --> 00:01:39.061
because there is no heartbreak
that chocolate can't fix.

00:01:40.116 --> 00:01:42.259
Okay, there's a few
that chocolate can't fix.

00:01:42.283 --> 00:01:44.521
But that's what the rain boots are for,

00:01:44.545 --> 00:01:47.934
because rain will wash away
everything, if you let it.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:49.934
I want her to look at the world

00:01:49.958 --> 00:01:52.540
through the underside
of a glass-bottom boat,

00:01:52.564 --> 00:01:53.934
to look through a microscope

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.934
at the galaxies that exist

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.133
on the pinpoint of a human mind,

00:01:58.157 --> 00:02:00.165
because that's the way my mom taught me.

00:02:00.189 --> 00:02:01.934
That there'll be days like this.

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:04.934
(Singing) There'll be days
like this, my momma said.

00:02:04.958 --> 00:02:06.934
When you open your hands to catch

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.505
and wind up with only
blisters and bruises;

00:02:09.529 --> 00:02:11.934
when you step out of the phone
booth and try to fly

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.835
and the very people you want to save

00:02:13.859 --> 00:02:15.598
are the ones standing on your cape;

00:02:15.622 --> 00:02:17.526
when your boots will fill with rain,

00:02:17.550 --> 00:02:19.934
and you'll be up to your knees
in disappointment.

00:02:19.958 --> 00:02:23.460
And those are the very days you have
all the more reason to say thank you.

00:02:23.484 --> 00:02:25.339
Because there's nothing more beautiful

00:02:25.363 --> 00:02:28.224
than the way the ocean refuses
to stop kissing the shoreline,

00:02:28.248 --> 00:02:30.490
no matter how many times it's sent away.

00:02:30.514 --> 00:02:34.545
You will put the wind
in win some, lose some.

00:02:34.569 --> 00:02:37.934
You will put the star
in starting over, and over.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.934
And no matter how many land
mines erupt in a minute,

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:42.584
be sure your mind lands

00:02:42.608 --> 00:02:44.965
on the beauty of this
funny place called life.

00:02:44.989 --> 00:02:47.751
And yes, on a scale
from one to over-trusting,

00:02:47.775 --> 00:02:49.934
I am pretty damn naive.

00:02:49.958 --> 00:02:53.457
But I want her to know
that this world is made out of sugar.

00:02:53.481 --> 00:02:54.934
It can crumble so easily,

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:57.934
but don't be afraid to stick
your tongue out and taste it.

00:02:57.958 --> 00:03:00.934
"Baby," I'll tell her, "remember,
your momma is a worrier,

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.792
and your poppa is a warrior,

00:03:02.816 --> 00:03:05.178
and you are the girl
with small hands and big eyes

00:03:05.202 --> 00:03:06.934
who never stops asking for more."

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.537
Remember that good things come in threes

00:03:09.561 --> 00:03:10.980
and so do bad things.

00:03:11.466 --> 00:03:14.346
Always apologize when
you've done something wrong,

00:03:14.370 --> 00:03:15.751
but don't you ever apologize

00:03:15.775 --> 00:03:17.934
for the way your eyes
refuse to stop shining.

00:03:17.958 --> 00:03:20.934
Your voice is small,
but don't ever stop singing.

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.934
And when they finally hand you heartache,

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:25.934
when they slip war
and hatred under your door

00:03:25.958 --> 00:03:27.934
and offer you handouts on street-corners

00:03:27.958 --> 00:03:29.934
of cynicism and defeat,

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:34.086
you tell them that they really
ought to meet your mother.

00:03:35.528 --> 00:03:36.529
(Applause)

00:03:36.553 --> 00:03:39.934
Thank you. Thank you.

00:03:39.958 --> 00:03:43.283
(Applause)

00:03:43.307 --> 00:03:44.671
Thank you.

00:03:44.695 --> 00:03:46.854
(Applause)

00:03:46.958 --> 00:03:48.967
Thanks.

00:03:48.991 --> 00:03:52.139
(Applause)

00:03:52.251 --> 00:03:53.434
Thank you.

00:03:53.458 --> 00:03:56.934
(Applause)

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.934
All right, so I want you to take a moment,

00:03:59.958 --> 00:04:03.934
and I want you to think of three things
that you know to be true.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.934
They can be about whatever you want --

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:08.516
technology, entertainment, design,

00:04:08.540 --> 00:04:10.469
your family, what you had for breakfast.

00:04:10.493 --> 00:04:12.461
The only rule is don't think too hard.

00:04:13.239 --> 00:04:14.958
Okay, ready? Go.

00:04:21.680 --> 00:04:22.688
Okay.

00:04:23.085 --> 00:04:25.292
So here are three things
I know to be true.

00:04:25.316 --> 00:04:28.347
I know that Jean-Luc Godard
was right when he said that,

00:04:28.371 --> 00:04:31.395
"A good story has a beginning,
a middle and an end,

00:04:31.419 --> 00:04:33.706
although not necessarily in that order."

00:04:33.730 --> 00:04:36.934
I know that I'm incredibly nervous
and excited to be up here,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.959
which is greatly inhibiting
my ability to keep it cool.

00:04:39.983 --> 00:04:41.316
(Laughter)

00:04:41.340 --> 00:04:42.934
And I know

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:45.682
that I have been waiting
all week to tell this joke.

00:04:46.294 --> 00:04:47.850
(Laughter)

00:04:47.874 --> 00:04:50.048
Why was the scarecrow invited to TED?

00:04:50.826 --> 00:04:53.239
Because he was out standing in his field.

00:04:53.723 --> 00:04:55.731
(Laughter)

00:04:56.501 --> 00:04:58.070
I'm sorry.

00:04:59.223 --> 00:05:02.359
Okay, so these are three things
I know to be true.

00:05:02.383 --> 00:05:05.566
But there are plenty of things
I have trouble understanding.

00:05:05.590 --> 00:05:08.486
So I write poems to figure things out.

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:11.768
Sometimes the only way I know
how to work through something

00:05:11.792 --> 00:05:13.245
is by writing a poem.

00:05:13.269 --> 00:05:15.167
Sometimes I get to the end of the poem,

00:05:15.191 --> 00:05:17.718
look back and go,
"Oh, that's what this is all about,"

00:05:17.742 --> 00:05:19.759
and sometimes I get to the end of the poem

00:05:19.783 --> 00:05:21.118
and haven't solved anything,

00:05:21.142 --> 00:05:23.316
but at least I have a new poem out of it.

00:05:23.340 --> 00:05:26.039
Spoken-word poetry is the art
of performance poetry.

00:05:26.063 --> 00:05:28.510
I tell people it involves creating poetry

00:05:28.534 --> 00:05:30.422
that doesn't just want to sit on paper,

00:05:30.446 --> 00:05:33.255
that something about it
demands it be heard out loud

00:05:33.279 --> 00:05:34.652
or witnessed in person.

00:05:35.207 --> 00:05:37.112
When I was a freshman in high school,

00:05:37.136 --> 00:05:40.934
I was a live wire of nervous hormones.

00:05:41.500 --> 00:05:44.934
And I was underdeveloped
and over-excitable.

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.934
And despite my fear

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:49.124
of ever being looked at for too long,

00:05:49.148 --> 00:05:52.369
I was fascinated by the idea
of spoken-word poetry.

00:05:52.393 --> 00:05:56.033
I felt that my two secret loves,
poetry and theater,

00:05:56.057 --> 00:05:58.986
had come together, had a baby,

00:05:59.010 --> 00:06:00.675
a baby I needed to get to know.

00:06:00.699 --> 00:06:02.644
So I decided to give it a try.

00:06:02.668 --> 00:06:04.572
My first spoken-word poem,

00:06:04.596 --> 00:06:07.934
packed with all the wisdom
of a 14-year-old,

00:06:07.958 --> 00:06:09.934
was about the injustice

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:11.524
of being seen as unfeminine.

00:06:11.984 --> 00:06:14.818
The poem was very indignant,

00:06:14.842 --> 00:06:15.984
and mainly exaggerated,

00:06:16.008 --> 00:06:19.236
but the only spoken-word poetry
that I had seen up until that point

00:06:19.260 --> 00:06:20.934
was mainly indignant,

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:23.292
so I thought
that's what was expected of me.

00:06:23.316 --> 00:06:24.934
The first time that I performed,

00:06:24.958 --> 00:06:28.447
the audience of teenagers hooted
and hollered their sympathy,

00:06:28.471 --> 00:06:30.934
and when I came off the stage,
I was shaking.

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.845
I felt this tap on my shoulder,

00:06:32.869 --> 00:06:34.425
and I turned around to see

00:06:34.449 --> 00:06:37.360
this giant girl in a hoodie
sweatshirt emerge from the crowd.

00:06:37.384 --> 00:06:38.799
She was maybe eight feet tall

00:06:38.823 --> 00:06:41.281
and looked like she could
beat me up with one hand,

00:06:41.305 --> 00:06:44.382
but instead she just nodded
at me and said,

00:06:44.488 --> 00:06:46.171
"Hey, I really felt that. Thanks."

00:06:47.472 --> 00:06:48.639
And lightning struck.

00:06:48.932 --> 00:06:50.203
I was hooked.

00:06:50.429 --> 00:06:53.697
I discovered this bar
on Manhattan's Lower East Side

00:06:53.721 --> 00:06:55.934
that hosted a weekly poetry open Mic,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.934
and my bewildered,
but supportive, parents took me

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:01.934
to soak in every ounce
of spoken word that I could.

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:04.934
I was the youngest by at least a decade,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.934
but somehow the poets
at the Bowery Poetry Club

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:11.179
didn't seem bothered
by the 14-year-old wandering about.

00:07:11.203 --> 00:07:12.728
In fact, they welcomed me.

00:07:12.752 --> 00:07:15.689
And it was here, listening to these poets
share their stories,

00:07:15.713 --> 00:07:18.896
that I learned that spoken-word
poetry didn't have to be indignant,

00:07:18.920 --> 00:07:21.240
it could be fun or painful

00:07:21.264 --> 00:07:23.200
or serious or silly.

00:07:23.224 --> 00:07:26.478
The Bowery Poetry Club became
my classroom and my home,

00:07:26.502 --> 00:07:28.138
and the poets who performed

00:07:28.162 --> 00:07:30.542
encouraged me to share my stories as well.

00:07:30.566 --> 00:07:32.455
Never mind the fact that I was 14.

00:07:32.479 --> 00:07:34.934
They told me, "Write about being 14."

00:07:35.598 --> 00:07:37.677
So I did and stood amazed every week

00:07:37.701 --> 00:07:39.934
when these brilliant, grown-up poets

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.959
laughed with me and groaned their sympathy

00:07:41.983 --> 00:07:45.286
and clapped and told me,
"Hey, I really felt that too."

00:07:46.119 --> 00:07:49.361
Now I can divide my spoken-word journey

00:07:49.385 --> 00:07:50.934
into three steps.

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:52.775
Step one was the moment I said,

00:07:52.799 --> 00:07:54.934
"I can. I can do this."

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:57.145
And that was thanks to a girl in a hoodie.

00:07:57.169 --> 00:07:59.224
Step two was the moment I said,

00:07:59.248 --> 00:08:01.332
"I will. I will continue.

00:08:01.440 --> 00:08:04.320
I love spoken word. I will keep
coming back week after week."

00:08:04.344 --> 00:08:05.934
And step three began

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:08.758
when I realized I didn't have
to write indignant poems,

00:08:08.782 --> 00:08:10.180
if that's not what I was.

00:08:10.204 --> 00:08:12.369
There were things
that were specific to me,

00:08:12.393 --> 00:08:14.934
and the more that I focused
on those things,

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.934
the weirder my poetry got,

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.934
but the more that it felt like mine.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:22.656
It's not just the adage
"Write what you know."

00:08:22.680 --> 00:08:25.505
It's about gathering up
all of the knowledge and experience

00:08:25.529 --> 00:08:27.140
you've collected up to now

00:08:27.164 --> 00:08:29.903
to help you dive into the things
you don't know.

00:08:29.927 --> 00:08:32.810
I use poetry to help me work
through what I don't understand,

00:08:32.834 --> 00:08:34.779
but I show up to each new poem

00:08:34.803 --> 00:08:37.934
with a backpack full
of everywhere else that I've been.

00:08:38.424 --> 00:08:41.149
When I got to university,
I met a fellow poet

00:08:41.173 --> 00:08:44.665
who shared my belief in the magic
of spoken-word poetry.

00:08:44.689 --> 00:08:46.683
And actually, Phil Kaye and I

00:08:46.707 --> 00:08:49.300
coincidentally also share
the same last name.

00:08:49.324 --> 00:08:52.059
When I was in high school I had
created Project V.O.I.C.E.

00:08:52.083 --> 00:08:54.934
as a way to encourage my friends
to do spoken word with me.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.934
But Phil and I decided to reinvent
Project V.O.I.C.E.,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.934
this time changing the mission

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.934
to using spoken-word poetry
as a way to entertain,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.934
educate and inspire.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.673
We stayed full-time students,
but in between we traveled,

00:09:07.697 --> 00:09:09.525
performing and teaching

00:09:09.549 --> 00:09:11.933
nine-year-olds to MFA candidates,

00:09:11.957 --> 00:09:15.303
from California to Indiana to India

00:09:15.327 --> 00:09:17.934
to a public high school
just up the street from campus.

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.935
And we saw over and over

00:09:19.959 --> 00:09:21.934
the way that spoken-word poetry

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.373
cracks open locks.

00:09:24.059 --> 00:09:28.178
But it turns out sometimes,
poetry can be really scary.

00:09:28.781 --> 00:09:30.273
Turns out sometimes,

00:09:30.297 --> 00:09:32.934
you have to trick teenagers
into writing poetry.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:36.423
So I came up with lists.
Everyone can write lists.

00:09:36.447 --> 00:09:38.473
And the first list that I assign

00:09:38.497 --> 00:09:41.177
is "10 Things I Know to be True."

00:09:41.780 --> 00:09:44.136
And here's what happens,
you would discover it too

00:09:44.160 --> 00:09:46.279
if we all started sharing
our lists out loud.

00:09:46.303 --> 00:09:51.633
At a certain point, you would realize
that someone has the exact same thing,

00:09:51.657 --> 00:09:53.634
or one thing very similar,

00:09:53.658 --> 00:09:54.934
to something on your list.

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:56.934
And then someone else

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:59.528
has something the complete
opposite of yours.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Third, someone has something
you've never even heard of before.

00:10:02.982 --> 00:10:06.427
Fourth, someone has something
you thought you knew everything about,

00:10:06.451 --> 00:10:08.934
but they're introducing
a new angle of looking at it.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.006
And I tell people that this is
where great stories start from --

00:10:12.030 --> 00:10:14.158
these four intersections

00:10:14.182 --> 00:10:15.934
of what you're passionate about

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:18.341
and what others might be invested in.

00:10:18.365 --> 00:10:20.934
And most people respond
really well to this exercise.

00:10:21.634 --> 00:10:24.079
But one of my students,
a freshman named Charlotte,

00:10:24.103 --> 00:10:25.563
was not convinced.

00:10:25.999 --> 00:10:29.625
Charlotte was very good at writing lists,
but she refused to write any poems.

00:10:29.649 --> 00:10:31.937
"Miss," she'd say,
"I'm just not interesting.

00:10:31.961 --> 00:10:34.388
I don't have anything interesting to say."

00:10:35.069 --> 00:10:36.934
So I assigned her list after list,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.609
and one day I assigned the list

00:10:38.633 --> 00:10:40.609
"10 Things I Should Have Learned by Now."

00:10:41.251 --> 00:10:43.161
Number three on Charlotte's list was,

00:10:43.185 --> 00:10:45.202
"I should have learned
not to crush on guys

00:10:45.226 --> 00:10:46.701
three times my age."

00:10:47.653 --> 00:10:49.026
I asked her what that meant,

00:10:49.050 --> 00:10:51.488
and she said, "Miss,
it's kind of a long story."

00:10:51.512 --> 00:10:54.336
And I said, "Charlotte, it sounds
pretty interesting to me."

00:10:54.360 --> 00:10:56.114
And so she wrote her first poem,

00:10:56.138 --> 00:10:59.715
a love poem unlike any
I had ever heard before.

00:10:59.739 --> 00:11:02.160
And the poem began,

00:11:02.184 --> 00:11:04.302
"Anderson Cooper is a gorgeous man."

00:11:04.326 --> 00:11:06.795
(Laughter)

00:11:06.819 --> 00:11:08.436
"Did you see him on 60 Minutes,

00:11:08.460 --> 00:11:10.240
racing Michael Phelps in a pool --

00:11:10.264 --> 00:11:11.934
nothing but swim trunks on --

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:15.090
diving in the water, determined
to beat this swimming champion?

00:11:15.114 --> 00:11:17.503
After the race, he tossed
his wet, cloud-white hair

00:11:17.527 --> 00:11:18.786
and said, 'You're a god.'

00:11:18.810 --> 00:11:20.934
No, Anderson, you're the god."

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:22.934
(Laughter)

00:11:22.958 --> 00:11:26.831
(Applause)

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:30.750
Now, I know that the number one
rule to being cool

00:11:30.774 --> 00:11:32.661
is to seem unfazed,

00:11:32.685 --> 00:11:35.881
to never admit that anything scares you

00:11:35.905 --> 00:11:37.514
or impresses you or excites you.

00:11:37.538 --> 00:11:38.934
Somebody once told me

00:11:38.958 --> 00:11:41.107
it's like walking through life like this.

00:11:41.131 --> 00:11:42.505
You protect yourself

00:11:42.529 --> 00:11:45.767
from all the unexpected miseries
or hurt that might show up.

00:11:45.791 --> 00:11:48.421
But I try to walk through life like this.

00:11:48.445 --> 00:11:51.312
And yes, that means catching
all of those miseries and hurt,

00:11:51.336 --> 00:11:55.062
but it also means
that when beautiful, amazing things

00:11:55.086 --> 00:11:56.503
just fall out of the sky,

00:11:56.527 --> 00:11:57.934
I'm ready to catch them.

00:11:57.958 --> 00:12:00.339
I use spoken word to help my students

00:12:00.363 --> 00:12:01.934
rediscover wonder,

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:04.724
to fight their instincts
to be cool and unfazed

00:12:04.748 --> 00:12:08.263
and, instead, actively pursue being
engaged with what goes on around them,

00:12:08.287 --> 00:12:11.580
so that they can reinterpret
and create something from it.

00:12:11.604 --> 00:12:13.897
It's not that I think
that spoken-word poetry

00:12:13.921 --> 00:12:15.397
is the ideal art form.

00:12:15.421 --> 00:12:18.556
I'm always trying to find
the best way to tell each story.

00:12:18.580 --> 00:12:21.605
I write musicals; I make short films
alongside my poems.

00:12:21.629 --> 00:12:23.803
But I teach spoken-word poetry

00:12:23.827 --> 00:12:25.772
because it's accessible.

00:12:25.796 --> 00:12:29.244
Not everyone can read music
or owns a camera,

00:12:29.268 --> 00:12:31.633
but everyone can communicate in some way,

00:12:31.657 --> 00:12:35.434
and everyone has stories
that the rest of us can learn from.

00:12:35.458 --> 00:12:38.690
Plus, spoken-word poetry allows
for immediate connection.

00:12:38.714 --> 00:12:40.909
It's not uncommon
to feel like you're alone

00:12:40.933 --> 00:12:42.526
or that nobody understands you,

00:12:42.550 --> 00:12:43.934
but spoken word teaches

00:12:43.958 --> 00:12:46.689
that if you have the ability
to express yourself

00:12:46.713 --> 00:12:49.530
and the courage to present
those stories and opinions,

00:12:49.554 --> 00:12:50.934
you could be rewarded

00:12:50.958 --> 00:12:52.934
with a room full of your peers,

00:12:52.958 --> 00:12:55.244
or your community, who will listen.

00:12:55.268 --> 00:12:57.563
And maybe even a giant girl in a hoodie

00:12:57.587 --> 00:12:59.633
who will connect with what you've shared.

00:12:59.657 --> 00:13:01.934
And that is an amazing
realization to have,

00:13:01.958 --> 00:13:03.804
especially when you're 14.

00:13:04.424 --> 00:13:05.934
Plus, now with YouTube,

00:13:05.958 --> 00:13:08.600
that connection's not even limited
to the room we're in.

00:13:08.624 --> 00:13:11.846
I'm so lucky that there's
this archive of performances

00:13:11.870 --> 00:13:13.534
that I can share with my students.

00:13:13.558 --> 00:13:16.003
It allows for even more opportunities

00:13:16.027 --> 00:13:19.430
for them to find a poet or a poem
that they connect to.

00:13:19.825 --> 00:13:22.292
Once you've figured this out,

00:13:22.316 --> 00:13:24.459
it is tempting to keep
writing the same poem,

00:13:24.483 --> 00:13:26.666
or keep telling the same story,
over and over,

00:13:26.690 --> 00:13:29.269
once you've figured out
that it will gain you applause.

00:13:29.293 --> 00:13:32.276
It's not enough to just teach
that you can express yourself.

00:13:32.300 --> 00:13:33.934
You have to grow and explore

00:13:33.958 --> 00:13:36.255
and take risks and challenge yourself.

00:13:36.279 --> 00:13:38.934
And that is step three:

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.934
infusing the work you're doing

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.006
with the specific things
that make you you,

00:13:43.030 --> 00:13:45.360
even while those things
are always changing.

00:13:45.667 --> 00:13:48.098
Because step three never ends.

00:13:48.507 --> 00:13:50.511
But you don't get to start on step three,

00:13:50.535 --> 00:13:52.699
until you take step one first:

00:13:52.723 --> 00:13:53.736
"I can."

00:13:53.760 --> 00:13:55.482
I travel a lot while I'm teaching,

00:13:55.506 --> 00:13:59.008
and I don't always get to watch
all of my students reach their step three,

00:13:59.032 --> 00:14:00.750
but I was very lucky with Charlotte,

00:14:00.774 --> 00:14:03.414
that I got to watch her journey
unfold the way it did.

00:14:03.438 --> 00:14:04.770
I watched her realize

00:14:04.794 --> 00:14:08.570
that, by putting the things that she knows
to be true into the work she's doing,

00:14:08.594 --> 00:14:11.034
she can create poems
that only Charlotte can write,

00:14:11.058 --> 00:14:13.997
about eyeballs and elevators
and Dora the Explorer.

00:14:14.370 --> 00:14:16.711
And I'm trying to tell
stories only I can tell --

00:14:16.735 --> 00:14:17.934
like this story.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:21.222
I spent a lot of time thinking
about the best way to tell this story,

00:14:21.246 --> 00:14:22.688
and I wondered if the best way

00:14:22.712 --> 00:14:24.815
was going to be
a PowerPoint, a short film --

00:14:24.839 --> 00:14:27.616
And where exactly was the beginning,
the middle or the end?

00:14:27.640 --> 00:14:30.013
I wondered whether I'd get
to the end of this talk

00:14:30.037 --> 00:14:32.591
and finally have
figured it all out, or not.

00:14:33.266 --> 00:14:36.530
And I always thought that my beginning
was at the Bowery Poetry Club,

00:14:36.554 --> 00:14:38.630
but it's possible
that it was much earlier.

00:14:38.654 --> 00:14:39.934
In preparing for TED,

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:42.197
I discovered this diary page
in an old journal.

00:14:42.221 --> 00:14:45.403
I think December 54th
was probably supposed to be 24th.

00:14:45.958 --> 00:14:47.934
It's clear that when I was a child,

00:14:47.958 --> 00:14:50.211
I definitely walked
through life like this.

00:14:50.235 --> 00:14:51.545
I think that we all did.

00:14:52.021 --> 00:14:54.934
I would like to help others
rediscover that wonder --

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:57.423
to want to engage with it,
to want to learn,

00:14:57.447 --> 00:14:59.334
to want to share what they've learned,

00:14:59.358 --> 00:15:01.034
what they've figured out to be true

00:15:01.058 --> 00:15:03.034
and what they're still figuring out.

00:15:03.058 --> 00:15:05.220
So I'd like to close with this poem.

00:15:06.764 --> 00:15:09.345
When they bombed Hiroshima,

00:15:09.369 --> 00:15:12.424
the explosion formed a mini-supernova,

00:15:12.448 --> 00:15:15.502
so every living animal, human or plant

00:15:15.526 --> 00:15:19.204
that received direct contact
with the rays from that sun

00:15:19.228 --> 00:15:20.824
was instantly turned to ash.

00:15:21.110 --> 00:15:23.199
And what was left
of the city soon followed.

00:15:23.223 --> 00:15:25.627
The long-lasting damage
of nuclear radiation

00:15:25.651 --> 00:15:28.568
caused an entire city and its population

00:15:28.592 --> 00:15:30.436
to turn into powder.

00:15:31.104 --> 00:15:34.717
When I was born, my mom says
I looked around the whole hospital room

00:15:34.741 --> 00:15:37.934
with a stare that said,
"This? I've done this before."

00:15:38.382 --> 00:15:40.036
She says I have old eyes.

00:15:40.298 --> 00:15:42.934
When my Grandpa Genji died,
I was only five years old,

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:45.107
but I took my mom
by the hand and told her,

00:15:45.131 --> 00:15:47.671
"Don't worry, he'll come back as a baby."

00:15:48.242 --> 00:15:51.406
And yet, for someone
who's apparently done this already,

00:15:51.430 --> 00:15:53.934
I still haven't figured anything out yet.

00:15:53.958 --> 00:15:56.934
My knees still buckle
every time I get on a stage.

00:15:56.958 --> 00:15:58.934
My self-confidence can be measured out

00:15:58.958 --> 00:16:00.934
in teaspoons mixed into my poetry,

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:03.934
and it still always
tastes funny in my mouth.

00:16:04.260 --> 00:16:07.481
But in Hiroshima, some people
were wiped clean away,

00:16:07.505 --> 00:16:10.259
leaving only a wristwatch or a diary page.

00:16:10.283 --> 00:16:13.715
So no matter that I have inhibitions
to fill all my pockets,

00:16:13.739 --> 00:16:14.934
I keep trying,

00:16:14.958 --> 00:16:16.934
hoping that one day I'll write a poem

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:19.101
I can be proud to let sit
in a museum exhibit

00:16:19.125 --> 00:16:21.362
as the only proof I existed.

00:16:21.813 --> 00:16:24.934
My parents named me Sarah,
which is a biblical name.

00:16:24.958 --> 00:16:29.315
In the original story, God told Sarah
she could do something impossible, and --

00:16:29.783 --> 00:16:31.037
she laughed,

00:16:31.061 --> 00:16:32.638
because the first Sarah,

00:16:32.662 --> 00:16:35.006
she didn't know what to do
with impossible.

00:16:35.030 --> 00:16:36.230
And me?

00:16:36.414 --> 00:16:37.934
Well, neither do I,

00:16:37.958 --> 00:16:39.934
but I see the impossible every day.

00:16:39.958 --> 00:16:42.863
Impossible is trying
to connect in this world,

00:16:42.887 --> 00:16:45.991
trying to hold onto others while things
are blowing up around you,

00:16:46.015 --> 00:16:47.691
knowing that while you're speaking,

00:16:47.715 --> 00:16:50.773
they aren't just waiting for their turn
to talk -- they hear you.

00:16:50.797 --> 00:16:52.288
They feel exactly what you feel

00:16:52.312 --> 00:16:53.934
at the same time that you feel it.

00:16:53.958 --> 00:16:56.435
It's what I strive for every time
I open my mouth --

00:16:56.459 --> 00:16:58.539
that impossible connection.

00:16:58.563 --> 00:17:00.934
There's this piece of wall in Hiroshima

00:17:00.958 --> 00:17:03.700
that was completely burnt
black by the radiation.

00:17:03.724 --> 00:17:06.398
But on the front step,
a person who was sitting there

00:17:06.422 --> 00:17:08.692
blocked the rays from hitting the stone.

00:17:08.716 --> 00:17:09.934
The only thing left now

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:12.466
is a permanent shadow of positive light.

00:17:12.883 --> 00:17:13.934
After the A-bomb,

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.546
specialists said it would take 75 years

00:17:16.570 --> 00:17:18.934
for the radiation-damaged
soil of Hiroshima City

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.934
to ever grow anything again.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:24.323
But that spring, there were
new buds popping up from the earth.

00:17:24.347 --> 00:17:26.350
When I meet you, in that moment,

00:17:26.374 --> 00:17:28.210
I'm no longer a part of your future.

00:17:28.234 --> 00:17:30.473
I start quickly becoming
part of your past.

00:17:30.497 --> 00:17:32.934
But in that instant,
I get to share your present.

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.934
And you, you get to share mine.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.934
And that is the greatest present of all.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.220
So if you tell me
I can do the impossible --

00:17:39.852 --> 00:17:41.346
I'll probably laugh at you.

00:17:41.370 --> 00:17:43.458
I don't know if I can change
the world yet,

00:17:43.482 --> 00:17:45.501
because I don't know that much about it --

00:17:45.525 --> 00:17:48.115
and I don't know that much
about reincarnation either,

00:17:48.139 --> 00:17:49.983
but if you make me laugh hard enough,

00:17:50.007 --> 00:17:52.235
sometimes I forget what century I'm in.

00:17:52.259 --> 00:17:55.718
This isn't my first time here.
This isn't my last time here.

00:17:55.742 --> 00:17:57.654
These aren't the last words I'll share.

00:17:57.678 --> 00:17:59.934

title: The magic washing machine
transcript: I was only four years old when I saw my mother load a washing machine for the very first time in her life. That was a great day for my mother. My mother and father had been saving money for years to be able to buy that machine, and the first day it was going to be used, even Grandma was invited to see the machine. And Grandma was even more excited. Throughout her life she had been heating water with firewood, and she had hand washed laundry for seven children. And now she was going to watch electricity do that work.My mother carefully opened the door, and she loaded the laundry into the machine, like this. And then, when she closed the door, Grandma said, "No, no, no, no. Let me, let me push the button." And Grandma pushed the button, and she said, "Oh, fantastic! I want to see this! Give me a chair! Give me a chair! I want to see it," and she sat down in front of the machine, and she watched the entire washing program. She was mesmerized. To my grandmother, the washing machine was a miracle.Today, in Sweden and other rich countries, people are using so many different machines. Look, the homes are full of machines. I can't even name them all. And they also, when they want to travel, they use flying machines that can take them to remote destinations. And yet, in the world, there are so many people who still heat the water on fire, and they cook their food on fire. Sometimes they don't even have enough food, and they live below the poverty line. There are two billion fellow human beings who live on less than two dollars a day. And the richest people over there — there's one billion people — and they live above what I call the "air line," because they spend more than $80 a day on their consumption.But this is just one, two, three billion people, and obviously there are seven billion people in the world, so there must be one, two, three, four billion people more who live in between the poverty and the air line. They have electricity, but the question is, how many have washing machines? I've done the scrutiny of market data, and I've found that, indeed, the washing machine has penetrated below the air line, and today there's an additional one billion people out there who live above the "wash line." (Laughter) And they consume more than $40 per day. So two billion have access to washing machines.And the remaining five billion, how do they wash? Or, to be more precise, how do most of the women in the world wash? Because it remains hard work for women to wash. They wash like this: by hand. It's a hard, time-consuming labor, which they have to do for hours every week. And sometimes they also have to bring water from far away to do the laundry at home, or they have to bring the laundry away to a stream far off. And they want the washing machine. They don't want to spend such a large part of their life doing this hard work with so relatively low productivity. And there's nothing different in their wish than it was for my grandma. Look here, two generations ago in Sweden — picking water from the stream, heating with firewood and washing like that. They want the washing machine in exactly the same way.But when I lecture to environmentally-concerned students, they tell me, "No, everybody in the world cannot have cars and washing machines." How can we tell this woman that she ain't going to have a washing machine? And then I ask my students, I've asked them — over the last two years I've asked, "How many of you doesn't use a car?" And some of them proudly raise their hand and say, "I don't use a car." And then I put the really tough question: "How many of you hand-wash your jeans and your bed sheets?" And no one raised their hand. Even the hardcore in the green movement use washing machines.(Laughter)So how come [this is] something that everyone uses and they think others will not stop it? What is special with this? I had to do an analysis about the energy used in the world. Here we are. Look here, you see the seven billion people up there: the air people, the wash people, the bulb people and the fire people. One unit like this is an energy unit of fossil fuel — oil, coal or gas. That's what most of electricity and the energy in the world is. And it's 12 units used in the entire world, and the richest one billion, they use six of them. Half of the energy is used by one seventh of the world's population. And these ones who have washing machines, but not a house full of other machines, they use two. This group uses three, one each. And they also have electricity. And over there they don't even use one each. That makes 12 of them.But the main concern for the environmentally-interested students — and they are right — is about the future. What are the trends? If we just prolong the trends, without any real advanced analysis, to 2050, there are two things that can increase the energy use. First, population growth. Second, economic growth. Population growth will mainly occur among the poorest people here because they have high child mortality and they have many children per woman. And [with] that you will get two extra, but that won't change the energy use very much.What will happen is economic growth. The best of here in the emerging economies — I call them the New East — they will jump the air line. "Wopp!" they will say. And they will start to use as much as the Old West are doing already. And these people, they want the washing machine. I told you. They'll go there. And they will double their energy use. And we hope that the poor people will get into the electric light. And they'll get a two-child family without a stop in population growth. But the total energy consumption will increase to 22 units. And these 22 units — still the richest people use most of it. So what needs to be done? Because the risk, the high probability of climate change is real. It's real. Of course they must be more energy-efficient. They must change behavior in some way. They must also start to produce green energy, much more green energy. But until they have the same energy consumption per person, they shouldn't give advice to others — what to do and what not to do. (Applause) Here we can get more green energy all over.This is what we hope may happen. It's a real challenge in the future. But I can assure you that this woman in the favela in Rio, she wants a washing machine. She's very happy about her minister of energy that provided electricity to everyone — so happy that she even voted for her. And she became Dilma Rousseff, the president-elect of one of the biggest democracies in the world — moving from minister of energy to president. If you have democracy, people will vote for washing machines. They love them.And what's the magic with them? My mother explained the magic with this machine the very, very first day. She said, "Now Hans, we have loaded the laundry. The machine will make the work. And now we can go to the library." Because this is the magic: you load the laundry, and what do you get out of the machine? You get books out of the machines, children's books. And mother got time to read for me. She loved this. I got the "ABC's" — this is where I started my career as a professor, when my mother had time to read for me. And she also got books for herself. She managed to study English and learn that as a foreign language. And she read so many novels, so many different novels here. And we really, we really loved this machine.And what we said, my mother and me, "Thank you industrialization. Thank you steel mill. Thank you power station. And thank you chemical processing industry that gave us time to read books."Thank you very much.(Applause)

title: Evolution's gift of play, from bonobo apes to humans
transcript: I just came back from a community that holds the secret to human survival. It's a place where women run the show, have sex to say hello, and play rules the day — where fun is serious business. And no, this isn't Burning Man or San Francisco. (Laughter) Ladies and gentlemen, meet your cousins. This is the world of wild bonobos in the jungles of Congo. Bonobos are, together with chimpanzees, your living closest relative. That means we all share a common ancestor, an evolutionary grandmother, who lived around six million years ago. Now, chimpanzees are well-known for their aggression.(Laughter)But unfortunately, we have made too much of an emphasis of this aspect in our narratives of human evolution. But bonobos show us the other side of the coin. While chimpanzees are dominated by big, scary guys, bonobo society is run by empowered females. These guys have really worked something out, since this leads to a highly tolerant society where fatal violence has not been observed yet. But unfortunately, bonobos are the least understood of the great apes. They live in the depths of the Congolese jungle, and it has been very difficult to study them.The Congo is a paradox — a land of extraordinary biodiversity and beauty, but also the heart of darkness itself — the scene of a violent conflict that has raged for decades and claimed nearly as many lives as the First World War. Not surprisingly, this destruction also endangers bonobo survival. We know them as the "make love, not war" apes since they have frequent, promiscuous and bisexual sex to manage conflict and solve social issues. Now, I'm not saying this is the solution to all of humanity's problems — since there's more to bonobo life than the Kama Sutra. Bonobos, like humans, love to play throughout their entire lives. Play is not just child's games. For us and them, play is foundational for bonding relationships and fostering tolerance. It's where we learn to trust and where we learn about the rules of the game. Play increases creativity and resilience, and it's all about the generation of diversity — diversity of interactions, diversity of behaviors, diversity of connections. And when you watch bonobo play, you're seeing the very evolutionary roots of human laughter, dance and ritual. Play is the glue that binds us together.Now, I don't know how you play, but I want to show you a couple of unique clips fresh from the wild. First, it's a ball game bonobo-style — and I do not mean football. So here, we have a young female and a male engaged in a chase game. Have a look what she's doing. (Laughter) So sex play is common in both bonobos and humans. In times when it seems least appropriate to play, it might be the times when it is most urgent.And so, my fellow primates, let us embrace this gift from evolution and play together, as we rediscover creativity, fellowship and wonder.Thank you.(Applause)
