00:00:33.958 --> 00:00:36.958
"Come to visit the children?

00:00:36.958 --> 00:00:38.958
How long are you staying?"

00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:41.958
Well actually, I hope for a while longer yet.

00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:44.958
I have been living and teaching in the Gulf

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:46.958
for over 30 years.

00:00:46.958 --> 00:00:50.958
(Applause)

00:00:50.958 --> 00:00:54.958
And in that time, I have seen a lot of changes.

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
Now that statistic

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:58.958
is quite shocking.

00:00:58.958 --> 00:01:00.958
And I want to talk to you today

00:01:00.958 --> 00:01:02.958
about language loss

00:01:02.958 --> 00:01:05.958
and the globalization of English.

00:01:05.958 --> 00:01:07.958
I want to tell you about my friend

00:01:07.958 --> 00:01:10.958
who was teaching English to adults in Abu Dhabi.

00:01:10.958 --> 00:01:12.958
And one fine day,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
she decided to take them into the garden

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
to teach them some nature vocabulary.

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
But it was she who ended up learning

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
all the Arabic words for the local plants,

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:22.958
as well as their uses --

00:01:22.958 --> 00:01:25.958
medicinal uses, cosmetics,

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:28.958
cooking, herbal.

00:01:28.958 --> 00:01:30.958
How did those students get all that knowledge?

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:32.958
Of course, from their grandparents

00:01:32.958 --> 00:01:35.958
and even their great-grandparents.

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:38.958
It's not necessary to tell you how important it is

00:01:38.958 --> 00:01:40.958
to be able to communicate

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
across generations.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
But sadly, today,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
languages are dying

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:48.958
at an unprecedented rate.

00:01:48.958 --> 00:01:51.958
A language dies every 14 days.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:54.958
Now, at the same time,

00:01:54.958 --> 00:01:56.958
English is the undisputed global language.

00:01:56.958 --> 00:01:58.958
Could there be a connection?

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:00.958
Well I don't know.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
But I do know that I've seen a lot of changes.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:06.958
When I first came out to the Gulf, I came to Kuwait

00:02:06.958 --> 00:02:09.958
in the days when it was still a hardship post.

00:02:09.958 --> 00:02:11.958
Actually, not that long ago.

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:14.958
That is a little bit too early.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
But nevertheless,

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
I was recruited by the British Council,

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:20.958
along with about 25 other teachers.

00:02:20.958 --> 00:02:22.958
And we were the first non-Muslims

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:25.958
to teach in the state schools there in Kuwait.

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
We were brought to teach English

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:31.958
because the government wanted to modernize the country

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:34.958
and to empower the citizens through education.

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
And of course, the U.K. benefited

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
from some of that lovely oil wealth.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
Okay.

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:44.958
Now this is the major change that I've seen --

00:02:44.958 --> 00:02:46.958
how teaching English

00:02:46.958 --> 00:02:48.958
has morphed

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:52.958
from being a mutually beneficial practice

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
to becoming a massive international business that it is today.

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:59.958
No longer just a foreign language on the school curriculum,

00:02:59.958 --> 00:03:01.958
and no longer the sole domain

00:03:01.958 --> 00:03:03.958
of mother England,

00:03:03.958 --> 00:03:05.958
it has become a bandwagon

00:03:05.958 --> 00:03:08.958
for every English-speaking nation on earth.

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
And why not?

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
After all, the best education --

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:16.958
according to the latest World University Rankings --

00:03:16.958 --> 00:03:18.958
is to be found in the universities

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:22.958
of the U.K. and the U.S.

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:26.958
So everybody wants to have an English education, naturally.

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
But if you're not a native speaker,

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:30.958
you have to pass a test.

00:03:30.958 --> 00:03:32.958
Now can it be right

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
to reject a student

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
on linguistic ability alone?

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
Perhaps you have a computer scientist

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
who's a genius.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:43.958
Would he need the same language as a lawyer, for example?

00:03:43.958 --> 00:03:46.958
Well, I don't think so.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
We English teachers reject them all the time.

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:52.958
We put a stop sign,

00:03:52.958 --> 00:03:54.958
and we stop them in their tracks.

00:03:54.958 --> 00:03:56.958
They can't pursue their dream any longer,

00:03:56.958 --> 00:03:59.958
'til they get English.

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
Now let me put it this way:

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:07.958
if I met a monolingual Dutch speaker

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
who had the cure for cancer,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:12.958
would I stop him from entering my British University?

00:04:12.958 --> 00:04:14.958
I don't think so.

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:17.958
But indeed, that is exactly what we do.

00:04:17.958 --> 00:04:20.958
We English teachers are the gatekeepers.

00:04:20.958 --> 00:04:23.958
And you have to satisfy us first

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:26.958
that your English is good enough.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
Now it can be dangerous

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
to give too much power

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
to a narrow segment of society.

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:37.958
Maybe the barrier would be too universal.

00:04:37.958 --> 00:04:39.958
Okay.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:42.958
"But," I hear you say,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
"what about the research?

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:46.958
It's all in English."

00:04:46.958 --> 00:04:48.958
So the books are in English,

00:04:48.958 --> 00:04:50.958
the journals are done in English,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:53.958
but that is a self-fulfilling prophecy.

00:04:53.958 --> 00:04:55.958
It feeds the English requirement.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
And so it goes on.

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:00.958
I ask you, what happened to translation?

00:05:00.958 --> 00:05:04.958
If you think about the Islamic Golden Age,

00:05:04.958 --> 00:05:07.958
there was lots of translation then.

00:05:07.958 --> 00:05:10.958
They translated from Latin and Greek

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:12.958
into Arabic, into Persian,

00:05:12.958 --> 00:05:14.958
and then it was translated on

00:05:14.958 --> 00:05:16.958
into the Germanic languages of Europe

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:18.958
and the Romance languages.

00:05:18.958 --> 00:05:22.958
And so light shone upon the Dark Ages of Europe.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
Now don't get me wrong;

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
I am not against teaching English,

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
all you English teachers out there.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
I love it that we have a global language.

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:34.958
We need one today more than ever.

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:36.958
But I am against using it

00:05:36.958 --> 00:05:38.958
as a barrier.

00:05:38.958 --> 00:05:41.958
Do we really want to end up with 600 languages

00:05:41.958 --> 00:05:44.958
and the main one being English, or Chinese?

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:47.958
We need more than that. Where do we draw the line?

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
This system

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:52.958
equates intelligence

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
with a knowledge of English,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
which is quite arbitrary.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:03.958
(Applause)

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:05.958
And I want to remind you

00:06:05.958 --> 00:06:08.958
that the giants upon whose shoulders

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
today's intelligentsia stand

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:12.958
did not have to have English,

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:14.958
they didn't have to pass an English test.

00:06:14.958 --> 00:06:17.958
Case in point, Einstein.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:21.958
He, by the way, was considered remedial at school

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
because he was, in fact, dyslexic.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
But fortunately for the world,

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
he did not have to pass an English test.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
Because they didn't start until 1964

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
with TOEFL,

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
the American test of English.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
Now it's exploded.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:40.958
There are lots and lots of tests of English.

00:06:40.958 --> 00:06:42.958
And millions and millions of students

00:06:42.958 --> 00:06:44.958
take these tests every year.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
Now you might think, you and me,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
"Those fees aren't bad, they're okay,"

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
but they are prohibitive

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
to so many millions of poor people.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:54.958
So immediately, we're rejecting them.

00:06:54.958 --> 00:06:57.958
(Applause)

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
It brings to mind a headline I saw recently:

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
"Education: The Great Divide."

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:04.958
Now I get it,

00:07:04.958 --> 00:07:07.958
I understand why people would want to focus on English.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
They want to give their children the best chance in life.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:14.958
And to do that, they need a Western education.

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
Because, of course, the best jobs

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:19.958
go to people out of the Western Universities,

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
that I put on earlier.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
It's a circular thing.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
Okay.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
Let me tell you a story about two scientists,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
two English scientists.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
They were doing an experiment

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
to do with genetics

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
and the forelimbs and the hind limbs of animals.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:38.958
But they couldn't get the results they wanted.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
They really didn't know what to do,

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:43.958
until along came a German scientist

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
who realized that they were using two words

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
for forelimb and hind limb,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:52.958
whereas genetics does not differentiate

00:07:52.958 --> 00:07:54.958
and neither does German.

00:07:54.958 --> 00:07:56.958
So bingo,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:58.958
problem solved.

00:07:58.958 --> 00:08:00.958
If you can't think a thought,

00:08:00.958 --> 00:08:03.958
you are stuck.

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
But if another language can think that thought,

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
then, by cooperating,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
we can achieve and learn so much more.

00:08:12.958 --> 00:08:14.958
My daughter

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:17.958
came to England from Kuwait.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
She had studied science and mathematics in Arabic.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
It's an Arabic-medium school.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
She had to translate it into English at her grammar school.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
And she was the best in the class

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
at those subjects.

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
Which tells us

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:34.958
that when students come to us from abroad,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
we may not be giving them enough credit

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
for what they know,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:41.958
and they know it in their own language.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
When a language dies,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
we don't know what we lose with that language.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:50.958
This is -- I don't know if you saw it on CNN recently --

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
they gave the Heroes Award

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
to a young Kenyan shepherd boy

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:58.958
who couldn't study at night in his village,

00:08:58.958 --> 00:09:00.958
like all the village children,

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
because the kerosene lamp,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
it had smoke and it damaged his eyes.

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:07.958
And anyway, there was never enough kerosene,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
because what does a dollar a day buy for you?

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
So he invented

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
a cost-free solar lamp.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
And now the children in his village

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
get the same grades at school

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:23.958
as the children who have electricity at home.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:29.958
(Applause)

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:31.958
When he received his award,

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:33.958
he said these lovely words:

00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.958
"The children can lead Africa from what it is today,

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:38.958
a dark continent,

00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:40.958
to a light continent."

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
A simple idea,

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
but it could have such far-reaching consequences.

00:09:46.958 --> 00:09:48.958
People who have no light,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
whether it's physical or metaphorical,

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:54.958
cannot pass our exams,

00:09:54.958 --> 00:09:57.958
and we can never know what they know.

00:09:57.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Let us not keep them and ourselves

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
in the dark.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
Let us celebrate diversity.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
Mind your language.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:12.958
Use it to spread great ideas.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:19.958
(Applause)

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
Thank you very much.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
(Applause)

title: Cracking Stuxnet, a 21st-century cyber weapon
transcript: The idea behind the Stuxnet computer worm is actually quite simple. We don't want Iran to get the bomb. Their major asset for developing nuclear weapons is the Natanz uranium enrichment facility. The gray boxes that you see, these are real-time control systems. Now if we manage to compromise these systems that control drive speeds and valves, we can actually cause a lot of problems with the centrifuge. The gray boxes don't run Windows software; they are a completely different technology. But if we manage to place a good Windows virus on a notebook that is used by a maintenance engineer to configure this gray box, then we are in business. And this is the plot behind Stuxnet.So we start with a Windows dropper. The payload goes onto the gray box, damages the centrifuge, and the Iranian nuclear program is delayed — mission accomplished. That's easy, huh? I want to tell you how we found that out. When we started our research on Stuxnet six months ago, it was completely unknown what the purpose of this thing was. The only thing that was known is it's very, very complex on the Windows part, the dropper part, used multiple zero-day vulnerabilities. And it seemed to want to do something with these gray boxes, these real-time control systems. So that got our attention, and we started a lab project where we infected our environment with Stuxnet and checked this thing out. And then some very funny things happened. Stuxnet behaved like a lab rat that didn't like our cheese — sniffed, but didn't want to eat. Didn't make sense to me. And after we experimented with different flavors of cheese, I realized, well, this is a directed attack. It's completely directed. The dropper is prowling actively on the gray box if a specific configuration is found, and even if the actual program code that it's trying to infect is actually running on that target. And if not, Stuxnet does nothing.So that really got my attention, and we started to work on this nearly around the clock, because I thought, "Well, we don't know what the target is. It could be, let's say for example, a U.S. power plant, or a chemical plant in Germany. So we better find out what the target is soon." So we extracted and decompiled the attack code, and we discovered that it's structured in two digital bombs — a smaller one and a bigger one. And we also saw that they are very professionally engineered by people who obviously had all insider information. They knew all the bits and bites that they had to attack. They probably even know the shoe size of the operator. So they know everything.And if you have heard that the dropper of Stuxnet is complex and high-tech, let me tell you this: the payload is rocket science. It's way above everything that we have ever seen before. Here you see a sample of this actual attack code. We are talking about — around about 15,000 lines of code. Looks pretty much like old-style assembly language. And I want to tell you how we were able to make sense out of this code. So what we were looking for is, first of all, system function calls, because we know what they do.And then we were looking for timers and data structures and trying to relate them to the real world — to potential real world targets. So we do need target theories that we can prove or disprove. In order to get target theories, we remember that it's definitely hardcore sabotage, it must be a high-value target and it is most likely located in Iran, because that's where most of the infections had been reported. Now you don't find several thousand targets in that area. It basically boils down to the Bushehr nuclear power plant and to the Natanz fuel enrichment plant.So I told my assistant, "Get me a list of all centrifuge and power plant experts from our client base." And I phoned them up and picked their brain in an effort to match their expertise with what we found in code and data. And that worked pretty well. So we were able to associate the small digital warhead with the rotor control. The rotor is that moving part within the centrifuge, that black object that you see. And if you manipulate the speed of this rotor, you are actually able to crack the rotor and eventually even have the centrifuge explode. What we also saw is that the goal of the attack was really to do it slowly and creepy — obviously in an effort to drive maintenance engineers crazy, that they would not be able to figure this out quickly.The big digital warhead — we had a shot at this by looking very closely at data and data structures. So for example, the number 164 really stands out in that code; you can't overlook it. I started to research scientific literature on how these centrifuges are actually built in Natanz and found they are structured in what is called a cascade, and each cascade holds 164 centrifuges. So that made sense, that was a match.And it even got better. These centrifuges in Iran are subdivided into 15, what is called, stages. And guess what we found in the attack code? An almost identical structure. So again, that was a real good match. And this gave us very high confidence for what we were looking at. Now don't get me wrong here, it didn't go like this. These results have been obtained over several weeks of really hard labor. And we often went into just a dead end and had to recover.Anyway, so we figured out that both digital warheads were actually aiming at one and the same target, but from different angles. The small warhead is taking one cascade, and spinning up the rotors and slowing them down, and the big warhead is talking to six cascades and manipulating valves. So in all, we are very confident that we have actually determined what the target is. It is Natanz, and it is only Natanz. So we don't have to worry that other targets might be hit by Stuxnet.Here's some very cool stuff that we saw — really knocked my socks off. Down there is the gray box, and on the top you see the centrifuges. Now what this thing does is it intercepts the input values from sensors — so for example, from pressure sensors and vibration sensors — and it provides legitimate program code, which is still running during the attack, with fake input data. And as a matter of fact, this fake input data is actually prerecorded by Stuxnet. So it's just like from the Hollywood movies where during the heist, the observation camera is fed with prerecorded video. That's cool, huh?The idea here is obviously not only to fool the operators in the control room. It actually is much more dangerous and aggressive. The idea is to circumvent a digital safety system. We need digital safety systems where a human operator could not act quick enough. So for example, in a power plant, when your big steam turbine gets too over speed, you must open relief valves within a millisecond. Obviously, this cannot be done by a human operator. So this is where we need digital safety systems. And when they are compromised, then real bad things can happen. Your plant can blow up. And neither your operators nor your safety system will notice it. That's scary.But it gets worse. And this is very important, what I'm going to say. Think about this: this attack is generic. It doesn't have anything to do, in specifics, with centrifuges, with uranium enrichment. So it would work as well, for example, in a power plant or in an automobile factory. It is generic. And you don't have — as an attacker — you don't have to deliver this payload by a USB stick, as we saw it in the case of Stuxnet. You could also use conventional worm technology for spreading. Just spread it as wide as possible. And if you do that, what you end up with is a cyber weapon of mass destruction. That's the consequence that we have to face. So unfortunately, the biggest number of targets for such attacks are not in the Middle East. They're in the United States and Europe and in Japan. So all of the green areas, these are your target-rich environments. We have to face the consequences, and we better start to prepare right now.Thanks.(Applause)Chris Anderson: I've got a question. Ralph, it's been quite widely reported that people assume that Mossad is the main entity behind this. Is that your opinion?Ralph Langner: Okay, you really want to hear that? Yeah. Okay. My opinion is that the Mossad is involved, but that the leading force is not Israel. So the leading force behind that is the cyber superpower. There is only one, and that's the United States — fortunately, fortunately. Because otherwise, our problems would even be bigger.CA: Thank you for scaring the living daylights out of us. Thank you, Ralph.(Applause)

00:00:19.958 --> 00:00:22.958
Their major asset for developing nuclear weapons

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:26.958
is the Natanz uranium enrichment facility.

00:00:26.958 --> 00:00:28.958
The gray boxes that you see,

00:00:28.958 --> 00:00:31.958
these are real-time control systems.

00:00:31.958 --> 00:00:34.958
Now if we manage to compromise these systems

00:00:34.958 --> 00:00:37.958
that control drive speeds and valves,

00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:40.958
we can actually cause a lot of problems

00:00:40.958 --> 00:00:42.958
with the centrifuge.

00:00:42.958 --> 00:00:44.958
The gray boxes don't run Windows software;

00:00:44.958 --> 00:00:47.958
they are a completely different technology.

00:00:47.958 --> 00:00:49.958
But if we manage

00:00:49.958 --> 00:00:52.958
to place a good Windows virus

00:00:52.958 --> 00:00:54.958
on a notebook

00:00:54.958 --> 00:00:56.958
that is used by a maintenance engineer

00:00:56.958 --> 00:00:59.958
to configure this gray box,

00:00:59.958 --> 00:01:01.958
then we are in business.

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:04.958
And this is the plot behind Stuxnet.

00:01:04.958 --> 00:01:09.958
So we start with a Windows dropper.

00:01:09.958 --> 00:01:12.958
The payload goes onto the gray box,

00:01:12.958 --> 00:01:14.958
damages the centrifuge,

00:01:14.958 --> 00:01:16.958
and the Iranian nuclear program is delayed --

00:01:16.958 --> 00:01:18.958
mission accomplished.

00:01:18.958 --> 00:01:20.958
That's easy, huh?

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
I want to tell you how we found that out.

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:26.958
When we started our research on Stuxnet six months ago,

00:01:26.958 --> 00:01:29.958
it was completely unknown what the purpose of this thing was.

00:01:29.958 --> 00:01:31.958
The only thing that was known

00:01:31.958 --> 00:01:34.958
is it's very, very complex on the Windows part, the dropper part,

00:01:34.958 --> 00:01:37.958
used multiple zero-day vulnerabilities.

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:40.958
And it seemed to want to do something

00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:42.958
with these gray boxes, these real-time control systems.

00:01:42.958 --> 00:01:44.958
So that got our attention,

00:01:44.958 --> 00:01:46.958
and we started a lab project

00:01:46.958 --> 00:01:50.958
where we infected our environment with Stuxnet

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:52.958
and checked this thing out.

00:01:52.958 --> 00:01:55.958
And then some very funny things happened.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:58.958
Stuxnet behaved like a lab rat

00:01:58.958 --> 00:02:01.958
that didn't like our cheese --

00:02:01.958 --> 00:02:03.958
sniffed, but didn't want to eat.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
Didn't make sense to me.

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
And after we experimented with different flavors of cheese,

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:12.958
I realized, well, this is a directed attack.

00:02:12.958 --> 00:02:14.958
It's completely directed.

00:02:14.958 --> 00:02:16.958
The dropper is prowling actively

00:02:16.958 --> 00:02:18.958
on the gray box

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:21.958
if a specific configuration is found,

00:02:21.958 --> 00:02:25.958
and even if the actual program code that it's trying to infect

00:02:25.958 --> 00:02:27.958
is actually running on that target.

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:30.958
And if not, Stuxnet does nothing.

00:02:30.958 --> 00:02:32.958
So that really got my attention,

00:02:32.958 --> 00:02:34.958
and we started to work on this

00:02:34.958 --> 00:02:36.958
nearly around the clock,

00:02:36.958 --> 00:02:39.958
because I thought, "Well, we don't know what the target is.

00:02:39.958 --> 00:02:41.958
It could be, let's say for example,

00:02:41.958 --> 00:02:43.958
a U.S. power plant,

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:45.958
or a chemical plant in Germany.

00:02:45.958 --> 00:02:48.958
So we better find out what the target is soon."

00:02:48.958 --> 00:02:50.958
So we extracted and decompiled

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
the attack code,

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:55.958
and we discovered that it's structured in two digital bombs --

00:02:55.958 --> 00:02:58.958
a smaller one and a bigger one.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:02.958
And we also saw that they are very professionally engineered

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:06.958
by people who obviously had all insider information.

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:08.958
They knew all the bits and bites

00:03:08.958 --> 00:03:10.958
that they had to attack.

00:03:10.958 --> 00:03:13.958
They probably even know the shoe size of the operator.

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
So they know everything.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
And if you have heard that the dropper of Stuxnet

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
is complex and high-tech,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
let me tell you this:

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
the payload is rocket science.

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
It's way above everything

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:29.958
that we have ever seen before.

00:03:29.958 --> 00:03:32.958
Here you see a sample of this actual attack code.

00:03:32.958 --> 00:03:34.958
We are talking about --

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:37.958
around about 15,000 lines of code.

00:03:37.958 --> 00:03:40.958
Looks pretty much like old-style assembly language.

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
And I want to tell you how we were able

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
to make sense out of this code.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
So what we were looking for is, first of all, system function calls,

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:49.958
because we know what they do.

00:03:49.958 --> 00:03:53.958
And then we were looking for timers and data structures

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
and trying to relate them to the real world --

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
to potential real world targets.

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:00.958
So we do need target theories

00:04:00.958 --> 00:04:03.958
that we can prove or disprove.

00:04:03.958 --> 00:04:05.958
In order to get target theories,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:07.958
we remember

00:04:07.958 --> 00:04:09.958
that it's definitely hardcore sabotage,

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
it must be a high-value target

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
and it is most likely located in Iran,

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:18.958
because that's where most of the infections had been reported.

00:04:18.958 --> 00:04:21.958
Now you don't find several thousand targets in that area.

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:23.958
It basically boils down

00:04:23.958 --> 00:04:25.958
to the Bushehr nuclear power plant

00:04:25.958 --> 00:04:27.958
and to the Natanz fuel enrichment plant.

00:04:27.958 --> 00:04:29.958
So I told my assistant,

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:32.958
"Get me a list of all centrifuge and power plant experts from our client base."

00:04:32.958 --> 00:04:34.958
And I phoned them up and picked their brain

00:04:34.958 --> 00:04:36.958
in an effort to match their expertise

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:39.958
with what we found in code and data.

00:04:39.958 --> 00:04:41.958
And that worked pretty well.

00:04:41.958 --> 00:04:43.958
So we were able to associate

00:04:43.958 --> 00:04:45.958
the small digital warhead

00:04:45.958 --> 00:04:47.958
with the rotor control.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:50.958
The rotor is that moving part within the centrifuge,

00:04:50.958 --> 00:04:52.958
that black object that you see.

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
And if you manipulate the speed of this rotor,

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:57.958
you are actually able to crack the rotor

00:04:57.958 --> 00:05:01.958
and eventually even have the centrifuge explode.

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
What we also saw

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
is that the goal of the attack

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
was really to do it slowly and creepy --

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
obviously in an effort

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
to drive maintenance engineers crazy,

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:16.958
that they would not be able to figure this out quickly.

00:05:16.958 --> 00:05:19.958
The big digital warhead -- we had a shot at this

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
by looking very closely

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
at data and data structures.

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:25.958
So for example, the number 164

00:05:25.958 --> 00:05:27.958
really stands out in that code;

00:05:27.958 --> 00:05:29.958
you can't overlook it.

00:05:29.958 --> 00:05:31.958
I started to research scientific literature

00:05:31.958 --> 00:05:33.958
on how these centrifuges

00:05:33.958 --> 00:05:35.958
are actually built in Natanz

00:05:35.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and found they are structured

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:39.958
in what is called a cascade,

00:05:39.958 --> 00:05:43.958
and each cascade holds 164 centrifuges.

00:05:43.958 --> 00:05:45.958
So that made sense, that was a match.

00:05:45.958 --> 00:05:47.958
And it even got better.

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
These centrifuges in Iran

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:53.958
are subdivided into 15, what is called, stages.

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
And guess what we found in the attack code?

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
An almost identical structure.

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
So again, that was a real good match.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:03.958
And this gave us very high confidence for what we were looking at.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
Now don't get me wrong here, it didn't go like this.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:09.958
These results have been obtained

00:06:09.958 --> 00:06:12.958
over several weeks of really hard labor.

00:06:12.958 --> 00:06:15.958
And we often went into just a dead end

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
and had to recover.

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
Anyway, so we figured out

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
that both digital warheads

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
were actually aiming at one and the same target,

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
but from different angles.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
The small warhead is taking one cascade,

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:31.958
and spinning up the rotors and slowing them down,

00:06:31.958 --> 00:06:33.958
and the big warhead

00:06:33.958 --> 00:06:35.958
is talking to six cascades

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and manipulating valves.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
So in all, we are very confident

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
that we have actually determined what the target is.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
It is Natanz, and it is only Natanz.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
So we don't have to worry

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:48.958
that other targets

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
might be hit by Stuxnet.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:53.958
Here's some very cool stuff that we saw --

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
really knocked my socks off.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
Down there is the gray box,

00:06:57.958 --> 00:07:00.958
and on the top you see the centrifuges.

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
Now what this thing does

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
is it intercepts the input values from sensors --

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
so for example, from pressure sensors

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
and vibration sensors --

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:12.958
and it provides legitimate program code,

00:07:12.958 --> 00:07:14.958
which is still running during the attack,

00:07:14.958 --> 00:07:16.958
with fake input data.

00:07:16.958 --> 00:07:18.958
And as a matter of fact, this fake input data

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:21.958
is actually prerecorded by Stuxnet.

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:23.958
So it's just like from the Hollywood movies

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
where during the heist,

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:28.958
the observation camera is fed with prerecorded video.

00:07:28.958 --> 00:07:30.958
That's cool, huh?

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:33.958
The idea here is obviously

00:07:33.958 --> 00:07:36.958
not only to fool the operators in the control room.

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:40.958
It actually is much more dangerous and aggressive.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
The idea

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:45.958
is to circumvent a digital safety system.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
We need digital safety systems

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:51.958
where a human operator could not act quick enough.

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
So for example, in a power plant,

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
when your big steam turbine gets too over speed,

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
you must open relief valves within a millisecond.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
Obviously, this cannot be done by a human operator.

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
So this is where we need digital safety systems.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:06.958
And when they are compromised,

00:08:06.958 --> 00:08:09.958
then real bad things can happen.

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
Your plant can blow up.

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
And neither your operators nor your safety system will notice it.

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
That's scary.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
But it gets worse.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:21.958
And this is very important, what I'm going to say.

00:08:21.958 --> 00:08:23.958
Think about this:

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
this attack is generic.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:30.958
It doesn't have anything to do, in specifics,

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:32.958
with centrifuges,

00:08:32.958 --> 00:08:35.958
with uranium enrichment.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.958
So it would work as well, for example,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
in a power plant

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
or in an automobile factory.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
It is generic.

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:47.958
And you don't have -- as an attacker --

00:08:47.958 --> 00:08:50.958
you don't have to deliver this payload

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
by a USB stick,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
as we saw it in the case of Stuxnet.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
You could also use conventional worm technology for spreading.

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
Just spread it as wide as possible.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
And if you do that,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:04.958
what you end up with

00:09:04.958 --> 00:09:09.958
is a cyber weapon of mass destruction.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:12.958
That's the consequence

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:15.958
that we have to face.

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:18.958
So unfortunately,

00:09:18.958 --> 00:09:21.958
the biggest number of targets for such attacks

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
are not in the Middle East.

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
They're in the United States and Europe and in Japan.

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:28.958
So all of the green areas,

00:09:28.958 --> 00:09:31.958
these are your target-rich environments.

00:09:31.958 --> 00:09:34.958
We have to face the consequences,

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
and we better start to prepare right now.

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:39.958
Thanks.

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:45.958
(Applause)

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:47.958
Chris Anderson: I've got a question.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
Ralph, it's been quite widely reported

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
that people assume that Mossad

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
is the main entity behind this.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
Is that your opinion?

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
Ralph Langner: Okay, you really want to hear that?

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
Yeah. Okay.

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:05.958
My opinion is that the Mossad is involved,

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:08.958
but that the leading force is not Israel.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:10.958
So the leading force behind that

00:10:10.958 --> 00:10:13.958
is the cyber superpower.

00:10:13.958 --> 00:10:15.958
There is only one,

00:10:15.958 --> 00:10:17.958
and that's the United States --

00:10:17.958 --> 00:10:19.958
fortunately, fortunately.

00:10:19.958 --> 00:10:21.958
Because otherwise,

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
our problems would even be bigger.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:28.958
CA: Thank you for scaring the living daylights out of us. Thank you, Ralph.

00:10:28.958 --> 00:10:30.958
(Applause)

title: The genius puppetry behind War Horse
transcript: Adrian Kohler: Well, we're here today to talk about the evolution of a puppet horse.Basil Jones: But actually we're going to start this evolution with a hyena.AK: The ancestor of the horse. Okay, we'll do something with it. (Laughter) Hahahaha. The hyena is the ancestor of the horse because it was part of a production called "Faustus in Africa," a Handspring Production from 1995, where it had to play draughts with Helen of Troy. This production was directed by South African artist and theater director, William Kentridge. So it needed a very articulate front paw. But, like all puppets, it has other attributes.BJ: One of them is breath, and it kind of breathes.AK: Haa haa haaa.BJ: Breath is really important for us. It's the kind of original movement for any puppet for us onstage. It's the thing that distinguishes the puppet —AK: Oops.BJ: From an actor. Puppets always have to try to be alive. It's their kind of ur-story onstage, that desperation to live.AK: Yeah, it's basically a dead object, as you can see, and it only lives because you make it. An actor struggles to die onstage, but a puppet has to struggle to live. And in a way that's a metaphor for life.BJ: So every moment it's on the stage, it's making the struggle. So we call this a piece of emotional engineering that uses up-to-the-minute 17th century technology — (Laughter) to turn nouns into verbs.AK: Well actually I prefer to say that it's an object constructed out of wood and cloth with movement built into it to persuade you to believe that it has life.BJ: Okay so.AK: It has ears that move passively when the head goes.BJ: And it has these bulkheads made out of plywood, covered with fabric — curiously similar, in fact, to the plywood canoes that Adrian's father used to make when he was a boy in their workshop.AK: In Port Elizabeth, the village outside Port Elizabeth in South Africa.BJ: His mother was a puppeteer. And when we met at art school and fell in love in 1971, I hated puppets. I really thought they were so beneath me. I wanted to become an avant-garde artist — and Punch and Judy was certainly not where I wanted to go. And, in fact, it took about 10 yearsto discover the Bambara Bamana puppets of Mali in West Africa, where there's a fabulous tradition of puppetry, to learn a renewed, or a new, respect for this art form.AK: So in 1981, I persuaded Basil and some friends of mine to form a puppet company. And 20 years later, miraculously, we collaborated with a company from Mali, the Sogolon Marionette Troupe of Bamako, where we made a piece about a tall giraffe. It was just called "Tall Horse," which was a life-sized giraffe.BJ: And here again, you see the same structure. The bulkheads have now turned into hoops of cane, but it's ultimately the same structure. It's got two people inside it on stilts, which give them the height, and somebody in the front who's using a kind of steering wheel to move that head.AK: The person in the hind legs is also controlling the tail, a bit like the hyena — same mechanism, just a bit bigger. And he's controlling the ear movement.BJ: So this production was seen by Tom Morris of the National Theatre in London. And just around that time, his mother had said, "Have you seen this book by Michael Morpurgo called 'War Horse'?"AK: It's about a boy who falls in love with a horse. The horse is sold to the First World War, and he joins up to find his horse.BJ: So Tom gave us a call and said, "Do you think you could make us a horse for a show to happen at the National Theatre?"AK: It seemed a lovely idea.BJ: But it had to ride. It had to have a rider.AK: It had to have a rider, and it had to participate in cavalry charges. (Laughter) A play about early 20th century plowing technology and cavalry charges was a little bit of a challenge for the accounting department at the National Theatre in London. But they agreed to go along with it for a while. So we began with a test.BJ: This is Adrian and Thys Stander, who went on to actually design the cane system for the horse, and our next-door neighbor Katherine, riding on a ladder. The weight is really difficult when it's up above your head.AK: And once we put Katherine through that particular brand of hell, we knew that we might be able to make a horse, which could be ridden. So we made a model. This is a cardboard model, a little bit smaller than the hyena. You'll notice that the legs are plywood legs and the canoe structure is still there.BJ: And the two manipulators are inside. But we didn't realize at the time that we actually needed a third manipulator, because we couldn't manipulate the neck from inside and walk the horse at the same time.AK: We started work on the prototype after the model was approved, and the prototype took a bit longer than we anticipated. We had to throw out the plywood legs and make new cane ones. And we had a crate built for it. It had to be shipped to London. We were going to test-drive it on the street outside of our house in Cape Town, and it got to midnight and we hadn't done that yet.BJ: So we got a camera, and we posed the puppet in various galloping stances. And we sent it off to the National Theatre, hoping that they believed that we created something that worked. (Laughter)AK: A month later, we were there in London with this big box and a studio full of people about to work with us.BJ: About 40 people.AK: We were terrified. We opened the lid, we took the horse out, and it did work; it walked and it was able to be ridden. Here I have an 18-second clip of the very first walk of the prototype. This is in the National Theatre studio, the place where they cook new ideas. It had by no means got the green light yet. The choreographer, Toby Sedgwick, invented a beautiful sequence where the baby horse, which was made out of sticks and bits of twigs, grew up into the big horse. And Nick Starr, the director of the National Theatre, saw that particular moment, he was standing next to me — he nearly wet himself. And so the show was given the green light. And we went back to Cape Town and redesigned the horse completely. Here is the plan.(Laughter)And here is our factory in Cape Town where we make horses. You can see quite a lot of skeletons in the background there. The horses are completely handmade. There is very little 20th century technology in them. We used a bit of laser cutting on the plywood and some of the aluminum pieces. But because they have to be light and flexible, and each one of them is different, they can't be mass-produced, unfortunately. So here are some half-finished horses ready to be worked in London. And now we would like to introduce you to Joey. Joey boy, you there? Joey. (Applause) (Applause) Joey. Joey, come here. No, no, I haven't got it. He's got it; it's in his pocket.BJ: Joey. AK: Joey, Joey, Joey, Joey. Come here. Stand here where people can see you. Move around. Come on. I'd just like to describe — I won't talk too loud. He might get irritated. Here, Craig is working the head. He has bicycle brake cables going down to the head control in his hand. Each one of them operates either an ear, separately, or the head, up and down. But he also controls the head directly by using his hand. The ears are obviously a very important emotional indicator of the horse. When they point right back, the horse is fearful or angry, depending upon what's going on in front of him, around him. Or, when he's more relaxed, the head comes down and the ears listen, either side. Horses' hearing is very important. It's almost more important than their eyesight. Over here, Tommy's got what you call the heart position. He's working the leg. You see the string tendon from the hyena, the hyena's front leg, automatically pulls the hoop up. (Laughter) Horses are so unpredictable. (Laughter) The way a hoof comes up with a horse immediately gives you the feeling that it's a convincing horse action. The hind legs have got the same action.BJ: And Mikey also has, in his fingers, the ability to move the tail from left to right, and up and down with the other hand. And together, there's quite a complex possibility of tail expression.AK: You want to say something about the breathing?BJ: We had a big challenge with breathing. Adrian thought that he was going to have to split the chest of the puppet in two and make it breathe like that — because that's how a horse would breathe, with an expanded chest. But we realized that, if that were to be happening, you wouldn't, as an audience, see the breath. So he made a channel in here, and the chest moves up and down in that channel. So it's anti-naturalistic really, the up and down movement, but it feels like breath. And it's very, very simple because all that happens is that the puppeteer breathes with his knees.AK: Other emotional stuff. If I were to touch the horse here on his skin, the heart puppeteer can shake the body from inside and get the skin to quiver. You'll notice, of course, that the puppet is made out of cane lines. And I would like you to believe that it was an aesthetic choice, that I was making a three-dimensional drawing of a horse that somehow moves in space. But of course, it was the cane is light, the cane is flexible, the cane is durable and the cane is moldable. And so it was a very practical reason why it was made of cane.The skin itself is made out of a see-through nylon mesh, which, if the lighting designer wants the horse to almost disappear, she can light the background and the horse becomes ghostlike. You see the skeletal structure of it. Or if you light it from above, it becomes more solid. Again, that was a practical consideration. The guys inside the horse have to be able to see out. They have to be able to act along with their fellow actors in the production. And it's very much an in-the-moment activity that they're engaged in. It's three heads making one character.But now we would like you to put Joey through some paces. And plant.(Whinny)Thank you. And now just — (Applause) All the way from sunny California we have Zem Joaquin who's going to ride the horse for us.(Applause)(Applause)(Music)So we would like to stress that the performance you see in the horse is three guys who have studied horse behavior incredibly thoroughly.BJ: Not being able to talk to one another while they're onstage because they're mic'd. The sound that that very large chest makes, of the horse — the whinnying and the nickering and everything — that starts usually with one performer, carries on with a second person and ends with a third.AK: Mikey Brett from Leicestershire. (Applause) Mikey Brett, Craig, Leo, Zem Joaquin and Basil and me.(Applause)Thank you. Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:13.958
Adrian Kohler: Well, we're here today

00:00:13.958 --> 00:00:16.958
to talk about the evolution of a puppet horse.

00:00:17.958 --> 00:00:20.958
Basil Jones: But actually we're going to start this evolution

00:00:20.958 --> 00:00:22.958
with a hyena.

00:00:22.958 --> 00:00:24.958
AK: The ancestor of the horse.

00:00:24.958 --> 00:00:26.958
Okay, we'll do something with it.

00:00:57.958 --> 00:01:01.958
(Laughter)

00:01:01.958 --> 00:01:08.958
Hahahaha.

00:01:20.958 --> 00:01:23.958
The hyena is the ancestor of the horse

00:01:23.958 --> 00:01:25.958
because it was part of a production

00:01:25.958 --> 00:01:27.958
called "Faustus in Africa,"

00:01:27.958 --> 00:01:30.958
a Handspring Production from 1995,

00:01:30.958 --> 00:01:33.958
where it had to play draughts with Helen of Troy.

00:01:33.958 --> 00:01:35.958
This production was directed

00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:37.958
by South African artist and theater director,

00:01:37.958 --> 00:01:39.958
William Kentridge.

00:01:39.958 --> 00:01:42.958
So it needed a very articulate front paw.

00:01:47.958 --> 00:01:50.958
But, like all puppets, it has other attributes.

00:01:50.958 --> 00:01:53.958
BJ: One of them is breath,

00:01:53.958 --> 00:01:55.958
and it kind of breathes.

00:01:55.958 --> 00:02:00.958
AK: Haa haa haaa.

00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:03.958
BJ: Breath is really important for us.

00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:05.958
It's the kind of original movement

00:02:05.958 --> 00:02:08.958
for any puppet for us onstage.

00:02:08.958 --> 00:02:11.958
It's the thing that distinguishes the puppet --

00:02:11.958 --> 00:02:13.958
AK: Oops.

00:02:13.958 --> 00:02:15.958
BJ: From an actor.

00:02:15.958 --> 00:02:18.958
Puppets always have to try to be alive.

00:02:18.958 --> 00:02:22.958
It's their kind of ur-story onstage,

00:02:22.958 --> 00:02:24.958
that desperation to live.

00:02:24.958 --> 00:02:27.958
AK: Yeah, it's basically a dead object, as you can see,

00:02:27.958 --> 00:02:29.958
and it only lives

00:02:29.958 --> 00:02:31.958
because you make it.

00:02:31.958 --> 00:02:33.958
An actor struggles to die onstage,

00:02:33.958 --> 00:02:35.958
but a puppet has to struggle to live.

00:02:35.958 --> 00:02:37.958
And in a way that's a metaphor for life.

00:02:37.958 --> 00:02:40.958
BJ: So every moment it's on the stage, it's making the struggle.

00:02:40.958 --> 00:02:43.958
So we call this

00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.958
a piece of emotional engineering

00:02:47.958 --> 00:02:50.958
that uses up-to-the-minute

00:02:50.958 --> 00:02:52.958
17th century technology --

00:02:52.958 --> 00:02:54.958
(Laughter)

00:02:54.958 --> 00:02:56.958
to turn nouns

00:02:56.958 --> 00:02:58.958
into verbs.

00:02:58.958 --> 00:03:00.958
AK: Well actually I prefer to say

00:03:00.958 --> 00:03:02.958
that it's an object

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:04.958
constructed out of wood and cloth

00:03:04.958 --> 00:03:06.958
with movement built into it

00:03:06.958 --> 00:03:09.958
to persuade you to believe that it has life.

00:03:09.958 --> 00:03:11.958
BJ: Okay so.

00:03:11.958 --> 00:03:13.958
AK: It has ears that move passively

00:03:13.958 --> 00:03:15.958
when the head goes.

00:03:15.958 --> 00:03:18.958
BJ: And it has these bulkheads

00:03:18.958 --> 00:03:20.958
made out of plywood,

00:03:20.958 --> 00:03:22.958
covered with fabric --

00:03:22.958 --> 00:03:24.958
curiously similar, in fact,

00:03:24.958 --> 00:03:26.958
to the plywood canoes

00:03:26.958 --> 00:03:28.958
that Adrian's father used to make

00:03:28.958 --> 00:03:31.958
when he was a boy in their workshop.

00:03:31.958 --> 00:03:34.958
AK: In Port Elizabeth, the village outside Port Elizabeth in South Africa.

00:03:34.958 --> 00:03:36.958
BJ: His mother was a puppeteer.

00:03:36.958 --> 00:03:38.958
And when we met at art school

00:03:38.958 --> 00:03:40.958
and fell in love

00:03:40.958 --> 00:03:42.958
in 1971,

00:03:42.958 --> 00:03:44.958
I hated puppets.

00:03:44.958 --> 00:03:47.958
I really thought they were so beneath me.

00:03:47.958 --> 00:03:50.958
I wanted to become an avant-garde artist --

00:03:50.958 --> 00:03:53.958
and Punch and Judy was certainly not where I wanted to go.

00:03:53.958 --> 00:03:55.958
And, in fact, it took about 10 years

00:03:55.958 --> 00:03:57.958
to discover

00:03:57.958 --> 00:04:01.958
the Bambara Bamana puppets of Mali in West Africa,

00:04:01.958 --> 00:04:05.958
where there's a fabulous tradition of puppetry,

00:04:05.958 --> 00:04:09.958
to learn a renewed, or a new, respect

00:04:09.958 --> 00:04:11.958
for this art form.

00:04:11.958 --> 00:04:14.958
AK: So in 1981, I persuaded Basil and some friends of mine

00:04:14.958 --> 00:04:16.958
to form a puppet company.

00:04:16.958 --> 00:04:19.958
And 20 years later, miraculously,

00:04:19.958 --> 00:04:21.958
we collaborated with a company from Mali,

00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:24.958
the Sogolon Marionette Troupe of Bamako,

00:04:24.958 --> 00:04:26.958
where we made a piece about a tall giraffe.

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.958
It was just called "Tall Horse," which was a life-sized giraffe.

00:04:29.958 --> 00:04:31.958
BJ: And here again, you see the same structure.

00:04:31.958 --> 00:04:36.958
The bulkheads have now turned into hoops of cane,

00:04:36.958 --> 00:04:38.958
but it's ultimately the same structure.

00:04:38.958 --> 00:04:40.958
It's got two people inside it on stilts,

00:04:40.958 --> 00:04:42.958
which give them the height,

00:04:42.958 --> 00:04:44.958
and somebody in the front

00:04:44.958 --> 00:04:47.958
who's using a kind of steering wheel to move that head.

00:04:47.958 --> 00:04:49.958
AK: The person in the hind legs

00:04:49.958 --> 00:04:52.958
is also controlling the tail, a bit like the hyena --

00:04:52.958 --> 00:04:55.958
same mechanism, just a bit bigger.

00:04:55.958 --> 00:04:58.958
And he's controlling the ear movement.

00:04:59.958 --> 00:05:01.958
BJ: So this production

00:05:01.958 --> 00:05:03.958
was seen by Tom Morris

00:05:03.958 --> 00:05:05.958
of the National Theatre in London.

00:05:05.958 --> 00:05:08.958
And just around that time,

00:05:08.958 --> 00:05:10.958
his mother had said,

00:05:10.958 --> 00:05:13.958
"Have you seen this book by Michael Morpurgo

00:05:13.958 --> 00:05:15.958
called 'War Horse'?"

00:05:15.958 --> 00:05:17.958
AK: It's about a boy who falls in love with a horse.

00:05:17.958 --> 00:05:19.958
The horse is sold to the First World War,

00:05:19.958 --> 00:05:21.958
and he joins up to find his horse.

00:05:21.958 --> 00:05:23.958
BJ: So Tom gave us a call and said,

00:05:23.958 --> 00:05:26.958
"Do you think you could make us a horse

00:05:26.958 --> 00:05:28.958
for a show to happen at the National Theatre?"

00:05:28.958 --> 00:05:30.958
AK: It seemed a lovely idea.

00:05:30.958 --> 00:05:32.958
BJ: But it had to ride. It had to have a rider.

00:05:32.958 --> 00:05:34.958
AK: It had to have a rider,

00:05:34.958 --> 00:05:37.958
and it had to participate in cavalry charges.

00:05:37.958 --> 00:05:40.958
(Laughter)

00:05:40.958 --> 00:05:42.958
A play about early 20th century plowing technology

00:05:42.958 --> 00:05:44.958
and cavalry charges

00:05:44.958 --> 00:05:46.958
was a little bit of a challenge for the accounting department

00:05:46.958 --> 00:05:48.958
at the National Theatre in London.

00:05:48.958 --> 00:05:50.958
But they agreed to go along with it for a while.

00:05:50.958 --> 00:05:52.958
So we began with a test.

00:05:52.958 --> 00:05:55.958
BJ: This is Adrian and Thys Stander,

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:59.958
who went on to actually design the cane system for the horse,

00:05:59.958 --> 00:06:01.958
and our next-door neighbor Katherine,

00:06:01.958 --> 00:06:03.958
riding on a ladder.

00:06:03.958 --> 00:06:06.958
The weight is really difficult when it's up above your head.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
AK: And once we put Katherine

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
through that particular brand of hell,

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
we knew that we might be able to make a horse, which could be ridden.

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:15.958
So we made a model.

00:06:15.958 --> 00:06:17.958
This is a cardboard model,

00:06:17.958 --> 00:06:19.958
a little bit smaller than the hyena.

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:21.958
You'll notice that the legs are plywood legs

00:06:21.958 --> 00:06:23.958
and the canoe structure is still there.

00:06:23.958 --> 00:06:25.958
BJ: And the two manipulators are inside.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
But we didn't realize at the time

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
that we actually needed a third manipulator,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
because we couldn't manipulate the neck

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
from inside

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
and walk the horse at the same time.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
AK: We started work on the prototype

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
after the model was approved,

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:43.958
and the prototype took a bit longer

00:06:43.958 --> 00:06:45.958
than we anticipated.

00:06:45.958 --> 00:06:48.958
We had to throw out the plywood legs and make new cane ones.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
And we had a crate built for it.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
It had to be shipped to London.

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
We were going to test-drive it on the street outside of our house in Cape Town,

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
and it got to midnight and we hadn't done that yet.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
BJ: So we got a camera,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:03.958
and we posed the puppet

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:08.958
in various galloping stances.

00:07:08.958 --> 00:07:11.958
And we sent it off

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
to the National Theatre,

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
hoping that they believed

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
that we created something that worked.

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:19.958
(Laughter)

00:07:19.958 --> 00:07:21.958
AK: A month later, we were there in London

00:07:21.958 --> 00:07:25.958
with this big box and a studio full of people about to work with us.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
BJ: About 40 people.

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
AK: We were terrified.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:31.958
We opened the lid, we took the horse out,

00:07:31.958 --> 00:07:34.958
and it did work; it walked and it was able to be ridden.

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
Here I have an 18-second clip

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
of the very first walk of the prototype.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
This is in the National Theatre studio,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
the place where they cook new ideas.

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
It had by no means got the green light yet.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
The choreographer, Toby Sedgwick,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
invented a beautiful sequence

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
where the baby horse,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
which was made out of sticks and bits of twigs,

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:04.958
grew up into the big horse.

00:08:04.958 --> 00:08:07.958
And Nick Starr, the director of the National Theatre,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
saw that particular moment, he was standing next to me -- he nearly wet himself.

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
And so the show was given the green light.

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.958
And we went back to Cape Town and redesigned the horse completely.

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
Here is the plan.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
(Laughter)

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
And here is our factory in Cape Town

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:27.958
where we make horses.

00:08:27.958 --> 00:08:30.958
You can see quite a lot of skeletons in the background there.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
The horses are completely handmade.

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:37.958
There is very little 20th century technology in them.

00:08:37.958 --> 00:08:39.958
We used a bit of laser cutting on the plywood

00:08:39.958 --> 00:08:41.958
and some of the aluminum pieces.

00:08:41.958 --> 00:08:43.958
But because they have to be light and flexible,

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:46.958
and each one of them is different,

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:49.958
they can't be mass-produced, unfortunately.

00:08:49.958 --> 00:08:52.958
So here are some half-finished horses

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:55.958
ready to be worked in London.

00:08:55.958 --> 00:08:57.958
And now we would like to introduce you

00:08:57.958 --> 00:08:59.958
to Joey.

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:03.958
Joey boy, you there?

00:09:03.958 --> 00:09:05.958
Joey.

00:09:06.958 --> 00:09:09.958
(Applause)

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:34.958
(Applause)

00:09:47.958 --> 00:09:49.958
Joey.

00:09:49.958 --> 00:09:51.958
Joey, come here.

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:08.958
No, no, I haven't got it.

00:10:08.958 --> 00:10:11.958
He's got it; it's in his pocket.

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
BJ: Joey.

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:29.958
AK: Joey, Joey, Joey, Joey.

00:10:29.958 --> 00:10:32.958
Come here. Stand here where people can see you.

00:10:39.958 --> 00:10:41.958
Move around. Come on.

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
I'd just like to describe --

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
I won't talk too loud. He might get irritated.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
Here, Craig is working the head.

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
He has bicycle brake cables

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
going down to the head control in his hand.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
Each one of them

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:04.958
operates either an ear, separately,

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:06.958
or the head, up and down.

00:11:06.958 --> 00:11:09.958
But he also controls the head directly

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:11.958
by using his hand.

00:11:11.958 --> 00:11:13.958
The ears are obviously

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
a very important emotional indicator of the horse.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:20.958
When they point right back,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:24.958
the horse is fearful or angry,

00:11:24.958 --> 00:11:27.958
depending upon what's going on in front of him, around him.

00:11:27.958 --> 00:11:29.958
Or, when he's more relaxed, the head comes down

00:11:29.958 --> 00:11:32.958
and the ears listen, either side.

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:36.958
Horses' hearing is very important.

00:11:36.958 --> 00:11:39.958
It's almost more important than their eyesight.

00:11:40.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Over here,

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Tommy's got what you call the heart position.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:47.958
He's working the leg.

00:11:47.958 --> 00:11:50.958
You see the string tendon from the hyena,

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:53.958
the hyena's front leg,

00:11:53.958 --> 00:11:56.958
automatically pulls the hoop up.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:12:01.958
(Laughter)

00:12:01.958 --> 00:12:03.958
Horses are so unpredictable.

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:07.958
(Laughter)

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:10.958
The way a hoof comes up with a horse

00:12:10.958 --> 00:12:12.958
immediately gives you the feeling

00:12:12.958 --> 00:12:14.958
that it's a convincing horse action.

00:12:14.958 --> 00:12:17.958
The hind legs have got the same action.

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
BJ: And Mikey also has,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:24.958
in his fingers,

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:26.958
the ability to move the tail

00:12:26.958 --> 00:12:28.958
from left to right,

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:30.958
and up and down with the other hand.

00:12:30.958 --> 00:12:33.958
And together, there's quite a complex possibility

00:12:33.958 --> 00:12:35.958
of tail expression.

00:12:35.958 --> 00:12:37.958
AK: You want to say something about the breathing?

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:40.958
BJ: We had a big challenge with breathing.

00:12:40.958 --> 00:12:42.958
Adrian thought

00:12:42.958 --> 00:12:44.958
that he was going to have to split the chest of the puppet in two

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
and make it breathe like that --

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
because that's how a horse would breathe, with an expanded chest.

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
But we realized

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
that, if that were to be happening,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
you wouldn't, as an audience, see the breath.

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:59.958
So he made a channel in here,

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
and the chest moves up and down in that channel.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
So it's anti-naturalistic really, the up and down movement,

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
but it feels like breath.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And it's very, very simple

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
because all that happens

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
is that the puppeteer breathes with his knees.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
AK: Other emotional stuff.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
If I were to touch the horse here

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:23.958
on his skin,

00:13:23.958 --> 00:13:26.958
the heart puppeteer can shake the body from inside

00:13:26.958 --> 00:13:28.958
and get the skin to quiver.

00:13:28.958 --> 00:13:30.958
You'll notice, of course,

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
that the puppet is made out of cane lines.

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:35.958
And I would like you to believe that it was an aesthetic choice,

00:13:35.958 --> 00:13:37.958
that I was making a three-dimensional drawing of a horse

00:13:37.958 --> 00:13:39.958
that somehow moves in space.

00:13:39.958 --> 00:13:41.958
But of course, it was the cane is light,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
the cane is flexible, the cane is durable

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
and the cane is moldable.

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:48.958
And so it was a very practical reason why it was made of cane.

00:13:48.958 --> 00:13:50.958
The skin itself

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
is made out of a see-through nylon mesh,

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
which, if the lighting designer

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:56.958
wants the horse to almost disappear,

00:13:56.958 --> 00:13:58.958
she can light the background

00:13:58.958 --> 00:14:01.958
and the horse becomes ghostlike.

00:14:01.958 --> 00:14:03.958
You see the skeletal structure of it.

00:14:03.958 --> 00:14:06.958
Or if you light it from above, it becomes more solid.

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:09.958
Again, that was a practical consideration.

00:14:09.958 --> 00:14:12.958
The guys inside the horse have to be able to see out.

00:14:12.958 --> 00:14:14.958
They have to be able to act

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:17.958
along with their fellow actors in the production.

00:14:17.958 --> 00:14:20.958
And it's very much an in-the-moment activity that they're engaged in.

00:14:20.958 --> 00:14:23.958
It's three heads making one character.

00:14:23.958 --> 00:14:26.958
But now we would like you to put Joey through some paces.

00:15:04.958 --> 00:15:06.958
And plant.

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:13.958
(Whinny)

00:15:21.958 --> 00:15:23.958
Thank you.

00:15:23.958 --> 00:15:25.958
And now just --

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:33.958
(Applause)

00:15:33.958 --> 00:15:35.958
All the way from sunny California

00:15:35.958 --> 00:15:37.958
we have Zem Joaquin

00:15:37.958 --> 00:15:39.958
who's going to ride the horse for us.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:43.958
(Applause)

00:16:34.958 --> 00:16:44.958
(Applause)

00:16:44.958 --> 00:16:50.958
(Music)

00:17:05.958 --> 00:17:07.958
So we would like to stress

00:17:07.958 --> 00:17:09.958
that the performance you see in the horse

00:17:09.958 --> 00:17:11.958
is three guys

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:14.958
who have studied horse behavior incredibly thoroughly.

00:17:14.958 --> 00:17:16.958
BJ: Not being able to talk to one another

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
while they're onstage

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:20.958
because they're mic'd.

00:17:20.958 --> 00:17:23.958
The sound that that very large chest makes, of the horse --

00:17:23.958 --> 00:17:26.958
the whinnying and the nickering and everything --

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:29.958
that starts usually with one performer,

00:17:29.958 --> 00:17:31.958
carries on with a second person

00:17:31.958 --> 00:17:33.958
and ends with a third.

00:17:33.958 --> 00:17:36.958
AK: Mikey Brett from Leicestershire.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:43.958
(Applause)

00:17:43.958 --> 00:17:46.958
Mikey Brett, Craig, Leo,

00:17:46.958 --> 00:17:49.958
Zem Joaquin and Basil and me.

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:52.958
(Applause)

Thank you. Thank you.

title: Google's driverless car
transcript: As a boy, I loved cars. When I turned 18, I lost my best friend to a car accident. Like this. And then I decided I'd dedicate my life to saving one million people every year. Now I haven't succeeded, so this is just a progress report, but I'm here to tell you a little bit about self-driving cars.I saw the concept first in the DARPA Grand Challenges where the U.S. government issued a prize to build a self-driving car that could navigate a desert. And even though a hundred teams were there, these cars went nowhere. So we decided at Stanford to build a different self-driving car. We built the hardware and the software. We made it learn from us, and we set it free in the desert. And the unimaginable happened: it became the first car to ever return from a DARPA Grand Challenge, winning Stanford 2 million dollars. Yet I still hadn't saved a single life.Since, our work has focused on building driving cars that can drive anywhere by themselves — any street in California. We've driven 140,000 miles. Our cars have sensors by which they magically can see everything around them and make decisions about every aspect of driving. It's the perfect driving mechanism. We've driven in cities, like in San Francisco here. We've driven from San Francisco to Los Angeles on Highway 1.We've encountered joggers, busy highways, toll booths, and this is without a person in the loop; the car just drives itself. In fact, while we drove 140,000 miles, people didn't even notice. Mountain roads, day and night, and even crooked Lombard Street in San Francisco. (Laughter) Sometimes our cars get so crazy, they even do little stunts.(Video) Man: Oh, my God. What? Second Man: It's driving itself.Sebastian Thrun: Now I can't get my friend Harold back to life, but I can do something for all the people who died. Do you know that driving accidents are the number one cause of death for young people? And do you realize that almost all of those are due to human error and not machine error, and can therefore be prevented by machines?Do you realize that we could change the capacity of highways by a factor of two or three if we didn't rely on human precision on staying in the lane — improve body position and therefore drive a little bit closer together on a little bit narrower lanes, and do away with all traffic jams on highways? Do you realize that you, TED users, spend an average of 52 minutes per day in traffic, wasting your time on your daily commute? You could regain this time. This is four billion hours wasted in this country alone. And it's 2.4 billion gallons of gasoline wasted.Now I think there's a vision here, a new technology, and I'm really looking forward to a time when generations after us look back at us and say how ridiculous it was that humans were driving cars.Thank you.(Applause)
