And then I saw

00:06:19.958 --> 00:06:22.958
my own parents, my first teachers.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
My father, very inventive, spatial thinker.

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:28.958
That's my brother Malcolm there on the right.

00:06:28.958 --> 00:06:30.958
And my mother,

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
who taught me in fourth grade

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:34.958
in segregated schools in Virginia,

00:06:34.958 --> 00:06:37.958
who was my inspiration.

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
And really, I feel as though,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
when I see the film --

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
I have a gesture she does, like this --

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:48.958
I feel like I am a continuation of her gesture.

00:06:48.958 --> 00:06:50.958
I am one of her teaching gestures.

00:06:50.958 --> 00:06:52.958
And the beautiful thing was,

00:06:52.958 --> 00:06:55.958
I got to teach my daughter in elementary school, Madeline.

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:57.958
And so that gesture of my mother's

00:06:57.958 --> 00:06:59.958
continues through many generations.

00:06:59.958 --> 00:07:01.958
It's an amazing feeling

00:07:01.958 --> 00:07:03.958
to have that lineage.

00:07:03.958 --> 00:07:05.958
And so I'm here standing on the shoulders of many people.

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
I'm not here alone.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:10.958
There are many people on this stage right now.

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:15.958
And so this World Peace Game I'd like to tell you about.

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:17.958
It started out like this:

00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:20.958
it's just a four-foot by five-foot plywood board

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:23.958
in an inner-city urban school, 1978.

00:07:23.958 --> 00:07:25.958
I was creating a lesson for students on Africa.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
We put all the problems of the world there,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
and I thought, let's let them solve it.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
I didn't want to lecture or have just book reading.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
I wanted to have them be immersed

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:38.958
and learn the feeling of learning through their bodies.

00:07:38.958 --> 00:07:40.958
So I thought, well they like to play games.

00:07:40.958 --> 00:07:42.958
I'll make something -- I didn't say interactive;

00:07:42.958 --> 00:07:44.958
we didn't have that term in 1978 --

00:07:44.958 --> 00:07:46.958
but something interactive.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:48.958
And so we made the game,

00:07:48.958 --> 00:07:50.958
and it has since evolved

00:07:50.958 --> 00:07:53.958
to a four-foot by four-foot by four-foot

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:56.958
Plexiglass structure.

00:07:56.958 --> 00:07:59.958
And it has four Plexiglass layers.

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:01.958
There's an outer space layer

00:08:01.958 --> 00:08:03.958
with black holes and satellites

00:08:03.958 --> 00:08:05.958
and research satellites and asteroid mining.

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
There's an air and space level

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:09.958
with clouds that are big puffs of cotton we push around

00:08:09.958 --> 00:08:11.958
and territorial air spaces and air forces,

00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:14.958
a ground and sea level with thousands of game pieces on it --

00:08:14.958 --> 00:08:16.958
even an undersea level

00:08:16.958 --> 00:08:18.958
with submarines and undersea mining.

00:08:18.958 --> 00:08:20.958
There are four countries around the board.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:23.958
The kids make up the names of the countries -- some are rich; some are poor.

00:08:23.958 --> 00:08:26.958
They have different assets, commercial and military.

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
And each country has a cabinet.

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:30.958
There's a Prime Minister, Secretary of State, Minister of Defense

00:08:30.958 --> 00:08:33.958
and a CFO, or Comptroller.

00:08:33.958 --> 00:08:36.958
I choose the Prime Minister based on my relationship with them.

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
I offer them the job, they can turn it down,

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
and then they choose their own cabinet.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:43.958
There's a World Bank, arms dealers and a United Nations.

00:08:43.958 --> 00:08:45.958
There's also a weather goddess

00:08:45.958 --> 00:08:48.958
who controls a random stock market and random weather.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
(Laughter)

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
That's not all.

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
And then there's a 13-page crisis document

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:56.958
with 50 interlocking problems.

00:08:56.958 --> 00:08:59.958
So that, if one thing changes, everything else changes.

00:08:59.958 --> 00:09:02.958
I throw them into this complex matrix,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:06.958
and they trust me because we have a deep, rich relationship together.

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:09.958
And so with all these crises,

00:09:09.958 --> 00:09:12.958
we have -- let's see -- ethnic and minority tensions;

00:09:12.958 --> 00:09:14.958
we have chemical and nuclear spills,

00:09:14.958 --> 00:09:16.958
nuclear proliferation.

00:09:16.958 --> 00:09:19.958
There's oil spills, environmental disasters,

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:22.958
water rights disputes, breakaway republics,

00:09:22.958 --> 00:09:24.958
famine, endangered species and global warming.

00:09:24.958 --> 00:09:26.958
If Al Gore is here,

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
I'm going to send my fourth-graders from Agnor-Hurt and Venable schools to you

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
because they solved global warming in a week.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
(Laughter)

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:37.958
(Applause)

00:09:37.958 --> 00:09:40.958
And they've done it several times too.

00:09:40.958 --> 00:09:42.958
(Laughter)

00:09:42.958 --> 00:09:45.958
So I also have in the game a saboteur --

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
some child -- it's basically a troublemaker --

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
and I have my troublemaker put to use

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
because they, on the surface,

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:55.958
are trying to save the world and their position in the game.

00:09:55.958 --> 00:09:58.958
But they're also trying to undermine everything in the game.

00:09:59.958 --> 00:10:01.958
And they do it secretly through misinformation

00:10:01.958 --> 00:10:03.958
and ambiguities and irrelevancies,

00:10:03.958 --> 00:10:05.958
trying to cause everyone to think more deeply.

00:10:05.958 --> 00:10:07.958
The saboteur is there,

00:10:07.958 --> 00:10:09.958
and we also read from Sun Tzu's "The Art of War."

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:12.958
Fourth-graders understand it -- nine years old --

00:10:12.958 --> 00:10:14.958
and they handle that and use that

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
to understand how to, not follow --

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
at first they do --

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:20.958
the paths to power and destruction,

00:10:20.958 --> 00:10:22.958
the path to war.

00:10:22.958 --> 00:10:24.958
They learn to overlook short-sighted reactions

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:26.958
and impulsive thinking,

00:10:26.958 --> 00:10:30.958
to think in a long-term, more consequential way.

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:33.958
Stewart Brand is here, and one of the ideas for this game came from him

00:10:33.958 --> 00:10:35.958
with a CoEvolution Quarterly article

00:10:35.958 --> 00:10:37.958
on a peace force.

00:10:37.958 --> 00:10:40.958
And in the game, sometimes students actually form a peace force.

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:43.958
I'm just a clock watcher.

00:10:43.958 --> 00:10:45.958
I'm just a clarifier. I'm just a facilitator.

00:10:45.958 --> 00:10:47.958
The students run the game.

00:10:47.958 --> 00:10:49.958
I have no chance to make any policy whatsoever

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
once they start playing.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:54.958
So I'll just share with you ...

00:10:54.958 --> 00:10:56.958
(Video) Boy: The World Peace Game is serious.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
You're actually getting taught something like how to take care of the world.

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:01.958
See, Mr. Hunter is doing that

00:11:01.958 --> 00:11:03.958
because he says his time has messed up a lot,

00:11:03.958 --> 00:11:05.958
and he's trying to tell us

00:11:05.958 --> 00:11:07.958
how to fix that problem.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:09.958
John Hunter: I offered them a --

00:11:09.958 --> 00:11:12.958
(Applause)

00:11:12.958 --> 00:11:15.958
Actually, I can't tell them anything because I don't know the answer.

00:11:15.958 --> 00:11:18.958
And I admit the truth to them right up front: I don't know.

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:21.958
And because I don't know, they've got to dig up the answer.

00:11:21.958 --> 00:11:23.958
And so I apologize to them as well.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:26.958
I say, "I'm so sorry, boys and girls,

00:11:26.958 --> 00:11:28.958
but the truth is

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:31.958
we have left this world to you in such a sad and terrible shape,

00:11:31.958 --> 00:11:33.958
and we hope you can fix it for us,

00:11:33.958 --> 00:11:35.958
and maybe this game will help you learn how to do it."

00:11:35.958 --> 00:11:37.958
It's a sincere apology,

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
and they take it very seriously.

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:42.958
Now you may be wondering what all this complexity looks like.

00:11:42.958 --> 00:11:45.958
Well when we have the game start, here's what you see.

00:11:45.958 --> 00:11:48.958
(Video) JH: All right, we're going into negotiations as of now. Go.

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:55.958
(Chatter)

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:59.958
JH: My question to you is, who's in charge of that classroom?

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
It's a serious question: who is really in charge?

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:05.958
I've learned to cede control of the classroom

00:12:05.958 --> 00:12:07.958
over to the students over time.

00:12:07.958 --> 00:12:09.958
There's a trust and an understanding

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
and a dedication to an ideal

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
that I simply don't have to do

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
what I thought I had to do as a beginning teacher:

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
control every conversation and response in the classroom.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:20.958
It's impossible. Their collective wisdom

00:12:20.958 --> 00:12:22.958
is much greater than mine,

00:12:22.958 --> 00:12:25.958
and I admit it to them openly.

00:12:25.958 --> 00:12:28.958
So I'll just share with you some stories very quickly

00:12:28.958 --> 00:12:31.958
of some magical things that have happened.

00:12:31.958 --> 00:12:34.958
In this game we had a little girl,

00:12:34.958 --> 00:12:37.958
and she was the Defense Minister of the poorest nation.

00:12:37.958 --> 00:12:41.958
And the Defense Minister -- she had the tank corps and Air Force and so forth.

00:12:41.958 --> 00:12:44.958
And she was next door to a very wealthy, oil-rich neighbor.

00:12:44.958 --> 00:12:46.958
Without provocation,

00:12:46.958 --> 00:12:49.958
suddenly she attacked, against her Prime Minister's orders,

00:12:49.958 --> 00:12:51.958
the next-door neighbor's oil fields.

00:12:51.958 --> 00:12:53.958
She marched into the oil field reserves,

00:12:53.958 --> 00:12:55.958
surrounded it, without firing a shot,

00:12:55.958 --> 00:12:57.958
and secured it and held it.

00:12:57.958 --> 00:12:59.958
And that neighbor was unable to conduct any military operations

00:12:59.958 --> 00:13:02.958
because their fuel supply was locked up.

00:13:02.958 --> 00:13:04.958
We were all upset with her, "Why are you doing this?

00:13:04.958 --> 00:13:06.958
This is the World Peace Game. What is wrong with you?"

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
(Laughter)

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
This was a little girl and, at nine years old,

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:13.958
she held her pieces and said, "I know what I'm doing."

00:13:13.958 --> 00:13:16.958
To her girlfriends she said that.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:18.958
That's a breach there.

00:13:18.958 --> 00:13:20.958
And we learned in this, you don't really ever want to cross

00:13:20.958 --> 00:13:22.958
a nine year-old girl with tanks.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:24.958
(Laughter)

00:13:24.958 --> 00:13:27.958
They are the toughest opponents.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:29.958
And we were very upset.

00:13:29.958 --> 00:13:32.958
I thought I was failing as a teacher. Why would she do this?

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
But come to find out, a few game days later --

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:38.958
and there are turns where we take negotiation from a team --

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:41.958
actually there's a negotiation period with all teams,

00:13:41.958 --> 00:13:43.958
and each team takes a turn,

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
then we go back in negotiation, around and around,

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
so each turn around is one game day.

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
So a few game days later it came to light

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:52.958
that we found out this major country

00:13:52.958 --> 00:13:54.958
was planning a military offensive

00:13:54.958 --> 00:13:57.958
to dominate the entire world.

00:13:57.958 --> 00:13:59.958
Had they had their fuel supplies, they would have done it.

00:13:59.958 --> 00:14:02.958
She was able to see the vectors and trend lines and intentions

00:14:02.958 --> 00:14:04.958
long before any of us

00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:06.958
and understand what was going to happen

00:14:06.958 --> 00:14:08.958
and made a philosophical decision

00:14:08.958 --> 00:14:11.958
to attack in a peace game.

00:14:11.958 --> 00:14:14.958
Now she used a small war to avert a larger war,

00:14:14.958 --> 00:14:16.958
so we stopped and had a very good philosophical discussion

00:14:16.958 --> 00:14:18.958
about whether that was right,

00:14:18.958 --> 00:14:21.958
conditional good, or not right.

00:14:21.958 --> 00:14:24.958
That's the kind of thinking that we put them in, the situations.

00:14:24.958 --> 00:14:26.958
I could not have designed that in teaching it.

00:14:26.958 --> 00:14:29.958
It came about spontaneously through their collective wisdom.

00:14:29.958 --> 00:14:35.958
(Applause)

00:14:35.958 --> 00:14:37.958
Another example, a beautiful thing happened.

00:14:37.958 --> 00:14:39.958
We have a letter in the game.

00:14:39.958 --> 00:14:41.958
If you're a military commander and you wage troops --

00:14:41.958 --> 00:14:44.958
the little plastic toys on the board -- and you lose them,

00:14:44.958 --> 00:14:46.958
I put in a letter.

00:14:46.958 --> 00:14:49.958
You have to write a letter to their parents --

00:14:49.958 --> 00:14:51.958
the fictional parents of your fictional troops --

00:14:51.958 --> 00:14:54.958
explaining what happened and offering your condolences.

00:14:54.958 --> 00:14:56.958
So you have a little bit more thought

00:14:56.958 --> 00:14:59.958
before you commit to combat.

00:14:59.958 --> 00:15:01.958
And so we had this situation come up --

00:15:01.958 --> 00:15:03.958
last summer actually,

00:15:03.958 --> 00:15:06.958
at Agnor-Hurt School in Albemarle County --

00:15:06.958 --> 00:15:09.958
and one of our military commanders got up to read that letter

00:15:09.958 --> 00:15:11.958
and one of the other kids said, "Mr. Hunter,

00:15:11.958 --> 00:15:13.958
let's ask -- there's a parent over there."

00:15:13.958 --> 00:15:15.958
There was a parent visiting that day, just sitting in the back of the room.

00:15:15.958 --> 00:15:17.958
"Let's ask that mom to read the letter.

00:15:17.958 --> 00:15:19.958
It'll be more realer if she reads it."

00:15:19.958 --> 00:15:22.958
So we did, we asked her, and she gamely picked up the letter.

00:15:22.958 --> 00:15:25.958
"Sure." She started reading. She read one sentence.

00:15:25.958 --> 00:15:28.958
She read two sentences.

00:15:28.958 --> 00:15:31.958
By the third sentence, she was in tears.

00:15:31.958 --> 00:15:34.958
I was in tears.

00:15:34.958 --> 00:15:36.958
Everybody understood

00:15:36.958 --> 00:15:39.958
that when we lose somebody, the winners are not gloating.

00:15:39.958 --> 00:15:42.958
We all lose.

00:15:42.958 --> 00:15:44.958
And it was an amazing occurrence and an amazing understanding.

00:15:44.958 --> 00:15:46.958
I'll show you what my friend David says about this.

00:15:46.958 --> 00:15:48.958
He's been in many battles.

00:15:48.958 --> 00:15:50.958
(Video) David: We've really had enough of people attacking.

00:15:50.958 --> 00:15:54.958
I mean, we've been lucky [most of] the time.

00:15:54.958 --> 00:15:56.958
But now I'm feeling really weird

00:15:56.958 --> 00:16:00.958
because I'm living what Sun Tzu said one week.

00:16:00.958 --> 00:16:02.958
One week he said,

00:16:02.958 --> 00:16:04.958
"Those who go into battle and win

00:16:04.958 --> 00:16:06.958
will want to go back,

00:16:06.958 --> 00:16:08.958
and those who lose in battle

00:16:08.958 --> 00:16:11.958
will want to go back and win."

00:16:11.958 --> 00:16:13.958
And so I've been winning battles,

00:16:13.958 --> 00:16:16.958
so I'm going into battles, more battles.

00:16:16.958 --> 00:16:18.958
And I think it's sort of weird to be living

00:16:18.958 --> 00:16:20.958
what Sun Tzu said.

00:16:22.958 --> 00:16:25.958
JH: I get chills every time I see that.

00:16:25.958 --> 00:16:28.958
That's the kind of engagement you want to have happen.

00:16:28.958 --> 00:16:31.958
And I can't design that, I can't plan that,

00:16:31.958 --> 00:16:33.958
and I can't even test that.

00:16:33.958 --> 00:16:35.958
But it's self-evident assessment.

00:16:35.958 --> 00:16:38.958
We know that's an authentic assessment of learning.

00:16:40.958 --> 00:16:43.958
We have a lot of data, but I think sometimes we go beyond data

00:16:43.958 --> 00:16:46.958
with the real truth of what's going on.

00:16:46.958 --> 00:16:49.958
So I'll just share a third story.

00:16:49.958 --> 00:16:52.958
This is about my friend Brennan.

00:16:52.958 --> 00:16:55.958
We had played the game one session after school

00:16:55.958 --> 00:16:58.958
for many weeks, about seven weeks,

00:16:58.958 --> 00:17:01.958
and we had essentially solved all 50 of the interlocking crises.

00:17:01.958 --> 00:17:04.958
The way the game is won is all 50 problems have to be solved

00:17:04.958 --> 00:17:06.958
and every country's asset value

00:17:06.958 --> 00:17:08.958
has to be increased above its starting point.

00:17:08.958 --> 00:17:11.958
Some are poor, some are wealthy. There are billions.

00:17:11.958 --> 00:17:13.958
The World Bank president was a third-grader one time.

00:17:13.958 --> 00:17:16.958
He says, "How many zeros in a trillion? I've got to calculate that right away."

00:17:16.958 --> 00:17:18.958
But he was setting fiscal policy in that game

00:17:18.958 --> 00:17:21.958
for high school players who were playing with him.

00:17:21.958 --> 00:17:24.958
So the team that was the poorest

00:17:24.958 --> 00:17:26.958
had gotten even poorer.

00:17:26.958 --> 00:17:28.958
There was no way they could win.

00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.958
And we were approaching four o'clock, our cut-off time --

00:17:30.958 --> 00:17:32.958
there was about a minute left --

00:17:32.958 --> 00:17:34.958
and despair just settled over the room.

00:17:34.958 --> 00:17:36.958
I thought, I'm failing as a teacher.

00:17:36.958 --> 00:17:39.958
I should have gotten it so they could have won.

00:17:39.958 --> 00:17:42.958
They shouldn't be failing like this.

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.958
I've failed them.

00:17:45.958 --> 00:17:47.958
And I was just feeling so sad and dejected.

00:17:47.958 --> 00:17:49.958
And suddenly, Brennan walked over to my chair

00:17:49.958 --> 00:17:51.958
and he grabbed the bell, the bell I ring

00:17:51.958 --> 00:17:53.958
to signal a change or a reconvening of cabinets,

00:17:53.958 --> 00:17:55.958
and he ran back to his seat, rang the bell.

00:17:55.958 --> 00:17:57.958
Everybody ran to his chair: there was screaming;

00:17:57.958 --> 00:17:59.958
there was yelling, waving of their dossiers.

00:17:59.958 --> 00:18:01.958
They get these dossiers full of secret documents.

00:18:01.958 --> 00:18:03.958
They were gesticulating; they were running around.

00:18:03.958 --> 00:18:06.958
I didn't know what they were doing. I'd lost control of my classroom.

00:18:07.958 --> 00:18:10.958
Principal walks in, I'm out of a job.

00:18:10.958 --> 00:18:12.958
The parents were looking in the window.

00:18:12.958 --> 00:18:15.958
And Brennan runs back to his seat. Everybody runs back to their seat.

00:18:15.958 --> 00:18:17.958
He rings the bell again. He says, "We have" --

00:18:17.958 --> 00:18:19.958
and there's 12 seconds left on the clock --

title: What it takes to do extreme astrophysics
transcript: I would like to talk today about what I think is one of the greatest adventures human beings have embarked upon, which is the quest to understand the universe and our place in it. My own interest in this subject, and my passion for it, began rather accidentally. I had bought a copy of this book, "The Universe and Dr. Einstein" — a used paperback from a secondhand bookstore in Seattle. A few years after that, in Bangalore, I was finding it hard to fall asleep one night, and I picked up this book, thinking it would put me to sleep in 10 minutes. And as it happened, I read it from midnight to five in the morning in one shot. And I was left with this intense feeling of awe and exhilaration at the universe and our own ability to understand as much as we do. And that feeling hasn't left me yet.That feeling was the trigger for me to actually change my career — from being a software engineer to become a science writer — so that I could partake in the joy of science, and also the joy of communicating it to others. And that feeling also led me to a pilgrimage of sorts, to go literally to the ends of the earth to see telescopes, detectors, instruments that people are building, or have built, in order to probe the cosmos in greater and greater detail. So it took me from places like Chile — the Atacama Desert in Chile — to Siberia, to underground mines in the Japanese Alps, in Northern America, all the way to Antarctica and even to the South Pole.And today I would like to share with you some images, some stories of these trips. I have been basically spending the last few years documenting the efforts of some extremely intrepid men and women who are putting, literally at times, their lives at stake working in some very remote and very hostile places so that they may gather the faintest signals from the cosmos in order for us to understand this universe.And I first begin with a pie chart — and I promise this is the only pie chart in the whole presentation — but it sets up the state of our knowledge of the cosmos. All the theories in physics that we have today properly explain what is called normal matter — the stuff that we're all made of — and that's four percent of the universe. Astronomers and cosmologists and physicists think that there is something called dark matter in the universe, which makes up 23 percent of the universe, and something called dark energy, which permeates the fabric of space-time, that makes up another 73 percent. So if you look at this pie chart, 96 percent of the universe, at this point in our exploration of it, is unknown or not well understood. And most of the experiments, telescopes that I went to see are in some way addressing this question, these two twin mysteries of dark matter and dark energy.I will take you first to an underground mine in Northern Minnesota where people are looking for something called dark matter. And the idea here is that they are looking for a sign of a dark matter particle hitting one of their detectors. And the reason why they have to go underground is that, if you did this experiment on the surface of the Earth, the same experiment would be swamped by signals that could be created by things like cosmic rays, ambient radio activity, even our own bodies. You might not believe it, but even our own bodies are radioactive enough to disturb this experiment. So they go deep inside mines to find a kind of environmental silence that will allow them to hear the ping of a dark matter particle hitting their detector.And I went to see one of these experiments, and this is actually — you can barely see it, and the reason for that is it's entirely dark in there — this is a cavern that was left behind by the miners who left this mine in 1960. And physicists came and started using it sometime in the 1980s. And the miners in the early part of the last century worked, literally, in candlelight. And today, you would see this inside the mine, half a mile underground. This is one of the largest underground labs in the world. And, among other things, they're looking for dark matter.There is another way to search for dark matter, which is indirectly. If dark matter exists in our universe, in our galaxy, then these particles should be smashing together and producing other particles that we know about — one of them being neutrinos. And neutrinos you can detect by the signature they leave when they hit water molecules. When a neutrino hits a water molecule it emits a kind of blue light, a flash of blue light, and by looking for this blue light, you can essentially understand something about the neutrino and then, indirectly, something about the dark matter that might have created this neutrino. But you need very, very large volumes of water in order to do this. You need something like tens of megatons of water — almost a gigaton of water — in order to have any chance of catching this neutrino. And where in the world would you find such water? Well the Russians have a tank in their own backyard.This is Lake Baikal. It is the largest lake in the world. It's 800 km long. It's about 40 to 50 km wide in most places, and one to two kilometers deep. And what the Russians are doing is they're building these detectors and immersing them about a kilometer beneath the surface of the lake so that they can watch for these flashes of blue light. And this is the scene that greeted me when I landed there. This is Lake Baikal in the peak of the Siberian winter. The lake is entirely frozen. And the line of black dots that you see in the background, that's the ice camp where the physicists are working. The reason why they have to work in winter is because they don't have the money to work in summer and spring, which, if they did that, they would need ships and submersibles to do their work. So they wait until winter — the lake is completely frozen over — and they use this meter-thick ice as a platform on which to establish their ice camp and do their work.So this is the Russians working on the ice in the peak of the Siberian winter. They have to drill holes in the ice, dive down into the water — cold, cold water — to get hold of the instrument, bring it up, do any repairs and maintenance that they need to do, put it back and get out before the ice melts. Because that phase of solid ice lasts for two months and it's full of cracks. And you have to imagine, there's an entire sea-like lake underneath, moving. I still don't understand this one Russian man working in his bare chest, but that tells you how hard he was working. And these people, a handful of people, have been working for 20 years, looking for particles that may or may not exist. And they have dedicated their lives to it. And just to give you an idea, they have spent 20 million over 20 years. It's very harsh conditions. They work on a shoestring budget. The toilets there are literally holes in the ground covered with a wooden shack. And it's that basic, but they do this every year.From Siberia to the Atacama Desert in Chile, to see something called The Very Large Telescope. The Very Large Telescope is one of these things that astronomers do — they name their telescopes rather unimaginatively. I can tell you for a fact, that the next one that they're planning is called The Extremely Large Telescope. (Laughter) And you wouldn't believe it, but the one after that is going to be called The Overwhelmingly Large Telescope. But nonetheless, it's an extraordinary piece of engineering. These are four 8.2 meter telescopes. And these telescopes, among other things, they're being used to study how the expansion of the universe is changing with time. And the more you understand that, the better you would understand what this dark energy that the universe is made of is all about.And one piece of engineering that I want to leave you with as regards this telescope is the mirror. Each mirror, there are four of them, is made of a single piece of glass, a monolithic piece of high-tech ceramic, that has been ground down and polished to such accuracy that the only way to understand what that is is [to] imagine a city like Paris, with all its buildings and the Eiffel Tower, if you grind down Paris to that kind of accuracy, you would be left with bumps that are one millimeter high. And that's the kind of polishing that these mirrors have endured. An extraordinary set of telescopes. Here's another view of the same. The reason why you have to build these telescopes in places like the Atacama Desert is because of the high altitude desert. The dry air is really good for telescopes, and also, the cloud cover is below the summit of these mountains so that the telescopes have about 300 days of clear skies.Finally, I want to take you to Antarctica. I want to spend most of my time on this part of the world. This is cosmology's final frontier. Some of the most amazing experiments, some of the most extreme experiments, are being done in Antarctica. I was there to view something called a long-duration balloon flight, which basically takes telescopes and instruments all the way to the upper atmosphere, the upper stratosphere, 40 km up. And that's where they do their experiments, and then the balloon, the payload, is brought down. So this is us landing on the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica. That's an American C-17 cargo plane that flew us from New Zealand to McMurdo in Antarctica. And here we are about to board our bus. And I don't know if you can read the lettering, but it says, "Ivan the Terribus." And that's taking us to McMurdo.And this is the scene that greets you in McMurdo. And you barely might be able to make out this hut here. This hut was built by Robert Falcon Scott and his men when they first came to Antarctica on their first expedition to go to the South Pole. Because it's so cold, the entire contents of that hut is still as they left it, with the remnants of the last meal they cooked still there. It's an extraordinary place. This is McMurdo itself. About a thousand people work here in summer, and about 200 in winter when it's completely dark for six months.I was here to see the launch of this particular type of instrument. This is a cosmic ray experiment that has been launched all the way to the upper-stratosphere to an altitude of 40 km. What I want you to imagine is this is two tons in weight. So you're using a balloon to carry something that is two tons all the way to an altitude of 40 km. And the engineers, the technicians, the physicists have all got to assemble on the Ross Ice Shelf, because Antarctica — I won't go into the reasons why — but it's one of the most favorable places for doing these balloon launches, except for the weather. The weather, as you can imagine, this is summer, and you're standing on 200 ft of ice. And there's a volcano behind, which has glaciers at the very top. And what they have to do is they have to assemble the entire balloon — the fabric, parachute and everything — on the ice and then fill it up with helium. And that process takes about two hours.And the weather can change as they're putting together this whole assembly. For instance, here they are laying down the balloon fabric behind, which is eventually going to be filled up with helium. Those two trucks you see at the very end carry 12 tanks each of compressed helium. Now, in case the weather changes before the launch, they have to actually pack everything back up into their boxes and take it out back to McMurdo Station. And this particular balloon, because it has to launch two tons of weight, is an extremely huge balloon. The fabric alone weighs two tons. In order to minimize the weight, it's very thin, it's as thin as a sandwich wrapper. And if they have to pack it back, they have to put it into boxes and stamp on it so that it fits into the box again — except, when they did it first, it would have been done in Texas. Here, they can't do it with the kind shoes they're wearing, so they have to take their shoes off, get barefoot into the boxes, in this cold, and do that kind of work. That's the kind of dedication these people have.Here's the balloon being filled up with helium, and you can see it's a gorgeous sight. Here's a scene that shows you the balloon and the payload end-to-end. So the balloon is being filled up with helium on the left-hand side, and the fabric actually runs all the way to the middle where there's a piece of electronics and explosives being connected to a parachute, and then the parachute is then connected to the payload. And remember, all this wiring is being done by people in extreme cold, in sub-zero temperatures. They're wearing about 15 kg of clothing and stuff, but they have to take their gloves off in order to do that. And I would like to share with you a launch.(Video) Radio: Okay, release the balloon, release the balloon, release the balloon.Anil Ananthaswamy: And I'll finally like to leave you with two images. This is an observatory in the Himalayas, in Ladakh in India. And the thing I want you to look at here is the telescope on the right-hand side. And on the far left there is a 400 year-old Buddhist monastery. This is a close-up of the Buddhist monastery. And I was struck by the juxtaposition of these two enormous disciplines that humanity has. One is exploring the cosmos on the outside, and the other one is exploring our interior being. And both require silence of some sort.And what struck me was every place that I went to to see these telescopes, the astronomers and cosmologists are in search of a certain kind of silence, whether it's silence from radio pollution or light pollution or whatever. And it was very obvious that, if we destroy these silent places on Earth, we will be stuck on a planet without the ability to look outwards, because we will not be able to understand the signals that come from outer space.Thank you.(Applause)

00:05:47.958 --> 00:05:49.958
which, if they did that,

00:05:49.958 --> 00:05:51.958
they would need ships and submersibles to do their work.

00:05:51.958 --> 00:05:53.958
So they wait until winter --

00:05:53.958 --> 00:05:55.958
the lake is completely frozen over --

00:05:55.958 --> 00:05:57.958
and they use this meter-thick ice

00:05:57.958 --> 00:06:00.958
as a platform on which to establish their ice camp and do their work.

00:06:00.958 --> 00:06:04.958
So this is the Russians working on the ice

00:06:04.958 --> 00:06:06.958
in the peak of the Siberian winter.

00:06:06.958 --> 00:06:08.958
They have to drill holes in the ice,

00:06:08.958 --> 00:06:10.958
dive down into the water -- cold, cold water --

00:06:10.958 --> 00:06:13.958
to get hold of the instrument, bring it up,

00:06:13.958 --> 00:06:16.958
do any repairs and maintenance that they need to do,

00:06:16.958 --> 00:06:18.958
put it back and get out before the ice melts.

00:06:18.958 --> 00:06:20.958
Because that phase of solid ice lasts for two months

00:06:20.958 --> 00:06:22.958
and it's full of cracks.

00:06:22.958 --> 00:06:25.958
And you have to imagine, there's an entire sea-like lake

00:06:25.958 --> 00:06:27.958
underneath, moving.

00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:30.958
I still don't understand this one Russian man

00:06:30.958 --> 00:06:32.958
working in his bare chest,

00:06:32.958 --> 00:06:35.958
but that tells you how hard he was working.

00:06:35.958 --> 00:06:37.958
And these people, a handful of people,

00:06:37.958 --> 00:06:39.958
have been working for 20 years,

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.958
looking for particles that may or may not exist.

00:06:41.958 --> 00:06:44.958
And they have dedicated their lives to it.

00:06:44.958 --> 00:06:46.958
And just to give you an idea,

00:06:46.958 --> 00:06:49.958
they have spent 20 million over 20 years.

00:06:49.958 --> 00:06:51.958
It's very harsh conditions.

00:06:51.958 --> 00:06:53.958
They work on a shoestring budget.

00:06:53.958 --> 00:06:55.958
The toilets there are literally holes in the ground

00:06:55.958 --> 00:06:58.958
covered with a wooden shack.

00:06:58.958 --> 00:07:00.958
And it's that basic,

00:07:00.958 --> 00:07:02.958
but they do this every year.

00:07:02.958 --> 00:07:05.958
From Siberia to the Atacama Desert in Chile,

00:07:05.958 --> 00:07:07.958
to see something called The Very Large Telescope.

00:07:07.958 --> 00:07:09.958
The Very Large Telescope

00:07:09.958 --> 00:07:11.958
is one of these things that astronomers do --

00:07:11.958 --> 00:07:13.958
they name their telescopes rather unimaginatively.

00:07:13.958 --> 00:07:15.958
I can tell you for a fact,

00:07:15.958 --> 00:07:18.958
that the next one that they're planning is called The Extremely Large Telescope.

00:07:18.958 --> 00:07:20.958
(Laughter)

00:07:20.958 --> 00:07:22.958
And you wouldn't believe it,

00:07:22.958 --> 00:07:25.958
but the one after that is going to be called The Overwhelmingly Large Telescope.

00:07:25.958 --> 00:07:27.958
But nonetheless,

00:07:27.958 --> 00:07:29.958
it's an extraordinary piece of engineering.

00:07:29.958 --> 00:07:32.958
These are four 8.2 meter telescopes.

00:07:32.958 --> 00:07:34.958
And these telescopes, among other things,

00:07:34.958 --> 00:07:36.958
they're being used to study

00:07:36.958 --> 00:07:39.958
how the expansion of the universe is changing with time.

00:07:39.958 --> 00:07:41.958
And the more you understand that,

00:07:41.958 --> 00:07:43.958
the better you would understand

00:07:43.958 --> 00:07:46.958
what this dark energy that the universe is made of is all about.

00:07:46.958 --> 00:07:49.958
And one piece of engineering that I want to leave you with

00:07:49.958 --> 00:07:51.958
as regards this telescope

00:07:51.958 --> 00:07:53.958
is the mirror.

00:07:53.958 --> 00:07:55.958
Each mirror, there are four of them,

00:07:55.958 --> 00:07:57.958
is made of a single piece of glass,

00:07:57.958 --> 00:07:59.958
a monolithic piece of high-tech ceramic,

00:07:59.958 --> 00:08:02.958
that has been ground down and polished to such accuracy

00:08:02.958 --> 00:08:05.958
that the only way to understand what that is

00:08:05.958 --> 00:08:07.958
is [to] imagine a city like Paris,

00:08:07.958 --> 00:08:10.958
with all its buildings and the Eiffel Tower,

00:08:10.958 --> 00:08:13.958
if you grind down Paris to that kind of accuracy,

00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:17.958
you would be left with bumps that are one millimeter high.

00:08:17.958 --> 00:08:20.958
And that's the kind of polishing that these mirrors have endured.

00:08:20.958 --> 00:08:22.958
An extraordinary set of telescopes.

00:08:22.958 --> 00:08:24.958
Here's another view of the same.

00:08:24.958 --> 00:08:26.958
The reason why you have to build these telescopes

00:08:26.958 --> 00:08:28.958
in places like the Atacama Desert

00:08:28.958 --> 00:08:31.958
is because of the high altitude desert.

00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.958
The dry air is really good for telescopes,

00:08:34.958 --> 00:08:36.958
and also, the cloud cover is below the summit of these mountains

00:08:36.958 --> 00:08:38.958
so that the telescopes have

00:08:38.958 --> 00:08:40.958
about 300 days of clear skies.

00:08:40.958 --> 00:08:42.958
Finally, I want to take you to Antarctica.

00:08:42.958 --> 00:08:46.958
I want to spend most of my time on this part of the world.

00:08:46.958 --> 00:08:48.958
This is cosmology's final frontier.

00:08:48.958 --> 00:08:50.958
Some of the most amazing experiments,

00:08:50.958 --> 00:08:52.958
some of the most extreme experiments,

00:08:52.958 --> 00:08:54.958
are being done in Antarctica.

00:08:54.958 --> 00:08:57.958
I was there to view something called a long-duration balloon flight,

00:08:57.958 --> 00:09:00.958
which basically takes telescopes and instruments

00:09:00.958 --> 00:09:02.958
all the way to the upper atmosphere,

00:09:02.958 --> 00:09:05.958
the upper stratosphere, 40 km up.

00:09:05.958 --> 00:09:07.958
And that's where they do their experiments,

00:09:07.958 --> 00:09:10.958
and then the balloon, the payload, is brought down.

00:09:10.958 --> 00:09:13.958
So this is us landing on the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica.

00:09:13.958 --> 00:09:15.958
That's an American C-17 cargo plane

00:09:15.958 --> 00:09:17.958
that flew us from New Zealand

00:09:17.958 --> 00:09:19.958
to McMurdo in Antarctica.

00:09:19.958 --> 00:09:21.958
And here we are about to board our bus.

00:09:21.958 --> 00:09:23.958
And I don't know if you can read the lettering,

00:09:23.958 --> 00:09:26.958
but it says, "Ivan the Terribus."

00:09:26.958 --> 00:09:29.958
And that's taking us to McMurdo.

00:09:29.958 --> 00:09:32.958
And this is the scene that greets you in McMurdo.

00:09:32.958 --> 00:09:34.958
And you barely might be able to make out

00:09:34.958 --> 00:09:36.958
this hut here.

00:09:36.958 --> 00:09:39.958
This hut was built by Robert Falcon Scott and his men

00:09:39.958 --> 00:09:41.958
when they first came to Antarctica

00:09:41.958 --> 00:09:43.958
on their first expedition to go to the South Pole.

00:09:43.958 --> 00:09:45.958
Because it's so cold,

00:09:45.958 --> 00:09:48.958
the entire contents of that hut is still as they left it,

00:09:48.958 --> 00:09:51.958
with the remnants of the last meal they cooked still there.

00:09:51.958 --> 00:09:53.958
It's an extraordinary place.

00:09:53.958 --> 00:09:56.958
This is McMurdo itself. About a thousand people work here in summer,

00:09:56.958 --> 00:09:58.958
and about 200 in winter

00:09:58.958 --> 00:10:00.958
when it's completely dark for six months.

00:10:00.958 --> 00:10:02.958
I was here to see the launch

00:10:02.958 --> 00:10:04.958
of this particular type of instrument.

00:10:04.958 --> 00:10:06.958
This is a cosmic ray experiment

00:10:06.958 --> 00:10:09.958
that has been launched all the way to the upper-stratosphere

00:10:09.958 --> 00:10:11.958
to an altitude of 40 km.

00:10:11.958 --> 00:10:14.958
What I want you to imagine is this is two tons in weight.

00:10:14.958 --> 00:10:16.958
So you're using a balloon

00:10:16.958 --> 00:10:18.958
to carry something that is two tons

00:10:18.958 --> 00:10:21.958
all the way to an altitude of 40 km.

00:10:21.958 --> 00:10:24.958
And the engineers, the technicians, the physicists

00:10:24.958 --> 00:10:27.958
have all got to assemble on the Ross Ice Shelf,

00:10:27.958 --> 00:10:30.958
because Antarctica -- I won't go into the reasons why --

00:10:30.958 --> 00:10:32.958
but it's one of the most favorable places for doing these balloon launches,

00:10:32.958 --> 00:10:34.958
except for the weather.

00:10:34.958 --> 00:10:36.958
The weather, as you can imagine,

00:10:36.958 --> 00:10:38.958
this is summer, and you're standing on 200 ft of ice.

00:10:38.958 --> 00:10:40.958
And there's a volcano behind,

00:10:40.958 --> 00:10:42.958
which has glaciers at the very top.

00:10:42.958 --> 00:10:44.958
And what they have to do

00:10:44.958 --> 00:10:46.958
is they have to assemble the entire balloon --

00:10:46.958 --> 00:10:49.958
the fabric, parachute and everything -- on the ice

00:10:49.958 --> 00:10:51.958
and then fill it up with helium.

00:10:51.958 --> 00:10:53.958
And that process takes about two hours.

00:10:53.958 --> 00:10:56.958
And the weather can change as they're putting together this whole assembly.

00:10:56.958 --> 00:10:59.958
For instance, here they are laying down the balloon fabric behind,

00:10:59.958 --> 00:11:02.958
which is eventually going to be filled up with helium.

00:11:02.958 --> 00:11:04.958
Those two trucks you see at the very end

00:11:04.958 --> 00:11:07.958
carry 12 tanks each of compressed helium.

00:11:07.958 --> 00:11:10.958
Now, in case the weather changes before the launch,

00:11:10.958 --> 00:11:13.958
they have to actually pack everything back up into their boxes

00:11:13.958 --> 00:11:16.958
and take it out back to McMurdo Station.

00:11:16.958 --> 00:11:18.958
And this particular balloon,

00:11:18.958 --> 00:11:20.958
because it has to launch two tons of weight,

00:11:20.958 --> 00:11:23.958
is an extremely huge balloon.

00:11:23.958 --> 00:11:25.958
The fabric alone weighs two tons.

00:11:25.958 --> 00:11:28.958
In order to minimize the weight,

00:11:28.958 --> 00:11:30.958
it's very thin, it's as thin as a sandwich wrapper.

00:11:30.958 --> 00:11:32.958
And if they have to pack it back,

00:11:32.958 --> 00:11:34.958
they have to put it into boxes

00:11:34.958 --> 00:11:37.958
and stamp on it so that it fits into the box again --

00:11:37.958 --> 00:11:39.958
except, when they did it first,

00:11:39.958 --> 00:11:41.958
it would have been done in Texas.

00:11:41.958 --> 00:11:44.958
Here, they can't do it with the kind shoes they're wearing,

00:11:44.958 --> 00:11:46.958
so they have to take their shoes off,

00:11:46.958 --> 00:11:48.958
get barefoot into the boxes, in this cold,

00:11:48.958 --> 00:11:50.958
and do that kind of work.

00:11:50.958 --> 00:11:52.958
That's the kind of dedication these people have.

00:11:52.958 --> 00:11:54.958
Here's the balloon being filled up with helium,

00:11:54.958 --> 00:11:56.958
and you can see it's a gorgeous sight.

00:11:56.958 --> 00:11:58.958
Here's a scene

00:11:58.958 --> 00:12:00.958
that shows you the balloon and the payload end-to-end.

00:12:00.958 --> 00:12:03.958
So the balloon is being filled up with helium on the left-hand side,

00:12:03.958 --> 00:12:06.958
and the fabric actually runs all the way to the middle

00:12:06.958 --> 00:12:09.958
where there's a piece of electronics and explosives

00:12:09.958 --> 00:12:11.958
being connected to a parachute,

00:12:11.958 --> 00:12:13.958
and then the parachute is then connected to the payload.

00:12:13.958 --> 00:12:15.958
And remember, all this wiring is being done

00:12:15.958 --> 00:12:18.958
by people in extreme cold, in sub-zero temperatures.

00:12:18.958 --> 00:12:21.958
They're wearing about 15 kg of clothing and stuff,

00:12:21.958 --> 00:12:24.958
but they have to take their gloves off in order to do that.

00:12:24.958 --> 00:12:27.958
And I would like to share with you a launch.

00:12:27.958 --> 00:12:29.958
(Video) Radio: Okay, release the balloon,

00:12:29.958 --> 00:12:32.958
release the balloon, release the balloon.

00:13:00.958 --> 00:13:03.958
Anil Ananthaswamy: And I'll finally like to leave you with two images.

00:13:03.958 --> 00:13:06.958
This is an observatory in the Himalayas, in Ladakh in India.

00:13:06.958 --> 00:13:08.958
And the thing I want you to look at here

00:13:08.958 --> 00:13:10.958
is the telescope on the right-hand side.

00:13:10.958 --> 00:13:12.958
And on the far left there

00:13:12.958 --> 00:13:14.958
is a 400 year-old Buddhist monastery.

00:13:14.958 --> 00:13:16.958
This is a close-up of the Buddhist monastery.

00:13:16.958 --> 00:13:19.958
And I was struck by the juxtaposition

00:13:19.958 --> 00:13:22.958
of these two enormous disciplines that humanity has.

00:13:22.958 --> 00:13:25.958
One is exploring the cosmos on the outside,

00:13:25.958 --> 00:13:27.958
and the other one is exploring our interior being.

00:13:27.958 --> 00:13:30.958
And both require silence of some sort.

00:13:30.958 --> 00:13:32.958
And what struck me was

00:13:32.958 --> 00:13:34.958
every place that I went to to see these telescopes,

00:13:34.958 --> 00:13:36.958
the astronomers and cosmologists

00:13:36.958 --> 00:13:38.958
are in search of a certain kind of silence,

00:13:38.958 --> 00:13:40.958
whether it's silence from radio pollution

00:13:40.958 --> 00:13:43.958
or light pollution or whatever.

00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:45.958
And it was very obvious

00:13:45.958 --> 00:13:47.958
that, if we destroy these silent places on Earth,

00:13:47.958 --> 00:13:50.958
we will be stuck on a planet without the ability to look outwards,

00:13:50.958 --> 00:13:53.958
because we will not be able to understand the signals that come from outer space.

00:13:53.958 --> 00:13:55.958
Thank you.

00:13:55.958 --> 00:13:58.958
(Applause)

title: 3 things I learned while my plane crashed
transcript: Imagine a big explosion as you climb through 3,000 ft. Imagine a plane full of smoke. Imagine an engine going clack, clack, clack. It sounds scary.Well, I had a unique seat that day. I was sitting in 1D. I was the only one who could talk to the flight attendants. So I looked at them right away, and they said, "No problem. We probably hit some birds." The pilot had already turned the plane around, and we weren't that far. You could see Manhattan. Two minutes later, three things happened at the same time.The pilot lines up the plane with the Hudson River. That's usually not the route.(Laughter)He turns off the engines. Now, imagine being in a plane with no sound. And then he says three words. The most unemotional three words I've ever heard. He says, "Brace for impact." I didn't have to talk to the flight attendant anymore.(Laughter)I could see in her eyes, it was terror. Life was over.Now I want to share with you three things I learned about myself that day. I learned that it all changes in an instant. We have this bucket list, we have these things we want to do in life, and I thought about all the people I wanted to reach out to that I didn't, all the fences I wanted to mend, all the experiences I wanted to have and I never did. As I thought about that later on, I came up with a saying, which is, "I collect bad wines." Because if the wine is ready and the person is there, I'm opening it. I no longer want to postpone anything in life. And that urgency, that purpose, has really changed my life.The second thing I learned that day — and this is as we clear the George Washington Bridge, which was by not a lot —(Laughter)I thought about, wow, I really feel one real regret. I've lived a good life. In my own humanity and mistakes, I've tried to get better at everything I tried. But in my humanity, I also allow my ego to get in. And I regretted the time I wasted on things that did not matter with people that matter. And I thought about my relationship with my wife, with my friends, with people. And after, as I reflected on that, I decided to eliminate negative energy from my life. It's not perfect, but it's a lot better. I've not had a fight with my wife in two years. It feels great. I no longer try to be right; I choose to be happy.The third thing I learned — and this is as your mental clock starts going, "15, 14, 13." You can see the water coming. I'm saying, "Please blow up." I don't want this thing to break in 20 pieces like you've seen in those documentaries. And as we're coming down, I had a sense of, wow, dying is not scary. It's almost like we've been preparing for it our whole lives. But it was very sad. I didn't want to go; I love my life. And that sadness really framed in one thought, which is, I only wish for one thing. I only wish I could see my kids grow up. About a month later, I was at a performance by my daughter — first-grader, not much artistic talent —(Laughter)Yet!(Laughter)And I'm bawling, I'm crying, like a little kid. And it made all the sense in the world to me. I realized at that point, by connecting those two dots, that the only thing that matters in my life is being a great dad. Above all, above all, the only goal I have in life is to be a good dad.I was given the gift of a miracle, of not dying that day. I was given another gift, which was to be able to see into the future and come back and live differently. I challenge you guys that are flying today, imagine the same thing happens on your plane — and please don't — but imagine, and how would you change? What would you get done that you're waiting to get done because you think you'll be here forever? How would you change your relationships and the negative energy in them? And more than anything, are you being the best parent you can?Thank you.(Applause)

00:02:47.504 --> 00:02:48.716
It feels great.

00:02:48.740 --> 00:02:51.040
I no longer try to be right;

00:02:51.064 --> 00:02:52.481
I choose to be happy.

00:02:54.012 --> 00:02:55.473
The third thing I learned --

00:02:55.497 --> 00:02:59.938
and this is as your mental clock
starts going, "15, 14, 13."

00:02:59.962 --> 00:03:01.398
You can see the water coming.

00:03:01.422 --> 00:03:02.934
I'm saying, "Please blow up."

00:03:02.958 --> 00:03:05.101
I don't want this thing
to break in 20 pieces

00:03:05.125 --> 00:03:07.147
like you've seen in those documentaries.

00:03:07.958 --> 00:03:10.219
And as we're coming down,

00:03:10.243 --> 00:03:14.934
I had a sense of, wow, dying is not scary.

00:03:14.958 --> 00:03:17.934
It's almost like we've been preparing
for it our whole lives.

00:03:18.661 --> 00:03:19.889
But it was very sad.

00:03:20.320 --> 00:03:22.280
I didn't want to go; I love my life.

00:03:23.165 --> 00:03:27.390
And that sadness
really framed in one thought,

00:03:27.414 --> 00:03:29.934
which is, I only wish for one thing.

00:03:30.770 --> 00:03:32.811
I only wish I could see my kids grow up.

00:03:34.455 --> 00:03:37.932
About a month later,
I was at a performance by my daughter --

00:03:37.956 --> 00:03:40.663
first-grader, not much artistic talent --

00:03:40.687 --> 00:03:41.761
(Laughter)

00:03:41.785 --> 00:03:42.888
Yet!

00:03:42.912 --> 00:03:44.766
(Laughter)

00:03:44.790 --> 00:03:48.933
And I'm bawling,
I'm crying, like a little kid.

00:03:49.962 --> 00:03:52.134
And it made all the sense
in the world to me.

00:03:52.542 --> 00:03:56.283
I realized at that point,
by connecting those two dots,

00:03:56.307 --> 00:03:58.649
that the only thing
that matters in my life

00:03:58.673 --> 00:03:59.934
is being a great dad.

00:04:00.850 --> 00:04:03.557
Above all, above all,

00:04:03.581 --> 00:04:05.949
the only goal I have in life
is to be a good dad.

00:04:07.278 --> 00:04:09.803
I was given the gift of a miracle,

00:04:09.827 --> 00:04:11.331
of not dying that day.

00:04:11.355 --> 00:04:13.168
I was given another gift,

00:04:13.192 --> 00:04:15.719
which was to be able
to see into the future

00:04:15.743 --> 00:04:17.020
and come back

00:04:17.044 --> 00:04:19.096
and live differently.

00:04:19.856 --> 00:04:22.848
I challenge you guys
that are flying today,

00:04:22.872 --> 00:04:25.523
imagine the same thing
happens on your plane --

00:04:25.547 --> 00:04:26.934
and please don't --

00:04:26.958 --> 00:04:29.551
but imagine, and how would you change?

00:04:29.575 --> 00:04:30.855
What would you get done

00:04:30.879 --> 00:04:34.555
that you're waiting to get done
because you think you'll be here forever?

00:04:34.579 --> 00:04:36.526
How would you change your relationships

00:04:36.550 --> 00:04:38.234
and the negative energy in them?

00:04:38.258 --> 00:04:41.234
And more than anything,
are you being the best parent you can?

00:04:41.702 --> 00:04:42.735
Thank you.

00:04:42.759 --> 00:04:45.759
(Applause)
